question: What are the side effects of long-acting hepcidin analogues?
answer:
Side Effects of Long-Acting Hepcidin Analogues

Long-acting hepcidin analogues, also known as minihepcidins, are still under investigation, and their side effects are not fully established. However, based on available data, some potential adverse effects include:

  • Abdominal disturbances and diarrhoeal symptoms, which typically subside within the first week of administration [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].
  • Periodic fever and common cold symptoms [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].
  • Itchy skin rash, which can be widespread or localized, usually appearing within the first 15 days of administration and typically subsiding without the need to stop or reduce the dose [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].
  • Increased creatinine levels, indicating potential effects on kidney function [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the best sources of vitamin D for thalassaemia patients?
answer:
Best Sources of Vitamin D for Thalassaemia Patients

Vitamin D is crucial for thalassaemia patients to protect against osteoporosis and other complications. Here are the best sources of vitamin D:

  • Fatty Fish: Sardines, salmon, and swordfish are excellent natural sources of vitamin D [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=20].
  • Fish Oils: Cod liver oil is a rich source of vitamin D [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=20].
  • Wild Mushrooms: Some mushrooms naturally contain vitamin D [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=20].
  • Egg Yolks: Egg yolks provide a modest amount of vitamin D [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=20].
  • Fortified Foods: In some countries, foods such as milk, cereals, yogurt, and orange juice are fortified with vitamin D [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=20].
  • Supplementation: Due to the difficulty of obtaining sufficient vitamin D from food alone, supplementation is often recommended. Adults may take 1,000 to 2,000 IU/day or 50,000 IU per month of vitamin D2 or D3 [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=20][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=104].

It is also recommended to have vitamin D levels in the blood assessed every 6 months to maintain optimal levels [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=20].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: what are the different types of thalassemia?
answer:
Types of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia is a group of inherited blood disorders characterized by decreased production of haemoglobin. There are two main types of thalassaemia:

  • Alpha (α) Thalassaemia: Occurs when a gene or genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • Beta (β) Thalassaemia: Occurs when similar genetic defects affect the production of the β-globin protein.

Thalassaemia can also be classified based on the severity of the condition:

  • Thalassaemia Minor: Individuals are generally healthy and may have a mild form of anaemia. They are also known as carriers.
  • Thalassaemia Intermedia: This form is of intermediate severity and may occasionally require blood transfusions.
  • Thalassaemia Major: The most severe form, also known as transfusion-dependent thalassaemia, requiring regular blood transfusions.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation.

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the long-term complications of TDT?
answer:
Long-Term Complications of Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT)

Patients with TDT face several long-term complications primarily due to chronic anaemia, iron overload from regular blood transfusions, and the side effects of conventional therapies. These complications can affect various bodily systems and significantly impact the patient's quality of life.

Endocrine Complications

Endocrine complications are common in TDT patients and include:

  • Hypogonadism: Affects both males and females, with rates between 40% and 80%. It is often due to iron deposition in the pituitary gland, leading to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Hormone replacement therapy can help alleviate symptoms and prevent long-term complications.
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Growth Retardation
  • Diabetes Mellitus: Impaired glucose tolerance and diabetes mellitus are more common in individuals with TDT.

Iron overload from chronic transfusions is the primary risk factor for these complications, although chronic anaemia, nutritional deficiencies, and chronic liver disease also contribute [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40].

Hepatic Complications

Hepatic complications include:

  • Cholelithiasis (Gall Stones): This can occur in suboptimally transfused patients due to increased peripheral haemolysis and precipitation of bilirubin in bile [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=252].
  • Hepatic Vaso-Occlusive Disease (VOD): Observed in 10-13% of cases after myeloablative busulfan therapy, which can be resolved with appropriate treatment [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=405].

Infectious Complications

Infections are a significant concern due to:

  • Transfusion-Transmitted Infections (TTI): Despite improved donor testing, long-term transfusion support carries a substantial cumulative lifetime risk of TTI [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=261].
  • Iron Chelation Therapy: This therapy, along with splenectomy and central venous catheters, can contribute to infectious complications [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=261].

Other Complications

Other long-term complications include:

  • Pathological Fractures and Facial Changes: Due to excessive intramedullary haematopoiesis [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=47].
  • Extramedullary Haematopoiesis: This can lead to clinically significant complications [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=47].
  • Infertility: Myeloablative chemo-conditioning may result in long-term infertility [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=405].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Outside USA
answer:
Non-Profit NGOs Outside USA

Non-profit NGOs (Non-Governmental Organizations) outside the USA operate under various national legislations, but they share some common characteristics and benefits:

  • They exist to fulfill their mission, not to make a profit. No owner, stakeholder, or trustee shares in the profits or losses of the NGO [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=15].
  • They may qualify for exemptions from several taxes, including corporate income tax, and can receive grants and donations. Individual donors may claim personal income tax deductions for their donations [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=15].
  • Board members, officers, and employees may be protected from personal liability for corporate debts or liabilities [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=15].
  • They may face restrictions such as no remuneration for Board members, no political campaigning, and no exemption from certain laws and regulations [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=15][ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=16].
  • Incorporation enhances the credibility of an NGO by requiring public accountability and provides legal rights such as owning property, obtaining bank loans, and signing contracts [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=28].

For more detailed guidance on establishing a non-profit NGO, including legal and financial considerations, please refer to the full guide here.

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: if i use saunders to pass nclex will it be enough to pass
answer:
Using Saunders to Pass NCLEX

The Saunders Comprehensive Review for the NCLEX-RN Examination is a highly regarded resource for preparing for the NCLEX exam. It provides comprehensive content review, practice questions, and test-taking strategies. However, whether it will be enough to pass the NCLEX depends on several factors:

  • Individual Study Habits: Consistent and thorough study habits are crucial. Using Saunders as part of a structured study plan can be very effective.
  • Supplementary Resources: While Saunders is comprehensive, some students may benefit from additional resources such as practice exams, online question banks, and other review books to cover any gaps and reinforce learning.
  • Clinical Experience: Practical experience and familiarity with clinical scenarios are important. Applying theoretical knowledge to practical situations can enhance understanding and retention.
  • Test-Taking Skills: Developing good test-taking strategies, such as time management and understanding the format of NCLEX questions, is essential. Saunders provides strategies, but practicing with a variety of question types can be beneficial.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How can I get help
answer:
Getting Help for Thalassaemia

If you need help with thalassaemia, here are some steps you can take:

  • Share your feelings with a healthcare provider, social worker, or a close friend. Talking about your fears can help you manage them better [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=31].
  • Inform your educational institution about your condition and communicate with professors, advisors, and relevant staff members about your needs and potential accommodations [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=6].
  • Build a support network in your location by connecting with fellow students, student organizations, or local patient associations. The Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) can assist you in finding these connections [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=6][LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=8].
  • Familiarize yourself with local healthcare facilities, haematologists, and other specialists who can provide necessary care and treatment. TIF can help you identify these resources [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=5].
  • Review your health insurance coverage to ensure it is valid in your new location or make necessary amendments [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=5].
  • For COVID-19 related concerns, you can reach the TIF COVID-19 Help Desk & Communication Line at TIF-COVID19@thalassaemia.org.cy [HbDisordersCOVID-19_Classification-of-Risk-Groups_V4.pdf#page=35].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Are there any specific exercises that should be avoided?
answer:
Exercises to Avoid for Thalassaemia Patients

While physical activity is beneficial for individuals with thalassaemia, certain exercises should be approached with caution or avoided altogether due to potential complications. Here are some key considerations:

Exercises to Avoid

  • High-impact activities: Avoid high-impact sports or exercises that can cause trauma or injury, especially if there is an enlarged spleen or other organ involvement [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=162].
  • Contact sports: Non-contact, weight-bearing activities are recommended over contact sports to prevent injury [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=163].
  • Strenuous cardiovascular exercises: Patients with significant cardiac iron overload or cardiomyopathy should avoid strenuous cardiovascular exercises that can strain the heart [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=160].
  • Heavy weightlifting: Avoid heavy weightlifting that can put excessive strain on bones and joints, especially in the presence of osteoporosis [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=160].

Recommendations

  • Consult with healthcare providers: All patients should consult their haematologist and cardiologist before starting any new exercise regimen to ensure safety and appropriateness [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=163].
  • Focus on non-contact, weight-bearing activities: Activities such as walking, yoga, and Pilates are generally safe and beneficial [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=162].
  • Work with physical therapists: Physical therapists can help translate physician recommendations into safe daily exercises [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=162].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Follow-up Questions

question: What are the symptoms of Yersinia infection?
answer:
Symptoms of Yersinia Infection in Thalassaemia Patients

Yersinia infection can be particularly severe in thalassaemia patients, especially those receiving desferrioxamine (DFO) therapy. Here are the common symptoms to watch for:

  • Abdominal pain [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=67][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=63][EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=13]
  • Diarrhoea [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=67][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=63][EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=13]
  • Joint pains [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=67][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=63]
  • Fever [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=67][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=63][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90]
  • Sore throat [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=67]
  • Vomiting [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=63]
  • Skin rashes [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=63]
  • Lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes) [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=13]
  • Pharyngitis-tonsillitis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90]
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90]
  • Polyarthritis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90]

In severe cases, the infection can progress to septicaemia, which may include complications such as hepatic and splenic abscesses, osteomyelitis, intussusception, nephritis, meningitis, and endocarditis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: hpersplenism and hypertransfuion protocol
answer:
Hypersplenism and Hypertransfusion Protocol

For patients with thalassaemia who are persistently anaemic, a trial of hypertransfusion with a pretransfusion haemoglobin target set at >10.5 g/dL may help shrink the spleen and settle hypersplenism. This approach can be beneficial in managing the condition without the need for splenectomy, provided that the patient has access to and can tolerate good chelation regimens [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=61].

Splenectomy Considerations

Splenectomy should only be considered in patients with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) following a multidisciplinary discussion and clear documentation of the risks and benefits. Post-splenectomy, a clear plan for monitoring and managing potential complications, such as pulmonary hypertension, should be established [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=61].

Indications for Splenectomy

Indication Comment
Increased blood requirements Annual transfusion volume of 200-275 ml/kg/yr red cells. If effective chelation therapy is maintained, splenectomy may not be necessary.
Hypersplenism Cytopenias causing clinical problems.
Symptomatic splenomegaly Symptoms such as left upper quadrant pain or early satiety, or massive splenomegaly causing concern about possible splenic rupture.

Splenectomy is generally not recommended as a standard procedure due to the associated risks and complications [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=31][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=103].

Monitoring and Management

It is vital to continue improving blood safety and reducing transfusion requirements and donor exposures. Adverse events reporting should be embedded within a haemovigilance framework [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=61].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Can DFO be combined with other chelation therapies?
answer:
Combination Chelation Therapy

Yes, Desferrioxamine (DFO) can be combined with other chelation therapies to improve outcomes, especially when monotherapy is inadequate. Here are some key points regarding combination therapy:

Combination Therapy Approaches

Combination therapy involves using two chelators either simultaneously or sequentially to enhance chelation efficacy. This approach can be beneficial in cases where monotherapy is insufficient or when there are dose-limiting toxicities [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=102].

Common Combinations

  • DFO + Deferiprone (DFP): This combination is often used for patients with significant cardiac iron overload or when rapid reduction of iron is needed. It is recommended to use DFO as often and as continuously as possible along with standard doses of DFP [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=44][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=106].
  • DFO + Deferasirox (DFX): This combination can also be effective, particularly in patients with high levels of body iron and cardiac iron. High doses of DFX have been shown to be effective in improving cardiac T2* values [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=44][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=106].

Considerations

While combination therapy can be effective, it is important to note that most combinations have not been subjected to large, randomized trials. Therefore, the level of evidence is typically less robust compared to monotherapies. Guidelines and expert reviews can help fill these gaps [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=102].

Additional Resources

If you need further assistance with your treatment plan, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-Up Questions

question: Thank you. I'm a patient with thalassemia. What should I think about if I want to get married and have a child?
answer:
Marriage and Family Planning for Thalassaemia Patients

As a patient with thalassaemia, there are several important considerations when planning to get married and have children:

Partner's Thalassaemia Status

The health of your children will depend on your partner's thalassaemia status:

  • If your partner is also a patient with thalassaemia, all children will be affected.
  • If your partner is a carrier of ß-thalassaemia, there is a 50% chance that each child will be affected and a 50% chance that each child will be a carrier.
  • If your partner is not a carrier, all children will be carriers but not affected.

Source: AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf

Reproductive Choices

There are several reproductive options available to avoid having affected children:

  • Carrier screening and genetic counselling before marriage.
  • Conventional prenatal diagnosis in early pregnancy.
  • Pre-implantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) before pregnancy.
  • Gamete donation or adoption.

Source: Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf

Genetic Counselling

It is essential to discuss your options with an expert health professional, preferably a genetic counsellor, to receive reliable and updated information. This will help you make informed decisions about family planning.

Source: TIF-PREVENTION_FINAL-1.pdf

Support and Resources

Patients with thalassaemia can lead near-normal lives with proper treatment and support. Many patients successfully marry and have children.

Source: AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf

If you have further questions or need more detailed information, please contact us at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Se ve afectada esta vía por la deficiencia de PK por la beta oxidación?
answer:
Deficiencia de PK y Beta Oxidación

No hay información específica en las fuentes proporcionadas que indique que la deficiencia de PK afecta directamente la beta oxidación. La deficiencia de PK afecta principalmente la vía glucolítica en los eritrocitos, lo que lleva a una disminución en la producción de ATP y otros metabolitos importantes, resultando en la desestabilización de las bombas de Na+/K+ y la muerte prematura de las células.

Para más información, puedes contactar a info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the common complications associated with TDT?
answer:
Common Complications Associated with Transfusion-Dependent β-Thalassaemia (TDT)

Bone Complications

Patients with TDT may experience thinning and pathological fractures of long bones, as well as extramedullary erythropoietic tissue masses and splenomegaly [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=35].

Cardiac Complications

Chronic anaemia can lead to cardiac enlargement and severe cardiac failure, increasing the risks of morbidity and mortality. Additionally, a hypercoagulable state due to abnormal red blood cells can result in thrombotic complications and pulmonary hypertension, especially in splenectomised adults [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=35].

Endocrine Complications

Endocrine abnormalities are common in TDT, including hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, growth retardation, and diabetes mellitus. These complications are primarily due to iron overload from chronic transfusions [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40].

Hepatic Complications

Iron overload can lead to liver fibrosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and other liver complications such as siderosis, viral hepatitis, fibrosis, cirrhosis, and liver failure [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15].

Haematological Complications

Haemolysis contributes to increased unconjugated bilirubin and the development of calcium bilirubin gallstones. Regular transfusions limit but do not eliminate ineffective erythropoiesis and its complications [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=35].

Transfusion-Related Complications

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a severe complication characterized by dyspnoea, tachycardia, fever, and hypotension during or within six hours of transfusion. Management includes oxygen, steroids, diuretics, and assisted ventilation if needed [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=63].

Growth and Development

Retarded growth may occur due to chronic anaemia and the excessive metabolic burden imposed by erythroid expansion [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=35].

Further Information

For more detailed information, please refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Contact

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: spleen removal
answer:
Splenectomy in Thalassaemia

A splenectomy, or the surgical removal of the spleen, is sometimes necessary for individuals with thalassaemia. This procedure is typically considered when the spleen becomes hyperactive and starts destroying other blood components, such as white blood cells and thrombocytes, leading to hypersplenism. The decision to remove the spleen is based on several medical factors, including:

  • An oversized spleen (usually more than 6 cm in length) causing discomfort.
  • An increasing need for blood transfusions, specifically when the amount of blood required increases 1.5 times or more than 200-220 ml/kg/year of packed red cells.
  • The age of the patient, who should be over 5 years old.

While splenectomy can solve specific problems related to an enlarged spleen, it does not cure thalassaemia. The spleen plays a crucial role in defending the body against infections, and its removal increases the risk of serious infections, particularly in children under 5 years old whose immune systems are not yet mature [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=77].

Methods of Splenectomy

Splenectomy can be performed via a laparotomy or a laparoscopic approach. Laparoscopic splenectomy is often preferred due to its lower rates of intraoperative blood loss, postoperative morbidity and mortality, shorter hospital stays, and better cosmetic outcomes. However, it may not be suitable for all patients, especially those with significant splenomegaly, due to the complexity of the procedure [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=24][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=111].

Post-Splenectomy Care

After a splenectomy, patients are at an increased risk of infections. Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended, and rapid evaluation of febrile episodes is critical. Despite prophylaxis, the risk of sepsis remains, and patients must be vigilant about infections [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=24].

Adverse Events

Potential complications of splenectomy include bleeding, atelectasis, subphrenic abscess, sepsis, thrombosis, and pulmonary hypertension. The risk of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection is particularly high in younger patients [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=205].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia impact cognitive function in pre-teens?
answer:
Impact of Thalassaemia on Cognitive Function in Pre-teens

Thalassaemia can impact cognitive function in pre-teens in several ways:

  • Children with thalassaemia often miss school for medical appointments and transfusions, which can negatively impact their school functioning and overall cognitive development [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=254].
  • Patients with thalassaemia may be vulnerable to experiencing cognitive deficits, as indicated by various studies [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=254].
  • Factors associated with chronic illness, rather than the disease itself, could play a potential role in the development of cognitive dysfunction [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=232].
  • Neuropsychological investigations have shown that there are clear intellectual and psychopathological problems in a limited number of thalassaemia patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=120].

If there are concerns from parents or the school, it may be valuable for patients to participate in neuropsychological testing to assess for any concerns and provide recommendations that could help support the patient's learning potential [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=254].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Is stem cell therapy good for everyone
answer:
Is Stem Cell Therapy Good for Everyone?

Stem cell therapy, specifically haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), is a highly advanced treatment option for thalassaemia. However, it is not suitable for everyone. Here are some key points to consider:

  • Eligibility: HSCT is primarily recommended for patients with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) who do not have a ß0/3º genotype and for whom HSCT is appropriate but lack an HLA-matched related donor [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=5].
  • Success Rates: HSCT has shown high success rates, with a cure achieved in 80% to 90% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=122].
  • Side Effects: Common side effects include stomatitis, febrile neutropenia, epistaxis, venoocclusive liver disease, and abdominal pain. These side effects are generally related to the conditioning regimen rather than the stem cell therapy itself [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=5].
  • Availability: Only about 20% of patients have a fully matched family donor, making HSCT inaccessible for many [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=23].
  • Specialized Centers: The procedure requires highly specialized centers and experienced physicians [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=5].

In summary, while stem cell therapy can be highly effective for certain patients with thalassaemia, it is not suitable for everyone due to eligibility criteria, side effects, and the need for specialized treatment centers.

If you need more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: signs and symptoms
answer:
Signs and Symptoms of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can present with a variety of signs and symptoms, which may vary in severity depending on the type and severity of the condition. Here are some common signs and symptoms:

  • Severe anaemia [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice) [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Dark urine [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Microcytosis (smaller than normal red blood cells) [FocusOnAThal_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Thrombophilia and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Malaise [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Enlarged abdomen and spleen [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Dental issues such as increased dental decay, delayed dental development, and changes in dental morphology [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=99]
  • Short stature and pubertal immaturity [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=15]

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Is wheatgrass actually useful in treating Thalassemia?
answer:
Is wheatgrass actually useful in treating Thalassemia?

Wheatgrass is a popular health food that contains chlorophyll, vitamins, minerals, and several enzymes. It is believed to increase the production of red cells and extend the interval between transfusions. Some studies have demonstrated these benefits in a small number of patients, but the long-term benefits remain uncertain [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=237].

However, the evidence on the efficacy of wheatgrass in contemporary patients with thalassemia is equivocal. The studies conducted have limitations such as small sample sizes, lack of generalizability to older patients, and inconsistent types of interventions (juice, pill, powder). More research is needed to determine its efficacy in a larger cohort of adult patients with thalassemia [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=140][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=170].

For further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sources:

  • TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf
  • NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf
  • NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf

question: Υποκατάστατα αιματος
answer:
Υποκατάστατα Αίματος

Τα υποκατάστατα αίματος είναι σημαντικά για τη διαχείριση ασθενών με δρεπανοκυτταρική αναιμία και άλλες αιμοσφαιρινοπάθειες. Ακολουθούν μερικές από τις κύριες μεθόδους και τεχνικές που χρησιμοποιούνται:

Πλύσιμο Ερυθρών Κυττάρων

Το πλύσιμο των ερυθρών κυττάρων αφαιρεί τις πρωτεΐνες του πλάσματος που αποτελούν στόχο των αντισωμάτων στον λήπτη. Αυτό μπορεί να γίνει με χειροκίνητες ή αυτοματοποιημένες τεχνικές. Τα πλυμένα ερυθρά κύτταρα που δεν είναι αναρτημένα σε διάλυμα αποθήκευσης πρέπει να μεταγγιστούν εντός 24 ωρών. Η αναστολή σε διάλυμα SAGM μετά το πλύσιμο επιτρέπει διάρκεια ζωής έως και 14 ημέρες [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=41].

Κρυοσυντηρημένα Ερυθρά Κύτταρα

Τα κρυοσυντηρημένα (κατεψυγμένα) ερυθρά κύτταρα είναι ένα συστατικό που προέρχεται από ολικό αίμα, όπου τα ερυθρά κύτταρα καταψύχονται, κατά προτίμηση εντός 7 ημερών από τη συλλογή [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=41].

Αλλογενής Μεταμόσχευση Αιμοποιητικών Βλαστικών Κυττάρων (HSCT)

Η αλλογενής μεταμόσχευση αιμοποιητικών βλαστικών κυττάρων είναι η μόνη διαθέσιμη θεραπευτική επιλογή για ασθενείς με εξαρτώμενη από μεταγγίσεις α-θαλασσαιμία. Η αρχή της HSCT είναι να αντικαταστήσει την αναποτελεσματική ή ανώμαλη ερυθροποίηση με ερυθρά αιμοσφαίρια που παράγουν επαρκή λειτουργική αιμοσφαιρίνη [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=129].

Διαχωρισμός Αίματος

Το αίμα διαχωρίζεται σε τρία κύρια συστατικά: πλάσμα, ερυθρά αιμοσφαίρια και αιμοπετάλια. Αυτά τα συστατικά μπορούν να σώσουν έως και τρεις ζωές. Τα ερυθρά αιμοσφαίρια μπορούν να αποθηκευτούν για έως και 35 ημέρες, και αν βρίσκονται σε διάλυμα θρεπτικών προσθέτων, έως και 42 ημέρες [BloodPoliciesEU_FactSheet_Final_20240110.pdf#page=3].

Για περισσότερες πληροφορίες, μπορείτε να επικοινωνήσετε με το email info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What lifestyle changes can help manage beta thalassemia minor?
answer:
Lifestyle Changes to Manage Beta Thalassemia Minor

Managing beta thalassemia minor involves several lifestyle changes that can help improve overall health and prevent complications. Here are some recommendations:

Dietary Recommendations

  • Small, Regular Meals: Consume small, regular meals spread throughout the day to maintain energy levels and manage blood sugar [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43].
  • High-Fiber Foods: Include high-fiber, starchy foods such as wholegrain breads, cereals, beans, peas, lentils, and oats in your diet [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43].
  • Calcium and Vitamin D: Ensure adequate intake of calcium from foods like milk, yogurt, tofu, and kale. Take a vitamin D supplement (1,000 - 2,000 IU/day or 50,000 IU monthly) to support bone health [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23][Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].
  • Limit Iron-Rich Foods: Avoid foods high in iron, especially if you are at risk of iron overload. Drinking tea with meals can help reduce iron absorption [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=27].
  • Hydration: Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water and avoiding sugary beverages [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].

Physical Activity

  • Regular Exercise: Engage in regular physical activity, including weight-bearing exercises like walking, jogging, dancing, and jumping to promote bone health. Activities like swimming and biking are also beneficial for cardiovascular health [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Flexibility Exercises: Incorporate exercises that improve flexibility, such as yoga and Pilates, to enhance muscle strength and balance [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

General Health Recommendations

  • Avoid Smoking: Do not smoke cigarettes as it can exacerbate health issues [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Limit Alcohol: Limit alcohol consumption, especially if you have liver issues [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=27].
  • Regular Health Checks: Regularly monitor your health, including cardiovascular assessments and blood tests, to manage any potential complications [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=123].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What about cases of Thalassemia carriers?
answer:
Thalassemia Carriers in India

In India, it is estimated that 1-3% of the population are carriers of Beta-Thalassemia, with this figure rising to up to 17% in some ethnic groups. This translates to approximately 162,000 new carriers each year, given the population size and carrier frequency.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Prevention of Thalassemia Volume 1 document.

Follow-up Questions

question: Is a blood preservative bad for me?
answer:
Blood Preservatives and Thalassaemia

The anticoagulant preservative solutions used in blood collection are designed to prevent coagulation and maintain the metabolic integrity of red cells during storage. These solutions typically contain sodium citrate, citric acid, and glucose, and may also include adenine, guanosine, and phosphate (e.g., CPD-A). Additives such as AS-1, AS-3, and AS-5 allow red cells to be stored for up to 42 days [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=42].

While these preservatives are necessary for the safe storage and transfusion of blood, there are some potential risks associated with stored blood. For example, free haem compounds released from the lysis of transfused red cells can provide iron for bacteria and promote infection. This risk increases with the storage duration of the blood [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=88].

If you have specific concerns about blood preservatives and their effects, it is best to discuss them with your healthcare provider. For further assistance, you can also contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: Apakah ada alternatif lain selain transfusi darah untuk mengobati thalassaemia?
answer:
Alternatif Pengobatan Selain Transfusi Darah untuk Thalassaemia

Selain transfusi darah, ada beberapa alternatif pengobatan yang tersedia atau sedang dikembangkan untuk mengobati thalassaemia. Berikut adalah beberapa opsi tersebut:

1. Transplantasi Sel Punca Hematopoietik (HSCT)

Transplantasi sel punca hematopoietik (HSCT) adalah satu-satunya metode kuratif yang tersedia saat ini untuk pasien dengan thalassaemia. Transplantasi ini melibatkan penggantian sumsum tulang yang rusak dengan sel punca sehat dari donor yang cocok. HSCT harus dilakukan sedini mungkin untuk hasil yang lebih baik sebelum terjadi disfungsi organ akibat kelebihan zat besi [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=140][TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=9].

2. Terapi Gen

Terapi gen adalah metode baru yang sedang diuji dalam uji klinis. Terapi ini melibatkan pengeditan gen untuk memperbaiki mutasi yang menyebabkan thalassaemia. Meskipun masih dalam tahap awal, terapi gen menunjukkan potensi sebagai pengobatan kuratif di masa depan [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=24].

3. Agen Baru dan Terapi yang Sedang Berkembang

Beberapa agen baru sedang dipelajari untuk thalassaemia, dengan yang paling menjanjikan adalah luspatercept dan mitapivat. Luspatercept adalah agen pematangan eritroid yang efektif dalam mengurangi ketergantungan transfusi pada pasien dengan β-thalassaemia dan meningkatkan anemia pada pasien dengan β-thalassaemia non-transfusi. Mitapivat adalah aktivator piruvat kinase yang meningkatkan kadar hemoglobin pada pasien dengan penyakit HbH. Hasil studi tentang penggunaan agen-agen baru ini diharapkan dalam beberapa tahun mendatang dan dapat menawarkan alternatif untuk transfusi dalam meningkatkan anemia pada pasien dengan thalassaemia [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=193].

4. Inhibitor JAK2

Inhibitor JAK2 seperti ruxolitinib sedang dipelajari untuk mengurangi eritropoiesis yang tidak efektif dan penyerapan zat besi pada pasien dengan thalassaemia. Studi awal menunjukkan bahwa inhibitor JAK2 dapat mengurangi splenomegali pada model tikus dengan thalassaemia intermedia dan mayor [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=106].

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut, Anda dapat menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Do thalassaemics suffer from cholesterol
answer:
Do Thalassaemics Suffer from Cholesterol?

Patients with thalassaemia typically have low serum levels of total cholesterol and low-density (LDL) cholesterol. Hypercholesterolaemia is uncommon in these patients. However, they often have low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, which is the "good" cholesterol that is heart-protective. Additionally, many thalassaemia patients have hypertriglyceridemia and elevated concentrations of highly atherogenic triglyceride-rich lipoprotein remnants, which can contribute to cardiovascular risks.

These lipid profile changes are often related to iron overload, oxidative stress, and liver damage, which are common in thalassaemia patients. Despite the low cholesterol levels, the presence of other risk factors such as low HDL cholesterol and hypertriglyceridemia can still pose a risk for cardiovascular disease.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • Nutrition Guide for Thalassaemia and PKD [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=50]
  • Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=25]

question: What are the signs of iron overload in thalassaemia patients?
answer:
Signs of Iron Overload in Thalassaemia Patients

Iron overload in thalassaemia patients can lead to several serious complications. Here are some of the signs and symptoms to watch for:

  • Skin Discoloration: A 'tanned' appearance due to iron deposition in the skin [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=15].
  • Liver Damage: Early signs include fibrosis, progressing to cirrhosis and potentially liver failure. This can occur within two years of starting transfusions if not managed properly [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=35].
  • Heart Disease: Iron overload can lead to cardiomyopathy and heart failure, which are significant causes of mortality in thalassaemia patients [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=52].
  • Endocrine Disorders: Iron deposition can cause diabetes mellitus, hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, and other hormonal deficiencies [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=35][EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=15].
  • Growth Retardation: Delayed sexual maturation and short stature due to endocrine failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58][EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=15].
  • Bone Abnormalities: Iron overload can impair erythropoiesis, leading to bone marrow expansion, skeletal deformities, and fractures [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=35][EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=15].
  • Jaundice: Due to liver complications or coexisting conditions like Gilbert's syndrome [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=15].

For more information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Transfusion Dependent Thalassemia
answer:
Transfusion Dependent Thalassemia (TDT)

Transfusion Dependent Thalassemia (TDT) is a severe form of thalassemia where patients require regular blood transfusions throughout their lifetime. These transfusions typically start during the first months of life and are essential for survival. Patients with TDT usually receive 2 or more blood bags every 2-5 weeks [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2][HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Iron Chelation Therapy

Due to the regular blood transfusions, iron accumulates in the body, which can be toxic to vital organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands. Therefore, iron chelation therapy is crucial to remove excess iron. This therapy is usually lifelong and starts in early childhood. There are three types of iron chelators: two are taken orally, and one is administered via subcutaneous injection [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].

Health Complications

Patients with TDT may experience various health complications, including:

  • Severe anemia
  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

Endocrine Complications

Endocrine complications are more frequently reported in TDT patients compared to those with non-transfusion-dependent thalassemia (NTDT). These complications include hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, growth retardation, and diabetes mellitus. Iron overload from chronic transfusions is a primary risk factor for these complications [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the full guidelines available here.

If you have further questions or need additional assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Thrombophilia and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Iron overload causing damage to organs such as the liver and heart [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58]
  • Delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice) [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Dark urine [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Endocrine problems such as delayed puberty, diabetes, and hypothyroidism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities such as heart failure and arrhythmias [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Liver complications such as cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Contact for Further Assistance

If you have more questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Is there a study on profile and outcomes of thalassemia in the Philippines
answer:
Study on Profile and Outcomes of Thalassemia in the Philippines

There is no specific mention of a study on the profile and outcomes of thalassemia in the Philippines in the provided sources. However, the importance of outcome studies in monitoring and evaluating the effectiveness and quality of services for thalassemia patients is highlighted. These studies include patient survival rates, age distribution, quality of life, complication rates, and health economic studies [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=33].

For more detailed information or specific studies related to the Philippines, you may contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What else she support
answer:
Support for Thalassaemia Patients

Support for individuals with thalassaemia is multifaceted and includes emotional, psychological, social, and financial aspects. Here are some key areas of support:

  • Emotional and Psychological Support: Patients benefit from the encouragement and positive attitude of family, friends, and medical staff. Psychological support helps manage pain and distress, and early intervention can prevent family conflicts and harmful coping mechanisms [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=354].
  • Social Support: Social support is crucial for the psychological functioning of patients and their families. This includes presenting information about the condition to friends and family, relying on existing support networks, and meeting other patients and families through events and support groups [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=352].
  • Financial Support: Fundraising activities by NGOs help cover treatment costs and provide consumables. This financial support is significant for patients, especially in developing countries where healthcare resources may be limited [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=31].
  • Educational Support: Patients and their families are encouraged to educate themselves about the condition and treatment options. This knowledge empowers them to actively participate in their care and make informed decisions [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=9].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: Are there any specialized thalassaemia centers in The Netherlands?
answer:
Specialized Thalassaemia Centers in The Netherlands

In The Netherlands, specialized thalassaemia care is provided through various healthcare settings. Here are some key points about the availability and structure of these centers:

  • Multidisciplinary Care: Thalassaemia management involves a multidisciplinary team of experienced physicians and nurses working collaboratively in specialized centers. This includes haematologists, specialized nurses, cardiologists, and endocrinologists [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=145][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].
  • Reference Centres: Patients may be treated in reference centers that provide comprehensive care. These centers are often associated with tertiary level hospitals and offer specialized services for thalassaemia patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=144][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=121].
  • Independent Units: There are independent thalassaemia units/centers based on the outpatient principle, attached to or associated with tertiary level hospitals. These units provide dedicated care for thalassaemia patients [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=323].
  • Networking with Expertise Centers: Patients treated in peripheral centers due to distance can benefit from networking with a center of expertise where their condition is periodically reassessed [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].

For further assistance in finding a specialized thalassaemia center in The Netherlands, you can contact:

  • Cornelis L. Harteveld, Assistant Professor of Genetics, Leiden University Medical Center [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=4].
  • Thalassaemia International Federation for additional guidance and support.

question: Any training course or fellowship courses
answer:
Thalassaemia Training and Fellowship Courses

The Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) offers several educational opportunities for healthcare professionals, patients, and their families. These include:

  • Renzo Galanello Fellowship Programme: This programme covers all aspects of the clinical management of haemoglobinopathies and is addressed to physicians, specialists in haematology, paediatrics, or internal medicine. It is offered through the Joint Red Cell Unit, Haematology Department of the University College London NHS Foundation Trust in London, UK, under the leadership of Dr Perla Eleftheriou [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf].
  • eThalED Course for Medical Specialists: This course offers specialised knowledge on the prevention and clinical management of thalassaemia to medical specialists. It is based on the "Guidelines for the Management of Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (4th edition, 2021)" [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf].
  • Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) e-Course: An online educational course for healthcare professionals covering all aspects of SCD clinical management [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf].
  • TIF e-Academy: Offers various e-courses for healthcare professionals and patients, including the Thal e-course for patients/parents [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf][TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf].

For more information on how to participate, please visit the TIF Education Page.

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the treatment options for thalassaemia?
answer:
Treatment Options for Thalassaemia

Blood Transfusions

Regular blood transfusions are a primary treatment for thalassaemia, especially for those with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT). Patients typically receive transfusions every 2-5 weeks to maintain pre-transfusion haemoglobin levels at 9.5 to 10 g/dL.

[Source: Thalassaemia International Federation]

Iron Chelation Therapy

Iron chelation therapy is essential to remove excess iron from the body, which accumulates due to frequent blood transfusions. There are three main types of iron chelators: two oral medications and one administered via subcutaneous injection.

[Source: Thalassaemia International Federation]

Splenectomy

Splenectomy, the surgical removal of the spleen, may be considered in cases where the spleen is significantly enlarged or causing discomfort, or when there is a high transfusion requirement.

[Source: Thalassaemia International Federation]

Novel Therapies

Luspatercept-aamt is a novel pharmaceutical agent that helps prolong the lifespan of red blood cells in thalassaemia patients, reducing the need for frequent transfusions and iron chelation therapy.

[Source: Thalassaemia International Federation]

Allogeneic Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT)

HSCT is currently the only curative option for thalassaemia. It involves replacing the patient's defective stem cells with healthy donor stem cells. This treatment is most effective in younger patients with an HLA-matched sibling donor.

[Source: Thalassaemia International Federation]

Gene Therapy

Emerging gene therapy approaches involve the genetic modification of patient-derived haematopoietic stem cells to correct the genetic defects causing thalassaemia. These therapies are still under development but hold promise for a definitive cure.

[Source: Thalassaemia International Federation]

For more information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

For thalassaemia major, complications due to iron overload from repeated blood transfusions can include:

  • Heart disease (heart failure, arrhythmias, myocarditis)
  • Liver complications (fibrosis, cirrhosis, liver failure)
  • Endocrine problems (delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, osteoporosis) [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

In thalassaemia intermedia, complications can include weak bones with deformities and fractures, thrombophilia, and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Thalassaemia and Employment

Thalassaemia can significantly impact employment and workplace challenges for adults due to several factors:

  • Many patients experience low self-esteem and feel that their health does not allow them to work, leading to a lower employment rate among thalassaemia patients. A survey indicated that only 32% of respondents were fully or part-time employed [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].
  • Prejudice from employers is still an issue in many parts of the world, with reasons including repeated absences from work and easy fatigue [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].
  • Inadequate healthcare systems that do not support out-of-hours treatment contribute to low work performance and employer reluctance [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].
  • Thalassaemia is considered a disability that hinders full participation in society, and the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities mandates equal employment rights and conditions for persons with disabilities [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].

Healthcare professionals and patient organizations play a crucial role in preparing patients for employment, advocating for their rights, and educating employers and the public [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].

Follow-up Questions

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, especially if not properly managed. These complications include:

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Thrombophilia and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Iron overload, which can cause serious damage to organs such as the liver, heart, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice) [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Dark urine [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Heart disease, including heart failure and arrhythmias [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Liver complications such as cirrhosis and liver failure [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Endocrine problems like diabetes, hypothyroidism, and delayed puberty [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Follow-Up Questions

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

  • Delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice) [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Dark urine [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Iron overload leading to damage in organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Heart failure, liver cirrhosis, and diabetes in poorly treated patients [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1]
  • Endocrine problems such as delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities such as pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, congestive heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities such as cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

There are more than 200 known ß-thalassaemia mutations, which can result in a range of phenotypic severities from very mild to very severe:

  • Severe (ß0) mutations: Examples include IVS1-1, IVS11-1, and C39.
  • Less severe (ß+) mutations: Examples include IVS1-110, IVS11-745, and IVS1-5.
  • Mild (ß++) mutations: Examples include -101, -87, -88, and -28.

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Impact of Genetic Modifiers

The severity of thalassaemia can be influenced by several genetic modifiers:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the imbalance between α- and ß-globin chains, leading to a milder form of the disease. [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101]
  • Increased production of γ-globin chains: This results in higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can ameliorate the severity of the disease. [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32]
  • Hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH): Mutations associated with high HbF levels can result in a milder form of ß-thalassaemia intermedia when combined with severe ß-thalassaemia alleles. [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32]
  • Genome-wide association studies (GWAS): Identified loci such as BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB intergenic region that influence disease severity. [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32]

Clinical Categories

Based on the genetic factors, thalassaemia can be broadly categorized into:

  • Thalassaemia Major: Patients require regular blood transfusions to survive.
  • Thalassaemia Intermedia: Patients may survive with occasional or no transfusions, or with chronic transfusions initiated at an older age. [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37]

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Are there any new treatments for iron overload in development?
answer:
New Treatments for Iron Overload in Development

Recent developments in the treatment of iron overload include the following approaches:

  • Long-acting hepcidin analogues (minihepcidins) are being studied for their potential to restrict iron absorption and utilization, which could be beneficial in managing iron overload and improving ineffective erythropoiesis [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=51].
  • Stimulating endogenous hepcidin production by downregulating TMPRSS6, a metalloprotease that plays a key role in hepcidin expression. Anti-sense oligonucleotides and siRNAs targeting TMPRSS6 have shown promise in pre-clinical models by increasing hepcidin levels, reducing iron burden, and improving ineffective erythropoiesis and red cell survival [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=51].
  • Combination therapy with existing iron chelators, such as deferoxamine and deferiprone, has shown effectiveness in patients with severe iron overload, particularly in improving cardiac function and survival [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=73].

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: how can I extend the period of transfusions and perserve the HB ?
answer:
Extending Transfusion Periods and Preserving Haemoglobin

To extend the period between transfusions and maintain haemoglobin (Hb) levels, consider the following strategies:

  • Maintain pre-transfusion haemoglobin levels at 90-105 g/L, with post-transfusion levels at 120 g/L [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=185].
  • For patients with heart disease or other medical conditions, a higher pre-transfusion haemoglobin level of 110-120 g/L may be appropriate [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=26].
  • Regularly reassess paediatric and young adult patients to adjust transfusion protocols as needed [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=44].
  • Use leucodepleted packed red cells and perform regular antibody screening to ensure compatibility and reduce transfusion reactions [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=31].

For more detailed guidance, please refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation.

question: How often should I have check-ups and what tests will be performed
answer:
Recommended Check-ups and Tests for Thalassaemia Patients

Regular check-ups and specific tests are crucial for managing thalassaemia effectively. Below is a summary of the recommended frequency and types of tests based on the condition:

General Monitoring

  • Serum Ferritin: Every 3 months for beta thalassaemia major or other transfusion-dependent anaemias; every 6 months for thalassaemia intermedia and NTDT [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=70].
  • Full Blood Count: Weekly [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=70].
  • Biochemical Analysis (Liver Function Test): Monthly [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=70].
  • Zinc Levels: 3 to 6 times yearly [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=70].
  • Viral Serology Tests (HBV, HIV, HCV): Every 6-12 months [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69].

Iron Overload Monitoring

Condition Serum Ferritin Myocardial T2* MRI Ferriscan (Liver Iron Content) Liver
Beta thalassaemia major or other transfusion-dependent anaemia Every 3 months From age 8: every 2 years if T2* > 20ms; yearly if 10-20ms; every 6 months if < 10ms or EF reduced From age 8 annually Only if indicated for histology or if laparotomy
Thalassaemia Intermedia, NTDT, or iron-loading anaemias Every 6 months Every 5 years after age 10, increase if iron load detected From age 10 annually Only if indicated for histology or if laparotomy

[NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=176]

Additional Tests

  • 24-hour Urine Samples: Every 3 months to determine iron content in the urine [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=70].
  • Liver Biopsy, SQUID, and/or MRI: As needed to assess iron content in the liver and cardiac muscle [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=70].

For more detailed information or specific cases, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: ist ß-thalassämi ein deutschland häufiger als a- thalassämie
answer:
In Deutschland ist Beta-Thalassämie häufiger als Alpha-Thalassämie. Dies liegt hauptsächlich an der Verteilung der Trägerpopulationen und den Migrationsmustern. Beta-Thalassämie ist besonders häufig in der Mittelmeerregion, im Nahen Osten und in Südostasien, Regionen, aus denen viele Einwanderer nach Deutschland kommen [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=204][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=5].

Alpha-Thalassämie ist ebenfalls in bestimmten Populationen präsent, insbesondere bei Menschen aus Südostasien und China, aber die Prävalenz ist im Vergleich zu Beta-Thalassämie in Deutschland geringer [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=4].

Für genauere Informationen oder spezifische Fragen wenden Sie sich bitte an info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Apakah ada gejala khusus yang menunjukkan adanya kista pada limpa?
answer:
Gejala Kista pada Limpa

Gejala kista pada limpa dapat bervariasi tergantung pada ukuran dan lokasi kista. Beberapa gejala yang mungkin muncul termasuk:

  • Nyeri perut atau ketidaknyamanan di daerah perut
  • Pembesaran limpa yang dapat dirasakan sebagai massa di perut
  • Gejala anemia seperti kelemahan, kelelahan, dan pucat [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=93]

Jika Anda mengalami gejala-gejala ini, penting untuk segera berkonsultasi dengan dokter untuk evaluasi lebih lanjut.

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut atau bantuan tambahan, Anda dapat menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Pertanyaan Lanjutan

question: mitapivat
answer:
Mitapivat

Mitapivat (trade name Pyrukynd®) is a first-in-class oral, small-molecule, allosteric activator of the red blood cell-specific form of pyruvate kinase (PK). It has shown efficacy and safety in treating anemia in adult patients with pyruvate kinase deficiency (PKD) and has received approval in the USA and Europe for this indication [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=25].

Mechanism of Action

Mitapivat works by activating pyruvate kinase, an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the glycolytic pathway of red blood cells. This activation increases ATP levels, which helps to reduce hemolysis and improve red blood cell survival [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=145].

Clinical Trials and Efficacy

  • Phase 2 Study: An open-label, multicenter, phase 2 study evaluated mitapivat in 20 adults with non-transfusion-dependent thalassemia (NTDT). The study included 15 patients with β-thalassemia and 5 with α-thalassemia. The results showed that 80% of patients had a hemoglobin increase of ≥1.0 g/dL. The most common treatment-emergent adverse events were initial insomnia (50%), dizziness (30%), and headache (25%) [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].
  • Phase 3 Trials: Mitapivat is currently being evaluated in two phase 3 trials for both non-transfusion-dependent and transfusion-dependent thalassemia. The ENERGIZE trial (NCT04770753) is a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study in adult patients with NTDT, aiming to enroll 171 patients over 24 weeks with an open-label extension for 5 years [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146].

Potential Benefits

Mitapivat has shown promise in increasing hemoglobin levels and improving markers of erythropoiesis and hemolysis in thalassemia patients. It may offer an alternative to transfusions for improving anemia in patients with α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=193].

Regulatory Status

Mitapivat has received approval in the USA and Europe for the treatment of anemia in adult patients with PK deficiency. Its application for regulatory approval for the treatment of anemia in NTDT was withdrawn in the USA in June 2022 due to a lack of agreement on benefit/risk [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].

For more detailed information, please refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Symptoms

  • Severe anaemia
  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

Common Complications

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, especially if not treated properly:

  • Iron overload, causing damage to major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Heart failure, liver cirrhosis, and diabetes [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1]
  • Delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities such as pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, and congestive heart failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities including cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: how can i connect to germany association ?
answer:
Connecting with the Thalassaemia Association in Germany

To connect with the Thalassaemia Association in Germany, you can reach out to the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF). TIF has extensive connections and can provide you with the necessary contact information for the relevant association in Germany.

For further assistance, you can contact TIF directly at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Additional Resources

For more information on patient associations and support networks, you can refer to the following sources:

  • Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF)
  • European Organisation for Rare Disorders (EURORDIS)

question: How to calculate dose for iron overload
answer:
Calculating Dose for Iron Overload

To calculate the dose for iron overload, particularly when using deferasirox, follow these guidelines:

Starting Dose

The starting dose of deferasirox is typically 10 mg/kg/day [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=52].

Dose Escalation After 1 Month

Baseline Liver Iron Concentration (LIC) Baseline Serum Ferritin (SF) Dose Modification
≥5 to ≤7 mg Fe/g dry weight ≥800 to ≤1500 ng/ml No escalation
>7 to ≤15 mg Fe/g dry weight >1500 to ≤3000 ng/ml Escalate to 15 mg/kg/day
>15 mg Fe/g dry weight >3000 ng/ml Escalate to 20 mg/kg/day

[NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=52]

Further Dose Escalation After 6 Months

6 Months LIC 6 Months SF Dose Modification
≥3 to ≤7 mg Fe/g dry weight ≥300 to ≤1500 ng/ml Same dose (maximum 10 mg/kg/day)
>7 to ≤15 mg Fe/g dry weight >1500 to ≤3000 ng/ml Increase by 5 mg/kg/day (maximum 20 mg/kg/day)
>15 mg Fe/g dry weight >3000 ng/ml Increase by 5-10 mg/kg/day (maximum 30 mg/kg/day)

[NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=52]

Discontinuation

Deferasirox therapy should be discontinued when patients reach a liver iron concentration value of 3 mg Fe/g dry weight or serum ferritin level 300 ng/ml [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=52].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: ferritin around 800
answer:
Ferritin Levels Around 800 ng/ml

A serum ferritin level of ≥800 ng/ml is considered a threshold after which patients are at risk of developing morbidity. This includes conditions such as thrombosis, pulmonary hypertension, hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=49][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=44].

For patients with non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (NTDT), a serum ferritin level >800 ng/ml is also an independent risk factor for death [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=49]. Additionally, iron overload associated with high ferritin levels can lead to renal dysfunction and liver disease [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=44][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=84].

It is recommended to monitor liver function and iron levels regularly. For NTDT patients, liver function tests should be conducted every 3 months, and liver ultrasounds should be performed annually if serum ferritin levels are ≥800 ng/ml [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=85].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: can alpha Thalassemia carrier have high hb h
answer:
Can Alpha Thalassemia Carriers Have High Hb H?

Alpha thalassemia carriers typically do not have high levels of Hb H. Carriers of alpha thalassemia, whether they have one or two abnormal or missing alpha-globin genes, usually do not exhibit significant symptoms and do not require treatment. They may have mild or no symptoms at all, and their red blood cells might be smaller than normal (microcytosis) with sometimes very mild anemia [PreventionVol1_English.pdf][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf].

Hb H disease, which involves having three abnormal or missing alpha-globin genes, is characterized by increased hemolysis and can range from moderate to severe anemia. Individuals with Hb H disease may require regular monitoring and treatment, including blood transfusions [PreventionVol1_English.pdf][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website or contact them at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Employment and Workplace Challenges for Adults with Thalassaemia

Many adult thalassaemia patients are employed without difficulty. However, several challenges can arise due to factors originating from both the patients and their employers or the broader social environment.

Challenges Faced by Patients

  • Low self-esteem and the belief that 'poor health' prevents them from working, especially if they have not received adequate psychosocial support [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Interruptions in educational or work schedules due to clinic and transfusion appointments, which are often during daytime working hours [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Feelings of being different or isolated, which can be exacerbated by societal views of thalassaemia as an 'immigrant disease' [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

Challenges from Employers and the Social Environment

  • Discrimination based on disability, which can affect equal remuneration and safe working conditions [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Lack of understanding and support from employers regarding the needs of thalassaemia patients [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

Statistics

In a survey of over 300 patients aged over 20 years, it was found that:

Employment Status Percentage
Fully Employed 50%
Part-Time Employed 19%
Unemployed 31% (14% by choice)

These figures exceed national unemployment statistics, indicating the unique challenges faced by thalassaemia patients [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

Recommendations

  • Adjusting transfusion services to include evening and weekend sessions to accommodate patients' work schedules [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Advocacy by thalassaemia care teams to educate employers and the public about the capabilities of thalassaemia patients [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Providing psychological support to help patients build self-esteem and confidence in their ability to work [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.
