question: Can minor thalassemia affect pregnancy?
answer:
Can Minor Thalassemia Affect Pregnancy?

Minor thalassemia, also known as thalassemia trait, generally does not significantly affect pregnancy. However, there are some considerations to keep in mind:

  • If both partners are carriers of the thalassemia trait, there is a risk of having a child with thalassemia major or intermedia. In such cases, genetic counseling and prenatal testing are recommended to understand the risks and options available [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=14][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=140].
  • Women with thalassemia minor may experience mild anemia during pregnancy, which can be managed with regular monitoring and appropriate supplementation, such as folate [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=228].
  • It is important for pregnant women with thalassemia minor to maintain a healthy hemoglobin level to support fetal development [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=92].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) guidelines.

If you have further questions or need personalized advice, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: hb e disease is like carrier clinically?
answer:
Hb E Disease: Clinical Similarity to Carrier State

Heterozygotes for Hb E are clinically normal and manifest only minimal changes in red blood cell indices, with the presence of Hb E on haemoglobin analyses. Homozygotes for Hb E are also clinically silent and may be only mildly anaemic. This means that individuals with Hb E disease (homozygous Hb E) are generally healthy and exhibit only mild anemia, similar to carriers of other haemoglobinopathies [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=28][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=33].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question:
I am a Beta Thalassemia Intermedia living in Finland now. I am 35 years old and I have managed to live without blood transfusion for almost all my life time with few exceptions when I had splenectomy surgery and had my gall bladder removed about 13 years ago. I have been taking Hydroxyuera 500 mg per day for over ten years now. My hemoglobin used to stay around 80 or 75 for the past years; however, it has started to lower to 65 and 60 recently. 
I have access to Finnish health care and hematology ward is in charge of my laboratory tests and wellbeing. But unfortunately even after 4 years, they could not find the match for blood transfusion with the same RBC phenotype. So I just contined with Hydroxyurea and was hoping to get a new treatment as soon as possible. My haematologist explore the possibility of finding a transfusion match through the International Committee of the Red Cross but without any success so far.
answer:
Thalassaemia Management

It sounds like you have been managing your Beta Thalassemia Intermedia quite well over the years. However, the recent drop in your hemoglobin levels is concerning. Here are some points to consider:

  • Hydroxyurea has been shown to improve hematological parameters in beta-thalassemia intermedia by enhancing beta-globin synthesis [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=40]. However, long-term use can lead to desensitization, which might explain the recent drop in your hemoglobin levels [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=43].
  • Blood transfusions are a common treatment for thalassemia intermedia when hemoglobin levels fall below 7g/dl or if the patient experiences significant symptoms [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=44].
  • Finding a compatible blood donor can be challenging, especially with specific RBC phenotypes. The International Committee of the Red Cross is one avenue, but other international blood donor registries might also be explored [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=11].
  • Other treatment options, such as erythropoietin and short-chain fatty acids, have shown variable benefits and might be worth discussing with your hematologist [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=41].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: Hur ofta bör jag övervaka mina järnnivåer under kelationsbehandling?
answer:
Övervakning av Järnnivåer under Kelationsbehandling

Det är viktigt att regelbundet övervaka järnnivåerna under kelationsbehandling för att säkerställa effektiv behandling och undvika överkelation. Här är de rekommenderade övervakningsintervallen:

  • Serumferritin: Bör kontrolleras var 3:e månad för att övervaka järnnivåerna och justera kelationsdosen vid behov [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=47].
  • Leverjärnkoncentration (LIC): Bör mätas årligen med hjälp av MRI eller andra tillförlitliga metoder för att bedöma järnackumulering i levern [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=120].
  • Hjärtfunktion: Regelbundna hjärtundersökningar, inklusive MRI T2*, bör utföras för att övervaka hjärtjärn och förebygga hjärtdysfunktion [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=123].

Om du behöver ytterligare hjälp, vänligen kontakta info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: when can i start oral iron chelation after pregnancy
answer:
Resuming Oral Iron Chelation After Pregnancy

Oral iron chelators, such as deferiprone and deferasirox, should generally be avoided during breastfeeding due to potential risks to the infant [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=239]. Here are the guidelines for resuming iron chelation therapy after pregnancy:

  • All chelation should be stopped as soon as a pregnancy is confirmed, and the need for chelation re-evaluated after the first trimester [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=233].
  • Deferoxamine (Desferal) can be resumed immediately after childbirth, even while breastfeeding [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=90].
  • Oral iron chelators, such as deferasirox or deferiprone, should generally be avoided during breastfeeding due to the potential risks to the infant [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=239].

It is essential to consult with your healthcare provider to determine the best course of action based on your specific medical condition and iron load.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the potential complications of thalassaemia?
answer:
Potential Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia, if not properly managed, can lead to a range of serious complications. These complications can affect various systems in the body and may include:

  • Growth retardation and short stature [ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf#page=2][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Endocrine complications such as hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus, and osteoporosis [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=82].
  • Cardiac abnormalities including pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, and congestive heart failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42][HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1].
  • Hepatic abnormalities such as cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42][HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1].
  • Splenic enlargement and possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Bone deformities, especially of the skull [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=38].
  • Severe anaemia leading to fatigue, severe pallor, and heart failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=38].
  • Darkening of the skin and feeling of weakness [ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf#page=2].
  • Increased vulnerability to infections, particularly in the presence of underlying complications [COVID-19-pandemic-and-haemoglobin-disorders_V3.pdf#page=5].

Proper treatment and adherence to medical guidelines are essential to prevent these complications and ensure a good quality of life for thalassaemia patients. For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation's website at www.thalassaemia.org.cy.

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the signs of haemolytic crises in HbH disease?
answer:
Signs of Haemolytic Crises in HbH Disease

Clinical Features

A haemolytic crisis in HbH disease is characterized by the following signs and symptoms:

  • Acute worsening of anaemia
  • Jaundice
  • Dark-coloured urine (haemoglobinuria)
  • Increased indirect bilirubin levels
  • Increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels
  • Increased aspartate transaminase (AST) levels
  • Low oxygen saturation (<90%)
  • Marked leucocytosis with predominant neutrophils
  • Presence of toxic granulation and vacuolization in white blood cells

These symptoms are often triggered by infections, fever, oxidative stress, hypersplenism, or pregnancy [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=77][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=107].

Severity

During a haemolytic crisis, haemoglobin levels can drop significantly, sometimes to as low as 30-40 g/L overnight. This rapid destruction of red cells with precipitated HbH can lead to severe complications such as shock and acute renal failure [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=78][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=107].

Management

Immediate intervention is required to manage a haemolytic crisis, including:

  • Prompt blood transfusions
  • Intravenous hydration and urine alkalinization
  • Antipyretics and empiric antibiotics
  • Monitoring and treatment for infections

These measures help to stabilize the patient and prevent further complications [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=78][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=107].

Additional Information

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: why is my creatinine elevated
answer:
Reasons for Elevated Creatinine Levels

Elevated creatinine levels can be a concern as they are closely associated with kidney function. Here are some potential reasons for elevated creatinine levels in patients with thalassaemia:

Medication-Related Causes

  • Dosage-related increase: In many cases, the increase in creatinine levels is related to the dosage of iron chelation therapy, such as Deferasirox (DFX). Reducing the dosage often brings creatinine levels back to normal [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=75].
  • Combination with other medications: The use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents (NSAIDs) or other medications can also contribute to elevated creatinine levels [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=99].

Health Conditions

  • Renal stones: Kidney stones can cause an increase in creatinine levels [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=99].
  • Acute illnesses: Conditions such as septicaemic shock or severe acute vaso-occlusive complications in sickle cell disease can lead to elevated creatinine levels. It is advisable to interrupt chelation therapy until the patient's condition stabilizes [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=99].

Other Factors

  • Proteinuria: Proteinuria, which is present in about a quarter of thalassaemia major patients, can also contribute to elevated creatinine levels. Regular monitoring of urine for protein is recommended [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=99].
  • Underlying kidney dysfunction: Patients with pre-existing kidney dysfunction are more likely to experience elevated creatinine levels when on chelation therapy [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=75].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Employment and Workplace Challenges for Adults with Thalassaemia

Many adult thalassaemia patients are employed without difficulty. However, several challenges can arise due to factors originating from patients, employers, and the social environment. These challenges include:

  • Low Self-Esteem: Some patients may have low self-esteem and feel that their health condition prevents them from working effectively [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Discrimination: Patients may face discrimination based on their health condition, which can affect their employment opportunities and workplace experiences [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Workplace Adjustments: The need to attend clinic and transfusion appointments during daytime working hours can disrupt their work schedule. Adjusting transfusion services to include evening and weekend sessions can help mitigate this issue [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Mental Health: A considerable proportion of adult patients with thalassaemia show evidence of depression and anxiety, which can impact their work performance and overall quality of life [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=112].

To address these challenges, it is important for thalassaemia care teams to advocate on behalf of their patients, educate potential employers, and instill a positive attitude in patients regarding their ability to work [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: ideal iron ferritin
answer:
Ideal Iron Ferritin Levels in Thalassaemia Patients

Monitoring and managing iron levels is crucial for patients with thalassaemia to prevent complications related to iron overload. Here are the recommended ferritin levels and guidelines for thalassaemia patients:

Target Ferritin Levels

  • General Population: Normal ferritin levels are up to 250 µg/l for men and between 10-120 µg/l for women [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=61].
  • Thalassaemia Patients: The aim is to keep ferritin levels between 1000-2000 µg/l to minimize the risk of iron-related complications [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=62].
  • Lower Risk of Cardiac Complications: Ferritin levels consistently below 2500 µg/l have been shown to reduce the risk of cardiac complications [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69].
  • Optimal Range: The target value for serum ferritin is currently between 500-1000 µg/l [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=34][EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=11].

Monitoring Frequency

  • Serum ferritin levels should be measured at least every 3 months to adjust iron chelation therapy as needed [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=34][EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=11].
  • For patients with thalassaemia intermedia or non-transfusion dependent thalassaemia (NTDT), ferritin levels should be checked every 6 months, with a target value of ≤800 µg/l [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69].

Considerations

It is important to note that serum ferritin levels can be influenced by various factors such as inflammation, liver function, and metabolic deficiencies. Therefore, ferritin trends over time are more reliable than single measurements for adjusting therapy [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=119][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=34].

If you need more detailed information or have specific concerns, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Thalassaemia and Employment

Adults with thalassaemia face several challenges in the workplace, which can affect their employment status and job performance. These challenges include:

  • Low self-esteem and the belief that poor health prevents them from working, often due to inadequate psychosocial support [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].
  • Prejudice from employers, who may be concerned about repeated absences and easy fatigue [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].
  • Inadequate healthcare systems that do not support out-of-hours treatment, leading to low work performance and employer reluctance [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].
  • Stigma and discrimination, particularly in regions where thalassaemia is viewed as an 'immigrant disease' [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].

Despite these challenges, many adult TDT patients are employed without difficulty. However, the employment rate among thalassaemia patients remains low, with only 32% of respondents in a recent survey being fully or part-time employed [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].

To address these issues, it is essential for healthcare professionals, patient organizations, and families to advocate for patients, educate employers, and instill a positive attitude in patients regarding their ability to work [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Hello TIF Chatbot! Do you speak multiple languages, or just English?
answer:
Hello!

Yes, the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) provides educational and informational materials translated into many languages. This includes books, factsheets, and other resources to support patients, healthcare professionals, and the community worldwide.

For more information, you can visit the TIF website or use the TIF mobile app (TIF Digital Library).

If you have any specific language needs or further questions, please contact us at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the potential side effects of iron chelation therapy?
answer:
Potential Side Effects of Iron Chelation Therapy

Iron chelation therapy is essential for managing iron overload in thalassaemia patients, but it can have several potential side effects. These vary depending on the specific chelating agent used:

Desferrioxamine (DFO)

  • Ocular effects: Visual disturbances, including night-blindness, impaired color vision, and reduced visual acuity. Severe cases may show signs of retinitis pigmentosa [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=95][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].
  • Auditory effects: High-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and deafness, particularly in young children [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=95][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].
  • Bone effects: Damage to growth plates of long bones and spine in growing children [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].
  • Local reactions: Reactions at the infusion site [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].
  • Increased risk of infection: Particularly with Yersinia enterocolitica [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].
  • Zinc deficiency: May require supplementation [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].

Deferasirox (DFX)

  • Gastrointestinal effects: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=75][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48].
  • Renal effects: Increased creatinine levels [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=75].
  • Hepatic effects: Increased hepatic enzymes [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=75].

Deferiprone (DFP)

  • Gastrointestinal effects: Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=75][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48].
  • Joint pain: Arthralgia [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48].
  • Hematological effects: Neutropenia and agranulocytosis [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=75][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Also entwickeln sich die Stammzellen im Knochenmark zu Erythrozyten?
answer:
Entwicklung von Stammzellen zu Erythrozyten

Ja, Stammzellen im Knochenmark entwickeln sich zu Erythrozyten (rote Blutkörperchen). Dieser Prozess, bekannt als Erythropoese, umfasst mehrere Schritte:

  1. Stammzellen: Die hämatopoetischen Stammzellen im Knochenmark sind die Ausgangszellen für die Bildung von Blutzellen.
  2. Proerythroblasten: Diese Stammzellen differenzieren sich zu Proerythroblasten, die die Vorläuferzellen der Erythrozyten sind.
  3. Erythroblasten: Proerythroblasten entwickeln sich weiter zu Erythroblasten, die Hämoglobin synthetisieren.
  4. Retikulozyten: Nach der Erythroblastenphase entwickeln sich die Zellen zu Retikulozyten, die ins Blut freigesetzt werden.
  5. Reife Erythrozyten: Retikulozyten reifen schließlich zu voll funktionsfähigen Erythrozyten heran, die Sauerstoff im Körper transportieren.

Stammzellen sind also die Ausgangszellen, die sich im Knochenmark zu hochspezialisierten Zellen wie Erythrozyten entwickeln, die Hämoglobin enthalten und Sauerstoff im Körper transportieren [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=3].

Weitere Informationen finden Sie in den folgenden Quellen:

  • TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=3]
  • TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=21]
  • AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=148]

Für weitere Fragen können Sie sich an info@thalassaemia.org.cy wenden.

question: What is my ideal jadenu dosage? My weight is 47kg and ferritin is 4000
answer:
Ideal Jadenu Dosage

Based on the information provided, the recommended starting dose for Jadenu (deferasirox) for thalassaemia major patients is 14 mg/kg/day. For patients with severe iron overload, doses of 21-28 mg/kg/day may be required.

Given your weight of 47 kg and a ferritin level of 4000 µg/L, you fall into the category of patients with severe iron overload. Therefore, your ideal dosage would be:

  • Minimum dose: 21 mg/kg/day
  • Maximum dose: 28 mg/kg/day

Calculating the dosage:

Dosage Calculation Result
Minimum dose 21 mg/kg/day * 47 kg 987 mg/day
Maximum dose 28 mg/kg/day * 47 kg 1316 mg/day

Therefore, your ideal Jadenu dosage would be between 987 mg/day and 1316 mg/day.

It is important to monitor your ferritin levels and serum creatinine regularly and adjust the dosage accordingly, especially if ferritin levels fall below 1000 µg/L.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sources:

  • TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0)
  • AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

The major clinical consequences of thalassaemia include severe, life-threatening anaemia and severe bone marrow hyperactivity, leading to:

  • Fatigue
  • Severe pallor
  • Growth failure
  • Bone deformities, especially of the skull
  • Heart failure and severe complications involving other vital organs if untreated [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=38]

Other common complications include:

Endocrine Problems

  • Delayed puberty
  • Growth retardation
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Hypoparathyroidism
  • Hypogonadism
  • Osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

Cardiac Abnormalities

  • Pericarditis
  • Arrhythmias
  • Biventricular failure
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Pulmonary hypertension (more common in thalassaemia intermedia) [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

Hepatic Abnormalities

  • Cirrhosis (especially if HCV and/or HBV co-exist with iron overload)
  • Liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

Other Complications

  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation guidelines.

question: How many transfusions are required per month to be classified as TDT
answer:
Transfusion Requirements for TDT

Patients with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) typically require regular blood transfusions throughout their lifetime. Specifically, TDT patients usually receive 2 or more blood bags every 2-5 weeks.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf.

Sources:

  • HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf

question: If Bed Side Filter is blocked can we ise use regular blood set for Trafusion
answer:
Blood Transfusion and Bedside Filters

If a bedside filter is blocked, it is not advisable to use a regular blood set for transfusion. Bedside filtration is only acceptable if there is no capacity for pre-storage filtration or blood bank pre-transfusion filtration. Using a regular blood set without a filter could increase the risk of transfusion-related complications, such as febrile non-haemolytic transfusion reactions and infections from cell-associated infectious agents like cytomegalovirus.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sources:

  • NursesGuide_English.pdf
  • NursesGuide_English.pdf
  • AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf
  • 2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf
  • TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf
  • EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf
  • 2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf

question: Mechanism of action of hydroxyurea in thalassemia in detail
answer:
Mechanism of Action of Hydroxyurea in Thalassemia

Hydroxyurea is a cytotoxic, anti-metabolic, and antineoplastic agent that has been identified as a potent fetal hemoglobin (HbF) inducer. Its exact mechanisms of action in inducing HbF production are not fully understood, but several pathways have been proposed:

Stress Erythropoiesis

Hydroxyurea's cytotoxic effect results in stress erythropoiesis, which leads to increased HbF levels. This is the most commonly proposed mechanism [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=33].

Nitric Oxide Production

More complex effects involving the production of nitric oxide and the activation of the soluble guanylyl cyclase and cyclic guanosine monophosphate-dependent protein kinase pathway have been proposed as responsible for HbF induction [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=33][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=26].

γ-mRNA Expression

Hydroxyurea therapy exerts a 2 to 9-fold increase in γ-mRNA expression in β-thalassemia patients. This leads to an improvement in the α/non-α chain imbalance and more effective erythropoiesis. There is a good correlation between in vitro γ-mRNA fold increase and in vivo HbF fold increase [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=33][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=26].

Globin Synthesis Augmentation

In addition to stimulating γ-globin production during stress erythropoiesis, hydroxyurea may have a more general role in augmenting globin synthesis, including β-globin in some NTDT patients who maintain the capacity to express normal β-globin chains [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=34][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=26].

Reduction of Phosphatidylserine Externalization

In splenectomized patients with NTDT, hydroxyurea diminishes phosphatidylserine externalization on the red cell. This is associated with reduced red cell survival and decreased thrombin generation, leading to a reduction in hypercoagulability and subsequent morbidity [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=34][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=26].

Reduction of Thrombin Generation and Coagulation Activation

Hydroxyurea decreases plasma markers of thrombin generation and coagulation activation in NTDT patients by reducing phospholipid expression on the surface of red blood cells. It may also decrease hemostatic activation by reducing the white blood cell count, particularly monocytes that express tissue factor [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=65].

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: is hb h and hb barts same?
answer:
Are HbH and Hb Bart's the Same?

No, HbH (Hemoglobin H) and Hb Bart's are not the same, although they are related and both are associated with alpha thalassemia. Here are the key differences:

Hb Bart's (γ4)

Hb Bart's is composed of four gamma (γ) globin chains. It is typically found in fetuses and newborns with severe alpha thalassemia, such as in cases of Hb Bart's hydrops fetalis. Hb Bart's has an exceptionally high affinity for oxygen, making it ineffective at delivering oxygen to tissues.

Source: AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf

HbH (β4)

HbH is composed of four beta (β) globin chains. It is usually found in individuals with HbH disease, which occurs when three out of four alpha-globin genes are affected. Like Hb Bart's, HbH has a high affinity for oxygen and is ineffective at oxygen transport. HbH can replace Hb Bart's in long-term survivors of Hb Bart's hydrops fetalis.

Source: AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf

Clinical Significance

Both HbH and Hb Bart's are ineffective oxygen transporters due to their high oxygen affinity. This leads to significant clinical symptoms such as severe anemia and hypoxia in affected individuals. The presence of these hemoglobins indicates a severe form of alpha thalassemia.

Source: AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf

Summary

While HbH and Hb Bart's are both associated with alpha thalassemia and share similar properties, they are distinct hemoglobins formed from different globin chains (β4 for HbH and γ4 for Hb Bart's). Their presence indicates different stages and severities of alpha thalassemia.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: is it possible the minor incompatible occur in the same blood group?
answer:
Minor Incompatibility in the Same Blood Group

Yes, minor incompatibility can occur even if the donor and recipient have the same ABO blood group. This is because red blood cells have 26 blood group systems, including over 600 different antigens. While it is not possible to match all of these antigens, efforts are made to match the most common ones, such as the ABO, Rhesus, and Kell systems [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=38].

Minor incompatibility can arise from mismatches in these other blood group systems, leading to potential adverse reactions even when the ABO and Rhesus groups are compatible [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=39].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

The symptoms of thalassaemia can vary and may include severe anaemia and other health problems, such as:

  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

If thalassaemia is left untreated or suboptimally treated, it can lead to many serious complications, including:

  • Cardiac failure
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Diabetes
  • Growth retardation
  • Darkening of the skin
  • Weakness and lack of energy
  • Spleen enlargement
  • Deformities in the face
  • Short stature [ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf#page=2][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]

For more information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: As a Thalassemia patient, is it okay for me to take magnesium supplements?
answer:
Magnesium Supplements for Thalassemia Patients

As a thalassemia patient, it is generally safe to take magnesium supplements if you are deficient. However, it is important to monitor your serum magnesium levels regularly and consult with your healthcare provider before starting any supplementation.

Studies have shown that magnesium supplementation can improve erythrocyte descriptors and circulating magnesium levels in thalassemia patients, although higher doses may cause mild diarrhea [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=123]. Additionally, low levels of magnesium are a risk factor for bone thinning, so ensuring adequate intake is important for bone health [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=22].

It is recommended to have your serum magnesium levels checked annually and to correct any deficiencies through dietary intake or supplements [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=169].

If you have further questions or need personalized advice, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: Which is the standard treatment for thalassemia major?
answer:
Standard Treatment for Thalassaemia Major

The standard treatment for thalassaemia major involves two main components:

1. Regular Blood Transfusions

Patients with thalassaemia major require lifelong regular blood transfusions to manage anaemia and maintain adequate haemoglobin levels. The typical regimen includes transfusions every two to five weeks to maintain pre-transfusion haemoglobin levels between 90-105 g/L. This helps promote normal growth, allows normal physical activities, suppresses bone marrow activity, and minimizes iron accumulation from transfusions [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=26][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39][TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

2. Iron Chelation Therapy

Due to the regular blood transfusions, iron overload becomes a significant issue. Iron chelation therapy is essential to remove excess iron from the body and prevent damage to vital organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands. The traditional iron chelating agent is Desferrioxamine, which is administered subcutaneously. Newer oral chelating agents, such as Deferiprone and Deferasirox, are also available and widely used [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=22][TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=23].

Additional Considerations

In some cases, a splenectomy may be necessary if the spleen becomes significantly enlarged or if there are other indications of an overactive spleen [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Best screening strategy
answer:
Best Screening Strategy for Thalassaemia

The best screening strategy for thalassaemia depends on several factors, including the prevalence of the disease in the population, the available resources, and the social and cultural context. Here are some key points to consider:

Types of Screening

  • Mass Screening: This approach is provided to the general population before and at childbearing age. It is more organizationally demanding and requires careful planning and adequate technical and financial resources. It is most appropriate in areas with a high frequency of thalassaemia, with particular emphasis on pregnant women when they first present for antenatal care [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=19].
  • Target Screening: This approach is restricted to specific population groups, such as couples preparing to marry, before conception, or in early pregnancy. It may also target newborns or adolescents. This method is effective in high-risk populations [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=19].

Screening in Different Prevalence Areas

  • Low Prevalence Areas: Ante-natal clinic screening is preferred as it tends to be more effective in these regions [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=22].
  • High Prevalence Areas: Pre-marital or school screening is preferable, as it allows couples to know their carrier status before any pregnancy, giving them more choices [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=22].

Screening Methods

  • Initial Screening: Combining findings from history and physical examination with analysis of red blood cells (low mean corpuscular volume, low mean corpuscular haemoglobin level, and normal red-cell distribution width), followed by haemoglobin electrophoresis or high-performance liquid chromatography to confirm [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=12].
  • Advanced Screening: DNA sequencing and allele-specific oligonucleotide probes for detecting a large variety of mutations quickly, especially for prenatal diagnosis [PreventionVol2_English.pdf#page=83].

For further assistance or more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins. There are two main types of thalassaemia based on the affected globin protein: α-thalassaemia and β-thalassaemia.

β-Thalassaemia

β-thalassaemia occurs due to mutations in the HBB gene, which affects the production of β-globin chains. The severity of β-thalassaemia can vary widely based on the specific mutations and other genetic factors:

  • More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe forms [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Severe mutations (β0) result in no β-globin production, leading to thalassaemia major, which requires regular blood transfusions for survival [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].
  • Less severe mutations (β+) allow some β-globin production, potentially resulting in thalassaemia intermedia, which may require occasional or no transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Mild mutations (β++) generally result in a very mild clinical phenotype [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

Several genetic factors can ameliorate the severity of β-thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia can reduce the imbalance between α- and β-globin chains, leading to a milder phenotype [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Mutations that increase the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) can also ameliorate the disease severity. For example, hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH) mutations can result in mild β-thalassaemia intermedia when combined with severe β-thalassaemia alleles [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Genome-wide association studies have identified loci such as BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB that are associated with increased HbF production, which can ameliorate the clinical outcome [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

α-Thalassaemia

α-thalassaemia occurs when genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated. The severity of α-thalassaemia depends on the number of affected genes:

  • Loss of one α-globin gene generally has minimal effect [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Loss of two α-globin genes can result in a milder form of thalassaemia intermedia [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].

For more detailed information or specific cases, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Thalasemua dan batu empedu
answer:
Thalassaemia and Gallstones

Patients with thalassaemia, particularly those with thalassaemia intermedia and non-deletional HbH disease, are at a higher risk of developing gallstones (cholelithiasis). This is primarily due to the increased breakdown of red blood cells (haemolysis), which releases bile pigments that can accumulate in the gallbladder and form stones.

Key Points

  • Thalassaemia intermedia patients develop gallstones more frequently than the general population. These stones can cause abdominal pain and may require the removal of the gallbladder if symptoms persist [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=108].
  • In non-deletional HbH disease, the incidence of gallstones is high due to chronic haemolysis. More than two-thirds of patients with thalassaemia may have asymptomatic gallstones [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=39].
  • Gallstones are more common in non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (NTDT) patients compared to those who are transfusion-dependent, again due to increased haemolysis [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=26].

Diagnosis and Management

Gallstones can be diagnosed using abdominal ultrasonography. Cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) is typically indicated only if there are recurrent symptoms, biliary obstruction, or cholecystitis [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=39].

Additional Information

If you need further assistance or have more specific questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the chances of having a child with thalassemia major?
answer:
Chances of Having a Child with Thalassaemia Major

If both parents are carriers of the beta thalassaemia trait, the chances for each pregnancy are as follows:

  • 25% chance that the child will be affected by thalassaemia major
  • 50% chance that the child will carry the thalassaemia trait
  • 25% chance that the child will be completely unaffected

This inheritance pattern is known as autosomal recessive Mendelian inheritance [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf][TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf].

For more information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: Explain luspratecet in thalassaemia
answer:
Luspatercept in Thalassaemia

Luspatercept-aamt is a novel pharmaceutical agent used in the treatment of thalassaemia. It is an erythroid maturation agent that acts in the late stages of red blood cell maturation. This agent helps prolong the lifespan of red blood cells produced by thalassaemia patients, allowing them to mature instead of being prematurely destroyed (haemolysis). As a result, haemoglobin levels rise, and the intervals between transfusions are increased. This leads to reduced transfusion requirements, which in turn helps decrease iron overload and the need for chelation therapy, ultimately improving the quality of life for patients [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf].

Luspatercept is particularly beneficial for patients with non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (NTDT), as it can increase haemoglobin levels by 1.0 - 1.5 g/dl and, in some cases, reduce transfusion needs by up to 100% [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf].

In clinical studies, luspatercept has shown effectiveness in reducing transfusion requirements in transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) and improving haemoglobin levels in NTDT. For example, in a phase 2 study, 77.1% of patients in the luspatercept arm achieved a significant increase in haemoglobin levels compared to none in the placebo group [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf].

However, luspatercept is not expected to benefit patients with haemoglobin Bart's hydrops foetalis, as these patients cannot produce functional haemoglobin. The most significant benefits are seen in patients with moderate to severe forms of haemoglobin H (HbH) disease, who require red blood cell transfusions and exhibit thalassaemia-related morbidities [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • Treating Thalassaemia
  • Alpha Thalassaemia Guidelines
  • TIF Guidelines for NTDT

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy for assistance.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

In more severe cases, complications can include:

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures
  • Thrombophilia
  • Pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Heart disease, including heart failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58]
  • Liver complications such as fibrosis and cirrhosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58]
  • Endocrine problems like delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, and hypogonadism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: What are the main complications associated with delta beta thalassemia?
answer:
Complications Associated with Delta Beta Thalassemia

Delta beta thalassemia can lead to several complications, including:

  • Thrombotic Events: Thrombotic disease, mostly venous, is a significant complication, affecting 14% of NTDT patients. Risk factors include splenectomy, age over 35 years, iron overload, and low hemoglobin levels [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=67].
  • Iron Overload: Increased iron absorption can lead to hepatic fibrosis and other liver complications such as siderosis, viral hepatitis, fibrosis, cirrhosis, and liver failure [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=21][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15].
  • Bone Disease: Patients may experience decreased bone mineral density, spontaneous fractures, and spinal deformities, often causing severe pain and discomfort [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=182].
  • Endocrine Problems: These include delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Cardiac Abnormalities: Complications such as pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, congestive heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension are common [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Hepatosplenomegaly and Gallstones: Enlargement of the liver and spleen, as well as the formation of gallstones, are also noted complications [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=21].

For more detailed information, you can contact the Thalassaemia International Federation at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the side effects of iron chelation therapy?
answer:
Side Effects of Iron Chelation Therapy

Iron chelation therapy, while essential for managing iron overload in thalassaemia patients, can have several side effects. These side effects vary depending on the specific chelating agent used. Here are some of the common side effects associated with different iron chelators:

Desferrioxamine (DFO)

  • Hearing problems: High frequency sensorineural loss, tinnitus, and deafness, particularly in young children with low iron burden [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=95].
  • Visual disturbances: Retinal effects, cataracts, night-blindness, impaired color vision, and reduced visual acuity [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=95].
  • Local reactions at the infusion site [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].
  • Bone effects: Damage to growth plates of long bones and spine in growing children [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].
  • Optic nerve damage and high tone hearing loss [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].
  • Increased risk of infection with Yersinia enterocolitica [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].
  • Zinc deficiency, which may need supplementation [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].

Deferasirox

  • Gastrointestinal symptoms [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48].
  • Joint pain or arthralgia [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48].
  • Neutropenia and agranulocytosis [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48].

General Considerations

  • Over-chelation increases the possibility of side effects, so doses should be decreased as serum ferritin or liver iron levels fall [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=47].
  • Cardiac iron accumulates later than liver iron and is rare before the age of 8 years [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=90].
  • Iron chelation can reverse iron-mediated cardiac dysfunction rapidly if 24-hour chelation cover is achieved [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=47].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Quali sono i principali contributi della Dott.ssa Eleftheriou nel campo della talassemia?
answer:
Principali Contributi della Dott.ssa Androulla Eleftheriou nel Campo della Talassemia

  • Ha organizzato e partecipato attivamente a numerosi workshop, conferenze e progetti nazionali e internazionali [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=3].
  • Ha collaborato con la Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) dal 1993, contribuendo a rendere le informazioni mediche sulla talassemia facilmente accessibili e fornendo opportunità di formazione continua per il personale medico [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=3].
  • È stata nominata Coordinatrice Scientifica della TIF nel 1997, ruolo che ha ricoperto con dedizione [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=3].
  • Ha svolto numerosi progetti di portata locale, nazionale, regionale e internazionale, lavorando a stretto contatto con esperti internazionali, medici locali e associazioni di talassemia in tutto il mondo [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=7][PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=10].
  • È autrice di diverse pubblicazioni per conto della TIF e in collaborazione con l'OMS e altri organismi internazionali su una vasta gamma di argomenti scientifici [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=7][PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=10].
  • È Caporedattrice della rivista trimestrale della TIF, distribuita a migliaia di abbonati in oltre 60 paesi [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=7][PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=10].

Per ulteriori informazioni, puoi contattare info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

  • AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf

question: i need drugs
answer:
Drug Information

For thalassaemia patients, there are specific drugs and treatments that are commonly used:

  • Iron Chelation Therapy: This therapy aims to balance the rate of iron accumulation in a patient's body from blood transfusions. The approved iron chelators are:
    • Deferoxamine (Desferal®)
    • Deferasirox
    • Deferiprone (Ferriprox™)
    Learn more about drug safety [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=17].
  • Pain Management: For managing pain, the following drugs are used:
    • Acetaminophen (Tylenol®/Panadol®/Tempra®)
    • NSAIDs such as Advil®, Motrin®, Profinal®
    • Codeine and codeine derivatives
    • Morphine and its derivatives

    Note: Acetaminophen should not be given if the patient has liver disease, and NSAIDs should be avoided if the patient has stomach, kidney disease, or a bleeding disorder [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=22].

If you need more specific information or assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: what is the latest development in the treatment of thalassaemia?
answer:
Latest Developments in Thalassaemia Treatment

Recent advancements in the treatment of thalassaemia include:

  • Gene Therapy: ZYNTEGLO™ by Bluebird Bio Inc is a new therapeutic option for patients with ß-thalassaemia major. It involves the transfer of a functional ß-globin gene into the patient's cells using a lentiviral vector, which addresses the underlying genetic cause of the disease. Clinical trials have shown that the majority of patients with the less severe form of the disease have become transfusion independent shortly after gene therapy [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=5].
  • Luspatercept: This erythroid maturation agent prolongs the lifespan of red blood cells, allowing them to mature and increasing haemoglobin levels. It has been approved in the USA and Europe for the treatment of anaemia in transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) and non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (NTDT) [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].
  • Mitapivat: An oral, small-molecule activator of pyruvate kinase, mitapivat has shown efficacy in reducing markers of ineffective erythropoiesis and improving anaemia in thalassaemia mouse models. It has received approval for the treatment of anaemia in adult patients with pyruvate kinase deficiency [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What is thalassemia?
answer:
What is Thalassaemia?

Thalassaemia is an inherited blood disorder caused by genetic defects that affect the production of haemoglobin, a protein in red blood cells responsible for carrying oxygen from the lungs throughout the body. This results in a shortage of functional red blood cells and low levels of oxygen in the bloodstream, leading to various health problems depending on the type and severity of the condition.

There are two main types of thalassaemia:

  • Alpha (α) Thalassaemia: Occurs when genes related to the production of alpha-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • Beta (β) Thalassaemia: Occurs when similar gene defects affect the production of beta-globin protein.

Thalassaemia can range from mild, clinically insignificant forms to severe forms that require regular medical treatment. Severe forms, such as beta-thalassaemia major, result in transfusion-dependent anaemia and require regular blood transfusions and chelation therapy to manage iron overload.

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Source: EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf, TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf, FocusOnAThal_EN.pdf, TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf, NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf, ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf, HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf, Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf

question: Hemophilia A
answer:
Hemophilia A

Hemophilia A is a genetic disorder that affects the blood's ability to clot. It is caused by a deficiency in clotting factor VIII. This condition can lead to prolonged bleeding following an injury, surgery, or even spontaneously.

For more detailed information and support, patient-driven NGOs play a crucial role. They provide individual time and counsel, which is often lacking in hospitals, and are a valuable source of information on specific diseases like hemophilia [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=14].

For guidelines and standards related to hemophilia care, you can refer to the European guidelines for the certification of Haemophilia Centres [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=385].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: Is there any evidence that Jadenu is better than exjade
answer:
Comparison of Jadenu and Exjade

There is evidence suggesting that Jadenu (the film-coated tablet formulation of deferasirox) may offer improvements over Exjade (the original dispersible tablet formulation of deferasirox) in terms of patient adherence and acceptability. Recent studies have shown that the new formulation (Jadenu) improves adherence and patient-reported acceptability [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=84].

Additionally, due to increased absorption of Jadenu, it can be taken at a lower dose (0.7 times the dose of Exjade) while maintaining effectiveness and safety. This means that the starting dose for Jadenu is 14 mg/kg/day for thalassaemia major patients who have received 10-20 transfusion episodes, compared to higher doses required for Exjade [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=84].

For further detailed information, you can refer to the EMA & Novartis Summary of Product Characteristics for Exjade [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=104].

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Complications

When Do Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Symptoms

  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

Common Complications

If thalassaemia is not treated properly, it can lead to several serious health complications, including:

  • Cardiac failure
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Diabetes
  • Growth retardation
  • Darkening of the skin
  • Heart problems
  • Spleen enlargement
  • Deformities in the child's face
  • Short stature [ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf#page=2][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]

For more information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Contact Information

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

In more severe cases, complications can include:

  • Iron overload, leading to damage to major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Heart failure, liver cirrhosis, and diabetes [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1]

  • Hepatic abnormalities such as cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

question: does alpha Thalassemia people have low hb a2?
answer:
Hb A2 Levels in Alpha Thalassemia

Individuals with alpha thalassaemia typically have Hb A2 levels in the low to low-normal range. Specifically:

  • For the α0-thalassaemia trait (α-thalassaemia-1), Hb A2 levels are usually in the range of 1.5-2.5% [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=52][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=45].
  • Carriers of α0-thalassaemia usually have a normal or slightly reduced Hb A2 level [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=46].

Therefore, alpha thalassaemia is associated with low to low-normal Hb A2 levels, and this can be an indicator when diagnosing the condition.

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: what is the epidemiology of thalassemia ?
answer:
Epidemiology of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia is a significant global health issue with varying prevalence across different regions. Here are some key points regarding its epidemiology:

  • Approximately 68,000 children are born with various thalassaemia syndromes each year [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=9].
  • Beta-thalassaemia is highly prevalent, with 80 to 90 million carriers worldwide, which is about 1.5% of the global population. Around half of these carriers are from South East Asia [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=9].
  • About 23,000 children are born with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) annually, while a smaller, less defined number have beta-thalassaemia intermedia [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=9].
  • Thalassaemia and sickle cell disease (SCD) are collectively known as haemoglobinopathies. Approximately 7% of the global population carries an affected haemoglobin gene, with 300,000 to 500,000 affected children born annually. More than 80% of these children are born in developing countries [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=55].
  • Thalassaemia is particularly common in the Mediterranean area, the Middle East, Southeast Asia, and the Pacific, with carrier rates ranging from 2-19% in different populations [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=64].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the sources provided or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How much dengerous Delta beta thalassemia ?
answer:
Delta Beta Thalassemia: How Dangerous Is It?

Delta beta thalassemia is a form of thalassemia characterized by deletions in the delta and beta globin genes. The severity of symptoms can vary depending on the specific genetic mutations involved.

Severity and Symptoms

The severity of delta beta thalassemia can range from mild to severe. In general, patients with this condition may experience symptoms similar to those seen in other forms of thalassemia, such as anemia, growth retardation, and skeletal deformities due to ineffective erythropoiesis and chronic anemia [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=87].

Complications

Patients with delta beta thalassemia may also be at risk for complications such as iron overload, which can lead to endocrine issues like diabetes, hypothyroidism, and hypogonadism, especially as they age [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=87].

Management

Management of delta beta thalassemia typically involves regular monitoring and treatment to manage anemia and prevent complications. This may include blood transfusions and iron chelation therapy to prevent iron overload [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=25].

For more detailed information or specific concerns, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

answer:
