Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Thrombophilia and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Iron overload, leading to liver fibrosis, cirrhosis, and heart disease [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58]
  • Delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice) [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Dark urine [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Endocrine problems such as delayed puberty, diabetes, and hypothyroidism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities like arrhythmias and heart failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities including cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: Apakah ada risiko tertentu yang harus diperhatikan saat berolahraga bagi penderita thalassemia?
answer:
Risiko Olahraga bagi Penderita Thalassemia

Olahraga memiliki banyak manfaat bagi penderita thalassemia, namun ada beberapa risiko yang perlu diperhatikan. Berikut adalah beberapa risiko yang harus diperhatikan saat berolahraga bagi penderita thalassemia:

  • Iron Overload: Kelebihan zat besi yang terakumulasi di jantung dapat mengurangi kapasitas latihan dengan mengurangi volume stroke dan kontraktilitas jantung, serta mencegah peningkatan detak jantung yang diinduksi oleh latihan [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=157].
  • Komplikasi Kardiovaskular: Penderita thalassemia dengan kardiomiopati terkait kelebihan zat besi, hepatitis, diabetes, osteoporosis, dan hipotiroidisme mungkin mengalami hambatan dalam partisipasi aktivitas fisik sedang hingga berat [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=160].
  • Anemia dan Kelelahan: Anemia kronis dan kelelahan yang sering terjadi pada penderita thalassemia dapat menghambat kemampuan mereka untuk berolahraga [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=157].
  • Nyeri Kronis: Nyeri kronis yang dilaporkan oleh lebih dari setengah pasien dewasa dapat mempengaruhi fungsi fisik dan mendorong perilaku sedentari seperti duduk lama dan menonton televisi [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=157].
  • Risiko Fraktur: Penyakit tulang yang umum pada penderita thalassemia meningkatkan risiko fraktur, sehingga perlu hati-hati dalam memberikan saran mengenai olahraga dan aktivitas fisik [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=232].
  • Evaluasi Kardiovaskular: Evaluasi kardiovaskular yang hati-hati diperlukan jika aktivitas atletik dipertimbangkan, terutama mengingat komorbiditas seperti penyakit tulang [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=232].

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut, Anda dapat menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sumber: Nutrition Guide Thal PKD, Nutrition Guide Thal PKD, Guidelines for the Management of Transfusion Dependent Thalassaemia

question: Bagaimana cara mengelola thalassaemia alpha setelah diagnosis?
answer:
Management of Alpha Thalassaemia After Diagnosis

Managing alpha thalassaemia involves a comprehensive approach that includes regular monitoring, treatment, and supportive care. Here are the key aspects:

Regular Monitoring and Assessments

  • Infants with alpha thalassaemia major should be closely monitored by developmental specialists and undergo neurologic assessments. These assessments should be repeated during school-age or if there are concerns regarding academic achievements [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=65].
  • Patients should have regular (every two to four weeks) blood transfusions to maintain pre-transfusion haemoglobin levels at 9.5 to 10 g/dL [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Monitoring for systemic complications affecting vital organs, including the heart, liver, and endocrine organs, is essential as patients age [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13].

Treatment Options

  • Blood Transfusions: Regular transfusions of packed red blood cells are necessary to manage anaemia [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Iron Chelation Therapy: This is used to prevent or reduce excess iron deposits in the body, which result from the breakdown of transfused red blood cells [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant: This should be considered early as a potential curative option for patients with alpha thalassaemia major [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=65].
  • Splenectomy: This procedure may be considered in cases of an oversized spleen causing discomfort or other signs of an overactive spleen [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

Supportive Care

  • Multidisciplinary care involving various specialists such as cardiologists, hepatologists, endocrinologists, and psychologists is crucial for comprehensive management [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1].
  • Psychosocial support and holistic care are important for addressing the emotional and psychological needs of patients and their families [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins, which are essential components of hemoglobin. The severity of thalassaemia can vary widely depending on the specific genetic mutations involved and their interactions.

Types of Thalassaemia

  • α-thalassaemia: Occurs when genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • β-thalassaemia: Occurs when similar genetic defects affect the production of the β-globin protein.

Severity of β-thalassaemia

β-thalassaemia can be classified into two main forms based on severity:

  • Thalassaemia Major: Severe, life-threatening anaemia requiring regular blood transfusions. This form occurs when an individual inherits the gene from both parents [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].
  • Thalassaemia Intermedia: Milder form that may require occasional or no transfusions. This form can result from various genetic interactions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].

Genetic Factors Influencing Severity

The severity of thalassaemia is influenced by several genetic factors:

  • Specific Mutations: More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from mild to very severe. For example, the mild β+-type mutation -88 (C->T) generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: The co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia can ameliorate the severity of β-thalassaemia. For instance, patients homozygous for a severe β-thalassaemia allele with two α-globin genes missing are more likely to have thalassaemia intermedia [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Increased HbF Production: Genetic factors that increase the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) can also reduce the severity of the disease. For example, the Xmn1 polymorphism in the Gy-globin gene is linked to elevated HbF levels [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=61].

Examples of Mutations

β++ mutations β+ mutations β0 mutations
-101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
C39

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: آیا درمان‌های جدیدی برای تالاسمی وجود دارد؟
answer:
درمان‌های جدید برای تالاسمی

در سال‌های اخیر، چندین درمان جدید برای تالاسمی معرفی شده‌اند که امید به بهبود کیفیت زندگی بیماران را افزایش داده‌اند:

عامل بلوغ اریتروئید: Luspatercept-aamt

Luspatercept-aamt یک عامل بلوغ اریتروئید است که در مراحل پایانی بلوغ سلول‌های قرمز خون عمل می‌کند. این دارو باعث افزایش طول عمر سلول‌های قرمز خون تولید شده توسط بیماران تالاسمی می‌شود و به آن‌ها اجازه می‌دهد تا به جای تخریب زودرس، بالغ شوند. این امر باعث افزایش سطح هموگلوبین و کاهش نیاز به انتقال خون می‌شود [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

درمان ژنی: Zynteglo®

درمان ژنی با استفاده از محصول Zynteglo® که توسط کمیسیون اروپا در ژوئن 2019 تأیید شده است، به عنوان یک گزینه درمانی برای بیماران تالاسمی وابسته به انتقال خون معرفی شده است. این درمان شامل اضافه کردن یک نسخه سالم از ژن بتا-گلوبین به سلول‌های بنیادی خون‌ساز بیمار است [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=128][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=286].

ویرایش ژن

ویرایش ژن به عنوان یک روش درمانی نویدبخش برای تالاسمی مطرح شده است. این روش شامل اصلاح دقیق ژن معیوب در محل خود یا ایجاد اثرات تعدیل‌کننده بیماری با استفاده از نوکلئازهای خاص است. با این حال، تجربه بالینی با ویرایش ژن محدود است و نیاز به داده‌های بالینی بیشتر و آزمایش‌های بزرگ‌مقیاس برای اثبات ایمنی و اثربخشی این روش وجود دارد [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=127][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=279].

برای اطلاعات بیشتر می‌توانید به سایت فدراسیون بین‌المللی تالاسمی مراجعه کنید.

منابع: TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf, TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf, TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf, TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf, TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf

سوالات متداول

question: how fresh should prbcs be?
answer:
Freshness of Packed Red Blood Cells (pRBCs)

For patients who need regular transfusions, it is recommended that the blood should be as fresh as possible. Specifically, pRBC units should preferably be stored for no more than 10 days to avoid potential complications.

Evidence suggests that pRBC units stored for more than 10 days may develop low molecular mass iron complexes, and those stored for more than 14 days show marked increases in non-transferrin bound iron and a decrease in antioxidant capacity. These changes can potentially increase the risk of infections and other complications.

Therefore, transfusions with pRBC units that have been stored for less than 14 days may provide benefits by avoiding the deleterious effects associated with longer storage periods.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • TDT-GUIDE-2022
  • NursesGuide_English
  • TDT 4TH EDITION

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely depending on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

There are more than 200 known ß-thalassaemia mutations, which can result in a range of phenotypic severities from very mild to very severe:

  • Severe (ß0) mutations: Examples include IVS1-1, IVS2-1, and C39 [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].
  • Less severe (ß+) mutations: Examples include IVS1-110 and IVS2-745 [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].
  • Mild (ß++) mutations: Examples include -101, -87, and -88 [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].

Impact of Genetic Modifiers

The severity of thalassaemia can be influenced by several genetic modifiers:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the imbalance between α- and ß-globin chains, leading to a milder form of the disease [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].
  • Increased production of γ-globin chains: This results in higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can ameliorate the severity of the disease [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32][NursesGuide_English.pdf].
  • Hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH): Certain HPFH mutations can lead to high HbF levels and result in a milder phenotype when combined with severe ß-thalassaemia alleles [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Genome-wide association studies (GWAS): Identified loci such as BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB that are associated with increased HbF production and milder disease severity [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

Clinical Implications

The clinical severity of thalassaemia can range from thalassaemia major, which requires regular blood transfusions, to thalassaemia intermedia, which may require occasional or no transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf]. Genetic counseling and prenatal diagnosis are important for managing the condition, especially in populations with high carrier rates [PreventionVol1_English.pdf].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Studi besi itu apa ?
answer:
Apa Itu Studi Besi?

Studi besi adalah serangkaian tes yang dilakukan untuk mengukur kadar besi dalam tubuh. Tes ini penting untuk mendiagnosis dan mengelola kondisi seperti thalassaemia, di mana kadar besi yang abnormal dapat menyebabkan komplikasi serius. Berikut adalah beberapa komponen utama dari studi besi:

  • Serum Ferritin: Mengukur jumlah ferritin dalam darah, yang mencerminkan jumlah total besi yang tersimpan dalam tubuh. Kadar ferritin yang tinggi dapat mengindikasikan kelebihan besi [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=35].
  • Serum Iron: Mengukur jumlah besi yang beredar dalam darah.
  • Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC): Mengukur kemampuan darah untuk mengikat dan mengangkut besi. Nilai TIBC yang tinggi dapat mengindikasikan defisiensi besi.
  • Transferrin Saturation: Mengukur persentase transferrin (protein pengangkut besi) yang terikat dengan besi. Nilai yang tinggi dapat mengindikasikan kelebihan besi.

Studi besi ini membantu dokter untuk menentukan apakah seseorang memiliki defisiensi besi, kelebihan besi, atau kondisi lain yang mempengaruhi metabolisme besi. Ini sangat penting dalam pengelolaan thalassaemia karena pasien dengan thalassaemia sering mengalami masalah dengan kadar besi akibat transfusi darah yang berulang [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=35].

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut atau bantuan, Anda dapat menghubungi kami di info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What should I do if my certificate is not accepted?
answer:
What to Do If Your Thalassaemia Status Certificate Is Not Accepted

If your certificate stating that you are not affected by thalassaemia is not accepted, you can take the following steps:

Steps to Take

  1. Verify the Requirements: Ensure that your certificate includes all the necessary information as required by the authority or institution that rejected it. This includes personal details, medical evaluation details, and the medical professional's information.
  2. Contact the Issuing Authority: Reach out to the healthcare provider or medical institution that issued the certificate. Explain the situation and request any additional documentation or clarification that might be needed.
  3. Translate Your Documents: If you are in a different country, ensure that your medical records and certificate are translated into the language of the Country of Care. This can help in avoiding misunderstandings or misinterpretations.
  4. Consult the National Contact Point: Contact the National Contact Point of your home country for guidance on cross-border healthcare issues. They can provide information on the specific regulations and services that apply to your situation.
  5. Obtain a Provisional Replacement Certificate (PRC): If you are in an EU/EEA country and your European Health Insurance Card (EHIC) is not available, contact your National Contact Point to issue a PRC.
  6. Seek Legal Recourse: If you believe your rights have been violated, you can seek recourse through the national courts of the EU member state in which you received treatment.

For further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

[Source: CrossBorderHealthcare-Factsheet.pdf]

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

There are more than 200 known ß-thalassaemia mutations, which can result in a range of phenotypic severities from very mild to very severe:

  • Severe (ß0) mutations: Examples include IVS1-1, IVS11-1, and C39.
  • Less severe (ß+) mutations: Examples include IVS1-110, IVS11-745, and IVS1-5.
  • Mild (ß++) mutations: Examples include -101, -87, -88, and -28.

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Impact of Genetic Modifiers

The severity of thalassaemia can be influenced by several genetic modifiers:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the imbalance between α- and ß-globin chains, leading to a milder form of the disease.
  • Increased production of γ-globin chains: This results in higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can ameliorate the severity of the disease.
  • Hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH): Mutations associated with HPFH can result in mild ß-thalassaemia intermedia when combined with severe ß-thalassaemia alleles.

[2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72]

Examples of Specific Mutations and Their Effects

Some specific mutations and their effects include:

  • ß+-type mutation -88 (C->T): Generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype.
  • ß+-thalassaemia mutation Cap+1 (A->C): Can result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients.

[Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72]

Conclusion

The genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity are complex and influenced by a variety of factors. Accurate genetic diagnosis and counseling are essential for managing the condition effectively.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Is depression common for thalassemia patients?
answer:
Depression in Thalassaemia Patients

Yes, depression is common among thalassaemia patients. Studies have shown that a considerable proportion of adult patients with both ß-thalassaemia major and intermedia exhibit evidence of depression, as measured by the Beck Depression Inventory [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf].

Patients with ß-thalassaemia intermedia are particularly prone to state anxiety, which is attributed to a shorter duration of living with a known thalassaemia diagnosis, leading to poorer adaptation to the disease [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf]. Additionally, the high prevalence of silent cerebral infarcts in these patients may also contribute to mental health issues [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf].

Overall, thalassaemia patients and their caregivers face many psychological and social challenges that impact emotional functioning, increasing vulnerability to psychiatric illnesses such as depression and anxiety [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How can we treat thalassemia ?
answer:
Treatment of Thalassaemia

The treatment of thalassaemia involves several key components:

Blood Transfusions

Regular blood transfusions are essential to manage anaemia in patients with thalassaemia major. These transfusions help maintain pre-transfusion haemoglobin levels at 9.5 to 10 g/dL and are typically required every 2-5 weeks. Transfusions help prevent complications such as poor growth, bone deformities, and organ enlargement [NursesGuide_English.pdf][TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].

Iron Chelation Therapy

Iron chelation therapy is necessary to remove excess iron from the body, which accumulates due to regular blood transfusions. This therapy helps prevent damage to vital organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands. There are three types of iron chelators: two are taken orally, and one is administered via injection [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf][TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf].

Splenectomy

In some cases, a splenectomy (removal of the spleen) may be necessary, particularly if the spleen becomes enlarged or overactive. However, this procedure has become less common with improved treatment options [NursesGuide_English.pdf].

Bone Marrow Transplantation

Allogeneic bone marrow transplantation is a potential curative treatment for thalassaemia, but it is limited to young patients with a well-matched donor. This procedure carries risks such as graft-vs-host disease and requires long-term immunosuppression [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf].

Gene Therapy

Gene therapy is an emerging treatment that aims to correct the genetic defects causing thalassaemia. This approach is still under development but holds promise for providing a cure [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf].

Multidisciplinary Care

Patients with thalassaemia should be managed in specialized centers by a team of medical specialists to ensure comprehensive care. This includes monitoring and treating complications that may arise as patients age [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf].

For more detailed guidelines, please visit the Thalassaemia International Federation.

Follow-up Questions

question: How can older thalassaemia patients improve their sleep quality?
answer:
Improving Sleep Quality for Older Thalassaemia Patients

Older thalassaemia patients can take several steps to improve their sleep quality:

  • Regular Physical Activity: Engaging in regular physical activity can improve sleep quality and reduce feelings of fatigue. Activities such as walking, swimming, or yoga can be beneficial [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=159].
  • Consistent Sleep Schedule: Maintaining a consistent sleep schedule by going to bed and waking up at the same time every day helps regulate the body's internal clock [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=261].
  • Comfortable Sleep Environment: Ensure the sleep environment is comfortable, quiet, and dark. Using earplugs or a sleep mask can help minimize disturbances [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=115].
  • Limit Stimulants: Avoid caffeine and heavy meals close to bedtime, as they can interfere with sleep [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=67].
  • Relaxation Techniques: Practice relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, or reading a book before bed to help unwind and prepare for sleep [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=112].
  • Medical Consultation: Consult with healthcare providers to address any underlying medical conditions or medications that may be affecting sleep quality [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=260].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the signs of protein deficiency?
answer:
Signs of Protein Deficiency

Protein deficiency, also known as protein calorie malnutrition (PCM), can manifest through various signs and symptoms. Though uncommon, the following are typical indicators of PCM:

  • Fatigue
  • Growth disturbances
  • Decreased muscle mass
  • Immune dysfunction
  • Thinning hair
  • Brittle nails
  • Dry skin

These signs are often associated with energy imbalance and can occur alongside other nutritional deficiencies. It is important to maintain a balanced diet to ensure adequate protein intake, especially for individuals with thalassemia.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: problems having sex
answer:
Sexual Problems in Thalassaemia Patients

Thalassaemia patients, particularly those with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT), may experience various sexual problems due to complications such as hypogonadism and iron overload. Here are some key points:

  • As many as 51% to 80% of TDT patients may experience pubertal failure, sexual dysfunction, and/or infertility due to hypogonadism [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=234].
  • Hypogonadism can lead to delayed puberty, underdeveloped genitalia, and reduced sexual function [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=84].
  • Iron overload, a common issue in thalassaemia patients, can affect the endocrine system, leading to hormonal imbalances that impact sexual health [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=234].
  • Male patients with thalassaemia who suffer from azoospermia (absence of sperm) often respond to a combination of therapeutic hormones administered over the course of one year [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=88].
  • Female patients with thalassaemia who have a normal menstrual cycle may conceive spontaneously, but those with primary or secondary amenorrhoea will need hormonal treatment to stimulate ovulation [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=88].

It is important for thalassaemia patients to receive regular evaluations by an endocrinologist to manage hypogonadism and other endocrine complications. Additionally, a multidisciplinary team approach involving haematologists, reproductive medicine specialists, and other healthcare providers can help address sexual health and fertility issues [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=215].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Employment and Workplace Challenges for Adults with Thalassaemia

Adults with thalassaemia face several employment and workplace challenges due to various factors originating from both the patients and their employers, as well as the broader social environment and healthcare system.

Challenges Faced by Patients

  • Many patients experience low self-esteem and feel that their health condition prevents them from working effectively [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].
  • Repeated absences from work and easy fatigue are common issues, which can lead to low work performance [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].

Challenges from Employers and Social Environment

  • Prejudice from employers is still prevalent in many parts of the world, contributing to difficulties in securing and maintaining employment [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].
  • There is a need for out-of-hours clinic and transfusion sessions to accommodate working patients, which is often unmet even in well-resourced settings [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].

Legal and Advocacy Support

If thalassaemia is considered a disability, the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities mandates equal employment opportunities and prohibits discrimination based on disability. This includes equal remuneration for work of equal value and safe and healthy working conditions [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].

Role of Healthcare Professionals and Family

  • Healthcare professionals and patient organizations have a duty to prepare patients for employment and advocate on their behalf [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=329].
  • Family members, including parents and siblings, play a significant role in influencing the patient's education and employment prospects [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=330].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins, which are essential components of hemoglobin. The severity of thalassaemia varies widely depending on the specific genetic mutations and their interactions.

Types of Thalassaemia

  • α-thalassaemia: Occurs when genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • β-thalassaemia: Occurs when similar genetic defects affect the production of the β-globin protein.

β-thalassaemia is further classified into two main forms:

  • Thalassaemia Major: Inheriting the gene from both parents causes severe, life-threatening anaemia.
  • Thalassaemia Minor: Inheriting the gene from one parent causes a milder form, often symptom-free.

[HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf]

Genetic Mutations and Their Impact

More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe. The severity of the condition is influenced by several factors:

  • Homozygous β-thalassaemia: Patients with severe β-thalassaemia alleles often develop thalassaemia major, requiring regular blood transfusions. However, the co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or gene modifiers that increase HbF production can ameliorate the condition to thalassaemia intermedia, which may require occasional or no transfusions [PreventionVol1_English.pdf][NursesGuide_English.pdf].
  • Compound Heterozygous Genotypes: The combination of a severe β-thalassaemia mutation with α-thalassaemia trait, Hb Lepore trait, or other genetic factors can result in thalassaemia intermedia [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf].
  • Specific Mutations: Some mutations, such as the mild β+-type mutation -88 (C->T), generally result in a very mild clinical phenotype. In contrast, the mild β+-thalassaemia mutation Cap+1 (A->C) has been reported to result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf].

Ameliorating Factors

Several genetic factors can reduce the severity of thalassaemia:

  • Decreased synthesis of α-chains: Reduces the imbalance between α- and β-chains, leading to a milder form of the disease [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].
  • Increased synthesis of γ-chains: Leads to increased production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can partially correct the imbalance [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].
  • Co-inheritance of raised HbF determinants: Such as the Xmn1 polymorphism, which can elevate HbF levels and ameliorate the condition [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What tests are recommended for evaluating male fertility in thalassaemia patients?
answer:
Recommended Tests for Evaluating Male Fertility in Thalassaemia Patients

Evaluating male fertility in thalassaemia patients involves a comprehensive approach to identify potential issues related to chronic anaemia, iron overload, and endocrine dysfunction. Here are the recommended tests and evaluations based on the provided sources:

Baseline Evaluations

  • Testosterone Levels: Baseline testosterone levels should be measured to assess hormonal status [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=217][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=110].
  • Semen Analysis: A baseline semen analysis is crucial to evaluate sperm count, motility, and morphology [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=217][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=110].

Hormonal Therapy Monitoring

  • hCG Therapy: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) therapy is administered at 2000 units twice-weekly for 6 months. Testosterone levels should be monitored during this period [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=217][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=110].
  • FSH and HMG Therapy: If no sperm is detected after 6 months of hCG therapy, Human Menopausal Gonadotrophin (HMG) or recombinant Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) is added at 75 units three times weekly for an additional 6 months [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=217][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=110].

Additional Evaluations

  • Ultrasonography: Comprehensive evaluations for genitourinary anomalies, including ultrasonography of the genitourinary system, are recommended [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=65].
  • Bone Survey and Echocardiography: These tests are recommended to assess bone health and cardiac function, which can be affected by iron overload and chronic anaemia [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=65].
  • Endocrine Assessment: Referral to an endocrinologist for a thorough assessment of puberty and fertility is recommended [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=65].

Genetic Testing

  • Molecular Genetic Testing: Molecular genetic testing can help in diagnosing thalassaemia and identifying genetic defects. This is crucial for couples at risk of having children with severe forms of the condition [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=21].

For more detailed and personalized advice, it is recommended to consult with a healthcare professional or endocrinologist who can provide guidance based on the latest research and individual health needs.

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What can I do?
answer:
What Can I Do?

There are several actions you can take depending on your context and needs:

For Promoting Your Organisation

  • Write letters, talk to people you know, and make presentations at offices, clubs, hospitals, clinics, other organisations, and schools to promote your organisation [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=36].
  • Differentiate your organisation by highlighting what makes it special or unique, and the benefits it offers to members and supporters [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=36].
  • Use television and other media effectively by planning regular communication and building good relationships with journalists [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=35].
  • Utilize word-of-mouth by engaging current supporters and building relationships with potential new supporters [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=37].

For Managing Thalassaemia

  • Engage in regular physical activity, especially weight-bearing exercises, and consume adequate calcium and vitamin D [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Establish a support system in your new location if relocating, and adapt your lifestyle to support your health [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=8].
  • Follow guidelines for self-isolation and social distancing to reduce the risk of infection [A-TIF-proposed-Haemoglobinopathy-Patient-Pathway.pdf#page=12][A-TIF-proposed-Haemoglobinopathy-Patient-Pathway.pdf#page=11].

For Children with Thalassaemia

  • Understand that regular blood transfusions are necessary to manage the condition and can be done at the hospital [All-About-Thalassaemia-Cartoon-Booklet-English.pdf#page=15].
  • Encourage children to engage in activities they enjoy during hospital visits to make the experience more pleasant [All-About-Thalassaemia-Cartoon-Booklet-English.pdf#page=16].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of globin proteins, which are crucial components of hemoglobin. The severity of thalassaemia can vary widely depending on the specific genetic mutations involved and their interactions.

Types of Thalassaemia

  • α-thalassaemia: Occurs when one or more genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • β-thalassaemia: Occurs due to genetic defects affecting the production of the β-globin protein. This type is further classified into thalassaemia major and thalassaemia minor.

[HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf]

Genetic Mutations and Their Impact

More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe. These mutations can interact in various ways to produce a spectrum of β-thalassaemia disorders, from mild thalassaemia intermedia to severe thalassaemia major.

[PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=64]

Examples of Mutations

β++ Mutations β+ Mutations β0 Mutations
-101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
C39

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Impact of Specific Mutations

  • The mild β+-type mutation -88 (C->T) generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype in patients homozygous for this mutation.
  • The mild β+-thalassaemia mutation Cap+1 (A->C) has been reported to result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients.
  • Patients homozygous for a severe β-thalassaemia allele with two α-globin genes missing are more likely to have thalassaemia intermedia.

[PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72]

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

Several genetic factors can ameliorate the severity of thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the imbalance between α- and β-chains, leading to a milder form of the disease.
  • Increased synthesis of fetal hemoglobin (HbF): Some mutations can increase the production of HbF, which can partially correct the imbalance and reduce the severity of the disease.

[NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Conclusion

The genetic causes of thalassaemia are complex and involve a wide range of mutations and interactions. The severity of the condition can be influenced by the specific mutations present and other genetic factors that may ameliorate the disease. Genetic counselling is essential to understand these complexities and provide appropriate guidance to affected individuals and their families.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: i am a thalassemia patient in bangladesh , i am suffering this problem since my age was 5 month, now i am 31 years old. Now i wanna know i am thinking about marriage, is there any obligation in my marrriage, what should i do in this case
answer:
Marriage Considerations for Thalassaemia Patients

As a thalassaemia patient, you can certainly get married and have children. However, there are important considerations regarding the thalassaemia status of your partner:

  • If your partner is also a thalassaemia patient, all children will be affected by thalassaemia.
  • If your partner is a carrier of ß-thalassaemia, there is a 50% chance that each child will be affected and a 50% chance that each child will be a carrier.
  • If your partner is not a carrier, all children will be carriers but will not be affected by thalassaemia.

It is recommended to undergo genetic counselling and screening before marriage to understand the risks and make informed decisions. This can help in planning for a healthy family life.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • About Thalassaemia
  • TIF Prevention
  • Prevention Volume 1

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the symptoms of thalassaemia major?
answer:
Symptoms of Thalassaemia Major

Thalassaemia major, also known as transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT), is the most severe form of thalassaemia. The symptoms typically manifest within the first year of life and can include a range of severe health issues.

Common Symptoms

  • Severe anaemia
  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

Clinical Presentation

The clinical presentation of ß-thalassaemia major usually occurs between 6 and 24 months of age with the following symptoms:

  • Severe microcytic anaemia
  • Mild jaundice
  • Hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen)
  • Failure to thrive
  • Progressive pallor
  • Feeding problems
  • Irritability
  • Recurrent bouts of fever due to a hypermetabolic state or intercurrent infection
  • Progressive enlargement of the abdomen caused by spleen and liver enlargement [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=25]

Untreated or Poorly Transfused Cases

In cases where patients are untreated or poorly transfused, additional symptoms may include:

  • Growth retardation
  • Pallor
  • Jaundice
  • Poor musculature
  • Genu valgum (knock knees)
  • Leg ulcers
  • Development of masses from extramedullary haematopoiesis
  • Skeletal changes resulting from expansion of the bone marrow, including deformities in the long bones of the legs and typical craniofacial changes (thalassaemic facies) [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=26]

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What lifestyle changes can help manage thalassaemia symptoms?
answer:
Lifestyle Changes for Managing Thalassaemia Symptoms

Managing thalassaemia effectively involves several lifestyle changes that can help alleviate symptoms and prevent complications. Here are some key recommendations:

Healthy Eating

  • Consume a varied, nutrient-dense diet with plenty of fruits and vegetables every day [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].
  • Include high-fibre, starchy foods such as wholegrain breads, cereals, beans, peas, lentils, and oats [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43].
  • Consume calcium from food sources like milk, yogurt, tofu, and kale [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Take a vitamin D supplement (1,000 - 2,000 IU/day or 50,000 IU monthly) and have your levels checked annually [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].
  • Limit vitamin C intake to no more than 1,000 mg per day [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].
  • Stay hydrated by drinking water and non-sugar sweetened beverages [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].

Physical Activity

  • Engage in regular physical activity, especially weight-bearing exercises like walking, jogging, dancing, and jumping to promote bone health [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Include activities that improve flexibility, such as yoga and Pilates, to enhance muscle strength and balance [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Monitoring and Prevention

  • Maintain a normal body weight and monitor glucose metabolism markers regularly [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=50].
  • Regular cardiovascular assessments should be part of a multidisciplinary monitoring program [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=123].

Antioxidants and Supplements

  • Consider antioxidants like vitamins C and E, flavonoids, curcuminoids, zinc, alpha lipoic acid, N-acetylcysteine (NAC), L-carnitine, arginine, fermented papaya, Omega-3 fatty acids, and gum arabic, although solid evidence for routine use is lacking [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=51].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Follow-up Questions

question: What are the carrier screenings algorithms and formulae
answer:
Carrier Screening Algorithms and Formulae

Carrier screening for thalassaemia involves a series of tests and algorithms to identify carriers. Below are the key components and flowcharts used in the screening process:

Carrier Screening Algorithm

The carrier screening algorithm uses five parameters: Hb A%, Hb F%, MCH, MCV, and Hb pattern. These parameters lead to five possible outcomes. The cut-off indices in the algorithm are widely used, but reference values should be defined for each population due to differences in thalassaemia alleles.

Figure 4.1 illustrates the best practice strategy used to diagnose carriers in high-risk areas:

Parameter Value Outcome
MCV (fl) >78 Normal
MCV (fl) <78 Further testing required
MCH (pg) >27 Normal
MCH (pg) <27 Further testing required
Hb A2 (%) <3.5% Normal
Hb A2 (%) >3.5% Possible β-thalassaemia trait
Hb F (%) 0.1-7% Further testing required
Hb F (%) <1% Normal
Hb pattern Variant Hb Further testing required

For more detailed information, please refer to the respective sources or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Can thalassaemia be prevented through genetic counselling?
answer:
Prevention of Thalassaemia Through Genetic Counselling

Yes, thalassaemia can be prevented through genetic counselling. Genetic counsellors play a crucial role in educating and guiding individuals and families at risk for thalassaemia. Here are some key aspects of how genetic counselling can help in the prevention of thalassaemia:

Role of Genetic Counsellors

  • Genetic counsellors are specially trained to discuss important aspects of thalassaemia, including where to be tested, how to interpret test results, and what it means to be a carrier [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=137].
  • They assist families in understanding the diagnosis, prognosis, management, and recurrence risks of thalassaemia [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=160].
  • They provide information on reproductive options for at-risk couples, including prenatal diagnosis and associated risks [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

Prevention Strategies

  • Genetic screening can establish whether both partners are carriers of a haemoglobinopathy, which is crucial for at-risk couples planning to have children [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=121].
  • Carrier status confirmation through molecular testing is essential for accurate diagnosis and reproductive planning [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=161].
  • Genetic counsellors can facilitate prenatal diagnosis to identify affected fetuses, allowing couples to make informed decisions about their pregnancy [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=144].

For more detailed genetic counselling and diagnosis, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Are there any ongoing studies on the use of silymarin for iron overload in thalassaemia?
answer:
Ongoing Studies on Silymarin for Iron Overload in Thalassaemia

Silymarin, derived from milk thistle, has shown potential in reducing iron overload and protecting cells from oxidative stress in thalassaemia patients. However, the number of studies specifically evaluating its effects on thalassaemia is limited.

Current Research

Several studies have reported the benefits of silymarin in combination with conventional iron chelators:

  • A study by Darvishi-Khezri et al. (2018) found that combined treatment with silymarin and conventional iron chelators was effective in reducing iron overload in β-thalassaemia major patients [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=142][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=312].
  • Another study by Hagag AA et al. (2015) also reported the therapeutic value of combined therapy with deferiprone and silymarin in Egyptian children with β-thalassaemia major [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=321].

Potential Benefits

Silymarin has been shown to have several protective effects, including:

  • Reduction of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and inhibition of haemolysis
  • Attenuation of inflammation
  • Reduction in hepatic and cardiac iron overload [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=312]

Need for Further Research

Despite these promising findings, more studies, especially long-term, are required to fully understand the efficacy and safety of silymarin as a treatment for iron overload in thalassaemia patients. Current research is limited, and broader recommendations cannot be made until more comprehensive data is available [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=142].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: how to treat antibodies for patients on chronic blood transfusions for thalassemia major
answer:
Treating Antibodies in Patients on Chronic Blood Transfusions for Thalassaemia Major

Development of specific red cell antibodies (alloimmunization) is a significant complication of chronic transfusion therapy in patients with thalassaemia major. Here are the recommended steps to manage this condition:

Compatibility Testing and Monitoring

  • Before starting transfusion therapy, patients should undergo extended red cell antigen typing, including at least C, c, D, E, e, and Kell. If the patient is already transfused, molecular testing can be used for antigen typing [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=26].
  • All patients should receive ABO and Rh (C, c, D, E, e) and Kell compatible blood to avoid alloimmunization against these antigens [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=26].
  • Maintain a valid group and antibody screen before each transfusion [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=26].
  • Keep detailed records of antigen typing, current and historical red cell antibodies, and transfusion reactions for each patient [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=26].

Managing Alloimmunization

  • Monitor patients carefully for the development of new antibodies [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=42].
  • Anti-E, anti-C, and anti-Kell alloantibodies are the most common, but 5-10% of patients may develop antibodies against other erythrocyte antigens [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=42].
  • In case of antibody development, eliminate donors with the corresponding antigens [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=26].

Transfusion Protocols

  • Transfuse 10-15 ml of RBC per kg body weight over 3-4 hours [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=168].
  • For patients with cardiac problems, transfuse at a rate of 2-5 ml of RBC per kg per hour [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=168].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

In more severe cases, complications can include:

  • Iron overload, leading to damage to major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Heart failure, liver cirrhosis, and diabetes [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1]
  • Delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities such as pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, and congestive heart failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities such as cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: Elaborate more on novel therapies
answer:
Novel Therapies for Thalassaemia

Several novel therapies are being developed and tested to improve the treatment and quality of life for thalassaemia patients. Here are some of the key advancements:

Luspatercept-aamt

Luspatercept-aamt is an erythroid maturation agent that helps prolong the lifespan of red blood cells in thalassaemia patients. It allows red blood cells to mature instead of being destroyed prematurely, which increases haemoglobin levels and reduces the need for frequent transfusions. This can significantly lower iron overload and reduce the need for iron chelation therapy, improving the overall quality of life for patients [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

Gene Therapy

Gene therapy aims to provide a cure for thalassaemia by correcting the genetic defects in haematopoietic stem cells. This can be achieved through:

  • Gene Addition: Inserting a healthy copy of the therapeutic gene into the cells using viral vectors.
  • Gene Editing: Precisely repairing the gene or inducing a disease-modifying effect using site-specific nucleases [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=127].

Gene therapy has shown promise in clinical trials, particularly with the use of autologous gene therapy using lentiviral vectors carrying the β-globin gene [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146].

Mitapivat and Etavopivat

Mitapivat and Etavopivat are pyruvate kinase activators currently in clinical trials. These agents target increased haemolysis and may offer robust efficacy in individuals with α-thalassaemia. Mitapivat has shown potential in increasing haemoglobin levels in patients with HbH disease [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146].

Iron Chelation and Hepcidin Modulation

Research is ongoing to develop agents that increase hepcidin levels or block ferroportin to improve erythropoiesis and anaemia. These agents aim to enhance the efficacy of iron chelation therapy, although results have been mixed so far [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146].

Ruxolitinib

Ruxolitinib, a JAK1/JAK2 inhibitor, is being studied as a potential therapy for targeting ineffective erythropoiesis and iron dysregulation in thalassaemia patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=129].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: ما هي الأعراض التي تشير إلى مضاعفات خطيرة في مرضى الثلاسيميا؟
answer:
الأعراض التي تشير إلى مضاعفات خطيرة في مرضى الثلاسيميا

مرضى الثلاسيميا قد يواجهون مضاعفات خطيرة إذا لم يتم إدارة حالتهم بشكل صحيح. من بين الأعراض التي تشير إلى مضاعفات خطيرة:

1. فشل القلب

الأعراض تشمل التعب الشديد، ضيق التنفس، وتورم الأطراف. فشل القلب هو أحد الأسباب الرئيسية للوفاة في مرضى الثلاسيميا [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58].

2. التحميل الزائد بالحديد

الأعراض تشمل التعب، اصفرار الجلد (اليرقان)، تضخم الكبد والطحال، وتغير لون البول إلى الداكن. التحميل الزائد بالحديد يمكن أن يؤدي إلى تلف الكبد والقلب [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58].

3. التهابات خطيرة

الأعراض تشمل الحمى، القشعريرة، وآلام البطن. المرضى الذين خضعوا لاستئصال الطحال هم أكثر عرضة للإصابة بالتهابات خطيرة مثل التهابات المكورات الرئوية والمكورات السحائية [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=13].

4. مشاكل في النمو والتطور

الأعراض تشمل تأخر النمو، قصر القامة، وتشوهات العظام. هذه المشاكل قد تكون نتيجة لفقر الدم المزمن وعدم كفاية العلاج [ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf#page=2][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40].

5. مضاعفات التخثر

الأعراض تشمل الألم والتورم في الأطراف، ضيق التنفس، وألم الصدر. التخثرات الدموية يمكن أن تؤدي إلى جلطات دموية خطيرة مثل الجلطات الوريدية العميقة والانصمام الرئوي [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=25].

للمزيد من المعلومات أو المساعدة، يرجى التواصل عبر البريد الإلكتروني info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Can i use lions mane mushrooms
answer:
Can I Use Lion's Mane Mushrooms?

There is no specific information available regarding the use of Lion's Mane mushrooms for individuals with thalassaemia in the provided sources. However, it is important to note that:

  • If you have a liver problem, you should discontinue use and consult a healthcare practitioner if you develop symptoms of liver trouble, such as abdominal pain, dark urine, or jaundice (yellowing of the skin or eyes) [source].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: What are common digestive issues in thalassaemia?
answer:
Common Digestive Issues in Thalassaemia

Individuals with thalassaemia may experience various digestive issues, including:

  • Poor appetite due to severe anaemia, adrenal insufficiency, zinc deficiency, or inactivity [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=69][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=70].
  • Nausea or other gastrointestinal complaints associated with the use of oral chelators, which can lead to missed meals, food intolerance, and decreased or altered food intake [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=69][Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=14].
  • Chronic constipation due to inactivity and inadequate fluid intake [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=70].
  • Lactose intolerance, leading to avoidance of dairy products rich in protein [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=70].
  • Abdominal pain and enterocolitis, particularly in cases of infection with Yersinia enterocolitica [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90][EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=13].
  • Reduced enzyme output from the pancreas due to iron damage, requiring enzyme supplements [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=14].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: My semen is coming out in jelly form
answer:
Semen Consistency and Thalassaemia

Changes in semen consistency, such as it appearing in a jelly-like form, can be concerning and may be related to various factors, including underlying health conditions. While the provided sources do not specifically address jelly-like semen in thalassaemia patients, there are several related considerations that might be relevant:

Potential Causes

  • Iron Overload: Iron overload can affect various organs, including the endocrine system, which plays a crucial role in reproductive health. Excess iron can lead to hormonal imbalances that might affect semen quality [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=84].
  • Endocrine Disorders: Thalassaemia patients are at risk of developing endocrine disorders such as hypogonadism, which can impact semen production and quality [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=109].
  • Infections: Thalassaemia patients have a higher risk of infections due to factors like anaemia, splenectomy, and iron overload, which can also affect reproductive health [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=89].
  • Priapism and Impotence: Conditions like priapism, which is common in sickle cell disease, can lead to long-term damage and affect semen quality [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=19][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=93].

Recommendations

If you are experiencing changes in semen consistency, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional for a thorough evaluation. They can help determine the underlying cause and recommend appropriate treatment. Here are some general steps you can take:

  • Schedule an appointment with a urologist or endocrinologist to discuss your symptoms and undergo necessary tests.
  • Maintain a healthy diet rich in essential nutrients that support reproductive health, such as vitamins E and C, folic acid, and zinc [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=17].
  • Ensure proper management of iron levels through regular monitoring and chelation therapy as prescribed by your healthcare provider [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=109].
  • Stay hydrated and avoid substances that can negatively impact reproductive health, such as alcohol and tobacco [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=168].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the greatest unmet needs in thalassemia?
answer:
Unmet Needs in Thalassaemia

Patients with thalassaemia face several significant unmet needs, including:

  • Basic Medical Care: Many patients lack access to essential medical care and treatments [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=339].
  • Multidisciplinary Care (MDC): Access to comprehensive care involving multiple specialists is limited, which is crucial for managing the complex needs of thalassaemia patients [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=337].
  • Expert Review in Reference Centres: Less than 2% of patients globally have access to expert review and care in specialized centres, which is essential for optimal management of the disease [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=339].
  • Organized Expert Services: There is a need for organized services to manage complications affecting major organs such as the liver, heart, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=24].
  • Access to Essential Drugs and Blood Transfusions: Lifelong follow-up and care require significant resources, including essential drugs and donated blood [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=24].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How is the thalassemia prevalence in China?
answer:
Thalassaemia Prevalence in China

Thalassaemia, particularly α-thalassaemia, is highly prevalent in China. Here are some key points regarding its prevalence:

  • α-thalassaemia is commonly encountered in China, with up to 40% of the regional population being carriers [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=22].
  • In certain areas of Southern China, the carrier frequency for α-thalassaemia can be as high as 80-90% of the population [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=12].
  • Haemoglobin E, a structural variant, is also prevalent in regions of China, contributing to the overall burden of thalassaemia in the country [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=5][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=9].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Guidelines for the Management of Transfusion Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT).

question: Quali sono i valori ottimali della LIC
answer:
Valori Ottimali della Liver Iron Concentration (LIC)

La concentrazione di ferro nel fegato (LIC) è un indicatore cruciale per monitorare il sovraccarico di ferro nei pazienti con talassemia. Ecco i valori ottimali e le soglie cliniche rilevanti per la LIC:

  • Valori normali: Fino a 1.8 mg/g di peso secco (dw) [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=62].
  • Obiettivo terapeutico accettabile: 3-7 mg/g dw, con raccomandazione di mantenere i livelli verso la parte inferiore di questo intervallo [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=35].
  • Sovraccarico moderato di ferro: >7 mg/g dw [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=61].
  • Sovraccarico severo di ferro: >15 mg/g dw [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=61].
  • Rischio aumentato di fibrosi epatica: >16 mg/g dw [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=61].

Per ulteriori informazioni, puoi contattare info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Ποια είναι η θεραπεία για τη δρεπανοκυτταρική αναιμία;
answer:
Θεραπεία για τη Δρεπανοκυτταρική Αναιμία

Η θεραπεία για τη δρεπανοκυτταρική αναιμία περιλαμβάνει διάφορες προσεγγίσεις, οι οποίες στοχεύουν στην ανακούφιση των συμπτωμάτων και την πρόληψη των επιπλοκών. Ακολουθούν μερικές από τις κύριες θεραπείες:

Φαρμακευτική Θεραπεία

  • Υδροξυουρία (Hydroxyurea): Αυτό το φάρμακο αυξάνει την παραγωγή εμβρυϊκής αιμοσφαιρίνης (HbF), η οποία βοηθά στην πρόληψη του σχηματισμού δρεπανοκυττάρων. Η υδροξυουρία μειώνει τη συχνότητα των επώδυνων κρίσεων και την ανάγκη για μεταγγίσεις αίματος [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=117][TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=52].
  • Κλοτριμαζόλη (Clotrimazole): Ένα αντιμυκητιασικό φάρμακο που βοηθά στην πρόληψη της απώλειας νερού από τα ερυθρά αιμοσφαίρια και μπορεί να μειώσει τον αριθμό των κυκλοφορούντων δρεπανοκυττάρων [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=28][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=118].
  • Νιτρικό οξείδιο (Nitric oxide): Ένα αέριο που μειώνει την κολλητικότητα των ερυθρών αιμοσφαιρίων και βοηθά στη διατήρηση των αιμοφόρων αγγείων ανοιχτών [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=28][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=118].

Πειραματικές Θεραπείες

  • Γονιδιακή θεραπεία: Οι ερευνητές μελετούν τη διόρθωση του ελαττωματικού γονιδίου και την εισαγωγή του στον μυελό των οστών των ασθενών, με στόχο την παραγωγή φυσιολογικής αιμοσφαιρίνης [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=28][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=118].

Μεταγγίσεις Αίματος

Οι μεταγγίσεις αίματος χρησιμοποιούνται για την πρόληψη ή τη διαχείριση οξέων αγγειακών αποφράξεων και για την αύξηση του όγκου του αίματος, αντικαθιστώντας τα δρεπανοκύτταρα με φυσιολογικά ερυθρά αιμοσφαίρια [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=51].

Μεταμόσχευση Αιμοποιητικών Βλαστικών Κυττάρων (HSCT)

Η μεταμόσχευση αιμοποιητικών βλαστικών κυττάρων, συμπεριλαμβανομένης της μεταμόσχευσης μυελού των οστών, είναι η μόνη θεραπεία που μπορεί να θεραπεύσει τη δρεπανοκυτταρική αναιμία. Απαιτείται συμβατός δότης και η διαδικασία περιλαμβάνει την καταστροφή του υπάρχοντος μυελού των οστών του ασθενούς πριν από τη μεταμόσχευση [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=52].

Για περισσότερες πληροφορίες, μπορείτε να επικοινωνήσετε με το email info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How many patients are poor responders to deferasirox
answer:
Poor Responders to Deferasirox

According to the available data, there is no specific percentage provided for patients who are poor responders to deferasirox. However, it is noted that some patients may not respond adequately to the standard once-daily dose of deferasirox. Studies have shown that twice-daily dosing can significantly improve clinical efficacy in transfusion-dependent thalassaemia patients who were inadequate responders to the standard once-daily dose [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=127].

For more detailed information, you may contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy for further assistance.

question: What should i check in my annual review for my 6 years child with thalassemia transfusion dependent
answer:
Annual Review Checklist for a 6-Year-Old Child with Thalassemia

For a 6-year-old child with transfusion-dependent thalassemia, the following assessments should be included in the annual review:

  • Physical Examination: Regular physical exams to monitor overall health and development [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=99].
  • Cardiovascular Assessment: History taking, physical examination, resting electrocardiogram (ECG), and transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=118].
  • Growth Monitoring: Regular monitoring of growth, including height and weight, to ensure the child is growing according to their genetic potential [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=175].
  • Serum Ferritin Levels: Assess serum ferritin levels every six months to monitor iron overload [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=35].
  • Review of Dietary Intake: Annual review of dietary intake to ensure nutritional needs are being met [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=175].
  • Bone Health: Bone densitometry (DXA) every 2-3 years starting from age 10, or earlier if clinically indicated [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=175].
  • Laboratory Tests: Regular complete blood count (CBC) every 6-12 months and other tests as advised by the doctor [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=99].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: treatment and management of hb e disease
answer:
Treatment and Management of Hemoglobin E Disease

The treatment and management of Hemoglobin E disease, particularly when it is combined with β-thalassemia (Hemoglobin E/β-thalassemia), involves several strategies to manage symptoms and prevent complications.

Blood Transfusions

Regular blood transfusions are considered for patients with declining baseline hemoglobin, rapid spleen enlargement, growth failure, or frequent hemolytic crises. During hemolytic episodes, red cell transfusions are provided to restore hemoglobin levels to 80-90 g/L [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=168].

For more severely affected patients, frequent transfusions may be necessary to prevent disease-related complications such as significant bone deformities and extramedullary hematopoiesis (EMH) [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=38].

Iron Chelation Therapy

Iron overload is a common complication due to increased intestinal iron absorption and frequent blood transfusions. Iron chelation therapy is essential to prevent or reduce excess iron deposits in the body [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

Management of Extramedullary Hematopoiesis (EMH)

EMH can occur in various locations, including the spleen, liver, and lymph nodes. Treatment options for EMH include hypertransfusion, radiation therapy, surgery, and hydroxyurea. Hypertransfusion is the preferred treatment, and radiotherapy has been shown to be effective due to the radiosensitivity of EMH masses [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=39].

Folic Acid Supplementation

Patients with Hemoglobin E disease should receive folic acid supplementation at a dose of 1-5 mg/day to support erythropoietic activity [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=168].

Vaccinations and Infection Management

Complete immunization against vaccine-preventable diseases, prompt treatment of fever and infections, and routine vaccinations against common infections such as influenza, pneumococcus, and SARS-CoV-2 are strongly recommended [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=38][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=169].

Monitoring and Support

Regular monitoring of hemoglobin levels, growth, and development is essential. Psychosocial support may be required, and patients should be monitored for complications of chronic transfusion and given iron chelation support as needed [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=169].

Additional Information

For further assistance or more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

  • What are the potential side effects of iron chelation therapy?
  • How often should patients with Hemoglobin E disease undergo monitoring?
  • Are there any dietary recommendations for patients with Hemoglobin E disease?

question: Recommendation for iron chelation at ferritin level 2700 if already child is on deferasirox
answer:
Recommendation for Iron Chelation at Ferritin Level 2700

If a child with thalassaemia has a ferritin level of 2700 ng/ml and is already on deferasirox, here are some key considerations and recommendations:

Current Treatment with Deferasirox

  • Deferasirox is an oral iron chelator taken once daily. The starting dose is typically 14 mg/kg/day, which can be increased up to 28 mg/kg/day if tolerated and if the iron load necessitates [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].
  • Regular monitoring of renal function, liver function, and ferritin levels is necessary while on deferasirox [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=67].

Monitoring and Adjustments

  • Ferritin levels should be monitored every 3-6 months to assess the effectiveness of the chelation therapy [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=67].
  • If the ferritin level remains high, it may be necessary to adjust the dose of deferasirox, ensuring it does not exceed the maximum recommended dose [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].
  • In cases where ferritin levels are significantly elevated, additional clinical or laboratory measures may be required to assess iron overload and adjust treatment accordingly [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=53].

Additional Considerations

  • Ensure adherence to the prescribed chelation therapy to maintain effective iron control [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=52].
  • Consider the potential for renal and liver function abnormalities, especially at higher doses, and monitor these functions closely [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32].

For more detailed guidance, please refer to the sources provided or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: La transmission de thalassémie
answer:
Transmission de la Thalassémie

La thalassémie est une forme héréditaire d'anémie, ce qui signifie qu'elle est transmise génétiquement des parents aux enfants. Elle est causée par des mutations dans les gènes responsables de la production de l'hémoglobine, la protéine dans les globules rouges qui transporte l'oxygène.

Voici quelques points clés sur la transmission de la thalassémie :

  • La thalassémie est transmise de manière autosomique récessive. Cela signifie qu'un enfant doit hériter de deux copies du gène muté (une de chaque parent) pour développer la forme sévère de la maladie, connue sous le nom de thalassémie majeure.
  • Si un enfant hérite d'une seule copie du gène muté, il sera porteur de la thalassémie (thalassémie mineure) et ne présentera généralement pas de symptômes graves, mais pourra transmettre le gène à ses propres enfants.
  • Les parents qui sont tous deux porteurs de la thalassémie ont un risque de 25% d'avoir un enfant atteint de thalassémie majeure à chaque grossesse.

Pour plus d'informations, vous pouvez consulter les sources suivantes :

  • TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf
  • NursesGuide_English.pdf

Si vous avez besoin de plus d'informations, veuillez contacter info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: que es lo examenes por alpha thalassemia
answer:
Exámenes para Alfa Talasemia

El diagnóstico de la alfa talasemia requiere una combinación de pruebas de laboratorio y análisis genéticos. A continuación, se describen los principales exámenes utilizados:

  • Conteo sanguíneo completo (CBC): Incluye la determinación del volumen corpuscular medio (MCV) y la hemoglobina corpuscular media (MCH) para detectar anemia microcítica e hipocrómica [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=18].
  • Análisis de hemoglobina: Se utilizan métodos automáticos como la cromatografía líquida de alta resolución (HPLC) y la electroforesis capilar (CE) para el análisis cualitativo y cuantitativo de los componentes de la hemoglobina [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=18].
  • Electroforesis de hemoglobina: Permite medir la hemoglobina A2 y la hemoglobina fetal (HbF) para descartar otras hemoglobinopatías [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=162].
  • Pruebas genéticas: La prueba del gen de la alfa-globina es crucial para detectar deleciones y mutaciones puntuales comunes en la alfa talasemia. Estas pruebas son esenciales para diferenciar entre los estados de portador de alfa talasemia [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=162].
  • Análisis molecular: Las pruebas genéticas moleculares permiten un diagnóstico definitivo y son esenciales para identificar parejas en riesgo de tener formas graves de la condición [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=21].

Para más información, puede contactar a info@thalassaemia.org.cy.
