  • Keberadaan hemoglobin janin (HbF) yang cukup dapat menyeimbangkan jumlah rantai globin (a dan y) yang membentuk HbF, melindungi anak dari proses produksi sel darah merah yang tidak efektif [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=32].
  • Diagnosis thalassaemia pada usia dini dapat dilakukan melalui teknik molekuler yang mengidentifikasi mutasi yang diwarisi anak dari masing-masing orang tua. Namun, tes ini biasanya hanya dilakukan jika ada kecurigaan khusus [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=32].
  • Program skrining bayi baru lahir dapat membantu dalam mendiagnosis keberadaan varian seperti HbE atau HbS, tetapi tes diagnostik untuk mengidentifikasi thalassaemia mayor seringkali tidak konklusif pada tahap awal ini [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=32][TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=24].
  • Pengujian genetik atau berbasis DNA dapat memberikan diagnosis definitif dan penting untuk membedakan antara berbagai jenis status pembawa thalassaemia [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=44].

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut, Anda dapat menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may differ in severity depending on the type of thalassaemia (major or intermedia) and the effectiveness of the treatment. Some common complications include:

  • Iron Overload: Due to regular blood transfusions, iron accumulates in the body, leading to damage in organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15].
  • Endocrine Problems: Delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Cardiac Abnormalities: Pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, congestive heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Hepatic Abnormalities: Cirrhosis, liver failure, and complications from viral hepatitis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Splenic Enlargement: Possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Bone Deformities: Bone deformities, fractures, and expansion of haemopoietic tissue [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15].
  • Growth and Development Issues: Delayed growth and development, short stature [ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf#page=2].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Follow-Up Questions
