question: how long does it take to remove cardiac iron overloD
answer:
Time to Remove Cardiac Iron Overload

Cardiac iron clearance is a slow process that can take several years to complete. Even with intensive chelation therapy, high levels of baseline heart iron (mT2* < 10 ms) will typically take several years to clear [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=83].

Combination therapy using desferrioxamine and deferiprone may more rapidly reduce cardiac iron load and improve cardiac function [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=81].

It is important to note that cardiac dysfunction generally lags behind cardiac iron deposition by several years, and chelation regimes must be adjusted to ensure a rapid fall in cardiac iron content [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=121].

Sources

  • TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf
  • AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf
  • TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf

question: Thalasseamia HBH
answer:
Thalassaemia HbH

Overview

HbH disease is a form of alpha-thalassaemia that arises due to the inactivation of three out of four alpha-globin genes. This leads to an imbalance in globin chain production, resulting in an excess of beta-globin chains that form tetramers known as HbH. These tetramers have a high oxygen affinity and are unstable, which means they do not effectively deliver oxygen to tissues and are prone to early haemolysis [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=20].

Genetic Basis

The most common genotype for deletional HbH disease involves combinations of alpha+-thalassaemia deletions (e.g., -a3.7, -a4.2) with alphaº-thalassaemia deletions (e.g., --SEA, --FIL). Patients with deletional HbH disease generally have a mild, non-transfusion-dependent haemolytic anaemia. However, non-deletional HbH disease, which involves point mutations or hyper-unstable alpha-globin variants, tends to present with more severe symptoms and may require regular transfusions [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=25][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=154].

Clinical Manifestations

Patients with HbH disease often exhibit chronic haemolysis and ineffective erythropoiesis. Symptoms can worsen during infections, fever, surgical procedures, or pregnancy. In severe cases, such as HbH hydrops foetalis, the condition can lead to severe foetal haemolytic anaemia and congenital abnormalities [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=61][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=52].

Management

Management of HbH disease includes monitoring and treating anaemia, which may involve blood transfusions, especially during periods of exacerbation. Prenatal diagnosis is recommended for families with a history of severe forms of HbH disease to assess the risk of Hb Bart's hydrops foetalis [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=95].

Additional Information

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: هل لديك معلمومات عن حقن تسريع البلوغ لمرضى الثلاسيميا المتمدين على نقل الدم المتكرر وما الفرق بينها وبين حقن هرمون النمو
answer:
حقن تسريع البلوغ وحقن هرمون النمو لمرضى الثلاسيميا

بالنسبة لمرضى الثلاسيميا الذين يعتمدون على نقل الدم المتكرر، يمكن أن يتأخر البلوغ بسبب عدة عوامل منها زيادة الحديد في الجسم وتأثيره على محور الغدة النخامية-الغدد التناسلية. في هذه الحالات، يمكن استخدام العلاج الهرموني لتحفيز البلوغ.

حقن تسريع البلوغ

تُستخدم حقن الهرمونات الجنسية لتحفيز البلوغ في المرضى الذين يعانون من تأخر البلوغ. في الذكور، يُستخدم التستوستيرون بجرعات تبدأ من 50 ملغ كل 4 أسابيع لمدة 3-6 أشهر. في الإناث، يُستخدم 17-بيتا استراديول بجرعات منخفضة، ويفضل أن تكون عبر الجلد [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=205].

حقن هرمون النمو

تُستخدم حقن هرمون النمو في حالات نقص هرمون النمو المثبتة والتي تظهر استجابة جيدة للعلاج. ومع ذلك، فإن استخدام هرمون النمو في مرضى الثلاسيميا محدود بسبب النتائج المتضاربة في الدراسات [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=83].

الفرق بين حقن تسريع البلوغ وحقن هرمون النمو

  • حقن تسريع البلوغ: تُستخدم لتحفيز البلوغ في المرضى الذين يعانون من تأخر البلوغ بسبب نقص الهرمونات الجنسية.
  • حقن هرمون النمو: تُستخدم لعلاج نقص هرمون النمو المثبت والذي يؤثر على النمو الطولي للمرضى.

إذا كنت بحاجة إلى مزيد من المعلومات، يمكنك التواصل عبر البريد الإلكتروني: info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Quale valore di t2 risonanza magnetica per misurare accumulo nel fegato
answer:
Valore di T2* per Misurare l'Accumulazione di Ferro nel Fegato

La risonanza magnetica (MRI) è uno strumento affidabile e non invasivo per valutare la concentrazione di ferro nel fegato (LIC). Esistono diverse tecniche di MRI, tra cui T2* e R2 (1/T2), che sono state validate contro la biopsia epatica.

Il metodo T2* è stato originariamente sviluppato per stimare il ferro miocardico, ma è stato dimostrato che esiste una chiara relazione tra T2* epatico e la concentrazione di ferro nel fegato misurata tramite biopsia. Tuttavia, il metodo T2* originale sottostimava la concentrazione di ferro nel fegato di circa due volte. Una nuova calibrazione ha mostrato una linearità e riproducibilità accettabili per una gamma di concentrazione di ferro nel fegato fino a 30 mg Fe/g di peso secco [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf].

Il limite superiore per stimare in modo affidabile la concentrazione di ferro nel fegato tramite risonanza magnetica è di circa 30-40 mg Fe/g di peso secco, a seconda delle specifiche dello scanner [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf].

Per ulteriori informazioni, puoi contattare info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: I have 2nd group disability in Azerbaijan, what will happen if I move to Poland?
answer:
Moving to Poland with a 2nd Group Disability from Azerbaijan

If you move to Poland, you will need to navigate the healthcare system there. Poland is a member of the European Union (EU), which means you can access healthcare services, but there are some steps you need to follow:

  • Contact the National Contact Point of your home country to get informed about the services of healthcare providers in EU/EEA countries.
  • Book an appointment at the healthcare provider of your preference in Poland.
  • You may need to pay upfront for healthcare services and collect all prescriptions and receipts.
  • For mandatory diagnosis or treatment, you might need to obtain a pre-authorization (S2 form) from your national health authority.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Cross Border Healthcare Factsheet [CrossBorderHealthcare-Factsheet.pdf#page=3].

If you have specific questions about your disability status and how it will be recognized in Poland, it is best to contact the relevant authorities or seek assistance from local support organizations.

For further assistance, you can email info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: لدى سؤال اخر اذا كنت مريض اعانى من الثلاسيميا ومستوى فيرتين هو الف ولكن اشغة الرنين الخاصة بى تظهر تراكم الحديد  داخل البنكرياس والكبد  هل استمر فى  تناول استخلاب الحديد؟
answer:
هل يجب الاستمرار في تناول علاج استخلاب الحديد؟

نعم، يجب الاستمرار في تناول علاج استخلاب الحديد حتى لو كان مستوى الفيريتين 1000 نانوغرام/مل وأشعة الرنين المغناطيسي تظهر تراكم الحديد في البنكرياس والكبد. تراكم الحديد في الأعضاء يمكن أن يسبب مضاعفات خطيرة، وعلاج استخلاب الحديد هو الطريقة الوحيدة الفعالة لتقليل مستويات الحديد في الجسم ومنع هذه المضاعفات.

تراكم الحديد يمكن أن يؤدي إلى فشل القلب، اضطرابات الغدد الصماء، وارتفاع إنزيمات الكبد، وهذه المضاعفات يمكن أن تُعكس باستخدام علاج استخلاب الحديد [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=119].

بالإضافة إلى ذلك، مستويات الفيريتين قد لا تعكس بدقة مستوى الحديد في الأعضاء، لذا من المهم الاعتماد على نتائج أشعة الرنين المغناطيسي لتقييم تراكم الحديد [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=41].

للمزيد من المعلومات أو المساعدة، يمكنك التواصل عبر البريد الإلكتروني: info@thalassaemia.org.cy

question: What is the best way to do desferal?
answer:
Best Way to Administer Desferal

Desferal (Deferoxamine) is an iron chelating agent used to treat chronic iron overload. The best way to administer Desferal is subcutaneously (under the skin) using a portable infusion pump. Here are the key steps and considerations:

Administration Method

  • Desferal is administered subcutaneously via a slow infusion over 8-12 hours, at least 6 days a week [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=8][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=57].
  • The drug is diluted at home by the parents or the patients themselves [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=11].
  • It is important to rotate the injection sites to avoid local irritation and infection [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=61].

Dosage

  • Children: 20-40 mg/kg/day [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=11].
  • Adults: 30-50 mg/kg/day, up to 60 mg/kg/day after growth is complete [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=11][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=57].

Preparation

  • Desferal comes as a dry white powder in 500 mg or 2 g vials [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=57].
  • To prepare a 10% solution, add 5 ml of distilled water to a 500 mg vial and allow it to dissolve [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=57].

Hygiene

  • Maintain strict hygiene and antisepsis to prevent infections [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=61].
  • Use topical anesthetics like EMLA cream to reduce pain at the injection site [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=61].

Emergency Situations

  • In emergencies, Desferal can be administered intravenously dissolved in saline over 24 hours [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=11].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How can I manage the pain at the place where needle inserted for blood transfusion. This area causes too much pain for 2-3 days after transfusion.
answer:
Managing Pain at the Needle Insertion Site for Blood Transfusions

Experiencing pain at the site where the needle was inserted for blood transfusions is a common issue. Here are some tips to help manage and reduce this pain:

  • Avoid Important Blood Vessels or Nerves: Ensure that the needle is not inserted near important blood vessels or nerves to minimize the risk of damage and bleeding [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].
  • Rotate Injection Sites: Change the site chosen for injection frequently. The abdomen is often the best site, but the upper arm or thigh can also be used. Rotating sites helps prevent local reactions over time [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf][NursesGuide_English.pdf].
  • Use Topical Anaesthetic Creams: Applying topical anaesthetic creams such as EMLA 30-60 minutes before the procedure can help reduce local pain [NursesGuide_English.pdf].
  • Warm Compress: Applying a warm compress to the affected area after the procedure can help reduce swelling and discomfort [NursesGuide_English.pdf].
  • Check Infusion Rate: Ensure that the infusion rate is appropriate, as administering the solution too quickly can cause swelling [NursesGuide_English.pdf].

If you continue to experience significant pain or have other concerns, please contact your healthcare provider for further assistance.

question: What other tests should be done regularly for NTDT patients?
answer:
Regular Tests for NTDT Patients

Patients with non-transfusion-dependent thalassemia (NTDT) should undergo a variety of regular tests to monitor their health status and manage potential complications. Here are the recommended tests:

General Health Monitoring

  • Complete Blood Cell Count: Regularly to monitor anemia and overall blood health [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=12].
  • Growth Monitoring (for patients <18 years):
    • Standing and sitting height: every 6 months
    • Bone age: annually if delayed puberty or growth
    • Growth hormone stimulation, IGF-1 level, IGF-BP3 level if growth issues are detected [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=89].

Endocrine Function

  • Hypothyroidism: Free thyroxine (FT4) and thyroid-stimulating hormone: annually [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=85].
  • Hypoparathyroidism: Calcium, phosphate, vitamin D: annually; Parathyroid hormone: if indicated [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=85].
  • Diabetes Mellitus: Fasting blood sugar: annually; Oral glucose tolerance test: if indicated [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=85].
  • Adrenal Insufficiency: Adrenocorticotropic hormone stimulation test: annually [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=85].
  • Hypogonadism (for patients 10-17 years): Tanner staging: annually; Gonadotropin-releasing hormone, luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, testosterone if pubertal delay is detected [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=89].

Bone Health

  • Osteoporosis: Bone Mineral Density (BMD) of spine, hips, radius, ulna (dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry): annually [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=85].
  • Spine Imaging: For back pain or neurological findings [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=85].

Liver Health

  • Liver Function Tests: Every 3 months [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=85].
  • Liver Ultrasound: Annually if liver iron concentration ≥5 mg Fe/g dry weight or serum ferritin level ≥800 ng/ml; every 6 months if abnormal findings [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=85].
  • Alpha-feto Protein: Annually in cirrhotic patients or patients >40 years [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=85].
  • Transient Elastography: Every 12-24 months if liver iron concentration ≥5 mg Fe/g dry weight or serum ferritin level ≥800 ng/ml [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=85].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins. There are two main types of thalassaemia based on the affected globin protein: α-thalassaemia and β-thalassaemia.

β-Thalassaemia

β-thalassaemia occurs due to mutations in the HBB gene, which affects the production of the β-globin protein. The severity of β-thalassaemia can vary widely based on the specific mutations and other genetic factors:

  • Severe mutations (β0) result in no β-globin production, leading to thalassaemia major, which requires regular blood transfusions for survival [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].
  • Less severe mutations (β+) result in reduced β-globin production, which can lead to thalassaemia intermedia or major, depending on the specific mutation and other genetic factors [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].
  • Mild mutations (β++) generally result in a very mild clinical phenotype, often presenting as thalassaemia intermedia [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

Several genetic factors can ameliorate the severity of β-thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia, which reduces the imbalance between α- and β-globin chains, leading to a milder phenotype [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Mutations that increase the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), such as hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH) mutations, can result in a milder form of thalassaemia intermedia [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Genetic determinants outside the β-globin gene cluster, such as BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB, which increase HbF production and ameliorate disease severity [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

α-Thalassaemia

α-thalassaemia occurs when one or more of the genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated. The severity of α-thalassaemia depends on the number of affected genes:

  • Loss of one α-globin gene generally has minimal effect [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Loss of two α-globin genes can lead to a milder form of thalassaemia intermedia [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].

For more detailed information or specific cases, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: is desferal recommended during pregnancy?
answer:
Desferal (Deferoxamine) Use During Pregnancy

Desferal (Deferoxamine) can be used during pregnancy under specific conditions:

  • It is generally recommended to avoid Deferoxamine in the first trimester if possible due to potential risks [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=70].
  • For pregnant patients with extremely high iron load or serious heart problems, a low dose of Deferoxamine (20-30 mg/kg/day) has been used in the later stages of pregnancy without adverse effects [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=68].
  • If cardiac function deteriorates during pregnancy, Deferoxamine may be used cautiously after the first trimester [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=38].
  • Women with significant myocardial iron loading should begin low-dose subcutaneous Deferoxamine (20 mg/kg/day) from 20 to 24 weeks of gestation under close supervision [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=236].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

There are more than 200 known ß-thalassaemia mutations, which can result in a range of phenotypic severities from very mild to very severe:

  • Severe (ßo) mutations: Examples include IVS1-1, IVS11-1, and C39.
  • Less severe (ß+) mutations: Examples include IVS1-110, IVS11-745, and IVS1-5.
  • Mild (ß++) mutations: Examples include -101, -87, -88, and -28.

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Impact of Genetic Modifiers

The severity of thalassaemia can be influenced by several genetic modifiers:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the imbalance between α- and ß-globin chains, leading to a milder form of the disease. [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101]
  • Increased production of γ-globin chains: This results in higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can ameliorate the severity of the disease. [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32]
  • Hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH) mutations: These mutations are associated with high HbF levels and can result in a milder form of ß-thalassaemia intermedia when combined with severe ß-thalassaemia alleles. [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32]

Examples of Specific Mutations

Some specific mutations and their typical clinical outcomes include:

  • ß+-type mutation -88 (C->T): Generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype. [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72]
  • ß+-thalassaemia mutation Cap+1 (A->C): Can result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients. [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72]

Conclusion

The genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity are complex and influenced by a variety of factors. Accurate genetic diagnosis and counseling are essential for managing the condition effectively.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How effective is gene therapy compared to traditional treatments?
answer:
Effectiveness of Gene Therapy Compared to Traditional Treatments for Thalassemia

Gene therapy offers a promising alternative to traditional treatments for thalassemia, with several potential advantages and some limitations. Here is a comparison based on the available information:

Gene Therapy

Gene therapy aims to provide a one-time, potentially curative treatment for thalassemia by correcting the genetic defect in the patient's own hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs). This approach has shown significant promise in clinical trials:

  • Gene therapy uses autologous stem cells, which eliminates the risk of graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) and other complications associated with allogeneic stem cell transplants [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=2].
  • It has the potential to be available to a larger number of patients, including those without an HLA-matched donor, which is a limitation for allogeneic HSCT [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=2].
  • Clinical trials have shown that gene therapy can lead to transfusion independence in a significant proportion of patients, particularly those with the less severe form of the disease (non-βº/βº genotype) [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=2].
  • Gene therapy has been successfully validated for β-thalassemia treatment using lentiviral vectors carrying the β-globin gene [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146].

Traditional Treatments

Traditional treatments for thalassemia include regular blood transfusions and iron chelation therapy, as well as hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) from an allogeneic donor:

  • Blood Transfusions and Iron Chelation: These treatments are effective in managing the symptoms of thalassemia but require lifelong adherence and can lead to complications such as iron overload [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=127].
  • Allogeneic HSCT: This is currently the only established curative treatment for thalassemia. However, it is limited to patients with a well-matched donor and carries risks such as GvHD, long-term immunosuppression, and transplant-related mortality [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=127].

Comparative Effectiveness

While gene therapy offers the potential for a one-time cure and circumvents many of the complications associated with traditional treatments, it is still in the experimental stage and requires further clinical trials to establish its long-term safety and efficacy:

  • Gene therapy has shown promising results in clinical trials, with some patients achieving transfusion independence and significant reductions in transfusion requirements [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=2].
  • Traditional treatments, while effective in managing the disease, do not offer a cure and require ongoing management [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=127].

In summary, gene therapy holds substantial promise as a curative treatment for thalassemia, potentially offering a life without the need for regular transfusions and iron chelation. However, more clinical trials are needed to confirm its long-term safety and efficacy [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=2][TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=2].

If you need further assistance or specific information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Blood component therapy in thalassemia patients
answer:
Blood Component Therapy in Thalassemia Patients

Blood component therapy is a crucial aspect of managing thalassemia, particularly for patients with thalassemia major. The primary goals of blood transfusion therapy are to alleviate anemia, ensure good growth and development, maintain good energy levels, and suppress intra and extramedullary hematopoiesis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=21].

Key Aspects of Blood Transfusion Therapy

  • Regular blood transfusions are essential to maintain pre-transfusion hemoglobin levels at 9.5 to 10 g/dL. This typically involves transfusions every two to four weeks [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Blood should be carefully selected, processed, and stored to ensure safety and effectiveness. It should be obtained from regular, voluntary, non-remunerated donors and adhere to quality and safety regulations [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=21].
  • Iron chelation therapy is necessary to manage iron overload resulting from frequent transfusions. This therapy helps prevent damage to vital organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine systems [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=3].
  • Splenectomy may be considered in cases of an oversized spleen or high transfusion requirements, although it has become less common with improved treatment options [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

Benefits of Regular Blood Transfusions

Regular blood transfusions significantly improve the quality and length of life for patients with thalassemia major. They help prevent complications such as poor growth, bone deformities, organ enlargement, and impaired physical activities [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=35].

Additional Considerations

Blood transfusion therapy should be administered by trained staff and involve informed patient consent. It is also important to have a good hemovigilance structure in place to monitor and manage any adverse reactions [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=21].

For more detailed guidelines, please refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) at www.thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins, which are essential components of hemoglobin. There are two main types of thalassaemia based on the affected globin chain: α-thalassaemia and β-thalassaemia.

β-Thalassaemia

β-thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the HBB gene, which encodes the β-globin protein. More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, leading to a wide range of phenotypic severity, from mild to very severe forms. The severity of β-thalassaemia can be influenced by several factors:

  • Type of Mutation: Mutations can be classified as severe (β0), less severe (β+), and mild (β++). For example, severe mutations like IVS1-1 and IVS1-[-25] often result in thalassaemia major, while mild mutations like -88 (C->T) generally result in a milder clinical phenotype [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: The co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia can ameliorate the severity of β-thalassaemia. For instance, patients homozygous for a severe β-thalassaemia allele with two α-globin genes missing are more likely to have thalassaemia intermedia rather than thalassaemia major [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Increased HbF Production: Genetic modifiers that increase the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) can also reduce the severity of β-thalassaemia. For example, the Xmn1 polymorphism in the Gy-globin gene is associated with elevated HbF levels and can result in a milder phenotype [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=61].

α-Thalassaemia

α-thalassaemia occurs when one or more of the genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated. The severity of α-thalassaemia depends on the number of affected α-globin genes:

  • One or Two Genes: The loss of one α-globin gene generally has minimal effect, while the loss of two genes can lead to a milder form of thalassaemia [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Three or Four Genes: The loss of three or four α-globin genes results in more severe forms of the disease, such as HbH disease or hydrops fetalis, respectively [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].

Overall, the genetic interactions and the presence of ameliorating factors contribute to the wide clinical spectrum observed in thalassaemia patients, making genetic counselling and diagnosis complex [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=64].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Life span of beta thalassemia patient without medical care
answer:
Life Span of Beta Thalassemia Patients Without Medical Care

Beta thalassemia, particularly thalassemia major, is a severe condition that requires regular medical care to manage. Without appropriate treatment, the life expectancy of patients with beta thalassemia major is significantly reduced. Here are the key points:

  • Patients with thalassemia major typically do not survive beyond 5-10 years without treatment [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].
  • If a chronic transfusion regimen is not started, patients with thalassemia major usually die within the first few years of life from high-output heart failure [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=26].
  • In most countries with medium and high-disease prevalence, patients with beta thalassemia major do not reach the age of 20 years due to suboptimal care [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].
  • Untreated children with beta thalassemia major have a very poor quality of life and most will die at a very young age [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=22].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: management for beta that minor
answer:
Management for Beta Thalassemia Minor

Beta thalassemia minor is generally a mild condition, but proper management is essential to ensure a good quality of life and to prevent complications. Here are the key management strategies:

Regular Monitoring

  • Complete Blood Count (CBC): Regular CBC tests to monitor hemoglobin levels and other blood parameters [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Iron Studies: Periodic iron studies, including serum ferritin levels, to rule out iron deficiency and monitor iron levels [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=35].
  • Physical Examination: Regular physical exams to assess for any signs of complications or changes in clinical status [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].

Diet and Lifestyle

  • Balanced Diet: Maintain a balanced diet rich in vitamins and minerals. Avoid iron-rich foods if there is a risk of iron overload [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=27].
  • Folic Acid Supplementation: Folic acid supplements may be recommended to support red blood cell production [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=26].
  • Regular Exercise: Engage in regular physical activity to maintain overall health and well-being [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Medical Interventions

  • Blood Transfusions: Blood transfusions may be necessary in cases of acute exacerbation of anemia, typically when hemoglobin levels drop below 70 g/L or when there are accompanying symptoms of anemia [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=35].
  • Iron Chelation Therapy: Although rare, iron chelation therapy may be required if there is significant iron overload due to frequent transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Splenectomy: Splenectomy is rarely needed but may be considered in cases of an oversized spleen causing discomfort or other complications [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

Multidisciplinary Care

  • Specialized Care: Management should involve a multidisciplinary team of experienced physicians and nurses working in specialized centers. Patients treated in peripheral centers should benefit from a networking process with a center of expertise for periodic reassessment [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Vitamina k
answer:
Vitamina K

La vitamina K è un gruppo di composti liposolubili essenziali per varie funzioni corporee. Esiste in due forme principali:

  • Vitamina K1 (Fillochinone): Presente principalmente nelle verdure a foglia verde, nei semi di soia, negli oli di soia, nelle noci, nei semi e in alcuni frutti. È la forma principale della vitamina nelle diete occidentali.
  • Vitamina K2 (Menachinone): Prodotta dai batteri e presente negli alimenti fermentati, nei cibi in salamoia e in alcune fonti animali come uova e formaggi. Ha una vita media più lunga nel corpo.

Funzioni della Vitamina K

La vitamina K è cruciale per:

  • La carbossilazione dell'acido glutammico nelle proteine della cascata della coagulazione, che attiva il processo di coagulazione.
  • La carbossilazione dei residui di acido glutammico nell'osteocalcina, una proteina integrale per la formazione delle ossa.
  • La riduzione della calcificazione vascolare attraverso la proteina Gla della matrice.
  • Agire come "chaperone del calcio", permettendo il deposito sicuro del calcio nelle ossa e prevenendo il deposito nelle arterie.

Fonti Alimentari

Fonte Alimentare, Quantità Vitamina K1, ug
Cavolo riccio, bollito 1/2 tazza 530
Spinaci, crudi 1 tazza 145
Broccoli, bolliti, 1/2 tazza 110
Olio di soia, 1 cucchiaio 25
Pignoli, 1 oncia 15
Anacardi, 1 oncia 10
Fonte Alimentare, Quantità Vitamina K2, ug
Natto, 1 cucchiaio (MK-7) 150
Petto di pollo, 3 once (MK-4) 13
Formaggio cheddar, 50 grammi (MK-4) 12
Uovo, sodo, 1 (MK-4) 4

Considerazioni Speciali

  • Gli individui che assumono anticoagulanti antagonisti della vitamina K (es. warfarin) devono mantenere un'assunzione costante di vitamina K per garantire un controllo efficace dell'anticoagulazione.
  • Gli antibiotici, in particolare le cefalosporine, possono ridurre l'assorbimento della vitamina K eliminando i batteri intestinali che producono vitamina K2. La supplementazione può essere necessaria per coloro che assumono antibiotici a lungo termine.
  • Non è stato stabilito un limite massimo per l'assunzione di vitamina K e non sono stati osservati effetti avversi dal consumo eccessivo.

Per ulteriori informazioni, contattare info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Can regular chelation decrease ferritin
answer:
Can Regular Chelation Decrease Ferritin?

Yes, regular chelation therapy can decrease serum ferritin levels. Chelation therapy is effective in managing iron overload by removing excess iron from the body. The effectiveness of chelation therapy in reducing serum ferritin levels depends on the dose, frequency of use, and adherence to the treatment regimen.

For example, a mean daily dose of 42 mg/kg resulted in a small mean decrease in serum ferritin over one year, whereas a dose of 51 mg/kg resulted in a decrease of approximately 1,000 µg/l [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=76].

It is important to tailor the chelation regimen to the individual patient's clinical situation and to adjust the dose as serum ferritin or liver iron levels fall to avoid over-chelation and its associated side effects [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=47].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Diagnosis and management of alloimmunization
answer:
Diagnosis and Management of Alloimmunization in Thalassaemia

Diagnosis

Alloimmunization occurs in 10-20% of patients with thalassaemia and is more common in children who begin transfusion therapy after 1-3 years of age. The use of extended antigen matched donor blood is effective in reducing the rate of alloimmunization [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=9][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=29].

Delayed transfusion reactions usually occur within 5-14 days of transfusion and are characterized by unexpected levels of anaemia, malaise, and jaundice. These reactions are usually caused by an alloantibody not detectable at the time of transfusion or by the development of a new antibody. A sample should be sent to the blood bank to investigate the presence of a new antibody and to repeat cross-matching of the last administered units [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=9][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=29].

Management

For the clinical management of autoimmune haemolytic anaemia, which is a serious complication usually but not always occurring in patients with alloantibodies, the following treatments are used: steroids, immunosuppressive drugs, intravenous immunoglobulin, and rituximab [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=9][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=29].

To minimize the risk of alloimmunization, it is recommended that patients have extended red cell antigen typing before starting transfusion therapy. This includes at least C, c, D, E, e, and Kell antigens. If the patient is already transfused, antigen typing can be performed using molecular rather than serological testing. All patients with thalassaemia should be transfused with ABO and Rh (C, c, D, E, e) and Kell compatible blood [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=26].

In cases of acute haemolytic reaction, the transfusion should be stopped immediately, and intravenous fluids should be administered to maintain intravascular volume. Diuretics may help to preserve renal function. The identification of the patient and the donor unit should be re-checked, and the blood bank should be alerted to the possibility of an undetected alloantibody [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=48].

Additional Considerations

The risk of alloimmunization is highest in minimally transfused and newly transfused patients, in splenectomized patients, and during pregnancy. The risk can be minimized by extended genotype and antibody screening, and the use of fully-phenotyped matched blood [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=19].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How is thalassemia diagnosed?
answer:
Diagnosis of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia is diagnosed through a combination of laboratory tests and genetic analysis. Here are the key methods used:

Laboratory Tests

  • Complete Blood Count (CBC): This test measures red blood cell indices, including mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and mean corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH) [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=19].
  • Haemoglobin Analysis: Techniques such as High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) and Capillary Electrophoresis (CE) are used to analyze haemoglobin components. These methods provide both qualitative and quantitative analyses [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=18][PreventionVol2_English.pdf#page=47].
  • HbA2 Quantification: This is particularly valuable for identifying β-thalassaemia carriers. Methods include CE, HPLC, and microchromatography [PreventionVol2_English.pdf#page=47].
  • Peripheral Blood Smear: Examination of a stained blood smear can reveal morphological changes such as microcytosis, hypochromia, and anisopoikilocytosis [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=29].

Genetic Testing

  • PCR Methods: Used to detect common mutations in the β-globin gene [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=36].
  • Reverse Dot Blot and Gap-PCR: Preferred methods for detecting deletions in α-thalassaemias [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=36].
  • MLPA: Used for detecting rare or unknown deletions [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=36].
  • DNA Analysis: Essential for definitive diagnosis and differentiation between different types of α-thalassaemia carrier states [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=44].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Wie viel prozent der weltbevölkerung hat a-thalassämie
answer:
Etwa 5% der Weltbevölkerung sind Träger eines defekten Alpha-Thalassämie-Gens, und ungefähr 1 Million Patienten sind weltweit von den verschiedenen Alpha-Thalassämie-Syndromen betroffen [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=10][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=5].

Für weitere Informationen oder spezifische Fragen wenden Sie sich bitte an info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Can we press the filter chamber if we have doubt of any big clot in bag of filter
answer:
Handling Clots in Blood Bags

It is not recommended to press the filter chamber if you suspect a clot in the blood bag. The nurse should check for clots before the transfusion process begins. If a clot is detected, the blood unit should not be used, and a new unit should be obtained. This ensures the safety and efficacy of the blood transfusion process.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: Why people with thalassemia have low TIBC
answer:
Why People with Thalassemia Have Low TIBC

People with thalassemia often have low Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) due to the condition's impact on iron metabolism. Thalassemia is characterized by ineffective erythropoiesis, which leads to an imbalance in iron regulation. This imbalance results in iron overload, as the body absorbs more iron than it needs to compensate for the ineffective production of red blood cells [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=115].

In thalassemia, the liver iron concentration (LIC) is often elevated, reflecting the body's excess iron stores. This excess iron reduces the need for transferrin, the protein that binds and transports iron in the blood, leading to a lower TIBC [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=24].

Additionally, the presence of iron in various organs, such as the pancreas, pituitary, or heart, further indicates iron overload, which is a common complication in thalassemia patients [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=115].

If you need more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How long will I live with thalassemia major?
answer:
Life Expectancy with Thalassaemia Major

Life expectancy for individuals with thalassaemia major has significantly improved with modern medical treatment. In countries that provide optimal treatment, patients can survive into their 50s and beyond. However, without proper treatment, patients typically do not survive beyond 5-10 years.

Proper management includes:

  • Adherence to good practice guidelines and national standards
  • Adequate and safe donor blood supply
  • Monitoring and controlling iron overload
  • Availability and affordability of iron chelating agents
  • Adherence to all treatment modalities
  • Free medical care
  • Monitoring of complications and early response
  • Adequate management of complications
  • Multidisciplinary care in expert centres
  • Psychosocial support and holistic care
  • Recognition of patients' rights

For more detailed information, you can refer to the sources:

  • PreventionVol1_English.pdf
  • TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf
  • HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: how long does it take ot recover from heart failure wiht IV desferal
answer:
Recovery from Heart Failure with IV Desferal

Continuous intravenous (IV) doses of Desferal (Desferrioxamine) at 50-60 mg/kg/day can normalize left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) over three months [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=77].

Reversal of heart failure can occur within a few weeks of starting continuous DFO therapy, although this will not succeed in all cases. Early intervention is critical for the best outcomes [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=45].

Sources

  • TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf
  • TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf

question: which region of the world is most affected by thalassemia?
answer:
Regions Most Affected by Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia is most prevalent in the following regions:

  • Southeast Asia
  • Southern China
  • The Middle East
  • Mediterranean countries
  • North and Central Africa

These areas have high carrier frequencies due to the historical presence of malaria, which led to genetic adaptations providing resistance to the disease.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the sources:

  • TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3
  • TDT 4TH EDITION
  • AlphaThalGuidelines
  • NTDT-final-combined
  • ThalCarrierCheck

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Apakah ada efek samping dari transfusi darah yang perlu diperhatikan?
answer:
Efek Samping dari Transfusi Darah pada Bayi dengan Thalassaemia

Transfusi darah adalah pengobatan yang sangat penting bagi bayi dengan thalassaemia mayor, namun ada beberapa efek samping yang perlu diperhatikan. Berikut adalah beberapa efek samping yang mungkin terjadi:

1. Overload Besi

Transfusi darah yang berulang dapat menyebabkan penumpukan zat besi dalam tubuh, yang dapat merusak organ-organ seperti hati, jantung, dan pankreas. Hal ini dapat menyebabkan komplikasi seperti diabetes, gangguan pertumbuhan, dan masalah endokrin lainnya [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40][HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

2. Reaksi Transfusi Akut

Reaksi transfusi akut dapat terjadi segera setelah transfusi dan dapat mencakup:

  • Reaksi hemolitik akut: disebabkan oleh ketidakcocokan ABO, gejalanya termasuk sesak napas, nyeri dada, demam, menggigil, nyeri punggung, hipotensi, dan gagal ginjal [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=47].
  • Reaksi anafilaktik: disebabkan oleh defisiensi IgA kongenital, gejalanya termasuk kemerahan kulit, gatal-gatal, sesak napas, muntah, diare, nyeri dada, hipertensi, kehilangan kesadaran, dan syok [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=47].
  • Kontaminasi bakteri (sepsis): disebabkan oleh bakteri dalam darah yang ditransfusikan, gejalanya termasuk demam, menggigil, muntah, diare, hipotensi, syok, gagal ginjal, dan DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=47].
  • Kelebihan sirkulasi: disebabkan oleh transfusi yang terlalu cepat, gejalanya termasuk sesak napas, sianosis, dan peningkatan tekanan sistolik [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=47].

3. Reaksi Imunologis

Reaksi imunologis seperti alloimunisasi dapat terjadi, di mana tubuh mengembangkan antibodi terhadap sel darah merah yang ditransfusikan, membuat transfusi berikutnya lebih sulit [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=26].

4. Komplikasi Endokrin

Komplikasi endokrin seperti hipogonadisme, hipotiroidisme, dan diabetes mellitus lebih sering terjadi pada pasien dengan thalassaemia yang bergantung pada transfusi. Hal ini terutama disebabkan oleh penumpukan zat besi di organ-organ endokrin [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40].

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut, Anda dapat menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Tif can work in pakistan
answer:
Can TIF Work in Pakistan?

Yes, the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) can work in Pakistan. TIF is a global organization with members from 64 countries, including developing countries. It collaborates closely with national thalassaemia associations and healthcare providers to promote the quality of care for patients with haemoglobin disorders, including thalassaemia.

TIF's mission is to ensure equal access to quality health care for every patient with thalassaemia worldwide. They work in official relations with the World Health Organization (WHO) and have a significant presence in many countries, including those with developing economies [HbDisordersCOVID-19_Classification-of-Risk-Groups_V4.pdf#page=4][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=116].

For more specific information or assistance regarding TIF's activities in Pakistan, you can contact them at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins, which are essential components of hemoglobin. The severity of thalassaemia can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Thalassaemia

  • α-thalassaemia: Occurs when genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • β-thalassaemia: Occurs when similar genetic defects affect the production of the β-globin protein. This type is further classified into thalassaemia major and thalassaemia minor.

[HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf]

Genetic Mutations and Their Impact

More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe. The severity of the condition can be influenced by the specific mutations and their interactions:

  • Homozygosity or compound heterozygosity for mild β-thalassaemia mutations can result in thalassaemia intermedia.
  • Severe β-thalassaemia mutations can lead to thalassaemia major, but the presence of ameliorating factors such as co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or increased HbF production can reduce severity.

[Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf]

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

Several genetic factors can ameliorate the severity of thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia can reduce the imbalance between α- and β-chains, leading to a milder form of the disease.
  • Increased production of γ-globin chains and HbF can partially correct the imbalance, reducing disease severity.
  • Specific mutations, such as deletional and non-deletional hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH), can result in higher HbF levels and milder phenotypes.

[2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf][PreventionVol1_English.pdf]

Examples of Specific Mutations

β++ Mutations β+ Mutations β0 Mutations
-101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
C39

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf]

Conclusion

The genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity are complex and influenced by various factors. Genetic counseling is recommended for individuals at risk to understand the potential outcomes and management options.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Can i became pregnant if i am delta beta thalassemia patient?
answer:
Pregnancy and Delta Beta Thalassemia

Yes, it is possible for women with delta beta thalassemia to become pregnant. Fertility is usually preserved in patients with non-transfusion-dependent thalassemia (NTDT), including delta beta thalassemia [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=88][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=92]. However, there are several considerations and potential complications to be aware of:

Potential Complications

  • Increased risk of abortion, pre-term delivery, and intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=88][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=92].
  • Higher likelihood of requiring Caesarean section delivery [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=88][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=92].
  • Thromboembolic events and the need for splenectomy may be common [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=88][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=92].
  • Exacerbation of anemia during pregnancy, often necessitating blood transfusions to maintain hemoglobin levels above 10 g/dL for optimal fetal development [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=88][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=92].

Management During Pregnancy

Pregnant women with delta beta thalassemia should be closely monitored by a multidisciplinary team, including obstetricians, hematologists, and other specialists. Key management strategies include:

  • Regular blood transfusions to manage anemia and support fetal growth [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=88][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=92].
  • Monitoring for and managing potential complications such as thromboembolic events [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=38].
  • Ensuring adequate prenatal care and monitoring fetal development closely [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=88][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=92].

For more detailed information or specific concerns, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What is the age of the blood transfusion for thalassemia patients?
answer:
Age of Blood for Transfusion in Thalassemia Patients

Patients with thalassemia should receive transfusions of packed red cells that are preferably not more than 7 days old. Even when nutrients are added to the stored blood, it is recommended that packed red cells should not be more than two weeks old. This is because there are no reliable studies confirming that red blood cells stored for longer periods are as beneficial in the treatment of thalassemia major as those kept for shorter periods.

Source: AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf

question: هل هناك إصدارات أخرى متاحة باللغة العربية؟
answer:
إصدارات أخرى باللغة العربية

نعم، هناك العديد من الإصدارات المتاحة باللغة العربية. يمكنك العثور على هذه الإصدارات من خلال زيارة موقع الاتحاد الدولي للثلاسيميا (TIF) على الرابط التالي: thalassaemia.org.cy أو عبر تطبيق TIF Digital Library.

بعض الإصدارات المتاحة تشمل:

  • دليل إدارة الثلاسيميا المعتمدة على نقل الدم
  • دليل إدارة الثلاسيميا غير المعتمدة على نقل الدم
  • الوقاية من الثلاسيميا واضطرابات الهيموغلوبين الأخرى
  • دليل الطوارئ لإدارة الثلاسيميا

للمزيد من المعلومات حول الإصدارات المتاحة، يمكنك التواصل مع الاتحاد عبر البريد الإلكتروني: thalassaemia@cytanet.com.cy.

المصدر: Thalassaemia International Federation

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. There are more than 200 known ß-thalassaemia mutations, which can result in a wide range of phenotypic severities, from silent to very severe forms of the disorder [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

Types of Mutations

ß++ Mutations ß+ Mutations ß0 Mutations
-101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
C39

These mutations can interact in various ways to produce different forms of thalassaemia, ranging from thalassaemia intermedia to thalassaemia major [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].

Factors Affecting Severity

The severity of thalassaemia is influenced by several genetic factors:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the imbalance between α- and ß-chains, leading to a milder form of the disease [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Increased synthesis of γ-chains: This results in higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can ameliorate the severity of the disease [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].
  • Specific mutations: For example, the mild ß+-type mutation -88 (C->T) generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype, while the Cap+1 (A->C) mutation can result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

Overall, the interaction between different mutations and genetic factors makes it challenging to predict the exact clinical outcome for each individual case [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=100].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Unfortunately, the specific date for the next Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) conference is not mentioned in the provided sources. For the most accurate and up-to-date information, please contact TIF directly at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the disorder can vary widely depending on the specific mutations involved and their interactions. Here are some key points:

Types of Mutations

  • More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Examples of severe (β0), less severe (β+), and mild (β++) mutations include:
    β++ mutations β+ mutations β0 mutations
    -101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
    IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
    IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
    C39
    [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Impact on Severity

  • The severity of homozygous β-thalassaemia can be influenced by ameliorating factors such as the co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or gene modifiers that increase Hb F production [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • For example, the mild β+-type mutation -88 (C->T) generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype in patients homozygous for this mutation [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Conversely, the mild β+-thalassaemia mutation Cap+1 (A->C) has been reported to result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Patients with thalassaemia major require regular blood transfusions, while those with thalassaemia intermedia may survive with occasional or no transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].

Additional Genetic Factors

  • Decreased synthesis of α-chains can reduce the severity of the disease by balancing the α- and β-chains [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].
  • Increased synthesis of γ-chains can lead to higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can ameliorate the clinical outcome [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources provided or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What’s the best hemoglobin lvl for a thalassemia beta nano?
answer:
Optimal Hemoglobin Level for Beta Thalassaemia Intermedia

For patients with beta thalassaemia intermedia (also referred to as beta thalassaemia minor or non-transfusion dependent thalassaemia), the optimal hemoglobin level is generally maintained between 90-120 g/L. This range helps to minimize complications such as growth failure, iron overload, and other related issues.

Specifically, maintaining a hemoglobin level of ≥10 g/dL has been associated with a lower risk of morbidity and better overall survival outcomes.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • TDT Guide 2022
  • TIF Guidelines for NTDT

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

The symptoms and complications of thalassaemia can vary depending on the type and severity of the condition. Common symptoms include:

  • Severe anaemia
  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

If thalassaemia is left untreated or suboptimally treated, it can lead to serious complications, including:

  • Cardiac complications such as heart failure and arrhythmias
  • Liver complications including cirrhosis and liver failure
  • Endocrine complications like diabetes and growth failure
  • Iron overload, which can cause damage to major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58]

For more information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Contact Information

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Jeg vil gerne være gravid og tager exjade. Hvad gør jeg?
answer:
Graviditet og Exjade (Deferasirox)

Det er vigtigt at være forsigtig, når du planlægger graviditet og tager Exjade (Deferasirox). Her er nogle vigtige overvejelser:

  • Deferasirox bør ikke anvendes under graviditet, medmindre det vurderes som absolut nødvendigt af din behandlende læge. Der er begrænset data om sikkerheden ved brug af Deferasirox under graviditet [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=75].
  • Der er rapporteret om normale graviditeter hos patienter med beta-thalassæmi major, der modtager jernkeleringsterapi med Deferasirox, men det er vigtigt at overvåge nøje og konsultere din læge [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=75].
  • Det anbefales at diskutere alternative behandlingsmuligheder med din læge, som kan være mere sikre under graviditet [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=110].

Kontakt din læge for at få en personlig vurdering og rådgivning om, hvordan du bedst kan håndtere din behandling under graviditet.

Kilde: Thalassaemia International Federation

question: What should my pre-transfusion hgb be kept at?
answer:
Pre-Transfusion Hemoglobin Levels

For most patients, a pre-transfusion hemoglobin (Hb) target of 80-90 g/L is acceptable. However, patients with a high proportion of circulating HbH and those with ineffective erythropoiesis may require higher pre-transfusion hemoglobin targets [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=181].

For patients with cardiac complications, the pre-transfusion hemoglobin should be maintained above 95-105 g/L, or up to 110-120 g/L [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=52].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: when we need to do dna test for Thalassemia
answer:
When to Perform DNA Testing for Thalassaemia

DNA testing for thalassaemia is recommended in the following circumstances:

  • When both individuals in a couple meet the MCV (Mean Corpuscular Volume) or MCH (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin) criteria, they need to be tested for α0-thalassaemia by DNA-based methods, along with Hb analysis, to detect coinheritance of β-thalassaemia carrier and other Hb variants. This is necessary regardless of β-thalassaemia status as coinheritance of α-thalassaemia and β-thalassaemia is common, except for the African population where α+-thalassaemia is common but α0-thalassaemia is rare [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=150][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=157].
  • In some circumstances, DNA tests need to be carried out to determine the presence or absence of the β- or α-thalassaemia trait. Such genetic tests are becoming more widely used to test for the thalassaemia trait [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=139].
  • For prenatal screening of thalassaemia carriers, when both individuals in a couple meet the MCV or MCH criteria, they need to be tested for α0-thalassaemia by DNA-based methods, along with Hb analysis, to detect coinheritance of β-thalassaemia carrier and other Hb variants [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=194].
  • When parents discover after a baby is born that they are carriers, molecular techniques that identify mutations the child has inherited from each parent may be used to diagnose thalassaemia at a very early age [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=32].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Does beta thalassemia trait affect cognitive functioning
answer:
Does Beta Thalassemia Trait Affect Cognitive Functioning?

Yes, beta thalassemia trait (also known as beta thalassemia minor) can affect cognitive functioning. Studies have indicated that individuals with beta thalassemia minor may experience cognitive dysfunction [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=328][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=364]. However, the exact pathology behind this phenomenon is not clearly understood, and cognitive impairment may also be influenced by other factors such as environmental, family, and societal restrictions to education, or stress related to treatment [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=328].

For further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Är generiska kelationsläkemedel lika tillförlitliga som ett varumärke?
answer:
Generiska Kelationsläkemedel

Generiska kelationsläkemedel är skapade för att vara samma som ett befintligt godkänt varumärkesläkemedel i doseringsform, säkerhet, styrka, administreringsväg, kvalitet och prestandaegenskaper [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=11].

Det innebär att generiska kelationsläkemedel är lika tillförlitliga som varumärkesläkemedel, förutsatt att de är korrekt tillverkade och godkända av relevanta myndigheter.

Om du behöver ytterligare hjälp, vänligen kontakta info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: آیا درمان‌های جدید تالاسمی در دسترس همه بیماران قرار دارد؟
answer:
دسترسی به درمان‌های جدید تالاسمی

درمان‌های جدید تالاسمی، مانند Luspatercept-aamt و درمان ژنی با Zynteglo®، امیدهای زیادی برای بهبود کیفیت زندگی بیماران ایجاد کرده‌اند. با این حال، دسترسی به این درمان‌ها برای همه بیماران ممکن است محدود باشد.

محدودیت‌های دسترسی

  • درمان ژنی: درمان ژنی با Zynteglo® تنها برای بیماران خاصی با شرایط مشخص و در محدوده سنی خاصی در دسترس است. این درمان نیاز به زیرساخت‌های پیشرفته و تیم‌های تخصصی دارد که ممکن است در همه کشورها موجود نباشد [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=286][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=122].
  • عامل بلوغ اریتروئید: Luspatercept-aamt نیز به تازگی وارد بازار شده و ممکن است هنوز در همه کشورها در دسترس نباشد. همچنین، هزینه‌های بالای این درمان‌ها می‌تواند مانعی برای دسترسی بیماران باشد [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

درمان‌های سنتی

درمان‌های سنتی مانند انتقال خون منظم و درمان‌های کاهنده آهن همچنان به عنوان روش‌های اصلی درمان تالاسمی در بسیاری از کشورها استفاده می‌شوند. این درمان‌ها به طور گسترده‌تری در دسترس هستند و می‌توانند به بیماران کمک کنند تا زندگی نسبتاً نرمالی داشته باشند [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=23].

برای اطلاعات بیشتر می‌توانید به سایت فدراسیون بین‌المللی تالاسمی مراجعه کنید.

منابع: TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf, TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf, TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf, TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf

سوالات متداول

question: hb e disease is like intermedia?
answer:
Hb E Disease and Thalassaemia Intermedia

Hb E disease itself is generally mild and does not typically resemble thalassaemia intermedia. However, when Hb E is combined with β-thalassaemia trait (Hb E/β-thalassaemia), the clinical picture can vary significantly. This compound heterozygous state can range from a condition similar to thalassaemia major to a mild form of thalassaemia intermedia [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=65].

Clinical Severity of Hb E/β-Thalassaemia

  • Mild: Hb levels remain at 9-12 g/dL. This form does not require treatment and rarely develops clinical problems [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Moderate: Hb levels range from 6-7 g/dL. Clinical symptoms are similar to thalassaemia intermedia. Iron overload may occur, and no regular blood transfusion is required unless there is a complication such as infection. Hepatosplenomegaly and bone changes occur in varying degrees [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Severe: Hb levels may be as low as 4-5 g/dL. Patients are managed as thalassaemia major patients and are typically transfusion-dependent [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].

Conclusion

While Hb E disease alone is not like thalassaemia intermedia, the combination of Hb E and β-thalassaemia trait (Hb E/β-thalassaemia) can present with a clinical severity that ranges from mild thalassaemia intermedia to severe thalassaemia major [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=65][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].

Additional Support

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Are there any patient support groups for thalassaemia in The Netherlands?
answer:
Patient Support Groups for Thalassaemia in The Netherlands

Patient support groups play a crucial role in providing psychosocial support, advocacy, and information for individuals with thalassaemia and their families. Here are some key points about patient support groups and how to find them in The Netherlands:

  • Role of Support Groups: Patient-driven NGOs and support groups are essential in addressing issues of concern to patients and their families, such as patients' rights, quality medical and psychological care, and social integration. These organizations provide unique services and support that may not be available in hospitals and other healthcare settings [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=14][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=258].
  • Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF): The Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) is a non-governmental, patient-driven umbrella organization that supports national thalassaemia associations worldwide. TIF can help connect you with local support groups and provide additional resources [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=2].
  • Networking and Advocacy: TIF has established the Thalassaemia Patient Advocacy Group (T-PAG) for Thalassaemia & Sickle Cell Disease, which includes national and regional groups. These groups work together to advocate for patients' rights and improve care standards [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=316].

To find a patient support group in The Netherlands, you can:

  • Contact the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) for assistance in locating a local support group. You can reach them at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.
  • Search for national patient organizations or associations dedicated to thalassaemia in The Netherlands. These organizations often provide support, resources, and advocacy for patients and their families.

For further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Bagaimana penanganan thalasemia?
answer:
Penanganan Thalasemia

Penanganan thalasemia melibatkan beberapa langkah penting yang harus diikuti secara teratur untuk memastikan kualitas hidup yang baik bagi pasien. Berikut adalah beberapa aspek utama dalam penanganan thalasemia:

Transfusi Darah

Transfusi darah secara teratur adalah metode yang paling efektif untuk mengatasi anemia pada pasien thalasemia mayor. Transfusi ini biasanya dilakukan setiap dua hingga lima minggu untuk menjaga kadar hemoglobin pra-transfusi pada 90-105 g/L. Pada beberapa kondisi medis tertentu, target kadar hemoglobin pra-transfusi yang lebih tinggi mungkin diperlukan [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=26][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

Terapi Kelasi Besi

Terapi kelasi besi diperlukan untuk mengurangi kadar besi berlebih yang terakumulasi dalam tubuh akibat transfusi darah kronis. Ada tiga jenis obat kelasi besi yang digunakan, dua di antaranya diberikan secara oral dan satu melalui injeksi subkutan [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].

Splenektomi

Splenektomi, atau pengangkatan limpa, dilakukan dalam kasus tertentu seperti limpa yang membesar lebih dari 6 cm di bawah margin kostal dan menyebabkan ketidaknyamanan, atau kebutuhan transfusi yang melebihi 200-220 mL/Kg/tahun [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

Perawatan Multidisiplin

Pasien thalasemia harus dirawat di pusat-pusat khusus thalasemia oleh spesialis medis yang bekerja sama dengan profesional kesehatan lainnya untuk memberikan perawatan holistik dan multidisiplin. Ini penting karena thalasemia dapat mempengaruhi hampir semua organ vital tubuh [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

Terapi Gen

Terapi gen adalah pendekatan yang menjanjikan untuk menyembuhkan thalasemia melalui manipulasi genom sel induk hematopoietik. Namun, terapi ini masih dalam tahap pengembangan dan belum tersedia secara luas [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=279].

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut, Anda dapat mengunjungi Thalassaemia International Federation atau menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Are all therapies are eligible for 16 year old bo?
answer:
Therapies for Thalassaemia Major

For a 16-year-old patient with thalassaemia major, the following therapies are available:

Gene Therapy

Gene therapy with Zynteglo™ is approved for young patients aged 12 to 17 years with a β+ genotype who do not have an HLA-compatible sibling donor. This therapy involves the addition of a functional β-globin gene into the patient's stem cells [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=128].

Allogeneic Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT)

HSCT is a curative option for young patients (≤17 years old) with a β+ or βº genotype who have an HLA-compatible sibling or a 10/10 matched volunteer donor. This procedure involves transplanting healthy stem cells from a donor to replace the patient's defective stem cells [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=125][Potentially-Curative-Approaches-for-β-Τhalassaemia.pdf#page=1].

Luspatercept-aamt

Luspatercept-aamt is a novel therapy that helps in the late stages of red blood cell maturation, increasing haemoglobin levels and reducing the frequency of transfusions. This therapy is suitable for patients who require regular blood transfusions [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website or contact us at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Ιατρική ορολογία Δρεπανοκυτταρικής
answer:
Ιατρική Ορολογία Δρεπανοκυτταρικής Αναιμίας

Η δρεπανοκυτταρική αναιμία είναι μια κληρονομική διαταραχή των ερυθρών αιμοσφαιρίων που προκαλείται από την παρουσία ανώμαλης αιμοσφαιρίνης, γνωστής ως αιμοσφαιρίνη S (HbS). Ακολουθούν ορισμένοι βασικοί όροι που σχετίζονται με τη δρεπανοκυτταρική αναιμία:

Βασικοί Όροι

  • Αιμοσφαιρίνη S (HbS): Η πιο κοινή μορφή ανώμαλης αιμοσφαιρίνης που αποτελεί τη βάση της δρεπανοκυτταρικής αναιμίας [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=14].
  • Αιμοσφαιρινοπάθεια: Διαταραχή του αίματος που προκαλείται από γενετικά καθορισμένη αλλαγή στη μοριακή δομή της αιμοσφαιρίνης. Η δρεπανοκυτταρική αναιμία ανήκει στην ευρύτερη οικογένεια των αιμοσφαιρινοπαθειών [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=14].
  • Αιμόλυση: Η διαδικασία καταστροφής των ερυθρών αιμοσφαιρίων [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=14].
  • Αυτοσωμική υπολειπόμενη κληρονομικότητα: Η δρεπανοκυτταρική αναιμία κληρονομείται από τους γονείς μέσω των γονιδίων και επηρεάζει εξίσου άνδρες και γυναίκες [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=76].
  • Απλαστική κρίση: Σταμάτημα της παραγωγής νέων ερυθρών αιμοσφαιρίων λόγω ορισμένων λοιμώξεων [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=15].
  • Οξεία σπληνική εγκλωβισμός: Αιφνίδια διόγκωση του σπλήνα που προκαλεί επιδείνωση της αναιμίας [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=15].
  • Κρίσεις πόνου: Οξείες εξάρσεις πόνου που προκαλούνται από την απόφραξη μικρών αιμοφόρων αγγείων [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=95].
  • Αιμοποιητική μεταμόσχευση βλαστικών κυττάρων (HSCT): Γνωστή και ως μεταμόσχευση μυελού των οστών, είναι η μεταμόσχευση πολυδύναμων αιμοποιητικών βλαστικών κυττάρων [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=14].

Για περισσότερες πληροφορίες, μπορείτε να επικοινωνήσετε με το email info@thalassaemia.org.cy.
