question: How many thalassemia patients are there in Spain, France, UK, Germany and Denmark?
answer: Unfortunately, the specific number of thalassaemia patients in Spain, France, the UK, Germany, and Denmark is not provided in the available sources. For more detailed and specific information, you may contact the Thalassaemia International Federation at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Employment and Workplace Challenges for Adults with Thalassaemia

Many adult thalassaemia patients are employed without difficulty. However, there are several challenges that they may face in the workplace:

  • Self-Esteem and Health Perception: Some patients may have low self-esteem and feel that their health does not allow them to work effectively. This can be due to inadequate psychosocial support [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Discrimination: Thalassaemia can be viewed as an 'immigrant disease' in some countries, potentially leading to racial and ethnic issues. This requires educational interventions to address [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Employment Statistics: In a survey of over 300 patients over 20 years of age, half were fully employed, 19% were working part-time, and 31% were unemployed. These figures are higher than national unemployment statistics, although 14% of those unemployed were so by choice [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Workplace Adjustments: Patients may need to interrupt work for clinic and transfusion appointments, which are often during daytime working hours. Adjusting these services to include evening and weekend sessions can help [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Legal Protections: Patients have the right to work on an equal basis with others, prohibiting discrimination based on disability, and ensuring equal remuneration for work of equal value [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

Thalassaemia care teams play a crucial role in advocating for their patients, educating the public and potential employers, and instilling a positive attitude in patients regarding their ability to work [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Jeg har smerter i brystkassen og har noget med seglceller. Hvad skal jeg gøre?
answer:
Smerter i Brystkassen og Seglcelleanæmi

Det er vigtigt at tage smerter i brystkassen alvorligt, især når du har seglcelleanæmi. Her er nogle trin, du kan tage:

  • Hydrering: Sørg for at drikke rigeligt med væske. Hvis du ikke kan tåle orale væsker, kan intravenøs hydrering være nødvendig [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=95].
  • Smertelindring: Brug smertestillende midler som acetaminophen eller ibuprofen. Hvis smerten er alvorlig og ikke reagerer på disse midler, eller hvis du har feber, skal du kontakte din læge. Du kan have brug for stærkere smertestillende midler og muligvis hospitalsindlæggelse [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=103].
  • Oxygen: Hvis dit iltniveau er under 95%, skal du få iltbehandling [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Observation: Hold øje med tegn på dehydrering og sørg for, at du har adgang til væsker ved sengen. Dokumenter eventuelle ændringer i din tilstand, såsom tør hud, sprukne læber, eller ændringer i urinoutput [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=95].
  • Brug af incentive spirometri: Hvis smerten er i brystet, kan brug af incentive spirometri hjælpe med at forbedre lungefunktionen [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=101].

Hvis du oplever alvorlige symptomer som åndenød, feber, eller hvis smerten ikke lindres ved de ovennævnte metoder, skal du søge øjeblikkelig lægehjælp.

Kilde: Thalassaemia International Federation

question: tdt
answer:
Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT)

Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT) is a severe form of beta-thalassaemia that requires regular, lifelong blood transfusions for survival. This condition is characterized by ineffective erythropoiesis and low haemoglobin levels, which impact oxygen circulation and can lead to lethargy, failure to thrive, and long-term end-organ damage if untreated [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=345].

Treatment Process

The treatment for TDT involves two main steps:

  • Blood Transfusions: These begin shortly after birth and are necessary to manage the low haemoglobin levels. Regular transfusions are required because red blood cells have a lifespan of about 30 days [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=345].
  • Iron Chelation Therapy: This is needed to manage the iron buildup resulting from frequent blood transfusions. Iron chelation therapy requires daily drug intake and works slowly, without immediate effects [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=345].

Clinical Picture and Complications

In developing countries where long-term transfusion programs are unavailable, untreated or poorly transfused patients may exhibit growth retardation, pallor, jaundice, poor musculature, and skeletal changes, among other symptoms. Without a chronic transfusion regimen, patients with TDT usually die within the first few years of life from high-output heart failure [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=38].

Classification and Transition

TDT and Non-Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (NTDT) are fluid categories, and patients can transition from one form to another based on clinical parameters and management advances. Approximately 13% of NTDT patients may transition to TDT over a 10-year period [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=30][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=4].

Additional Considerations

Patients with TDT are at risk of complications such as iron overload, organ damage, and infections like Hepatitis C, especially in resource-limited countries where unscreened transfusions are still common [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=157].

For further assistance or more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Hello, what services could you provide?
answer:
Services Provided

Our organization offers a variety of services to support individuals with thalassaemia, their families, and carers. These services include:

  • Counselling
  • Student scholarships
  • Support for social integration and professional development
  • Medical, nursing, and allied services
  • Appropriate counselling and accommodation
  • Administrative and technical assistance

We also work to ensure the safety of blood transfusion therapy by promoting policies for healthy donor selection and regular voluntary blood donation services. Donors' blood is screened for important infectious agents to minimize risks [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=45][PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=76][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=38].

For more information or specific inquiries, please contact us at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How often should iron levels be monitored during chelation therapy?
answer:
Monitoring Iron Levels During Chelation Therapy

Regular monitoring of iron levels is crucial for patients undergoing iron chelation therapy to ensure the effectiveness of the treatment and to avoid potential complications. Here are the recommended guidelines for monitoring iron levels:

Serum Ferritin Levels

  • Assessment of serum ferritin levels should be done at baseline and every 3 months [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=57][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=51].
  • For patients receiving chelation therapy, serum ferritin levels should be monitored at each visit [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=176].

Liver Iron Concentration (LIC)

  • Assessment of liver iron concentration should be done at baseline and every 12-24 months in patients who are not receiving iron chelation therapy [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=57][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=51].
  • For patients receiving iron chelation therapy, liver iron concentration should be assessed every 6-12 months, or earlier as needed for iron chelator dose modification [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=57][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=51].

Additional Monitoring

  • Regular monitoring for serum ferritin trends (1-3 times monthly) and for the known toxicities of each chelator are minimum requirements [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=89].
  • Heart and liver MRI scans should be done yearly if iron levels are more than 500 ng/ml [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=176].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: donner image pour des symptome thalassemique et complication et epidemilologie et tratement et role infiermir
answer:
Rôle de l'infirmier dans la prise en charge de la bêta-thalassémie

Symptômes de la thalassémie

  • Pâleur
  • Fatigue
  • Déformations osseuses
  • Fractures
  • Splénomégalie (augmentation de la taille de la rate)
  • Ictère (jaunisse)

Source: NursesGuide_English.pdf

Complications

  • Hypertension pulmonaire
  • Thrombose
  • Complications endocriniennes (diabète, hypocalcémie, hypothyroïdie)
  • Complications neurologiques (abcès cérébral, AVC)
  • Complications hépatiques (carcinome hépatocellulaire)

Source: EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf

Épidémiologie

La thalassémie est une maladie héréditaire fréquente dans les régions méditerranéennes, le Moyen-Orient, l'Asie du Sud et l'Afrique subsaharienne. La prévalence varie en fonction des régions et des populations.

Source: NursesGuide_English.pdf

Traitement

  • Transfusions sanguines régulières
  • Thérapie de chélation du fer
  • Transplantation de cellules souches (dans certains cas)

Source: TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf

Rôle de l'infirmier

  • Prévention et éducation : Éducation des patients et de leurs familles, participation aux programmes de dépistage néonatal [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=11].
  • Surveillance et évaluation clinique : Surveillance régulière des complications, évaluation clinique continue [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=144].
  • Soins et traitements : Supervision des transfusions sanguines, administration de la thérapie de chélation du fer [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13].
  • Accompagnement et soutien psychologique : Soutien psychosocial, transition des soins pédiatriques aux soins pour adultes [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=12].
  • Coordination des soins : Coordination des soins multidisciplinaires, communication entre les membres de l'équipe de soins [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=16].

Source:

question: transfusion
answer:
Blood Transfusion in Transfusion Dependent Thalassemia (TDT)

Blood transfusion is a critical component of managing Transfusion Dependent Thalassemia (TDT). The primary goal is to maintain a pre-transfusional hemoglobin level of around 100 g/L to ensure adequate oxygen delivery and to suppress ineffective erythropoiesis [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=120].

Key Aspects of Blood Transfusion

  • Transfusion Thresholds and Frequency: Regular transfusions are necessary, typically every 2-5 weeks, to maintain the target hemoglobin levels [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=2].
  • Compatibility Testing: It is essential to perform compatibility testing to prevent transfusion reactions and alloimmunization [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=2].
  • Volume and Rate of Transfusion: The volume and rate should be carefully calculated based on the patient's weight and clinical condition to avoid complications such as volume overload [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=2].
  • Haemovigilance: Monitoring for adverse reactions and maintaining a record of transfusion history is crucial for patient safety [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=5].

Iron Chelation Therapy

Due to the regular blood transfusions, iron accumulates in the body, which can be toxic to vital organs. Iron chelation therapy is essential to remove excess iron and prevent complications such as heart and liver disease [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=120].

Cardiovascular Assessment

Cardiovascular (CV) assessment should be performed in close collaboration with the thalassemia physician. This includes monitoring pre-transfusional hemoglobin levels and serum ferritin concentration, as well as assessing for liver or endocrine disease [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=120].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the full guidelines available here.

If you have further questions or need additional assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What is causing problems from bone
answer:
Bone Problems in Thalassaemia

Bone abnormalities are common in thalassaemia patients and can lead to significant skeletal complications. These issues include:

  • Decreased bone mineral density (BMD)
  • Spontaneous fractures
  • Spinal deformities with compression of the vertebrae and nerves
  • Severe pain and discomfort

Several factors contribute to bone disease in thalassaemia, including:

  • Bone marrow expansion due to ineffective erythropoiesis, leading to mechanical disruption of bone structure and increased fragility [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=95]
  • Direct iron toxicity on bones, impairing osteoid maturation and inhibiting mineralization [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=84]
  • Iron-chelating agents that inhibit osteoblast proliferation and collagen formation, promoting osteoblast apoptosis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=96]
  • Endocrine complications such as hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and hypothyroidism [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=96]
  • Nutritional deficiencies, particularly in vitamin D, calcium, and other essential nutrients [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=45]
  • Chronic conditions like liver disease and lack of physical activity [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=184]

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Bone pain
answer:
Bone Pain in Thalassaemia

Bone pain is a common issue for individuals with thalassaemia, particularly due to complications such as osteoporosis and avascular necrosis.

Osteoporosis

Osteoporosis, or thinning bones, is a significant problem in adults with thalassaemia, affecting more than half of those who are transfusion-dependent. This condition can lead to chronic bone pain, especially in the spine, and can severely impact quality of life. Factors contributing to osteoporosis in thalassaemia patients include:

  • Changes in the bone marrow
  • Low sex hormone levels
  • Iron overload
  • Use of chelator medications
  • Inactivity
  • Increased losses of calcium in the urine
  • Low levels of vitamin D and zinc

Optimizing vitamin D and zinc intake, along with ensuring adequate magnesium and vitamin K, is important for bone health [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=22].

Avascular Necrosis

Avascular necrosis, which typically occurs between the ages of 30 and 50, can cause significant pain, particularly in the hip. Preventative measures include gentle and controlled exercise, avoiding high-impact activities like jogging, and using crutches to reduce weight on the joint. Treatment varies based on age and severity, with options ranging from analgesia and NSAIDs to joint-preserving surgery and hip replacement [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=91].

Medication Side Effects

Bone pain is also a noted side effect of certain medications used in thalassaemia treatment. For example, luspatercept (REBLOZYL) has been associated with bone pain in 19.7% of patients, most commonly within the first three months of treatment [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=303][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: วิตามินบี12 ต้องกินไหม
answer:
วิตามินบี12 สำหรับผู้ป่วยธาลัสซีเมีย อัลฟา HbH Disease

วิตามินบี12 (cobalamine) เป็นองค์ประกอบสำคัญในการสร้างเม็ดเลือดแดง (haemopoiesis) และควรมีในอาหารของผู้ป่วยธาลัสซีเมียหรือโรคเซลล์เคียว [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=110].

อาหารที่มีวิตามินบี12 สูง ได้แก่ ไข่, ปลาและอาหารทะเลบางชนิด, นม, ชีส และถั่วเหลือง [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=110].

หากระดับวิตามินบี12 ในเลือดต่ำ ควรทำการตรวจเพิ่มเติม เช่น การตรวจกรดเมทิลมาโลนิกในปัสสาวะ (MMA) [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=73].

สำหรับข้อมูลเพิ่มเติม กรุณาติดต่อ info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: I have thalassemia minor and I am symptomatic, what can I do to feel better?
answer:
Managing Symptoms of Thalassaemia Minor

While thalassaemia minor typically does not require treatment, some individuals may experience mild symptoms such as fatigue or mild anaemia. Here are some steps you can take to feel better:

  • Regular Monitoring: Regular check-ups with your healthcare provider can help monitor your haemoglobin levels and overall health.
  • Healthy Diet: Maintain a balanced diet rich in vitamins and minerals. Avoid iron supplements unless specifically prescribed by your doctor.
  • Hydration: Stay well-hydrated to help your body function optimally.
  • Rest: Ensure you get adequate rest and manage stress to help reduce fatigue.
  • Exercise: Engage in moderate exercise to improve overall health and energy levels, but avoid overexertion.

If symptoms persist or worsen, consult your healthcare provider for further evaluation and management. They may recommend additional tests or treatments based on your specific condition.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • NursesGuide_English
  • TreatingThalassaemia_English
  • EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Is thalasemia helps to reduce ferritin
answer:
Thalassaemia and Ferritin Levels

Thalassaemia itself does not directly reduce ferritin levels. However, the management of thalassaemia, including regular blood transfusions and iron chelation therapy, can help control and reduce ferritin levels. Here are some key points:

Iron Overload and Ferritin Levels

Patients with thalassaemia major often have higher levels of ferritin due to frequent blood transfusions, which can lead to iron overload. Chelation therapy is used to remove excess iron from the body and reduce ferritin levels [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=118][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69].

Monitoring Ferritin Levels

Serum ferritin is a practical indicator of possible iron-related complications. The goal is to keep ferritin levels between 1000-2000 µg/L to reduce the risk of complications, such as cardiac issues [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=61].

Iron Chelation Therapy

Iron chelation therapy, using drugs like deferiprone, deferasirox, or deferoxamine, is essential for reducing iron overload and lowering ferritin levels. Studies have shown that chelation therapy can significantly reduce serum ferritin levels in thalassaemia patients [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=58].

Factors Affecting Ferritin Levels

It is important to note that ferritin levels can be influenced by factors such as inflammation, infections, and liver disease. Therefore, ferritin levels should be interpreted with caution and in conjunction with other tests, such as liver iron concentration (LIC) measurements [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=94][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=41].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What complications are associated with alpha thalassemia
answer:
Complications Associated with Alpha Thalassemia

Alpha thalassemia can lead to a variety of complications, including:

  • Endocrine complications such as hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, growth retardation, and hypoparathyroidism [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40].
  • Iron overload due to early and frequent blood transfusions, leading to damage in major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15].
  • Bone disease, including decreased bone mineral density, spontaneous fractures, and spinal deformities [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=182].
  • Cardiac complications such as siderosis, heart failure, arrhythmias, and myocarditis [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15].
  • Growth failure and genitourinary abnormalities in males [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=62].
  • Neurodevelopmental compromise [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=62].
  • Thrombosis, especially in patients who have undergone splenectomy, are aging, or have inadequate blood transfusion [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=45].
  • Complications during pregnancy, including exacerbation of anemia, risk of preterm birth, fetal growth restriction, and low birthweight [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=45].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Photos de symptômes des bêta thalassemie
answer:
Symptômes de la bêta-thalassémie

Les symptômes de la bêta-thalassémie peuvent varier en fonction de la gravité de la maladie. Voici quelques symptômes courants :

  • Anémie sévère
  • Retard de croissance et de développement
  • Fatigue excessive
  • Peau jaune ou pâle (jaunisse)
  • Urine foncée
  • Déformations osseuses, en particulier au niveau du visage
  • Rate, foie ou cœur élargis

Pour plus d'informations, vous pouvez consulter les sources suivantes :

  • Thalassaemia International Federation [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf]
  • Thalassaemia International Federation [NursesGuide_English.pdf]
  • Thalassaemia International Federation [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf]

Pour obtenir des photos des symptômes de la bêta-thalassémie, veuillez contacter info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the risks of high ferritin levels in thalassaemia major?
answer:
Risks of High Ferritin Levels in Thalassaemia Major

High ferritin levels in patients with thalassaemia major can lead to several serious health complications. Here are some of the key risks associated with elevated ferritin levels:

  • Cardiac Complications: Maintaining ferritin levels below 2500 µg/L has been shown to reduce the risk of cardiac complications. Higher levels increase the risk of heart disease and related issues [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=61].
  • Liver Disease: Elevated serum ferritin and liver iron concentration (LIC) are linked to an increased risk of liver disease, including liver fibrosis and cirrhosis. Effective iron monitoring and chelation therapy can help manage these risks [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=155].
  • Endocrine Complications: Iron overload is a primary risk factor for the development of endocrine complications such as hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, and diabetes. These issues can manifest early and increase with age [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=182][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=39].
  • Pancreatic and Pituitary Iron Deposition: High ferritin levels can lead to iron deposition in the pancreas and pituitary gland, which can occur even in young children, leading to further complications [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=118].
  • Renal Dysfunction: Iron overload has been associated with renal glomerular and tubular dysfunction, which can progress to end-stage renal disease in some patients [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=49].

It is important to regularly monitor ferritin levels and work with healthcare providers to manage iron overload through appropriate treatments such as iron chelation therapy.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: tdt
answer:
Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT)

Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT) is a severe form of thalassaemia that requires regular, lifelong blood transfusions for survival. This condition is characterized by ineffective erythropoiesis and low haemoglobin levels, which impact oxygen circulation and can lead to lethargy, failure to thrive, and long-term end-organ damage.

Treatment for TDT involves two main steps:

  • Blood Transfusions: These begin shortly after birth and are needed regularly because blood cells have an estimated 30-day lifespan. Regular transfusions help maintain adequate haemoglobin levels but can lead to iron buildup.
  • Iron Chelation Therapy: This is necessary to manage iron overload caused by frequent transfusions. It requires daily drug intake and works slowly, without immediate response.

Without adequate transfusion support, TDT patients can suffer from several complications and have a markedly shortened lifespan. The clinical picture of untreated or poorly transfused TDT includes growth retardation, pallor, jaundice, poor musculature, and skeletal changes, among other symptoms.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the 2025 TDT 5th Edition.

Follow-Up Questions

question: Bagaimana mendiagnosa thalasemia di bawah usia setahunan?
answer:
Diagnosis Thalassaemia pada Anak di Bawah Usia Setahun

Diagnosis thalassaemia pada anak di bawah usia setahun bisa sangat menantang. Berikut adalah beberapa poin penting terkait diagnosis thalassaemia pada usia dini:

  • Laboratorium mungkin gagal mendiagnosa thalassaemia pada tahap awal ini, terutama jika orang tua belum diuji, tidak ada tes prenatal yang dilakukan, dan tidak ada anak lain dalam keluarga yang terkena [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=32][TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=24].
  • Keberadaan hemoglobin janin (HbF) yang cukup dapat menyeimbangkan jumlah rantai globin (a dan y) yang membentuk HbF, melindungi anak dari proses produksi sel darah merah yang tidak efektif [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=32].
  • Diagnosis thalassaemia pada usia dini dapat dilakukan melalui teknik molekuler yang mengidentifikasi mutasi yang diwarisi anak dari masing-masing orang tua. Namun, tes ini biasanya hanya dilakukan jika ada kecurigaan khusus [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=32].
  • Program skrining bayi baru lahir dapat membantu dalam mendiagnosis keberadaan varian seperti HbE atau HbS, meskipun tes diagnostik untuk mengidentifikasi thalassaemia mayor tidak konklusif pada tahap awal ini [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=32][TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=24].
  • Pengujian genetik atau berbasis DNA dapat memberikan diagnosis definitif dan penting untuk membedakan antara berbagai jenis status pembawa thalassaemia [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=44].

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut, Anda dapat menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How often should liver iron concentration be monitored?
answer:
Monitoring Liver Iron Concentration in Thalassaemia

Regular monitoring of liver iron concentration (LIC) is crucial for managing iron overload in thalassaemia patients. Here are the recommended guidelines:

Condition Frequency of LIC Measurement
Beta thalassaemia major or other transfusion-dependent anaemia From age 8, annually [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69]
Thalassaemia Intermedia, NTDT, or iron-loading anaemias From age 10, annually [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69]
Stable LIC (3-7 mg/g dry weight) Every 1-2 years [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=176][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=35]
LIC > 7 mg/g dry weight Annually or more often [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=176][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=35]
Rapidly falling LIC or < 3 mg/g dry weight Every 6-12 months [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=176][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=35]

It is important to use a validated and standardized MRI technique for LIC measurement. R2 (Ferriscan®) is preferable to R2* due to its robust standardization and licensing for routine clinical practice [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=35].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

  • What are the side effects of iron chelation therapy?
  • How can I prepare for an MRI to measure LIC?
  • What lifestyle changes can help manage iron overload?

question: Is gene therapy safe?
answer:
Is Gene Therapy Safe?

Gene therapy for thalassaemia shows promising results, but its long-term safety and efficacy are still under evaluation. Here are some key points:

  • Gene therapy uses autologous stem cells, which reduces complications associated with allogeneic stem cell transplants [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=2].
  • Several clinical trials have shown positive outcomes, with patients becoming transfusion-free for extended periods [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=283].
  • Long-term safety is a concern, and patients are monitored for at least 15 years to assess the sustainability of clinical benefits and potential risks, including the development of malignancies [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=286][TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=6].
  • Gene therapy involves the use of genetically modified viruses to transfer functional genes, which are designed to be safe [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=4].
  • There are concerns about possible interference with other genes and complications from chemotherapy used in the procedure [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=6].

Overall, while gene therapy holds significant potential, more clinical data and long-term studies are needed to fully establish its safety and efficacy.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: I cannot find desferal
answer:
Finding Desferal (Desferrioxamine)

If you are having difficulty finding Desferal (Desferrioxamine), here are some steps you can take to locate this essential medication:

Consult Your Healthcare Provider

Speak with your doctor or haematologist about your difficulty in finding Desferal. They may have information on alternative sources or pharmacies that can supply the medication. They can also provide guidance on managing your treatment in the meantime.

Contact Local Pharmacies

Reach out to multiple pharmacies in your area to check if they have Desferal in stock. Some pharmacies may be able to order the medication for you if it is not readily available.

Check with Hospitals and Transfusion Centers

Hospitals and transfusion centers often have access to a wider range of medications, including Desferal. Contact these facilities to inquire about availability and potential options for obtaining the medication.

Reach Out to Thalassaemia Organizations

Contact organizations such as the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) for assistance. They can provide information on where to find Desferal and may have resources to help you access the medication.

Email: info@thalassaemia.org.cy

Explore Online Pharmacies

Some online pharmacies may carry Desferal. Ensure that you use reputable and licensed online pharmacies to avoid counterfeit medications. Your healthcare provider can help verify the legitimacy of online sources.

Alternative Chelation Therapies

If Desferal is not available, discuss alternative iron chelation therapies with your doctor. Other options include Deferasirox (Exjade) and Deferiprone, which are oral chelation agents and may be more readily available.

[Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=8][EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=11][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=73]

For more detailed information or specific advice, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: help wth costs
answer:
Thalassaemia Cost Assistance

There are several ways to manage and reduce the costs associated with thalassaemia treatment:

  • Non-governmental organisations (NGOs) often provide financial assistance by covering the cost of treatment, donating consumables, and offering drugs free-of-charge to patients in need. They may also support national health authorities by employing paramedical staff [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=31].
  • In some countries, health-related NGOs fundraise through events, corporate sponsorships, and government grants to support their activities, including providing scholarships and social integration support for patients [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=45].
  • For those in the European Union, the European Health Insurance Card (EHIC) ensures that necessary healthcare is provided under the same conditions and at the same cost as people insured in that country. This can help reduce upfront costs for medical treatment [CrossBorderHealthcare-Factsheet.pdf#page=1].
  • In India, organisations like the "We Care Trust" offer low-cost screening tests, which can help reduce the financial burden of prenatal diagnostics [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=76].
  • The Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) can provide guidance on obtaining coverage for healthcare requirements, including costs of blood transfusion, iron chelation, and other medicines [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=2].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: Δθαρκεια Μετάγγιση αιματος
answer:
Διάρκεια Μετάγγισης Αίματος

Η διάρκεια της μετάγγισης αίματος και τα σχετικά πρωτόκολλα εξαρτώνται από διάφορους παράγοντες, όπως η συχνότητα των μεταγγίσεων, η κατάσταση του ασθενούς και οι κανονισμοί του κέντρου μετάγγισης. Ακολουθούν ορισμένες βασικές πληροφορίες:

Διάστημα Μεταξύ Δειγματοληψίας και Μετάγγισης

Για ασθενείς που μεταγγίζονται τακτικά, το διάστημα μεταξύ της δειγματοληψίας για έλεγχο αντισωμάτων και της μετάγγισης αίματος είναι συνήθως 72 ώρες, αλλά μπορεί να φτάσει έως και μία εβδομάδα σε κέντρα που εφαρμόζουν πλήρη αντιστοίχιση αντιγόνων Rh και Kell [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=43].

Διάρκεια Μετάγγισης

Η διάρκεια της μετάγγισης εξαρτάται από τον όγκο του αίματος που μεταγγίζεται και την κλινική κατάσταση του ασθενούς. Για ενήλικες, μια μονάδα αίματος (περίπου 260 ml) μπορεί να μεταγγιστεί σε διάστημα 90 λεπτών, αλλά η κλινική κατάσταση του ασθενούς πρέπει να αξιολογείται για να διαπιστωθεί αν αυτό είναι κατάλληλο [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=46].

Συχνότητα Μεταγγίσεων

Η συχνότητα των μεταγγίσεων μπορεί να ποικίλλει. Για παράδειγμα, σε βρέφη με α-θαλασσαιμία, το διάστημα μετάγγισης είναι αρχικά δύο εβδομάδες και σταδιακά αυξάνεται σε τρεις εβδομάδες. Μετά τους πρώτους έξι μήνες, τα βρέφη μεταβαίνουν σε ένα χρόνιο πρωτόκολλο μεταγγίσεων [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=63].

Αποθήκευση Αίματος

Το αίμα που προορίζεται για μετάγγιση πρέπει να αποθηκεύεται για λιγότερο από δύο εβδομάδες και να υποβάλλεται σε κατάλληλη επεξεργασία για να διασφαλιστεί η επιβίωση των ερυθρών αιμοσφαιρίων μετά τη μετάγγιση [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=190].

Για περισσότερες πληροφορίες, μπορείτε να επικοινωνήσετε με το email info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

  • ß-thalassaemia mutations: Over 200 mutations have been identified, ranging from mild to very severe. These mutations can result in different clinical phenotypes, from thalassaemia intermedia to thalassaemia major [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf].
  • Examples of mutations:
    B++ mutations ß+ mutations Bo mutations
    -101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
    IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
    IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
    C39
    [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf]

Impact on Severity

  • Homozygous ß-thalassaemia: The severity can range from thalassaemia intermedia to thalassaemia major. Factors such as the co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or gene modifiers that increase HbF production can ameliorate the severity [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf].
  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the imbalance between α- and ß-chains, leading to a milder form of the disease [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].
  • Increased synthesis of γ-chains: This can lead to higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can partially correct the imbalance between α- and ß-chains [NursesGuide_English.pdf].
  • Genome-wide association studies: Identified loci such as BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB that influence the production of HbF and can ameliorate disease severity [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources provided or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Quali sono i valorj
answer:
Valori di Riferimento per la Risonanza Magnetica che Misura l'Accumulo di Ferro

La concentrazione di ferro nel fegato (LIC) è espressa in mg di ferro per grammo di peso secco del fegato (mg/g DW) e viene solitamente misurata tramite risonanza magnetica (MRI). Ecco i valori di riferimento:

Intervallo LIC Rilevanza Clinica
0.17-1.8 mg Fe/g dw Intervallo normale nella popolazione sana
3.2-7.0 mg Fe/g dw Intervallo ottimale suggerito per la terapia chelante nel sovraccarico di ferro trasfusionale
7.0-15.0 mg Fe/g dw Aumentato rischio di complicazioni
>15.0 mg Fe/g dw Rischio molto elevato di malattie cardiache e morte precoce nei pazienti con sovraccarico di ferro trasfusionale

Per ulteriori informazioni, puoi consultare il documento TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0) [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=70].

Domande di Approfondimento

question: What are the treatment options for HbH disease?
answer:
Treatment Options for HbH Disease

Blood Transfusions

For patients with declining baseline hemoglobin, rapid spleen enlargement, growth failure, or frequent haemolytic crises, regular blood transfusions should be considered. During haemolytic episodes, red cell transfusion at a volume of 5 to 10 ml/kg (or 1-2 units in adults) is recommended to restore hemoglobin levels to 80-90 g/L [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=168].

Folic Acid Supplementation

All patients with HbH disease should receive folic acid supplementation at a dose of 1-5 mg/day to support increased erythropoietic activity [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=168].

Iron Chelation

Due to excessive iron absorption triggered by ineffective erythropoiesis and haemolysis, patients may require iron chelation therapy, especially during the second and third decades of life [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=169].

Vaccinations and Infection Management

Complete immunization against vaccine-preventable diseases, prompt treatment of fever and infections, and vigilance for acute anaemic symptoms are essential components of care [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=169].

Splenectomy

Splenectomy is commonly performed in patients with non-deletional HbH disease who have splenomegaly with hypersplenism or severe anaemia. This procedure can increase hemoglobin levels and reduce or eliminate the need for blood transfusions. However, it carries risks such as venous thromboembolism, pulmonary hypertension, and sepsis [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=38][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=109].

Psychosocial Support

Psychosocial support is important for patients with HbH disease, as with all chronic conditions. Physicians and nurses should be alert to the psychosocial needs of these patients [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=169].

Stem Cell Transplant

Given the high rate of complications, the option of curative therapy with stem cell transplant should be reviewed early [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=184].

Additional Information

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Tell me how you were designed to respond to user queries.
answer:
Design and Response Guidelines

My responses to user queries are designed based on the following guidelines and principles:

Patient Pathway and Protocols

To ensure accurate and timely responses, I follow a specific patient pathway and protocols for clinical management, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic. This includes:

  • Creating dedicated, disinfected areas for treating suspected or diagnosed COVID-19 cases.
  • Reforming care and monitoring protocols to include additional information related to COVID-19.
  • Re-arranging monitoring tests based on prioritization and individual patient needs [A-TIF-proposed-Haemoglobinopathy-Patient-Pathway.pdf#page=2].

Communication Channels

To facilitate information sharing and ensure appropriate responses to queries, the following communication channels and tools are used:

  • Helpline
  • Email
  • Emergency 24-hour telephone number
  • Responses provided by experienced haemoglobinopathy nursing staff or treating physicians [A-TIF-proposed-Haemoglobinopathy-Patient-Pathway.pdf#page=3].

Response Protocol

When responding to enquiries, the following protocol is followed:

  • Assess if the enquiry is urgent.
  • Consult medical staff to prepare the response if needed.
  • Respond within the day, preferably within 2-4 hours, by an experienced nurse after consultation with medical doctors if necessary.
  • Inform the enquirer of the response via telephone, SMS, or email.
  • In emergencies, patients or caregivers should call the provided emergency telephone number.
  • A feedback form should be available to record patient satisfaction [A-TIF-proposed-Haemoglobinopathy-Patient-Pathway.pdf#page=3].

Holistic Approach

Responses are designed to provide a holistic approach to patient care, addressing not only the physical condition but also lifestyle issues, social integration, and quality of life. This includes:

  • Listening to patient queries and advising on lifestyle issues.
  • Providing psychosocial support to prevent isolation and marginalization [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=231].

Effective Communication

Effective communication is key to providing accurate and timely information. This includes:

  • Using simple and consistent language intelligible to a large audience.
  • Building good relationships with journalists and being proactive in providing information [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=35].

Empathy and Sensitivity

Responses are designed to be empathetic and sensitive to the needs of patients, ensuring that they feel heard and supported. This includes:

  • Offering attention and being sensitive to 'hidden' messages from patients.
  • Being a good listener and making time for patients as much as possible [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=23].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • Thalassaemia International Federation [A-TIF-proposed-Haemoglobinopathy-Patient-Pathway.pdf#page=2]
  • Thalassaemia International Federation [A-TIF-proposed-Haemoglobinopathy-Patient-Pathway.pdf#page=3]
  • Thalassaemia International Federation [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=231]
  • Thalassaemia International Federation [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=35]
  • Thalassaemia International Federation [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=23]

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Iron overload, leading to damage in major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Endocrine problems such as delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities including pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, congestive heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities such as cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: What are the alternatives to luspatercept for managing thalassaemia?
answer:
Alternatives to Luspatercept for Managing Thalassaemia

There are several alternatives to luspatercept for managing thalassaemia, including medications, gene therapy, and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Below are some of the key alternatives:

Medications

  • Mitapivat: An activator of pyruvate kinase currently in phase 3 clinical trials for both transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) and non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (NTDT). It targets increased haemolysis and may offer robust efficacy in individuals with alpha-thalassaemia [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146].
  • Etavopivat: Another pyruvate kinase activator currently in phase 2 clinical trials [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146].
  • Iron Chelation Medications: These medications aim to manage iron overload, which is a common issue in thalassaemia due to frequent blood transfusions and increased gastrointestinal iron absorption. Agents that increase hepcidin levels or block ferroportin are being studied [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146].
  • VIT-2763: An oral ferroportin inhibitor currently under investigation [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=294].
  • TMPRSS6-LRx: Anti-sense oligonucleotides that downregulate TMPRSS6, currently in clinical trials [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=294].

Gene Therapy

Autologous gene therapy using lentiviral vectors carrying the beta-globin gene has been successfully validated for beta-thalassaemia treatment. This approach aims to provide a long-term cure by correcting the genetic defect [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146].

Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT)

HSCT has significantly improved outcomes for thalassaemia patients, including those with high-risk profiles. The use of alternative donors (haploidentical, unrelated) has expanded, and outcomes are now comparable to those with matched sibling donors. However, HSCT survivors require lifelong monitoring for long-term consequences and residual symptoms [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=193].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How is thalassaemia managed in Greece?
answer:
Management of Thalassaemia in Greece

Thalassaemia management in Greece involves several key strategies and programs:

Blood Transfusions

Greece collects approximately 2,996,264 units of blood annually, with an estimated need of 550,000-600,000 units of blood annually to meet domestic needs. However, Patient Blood Management strategies and techniques are not uniformly applied throughout the country [BloodPoliciesEU_FactSheet_Final_20240110.pdf#page=5].

National Control Programs

Greece has been one of the countries where thalassaemia was first recognized as an important public health issue. The Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) has been instrumental in promoting the development of National Control Programs, which include both prevention and clinical management components [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=4][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=12].

Support from Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF)

TIF, founded in 1986, works in collaboration with national, regional, and international health authorities to prioritize thalassaemia on health agendas and develop national disease-specific programs for effective control, prevention, holistic care, and research [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=9][TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=11].

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins, which are essential components of hemoglobin. The severity of thalassaemia varies widely depending on the specific genetic mutations involved and their interactions.

Types of Thalassaemia

  • α-thalassaemia: Occurs when genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • β-thalassaemia: Occurs when similar genetic defects affect the production of the β-globin protein.

Severity of β-thalassaemia

The severity of β-thalassaemia can range from mild to very severe, depending on the specific mutations and their interactions:

  • Thalassaemia Major: Patients cannot survive long without regular blood transfusions. This condition is often caused by severe β-thalassaemia mutations.
  • Thalassaemia Intermedia: Patients may survive with occasional or no transfusions, or with chronic transfusions initiated at an older age. This condition can result from a combination of mild and severe mutations, or the co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or other genetic factors that ameliorate the condition.

Genetic Factors Influencing Severity

Several genetic factors can influence the severity of thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: The loss of one or more α-globin genes can reduce the imbalance between α- and β-chains, leading to a milder form of the disease [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].
  • Increased HbF Production: Genetic modifiers that increase the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) can ameliorate the severity of the disease by partially correcting the imbalance between α- and β-chains [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=61].
  • Specific Mutations: More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, each with varying phenotypic severity. For example, the mild β+-type mutation -88 (C->T) generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype, while the β+-thalassaemia mutation Cap+1 (A->C) can result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Come vengono diagnosticate le masse extra midollari?
answer:
Diagnosi delle Masse Extra Midollari

Le masse extra midollari possono essere diagnosticate utilizzando diverse tecniche di imaging. Ecco i metodi principali:

  • Risonanza Magnetica (MRI): Attualmente considerata il metodo di scelta per la diagnosi e la valutazione del follow-up delle masse extra midollari. La MRI può mostrare chiaramente i dettagli anatomici, inclusi il sito e l'estensione delle masse all'interno del canale spinale, con alta sensibilità per la delineazione dei tessuti molli [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=98].
  • Tomografia Computerizzata (CT): In passato, la CT era preferita per la diagnosi delle masse paraspinali. Tuttavia, la MRI ha sostituito la CT come metodo principale [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=98][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=95].
  • Scintigrafia Ossea con 99mTc: Utilizzata per diagnosticare pseudotumori ematopoietici paraspinali, ma la diagnosi nello spazio epidurale può essere difficile a causa della vicinanza al midollo osseo [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=98][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=95].
  • Radiografie Semplici: Possono rivelare masse paraspinali ben demarcate e cambiamenti ossei associati all'anemia cronica, come trabecolazione, costole allargate o calvaria ispessita. Tuttavia, la distruzione ossea o le fratture patologiche sono solitamente assenti [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=95].

La diagnosi differenziale è spesso facilitata dalla presenza di lesioni multifocali o bilaterali, e la storia clinica di anemia emolitica congenita aiuta a distinguere le masse extra midollari da altre patologie come tumori mesenchimali o tumori del tessuto nervoso [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=96].

Per ulteriori informazioni, si prega di contattare info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: I have a pain in my knee
answer:
Πόνος στο Γόνατο

Ο πόνος στο γόνατο μπορεί να είναι σύμπτωμα οστεοπάθειας, η οποία είναι συχνή σε ασθενείς με θαλασσαιμία. Οι ασθενείς με θαλασσαιμία έχουν μειωμένη οστική πυκνότητα και αυξημένο κίνδυνο καταγμάτων και παραμορφώσεων, που μπορεί να προκαλέσουν πόνο και δυσφορία [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=183].

Επιπλέον, η χρήση του φαρμάκου Deferiprone μπορεί να προκαλέσει πόνο και φλεγμονή στις αρθρώσεις, όπως τα γόνατα. Σε ορισμένες περιπτώσεις, ο πόνος μπορεί να είναι τόσο σοβαρός που να απαιτεί τη διακοπή του φαρμάκου [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=66][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=71].

Για την ανακούφιση του πόνου, μπορείτε να δοκιμάσετε μη φαρμακευτικές μεθόδους όπως:

  • Μασάζ
  • Ζεστό μπάνιο
  • Εφαρμογή θερμαντικών επιθεμάτων
  • Θεραπεία απόσπασης προσοχής (π.χ. παιχνίδι, τηλεόραση)
  • Χρήση συσκευής Tens (διαδερμική ηλεκτρική νευρική διέγερση) [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=97]

Εάν ο πόνος επιμένει, συνιστάται να επικοινωνήσετε με τον γιατρό σας για περαιτέρω αξιολόγηση και θεραπεία. Για περισσότερες πληροφορίες, παρακαλούμε επικοινωνήστε με το info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does gene therapy work for TDT patients?
answer:
Gene Therapy for Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT) Patients

Gene therapy offers a promising treatment option for patients with Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT). This approach involves the collection, selection, and ex vivo genetic modification of patient-derived haematopoietic stem cells (HSCs), followed by reinfusion after a myeloablative conditioning regimen [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=396].

Mechanisms of Gene Therapy

Gene therapy for TDT primarily employs two strategies:

  • Gene Addition: This involves the semi-random integration of a functional copy of the therapeutic gene into the cellular genome via viral vectors. This method aims to promote normal ß-globin synthesis or reactivate foetal y-globin production, thereby reducing the accumulation of excess, unbound a-globin chains and restoring the balance between a and non-a globin within red blood cells (RBCs) [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=396].
  • Gene Editing: This strategy uses site-specific nucleases to precisely target and alter specific genomic sequences, inducing a disease-modifying effect. This correction improves erythropoiesis, extends the lifespan of RBCs, and results in a higher number of erythrocytes with increased haemoglobin that persist longer in the bloodstream [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=396].

Advantages of Gene Therapy

Compared to allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), gene therapy offers several advantages:

  • Donor Independence: Gene therapy uses autologous HSCs sourced directly from the patient, eliminating the need for an HLA-matched donor and circumventing the limitations and risks associated with donor availability and compatibility [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=406].
  • Reduced Immune-Mediated Complications: Using the patient's own genetically modified HSCs abrogates the risk of graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) and graft rejection, which are major contributors to morbidity and mortality in allogeneic HSCT [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=406].
  • Lower Toxicity: The safety profile observed in clinical trials is generally consistent with single-agent busulfan myeloablation in the context of an autologous HSCT procedure [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=406].

Clinical Trials and Outcomes

Several clinical trials have demonstrated the efficacy of gene therapy in TDT patients:

  • In a phase 1/2 safety study conducted by the San Raffaele Telethon Institute for Gene Therapy (SR-TIGET), three adults and six children with TDT received intra-bone administration of stem cells transduced with the GLOBE lentiviral vector. The treatment resulted in successful haematopoietic engraftment in all patients, with three out of four children becoming independent of blood transfusions [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=398].
  • In two phase 1/2 clinical trials involving adolescents and adults, 11 out of 14 patients with TDT achieved transfusion independence following infusion of betibeglogene autotemcel (beti-cel) [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=397].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the 2025 TDT 5th Edition.

question: What should we eat?
answer:
Diet Recommendations for Thalassaemia

For individuals with thalassaemia, it is important to manage iron intake and ensure a balanced diet. Here are some dietary guidelines:

Foods to Include

  • Fruits and Vegetables: Aim for 5 portions daily. Examples include apples, pears, bananas, oranges, tomatoes, carrots, courgettes, French beans, and small salads. Light steaming preserves vitamins better than boiling [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=163].
  • Whole Grains: Include at least 3 servings per day, such as whole grain bread, pasta, oatmeal, or brown rice. These are rich in fibre and B-vitamins [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=10].
  • Calcium-Rich Foods: Dairy products like milk and cheese are important for bone health. Opt for lower fat varieties if watching weight [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=161].
  • Vitamin E-Rich Foods: Include eggs, vegetable oils (e.g., olive oil, corn oil), nuts, and cereals [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=236].
  • Proteins: Meat, poultry, fish, and seafood are good sources of complete proteins. For vegetarians, combine plant-based foods to ensure complete protein intake [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=10].

Foods to Limit

  • Iron-Fortified Foods: In the UK, many foods like breakfast cereals and wheat flour are fortified with iron. Choose unfortified wholemeal options when possible [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=160].
  • Vitamin C with Meals: Avoid consuming vitamin C-rich foods (e.g., fruit juice) with meals as it increases iron absorption. Instead, have them as snacks [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=161].
  • Pickled and Fermented Foods: These enhance iron absorption and should be consumed in moderation [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=161].

General Tips

  • Drink at least 8 cups of water daily to maintain hydration and support kidney function [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=9].
  • Include a variety of foods to ensure a balanced intake of macronutrients and micronutrients [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=9].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How can i use jadenu and desferal together
answer:
Using Jadenu and Desferal Together

Combining Jadenu (Deferasirox) and Desferal (Deferoxamine) can be an effective strategy for managing severe iron overload. Here are the key points to consider:

Administration

  • Jadenu: Taken orally once daily. The starting dose for Jadenu is typically 14 mg/kg/day for thalassaemia major patients, with adjustments based on the transfusional iron-loading rate [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=84].
  • Desferal: Administered subcutaneously via a slow infusion over 8-12 hours, at least 6 days a week. The recommended dose is 20-40 mg/kg/day in children and up to 60 mg/kg/day in adults [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=8][EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=11].

Combination Therapy

  • Combining these two chelators can enhance the removal of iron from different body compartments, potentially leading to a more rapid reduction in iron levels [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=81].
  • Careful monitoring of serum ferritin and other iron parameters is essential to adjust dosages and avoid toxicity [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=82].

Monitoring and Safety

  • Regular monitoring of kidney function (serum creatinine) and liver function tests is necessary due to the potential toxicity of both drugs [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=123].
  • Patients should be educated on the signs of potential side effects, such as gastrointestinal issues, hearing loss, or vision changes, and report them to their healthcare provider promptly [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=123].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: I have a 1 month old granddaughter that, more than likely, has major. Can you explain what we have to look forward to and let me know any information that we can read up on
answer:
Understanding Thalassaemia Major in Infants

Thalassaemia major is a serious condition that requires ongoing medical care and attention. Here are some key points to consider for your granddaughter:

Early Years and Treatment

In the early years, your granddaughter will experience the discomfort of treatments, even though she may not fully understand what is happening. It is crucial for parents and caregivers to build a strong, healthy relationship with her, helping her through the treatment process. This includes fostering trust and confidence [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=123].

Medical Care and Hospital Visits

Children with thalassaemia major will need regular visits to outpatient units or emergency rooms for immediate treatment of certain medical problems. More serious health issues may require hospitalization for additional treatment and close observation. Treatments can include medications, blood transfusions, supplemental oxygen, and antibiotics [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=20].

Specialized Care

It is advisable to enroll your granddaughter in a specialized thalassaemia care center. These centers have a team of health professionals experienced in thalassaemia care and research, including doctors, nurses, genetic counselors, social workers, and dieticians. Regular visits to these centers will help manage her condition and screen for possible complications [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=21].

Parental Involvement

Your continuous involvement, knowledge, and caring will make a significant difference in your granddaughter's outlook. Responsible and dedicated parents can help their children lead normal lives and grow to be healthy and productive citizens if they receive optimal care from an early age [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=20].

Additional Resources

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following resources:

  • Living with Thalassaemia Travel Booklet
  • Sickle Cell Disease Booklet
  • About Thalassaemia

If you have further questions or need more specific information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Was weiß man über thomas benton cooley in bezug auf thalassämie
answer:
Thomas Benton Cooley und Thalassämie

Thomas Benton Cooley war ein amerikanischer Kinderarzt und Hämatologe, der eine bedeutende Rolle bei der Beschreibung der Thalassämie spielte. Die Krankheit ist auch als Cooley's Anämie bekannt, benannt nach ihm. Cooley veröffentlichte 1925 seine Beobachtungen über Patienten mit Ursprung aus Ländern rund um das Mittelmeer, was zur Namensgebung der Krankheit führte.

Weitere Informationen zu Cooley's Anämie finden Sie in den folgenden Quellen:

  • Thalassaemia from A to Z: A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=6]
  • TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=55]
  • AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=21]

Für weitere Fragen können Sie sich an info@thalassaemia.org.cy wenden.

question: How many transfusions are required to classify an individual as NTDT
answer:
Transfusion Requirements for NTDT

Non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (NTDT) refers to patients who do not require lifelong regular transfusions for survival. These patients may need occasional or even frequent transfusions in certain clinical settings and for defined periods of time, but they do not depend on regular transfusions for survival.

In recent clinical trials, the use of the NTDT/TDT classification has commonly been associated with the patient's transfusion profile in the past six months. For NTDT, this typically means receiving fewer than 6 red blood cell units in that period.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the TIF Guidelines and the NTDT Guidelines.

Sources:

  • TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf
  • NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf

question: le role de linfirmier theorique et pratique lors de la prise en charge de thalassemie (traitemnt surviellance depistage complication suivie education)
answer:
Rôle de l'infirmier dans la prise en charge de la thalassémie

Théorique

  • Utilisation d'un langage simple et prise de temps pour s'assurer que le patient comprend les informations nécessaires [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=27].
  • Encouragement des patients à suivre correctement et régulièrement leur traitement pour éviter les complications inutiles et maintenir une meilleure qualité de vie à long terme [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=27].
  • Éducation des patients et de leurs familles sur la gestion de la maladie, la prévention des complications et la transition des soins pédiatriques aux soins pour adultes [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=11].
  • Soutien psychosocial pour aider les patients à gérer l'anxiété, la culpabilité et la peur de l'inconnu [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=11].

Pratique

  • Supervision des transfusions sanguines et triage des patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=145][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=370].
  • Surveillance et contrôle de la surcharge en fer [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=15].
  • Coordination des soins multidisciplinaires et collaboration avec d'autres spécialistes pour une prise en charge appropriée [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=16][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13].
  • Détection précoce des complications systémiques et gestion des complications cardiovasculaires et hépatiques [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=144].
  • Participation au dépistage néonatal pour identifier précocement les patients et initier une prophylaxie contre les infections [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=15].
  • Surveillance régulière des complications par échocardiogrammes et IRM [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=144].
  • Fournir un soutien et des conseils pratiques pour aider les patients à gérer leur traitement et à maintenir une bonne qualité de vie [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=16].

Pour plus d'informations ou des questions supplémentaires, veuillez contacter info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Questions de suivi

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins. There are two main types of thalassaemia based on the affected globin protein: α-thalassaemia and β-thalassaemia.

β-Thalassaemia

β-thalassaemia occurs due to mutations in the HBB gene, which affects the production of the β-globin protein. The severity of β-thalassaemia can vary widely based on the specific mutations and other genetic factors:

  • Severe mutations (β0) result in no β-globin production, leading to thalassaemia major, which requires regular blood transfusions for survival [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].
  • Less severe mutations (β+) result in reduced β-globin production, which can lead to thalassaemia intermedia or major, depending on the specific mutation and other genetic factors [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].
  • Mild mutations (β++) generally result in a very mild clinical phenotype, often presenting as thalassaemia intermedia [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

Several genetic factors can ameliorate the severity of β-thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia, which reduces the imbalance between α- and β-globin chains, leading to a milder phenotype [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Mutations that increase the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), such as hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH) mutations, can result in a milder form of thalassaemia intermedia [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Genetic determinants outside the β-globin gene cluster, such as BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB, which increase γ-globin chain production and HbF levels, can also ameliorate disease severity [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

α-Thalassaemia

α-thalassaemia occurs when one or more of the genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated. The severity of α-thalassaemia depends on the number of affected genes:

  • Loss of one α-globin gene generally has minimal effect and may result in a silent carrier state [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Loss of two α-globin genes can lead to α-thalassaemia trait, which may present with mild anemia [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Loss of three or four α-globin genes results in more severe forms, such as HbH disease or hydrops fetalis, respectively [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What is the usual hemoglobin count for someone with thalassemia major
answer:
Usual Hemoglobin Count for Someone with Thalassemia Major

Individuals with thalassemia major typically require lifelong regular blood transfusions to maintain their hemoglobin levels. The goal of these transfusions is to maintain a pre-transfusion hemoglobin level of 90-105 g/L. This regimen helps promote normal growth, allows for normal physical activities, adequately suppresses bone marrow activity, and minimizes transfusional iron accumulation.

In some cases, a higher target pre-transfusion hemoglobin level of 110-120 g/L may be appropriate for patients with heart disease, clinically significant extramedullary hematopoiesis, or other medical conditions.

[TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=26]

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Complications

When Do Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Symptoms

  • Severe anaemia
  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

Common Complications

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures
  • Thrombophilia
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Iron overload leading to liver fibrosis, cirrhosis, and heart disease
  • Delayed sexual maturation
  • Growth retardation
  • Heart problems, including heart failure
  • Splenic enlargement
  • Endocrine problems such as diabetes, hypothyroidism, and hypogonadism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58][ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf#page=2][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15][HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Follow-up Questions

question: What supplements can i use
answer:
Recommended Supplements for Thalassaemia

For individuals with thalassaemia, the following supplements are often recommended:

  • Vitamin D: Recommended at a dose of 1,000 to 2,000 IU/day or 50,000 IU per month in adults. It helps protect against osteoporosis or bone thinning. Regular monitoring of vitamin D levels is advised [source][source].
  • Vitamin E: Works with vitamin C to protect against oxidative stress. Found in vegetable oils, nuts, and wheat germ. Supplementation may be useful, especially for those with elevated liver iron [source][source].
  • Zinc: Important for immunity, growth, and bone health. Found in protein-rich foods like beef, chicken, and cheese. Supplementation may improve growth in children and bone health in adults [source][source].
  • Folic Acid: Recommended for all patients due to its importance in cell division and erythropoiesis. A dose of 1 mg/day or 5 mg/week is sufficient [source][source].
  • Vitamin C: Useful for reducing oxidative stress and improving chelator efficacy. Recommended only in conjunction with deferoxamine infusions [source][source].
  • Calcium: Recommended along with vitamin D to support bone health. A diet high in calcium is preferred, but supplements may be necessary [source][source].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: Hi, would you be able to let me know how many patients globally have clinically significant form of  thalassemia disease?
answer:
Thalassaemia Patients Globally

Approximately 200,000 patients with thalassaemia major are alive and registered as receiving treatment around the world [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=132]. Additionally, around 1 million patients are affected by various alpha-thalassaemia syndromes globally [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=10].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Is the term "Thalassaemia major" still used?
answer:
Is the Term "Thalassaemia Major" Still Used?

Yes, the term "thalassaemia major" is still used, particularly in the context of describing the severe, transfusion-dependent form of β-thalassaemia. However, there is a shift towards using the term "transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT)" to describe patients who require lifelong regular transfusion therapy for survival. This includes patients with β-thalassaemia major and severe haemoglobin E/β-thalassaemia [source: TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf].

The term "thalassaemia major" is still prevalent in medical literature and clinical settings, especially in developing countries where resources for long-term transfusion programs may be limited [source: TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf].

For further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the side effects of sildenafil citrate?
answer:
Side Effects of Sildenafil Citrate

Sildenafil citrate, used for managing pulmonary hypertension in thalassaemia patients, can have several side effects. These include:

  • Abdominal disturbance and diarrhoeal symptoms, which are common within the first week of drug administration. These symptoms usually subside and rarely require dose reduction [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].
  • Periodic fever and common cold symptoms have also been reported [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].
  • About 10% of patients may experience an itchy skin rash, which can be widespread or localized on the palms or soles. This rash typically appears within the first 15 days of administration and usually subsides without the need to stop or reduce the dose [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].
  • An increase in creatinine levels, which is associated with kidney function, has been observed in some patients [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the About Thalassaemia document.

question: Lifespan of beta thalassemia
answer:
Lifespan of Beta Thalassemia

The lifespan of individuals with beta thalassemia varies significantly depending on the severity of the condition and the treatment received.

Beta Thalassemia Major

Without treatment, patients with beta thalassemia major typically do not survive beyond the first few years of life due to severe anemia and complications such as high-output heart failure [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=26]. However, with modern treatment, including regular blood transfusions and iron chelation therapy, patients can survive into adulthood. Optimal basic therapy can ensure survival to adult life [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].

Beta Thalassemia Intermedia

Individuals with beta thalassemia intermedia have a milder form of the disease and present later in life. They may not require regular transfusions initially but can become increasingly transfusion-dependent as they age or if complications arise [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=8]. These patients can survive into adulthood, but they may develop complications related to iron overload after the third decade of life [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=92].

For more detailed information, please refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: how is TIBC and transferrin related
answer:
Relationship Between TIBC and Transferrin

Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) and transferrin are closely related as TIBC is a measure of the blood's capacity to bind iron with transferrin. Here are the key points explaining their relationship:

  • Transferrin: Transferrin is a protein that transports iron in the blood. It can be measured directly using immunological methods or indirectly as TIBC [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=28][PreventionVol2_English.pdf#page=44].
  • TIBC: TIBC is the total amount of iron that can be bound by transferrin in the blood. It is determined by adding a known amount of iron to the blood sample and measuring how much iron is bound by transferrin [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=28][PreventionVol2_English.pdf#page=44].
  • Iron Status Indicator: Both TIBC and transferrin levels are used to assess iron status. High TIBC or transferrin levels may indicate iron deficiency, while low levels can be seen in conditions like chronic infections, inflammation, and malignancy [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=28][PreventionVol2_English.pdf#page=44].

For further details, please refer to the sources or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sources:

  • Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf
  • PreventionVol2_English.pdf

question: Si può guarire dalla talassemia?
answer:
Si può guarire dalla talassemia?

Attualmente, la talassemia non può essere curata completamente con i trattamenti convenzionali. Tuttavia, ci sono due principali approcci curativi in fase di sviluppo e utilizzo:

  • Trapianto di midollo osseo: Questo è attualmente l'unico trattamento curativo per la ß-talassemia. È più efficace nei bambini piccoli e richiede un donatore compatibile HLA, solitamente un fratello o un parente [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=60].
  • Terapia genica: Ci sono stati progressi significativi nella ricerca sulla terapia genica, che offre speranza per una cura definitiva in futuro. Tuttavia, ci sono ancora molte difficoltà tecniche da superare [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=24][PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=125].

Per ulteriori informazioni e aggiornamenti sui trattamenti curativi, è consigliabile consultare un medico specialista, un consulente genetico o contattare la Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) all'indirizzo info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Fonti

  • TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf
  • Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf
  • PatientsRights_English.pdf
