question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins. There are two main types of thalassaemia based on the affected globin protein: α-thalassaemia and β-thalassaemia.

β-Thalassaemia

β-thalassaemia occurs due to mutations in the HBB gene, which affects the production of the β-globin protein. The severity of β-thalassaemia can vary widely based on the specific mutations and other genetic factors:

  • Severe mutations (β0) often result in thalassaemia major, characterized by severe, life-threatening anaemia requiring regular blood transfusions [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].
  • Less severe mutations (β+) can lead to thalassaemia intermedia, where patients may require occasional or no transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Mild mutations (β++) generally result in a very mild clinical phenotype [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

α-Thalassaemia

α-thalassaemia is caused by deletions or mutations in the genes related to the α-globin protein. The co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia can ameliorate the severity of β-thalassaemia by reducing the imbalance between α- and β-globin chains [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

Several genetic factors can modify the severity of thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia can reduce the severity of β-thalassaemia [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Mutations that increase the production of foetal haemoglobin (HbF) can lead to a milder phenotype [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Changes in the ubiquitin-proteasome system or expression of α-haemoglobin stabilising protein can also ameliorate disease severity [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

Conclusion

The genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity are complex and influenced by various factors. Accurate genetic diagnosis and counselling are essential for managing the condition effectively.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Can a b thallasaimia patient use steroids
answer:
Can a β-Thalassaemia Patient Use Steroids?

The use of steroids in β-thalassaemia patients can be considered under specific circumstances, but it should be done with caution and under medical supervision. Here are some scenarios where steroids might be used:

  • Autoimmune Haemolytic Anaemia: Steroids, along with immunosuppressive drugs, intravenous immunoglobulin, and rituximab, are used for the clinical management of autoimmune haemolytic anaemia, which can be a serious complication in thalassaemia patients [source][source].
  • Prophylaxis Against Alloimmunization: Concomitant administration of steroids for 3 to 5 days has been reported as prophylaxis against alloimmunization, although the efficacy of this intervention is controversial [source].
  • COVID-19 Management: Low-dose corticosteroids can be prescribed if necessary for thalassaemia patients with haemodynamic instability during COVID-19, but it should be noted that this treatment may prolong the clearance of viral DNA from the respiratory tract and increase complication rates [source].

It is crucial to consult with a healthcare professional before using steroids to ensure they are appropriate for your specific condition and to manage any potential risks.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: which is the best iron chelator to removed excess iron from liver
answer:
Best Iron Chelator for Liver Iron Overload

Three iron chelators are currently available for the treatment of iron overload in thalassaemia patients: deferoxamine (DFO), deferiprone (DFP), and deferasirox (DFX). All three chelators are proven to effectively reduce liver iron concentration (LIC) [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=128][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=61].

Among these, deferasirox (DFX) may have a positive effect on liver fibrosis in addition to reducing LIC [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=128][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=61]. This makes DFX a particularly effective option for managing liver iron overload and potentially improving liver health.

For more detailed information or personalized advice, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

  • What are the side effects of deferasirox?
  • How often should liver iron concentration be monitored?
  • Can iron chelators be used in combination for better results?

question: Are there any financial assistance programs for thalassaemia treatment in The Netherlands?
answer:
Financial Assistance Programs for Thalassaemia Treatment in The Netherlands

There are several avenues for financial assistance for thalassaemia treatment in The Netherlands. Here are some key points to consider:

  • National Health Insurance: The Dutch healthcare system provides coverage for necessary medical treatments, including those for chronic conditions like thalassaemia. Ensure you are registered with the national health insurance to access these benefits [CrossBorderHealthcare-Factsheet.pdf#page=2].
  • Cross-Border Healthcare: If you need to access treatment not available in The Netherlands, you can benefit from the EU's cross-border healthcare provisions. For planned treatments abroad, you can request the S2 form to avoid upfront medical costs. For treatments available in another EU Member State, you may need to pay upfront and claim reimbursement afterward [CrossBorderHealthcare-Factsheet.pdf#page=2].
  • Government Support: Securing financial support from the government is essential for accessing quality healthcare. This may involve lobbying for insurance coverage, funding, and grants. Establishing contact with government officials and creating awareness campaigns can help in obtaining this support [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=54][ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=56].
  • Equal Access Programs: The vision is to establish equal access for every patient with thalassaemia to high-quality health and social care services. This includes advocating for patient-centred healthcare systems that provide comprehensive coverage for thalassaemia treatment [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=12][TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=10].

For further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins, which are essential components of hemoglobin. The severity of thalassaemia can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Genetic Mutations

  • ß-thalassaemia: Caused by mutations in the ß-globin gene, leading to reduced or absent ß-globin chain production. There are over 200 known ß-thalassaemia mutations, ranging from mild to very severe [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • a-thalassaemia: Caused by mutations in the a-globin gene, leading to reduced or absent a-globin chain production [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].

Impact on Severity

The severity of thalassaemia is influenced by the specific mutations and the presence of other genetic factors:

  • Homozygous Severe ß-thalassaemia: Typically results in thalassaemia major, requiring regular blood transfusions for survival [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Co-inheritance of a-thalassaemia: Can ameliorate the severity of ß-thalassaemia. For example, the loss of two a-globin genes can result in thalassaemia intermedia rather than major [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Increased HbF Production: Genetic determinants that increase fetal hemoglobin (HbF) production can lead to a milder phenotype. This includes hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH) mutations [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Specific ß-thalassaemia Mutations: Some mutations, such as the mild ß+-type mutation -88 (C->T), result in a very mild clinical phenotype [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

Overall, the genetic interactions leading to thalassaemia phenotypes are highly heterogeneous, making genetic counseling and diagnosis complex [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=64].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How can I interpret my Iron Profile results?
answer:
Interpreting Your Iron Profile Results

Interpreting iron profile results involves understanding various parameters that reflect different aspects of iron status in the body. Here are some key points to consider:

Key Parameters

  • Zinc Protoporphyrin (ZnPP): Elevated levels indicate iron deficiency but can be falsely high in cases of lead intoxication or elevated bilirubin levels [PreventionVol2_English.pdf#page=17][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=28].
  • Serum Ferritin: Commonly used to indicate iron deficiency, but results can be falsely high during infection, liver disease, or neoplasia. It is an indirect measurement of iron burden and is inexpensive, but it fluctuates in response to inflammation and requires serial measurements for accurate monitoring [PreventionVol2_English.pdf#page=17][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=70].
  • Transferrin Saturation: Calculated from serum iron and total iron-binding capacity (TIBC). It is more accurate than ferritin but lacks a standardized protocol [PreventionVol2_English.pdf#page=17][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=28].
  • Liver Iron Concentration (LIC): Measured by MRI, it reflects total body iron content. LIC values greater than 7 mg/g dry weight indicate moderate iron overload, while values over 15 mg/g indicate severe overload [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=115][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=61].

Considerations

It is important to distinguish between uncomplicated iron deficiency and thalassaemia traits, as iron deficiency can coexist with thalassaemia. In such cases, repeating the haematology screen after correcting iron deficiency may be necessary [PreventionVol2_English.pdf#page=18].

Additional Resources

If you need further assistance interpreting your results, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-Up Questions

question: What are the risks associated with washed packed red blood cells?
answer:
Risks Associated with Washed Packed Red Blood Cells

While washed packed red blood cells offer significant benefits for certain patient populations, there are also some risks and limitations associated with their use:

  • Shorter Shelf Life: Washed red cells that are not suspended in a storage solution must be used within 24 hours. This shorter shelf life can lead to potential wastage if patients are not available for transfusion at the time the blood is prepared. If suspended in SAGM (saline-adenine-glucose-mannitol) after washing, the shelf life can be extended to 14 days, but this requires a closed circuit [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=41].
  • Loss of Red Blood Cells: The washing process can remove some erythrocytes from the transfusion product. This means that post-transfusion hemoglobin levels should be monitored to ensure that the targeted hemoglobin level is achieved [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=41].
  • Inadequate Leucocyte Reduction: Washing alone does not result in adequate leucocyte reduction and should not be used as a substitute for leucoreduction. It should be used in conjunction with filtration to ensure the removal of white blood cells [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=41].
  • Resource Intensive: The process of washing red cells is resource-intensive and may not be necessary for most patients. It is typically reserved for those with severe allergic reactions or specific conditions such as IgA deficiency [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=40].

Source: TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf, AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf

question: What are the side effects of luspatercept-aamt?
answer:
Side Effects of Luspatercept-aamt

Luspatercept-aamt, marketed as REBLOZYL, is used to treat anaemia in patients with thalassaemia. Here are the most common and significant side effects associated with its use:

Common Adverse Reactions

  • Headache (26%)
  • Bone pain (20%)
  • Arthralgia (19%)
  • Fatigue (14%)
  • Cough (14%)
  • Abdominal pain (14%)
  • Diarrhea (12%)
  • Dizziness (11%)

[TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=303]

Selected Adverse Reactions

  • Bone pain: Reported in 19.7% of patients, most common in the first 3 months. Most events were Grade 1-2, with 3 events Grade 3. One event was serious, and 1 event led to treatment discontinuation [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=303].
  • Arthralgia: Reported in 19.3% of patients, leading to treatment discontinuation in 2 patients (0.9%) [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=303].
  • Hypertension: Reported in 8.1% of patients, with an average increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure of 5 mmHg. Grade 3 events were reported in 1.8% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=303].
  • Hypersensitivity reactions: Including eyelid oedema, drug hypersensitivity, swelling face, periorbital oedema, face oedema, angioedema, lip swelling, and drug eruption, reported in 4.5% of patients. All events were Grade 1/2, with treatment discontinuation in 1 patient (0.4%) [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=139][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=303].
  • Injection site reactions: Including erythema, pruritus, swelling, and rash, reported in 2.2% of patients. All events were Grade 1 and none led to discontinuation [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=139][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=304].
  • Thromboembolic events: Including deep vein thrombosis, portal vein thrombosis, ischaemic stroke, and pulmonary embolism, occurred in 3.6% of patients. All events were reported in patients who had undergone splenectomy and had at least one other risk factor [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=139][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=304].

For more detailed information, please refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation website or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: If blood filter is blocked, can we transfuse the rest of the blood through regular BD set
answer:
Blood Transfusion and Blocked Filters

If a blood filter becomes blocked during a transfusion, it is not advisable to continue the transfusion using a regular BD set. The primary reason for using special filters is to remove white blood cells and associated infectious agents, which is crucial for the safety of the patient, especially those with thalassaemia.

According to international guidelines, blood should be filtered to remove white blood cells to prevent infections and other complications. Using a regular BD set bypasses this critical step, potentially exposing the patient to risks such as infections and immune reactions [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=41][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=45].

If you encounter a blocked filter, it is best to consult with a healthcare professional to determine the appropriate course of action. For further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the legal protections for thalassaemia patients in the workplace?
answer:
Legal Protections for Thalassaemia Patients in the Workplace

Thalassaemia patients are entitled to several legal protections in the workplace to ensure they can work on an equal basis with others. Here are some key points:

  • Discrimination on the basis of disability is prohibited. This includes ensuring equal remuneration for work of equal value and providing safe and healthy working conditions [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Patients' rights are a specific application of human rights in the field of health services. These rights outline the relationship between patients and healthcare providers, ensuring that patients are treated with dignity and respect [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=11].
  • The Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) is committed to protecting the rights and safety of thalassaemia patients globally. TIF works with various organizations to promote the rights of chronically ill patients and ensure they receive appropriate and safe treatment [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=71].
  • Patients should educate themselves on the laws and regulations that give them rights as patients to be able to demand those rights effectively [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=11].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: I have a sickle cell thalaessemia and I want to know what is the best medicine for it
answer:
Best Medicine for Sickle Cell Thalassemia

The most promising and widely-used medication for sickle cell thalassemia is hydroxyurea (Droxia®, Hydrea®, Cytodrox®). This drug works by stimulating the production of foetal haemoglobin, which helps prevent the formation of sickle cells. Hydroxyurea has been proven to be very helpful for both adults and children with severe disease. When taken daily, it decreases the frequency of painful crises and may reduce the need for blood transfusions.

However, hydroxyurea is not suitable for everyone. It may not be appropriate for patients who are likely to become pregnant or those who have difficulty adhering to treatment instructions. Regular follow-up and clinic visits are necessary to monitor its effects and manage any potential side effects, such as an increased risk of infection due to reduced bone marrow activity.

Other experimental treatments and investigational approaches include:

  • Butyric acid compounds: Increase HbF production in erythroid cells.
  • Clotrimazole: Inhibits cation transport channels in erythrocyte membranes, reducing cellular dehydration.
  • Nitric oxide: Reduces red blood cell stickiness and helps keep blood vessels open.
  • Gene therapy: Early promise demonstrated in a transgenic mouse model, but clinical evidence is still limited.

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources below:

  • NursesGuide_English.pdf
  • Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf
  • TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: alpha thalassemia new therapies
answer:
New Therapies for Alpha Thalassaemia

Recent advancements in the treatment of alpha thalassaemia have introduced several promising therapies aimed at improving patient outcomes. Here are some of the key developments:

Luspatercept

Luspatercept is an erythroid maturation agent that has shown good efficacy in decreasing transfusion dependency in beta-thalassaemia and improving anaemia in beta non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia. It is currently being studied for its potential benefits in alpha thalassaemia, with results expected in the next few years. If successful, it may offer an alternative to transfusions for improving anaemia in patients with alpha thalassaemia.

[AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=193][TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1]

Mitapivat

Mitapivat is an activator of pyruvate kinase that increases haemoglobin levels in patients with HbH disease, a form of alpha thalassaemia. Clinical trials are ongoing, and the results are anticipated to provide more insights into its efficacy and safety for alpha thalassaemia patients.

[AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=193][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=147]

Gene Therapy

Gene therapy for alpha thalassaemia is still in the early stages of development. Potential strategies include:

  • Gene addition: Introducing the alpha-globin gene using lentiviral vectors.
  • Gene editing: Correcting specific point mutations using methods like base editing, which may be applicable for specific non-deletional types of alpha thalassaemia.

Currently, no gene therapy clinical trials are available for alpha thalassaemia patients, but research is ongoing to explore these approaches.

[AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146]

Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT)

HSCT remains the only available curative option for alpha thalassaemia. Advances in graft manipulation and graft versus host disease prophylaxis have expanded the use of alternative donors, such as haploidentical and unrelated donors, with outcomes comparable to matched sibling donors. However, HSCT survivors require lifelong monitoring and follow-ups for long-term consequences and residual symptoms of pre-HSCT disease.

[AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=193][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=128]

For more detailed information or specific advice, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Treatment for NTD Thalassemia
answer:
Treatment for Non-Transfusion Dependent Thalassaemia (NTDT)

Non-Transfusion Dependent Thalassaemia (NTDT) patients typically receive transfusions occasionally and usually at older ages. The treatment for NTDT focuses on managing anaemia and iron overload, as well as improving overall quality of life.

Iron Chelation Therapy

Iron chelation therapy is essential for NTDT patients to remove excess iron from the body, which can accumulate due to occasional transfusions or increased iron absorption. Three types of iron chelators are used:

  • Deferasirox (oral)
  • Deferiprone (oral)
  • Deferoxamine (subcutaneous injection)

Studies have shown that deferasirox effectively reduces iron overload in NTDT patients [info1.txt][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=57].

Treatment of Anaemia

Several treatments are available for managing anaemia in NTDT patients:

  • Luspatercept: Approved in Europe for treating anaemia in adult NTDT patients [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].
  • Mitapivat: An oral medication that has shown efficacy in reducing markers of ineffective erythropoiesis and improving anaemia in thalassaemia mouse models [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].

Other Considerations

For NTDT patients, it is important to consider the following:

  • Short-term or long-term interventions targeting ineffective erythropoiesis and anaemia based on patient profiles [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=32].
  • Monitoring and managing iron overload, especially if transfusion therapy is considered [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=32].
  • Appropriate nutritional, vitamin, and supplement support [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=113].

For more detailed information or specific queries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Are there any long-term studies on the use of hydroxyurea in thalassemia patients?
answer:
Long-Term Studies on the Use of Hydroxyurea in Thalassemia Patients

Several long-term studies have been conducted to evaluate the safety and efficacy of hydroxyurea in thalassemia patients. Here are some key findings:

Study Findings

  • Response and Efficacy: Response to hydroxyurea therapy is commonly noted within the first 3 to 6 months, with further improvements observed up to 12 months. Sustained responses have been observed over long-term follow-up. However, some studies noted a decline in hematological response beyond 12 months, suggesting potential impairment in the ability of certain hematopoietic stem cells to effectively give rise to erythroid lineage cells [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=35].
  • Safety and Tolerability: Hydroxyurea therapy was generally well tolerated at the doses used in NTDT studies, with some studies reporting no adverse events even with long-term therapy. The rate of myelotoxicity ranged between 2% and 30%, and it was usually dose-dependent, especially when doses exceeded 20 mg/kg/day. Myelotoxicity could be reversed upon dose reduction [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=35].
  • Comprehensive Single-Center Experience: A comprehensive single-center study reported the long-term safety and efficacy of hydroxyurea in patients with non-transfusion-dependent beta-thalassemia. This study highlighted the sustained benefits and manageable side effects of long-term hydroxyurea therapy [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=43].
  • Combination Therapy: Studies have also explored the combination therapy of hydroxyurea with other agents like L-carnitine and magnesium chloride, showing improvements in hematologic parameters and cardiac function in patients with beta-thalassemia intermedia [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=43].
  • Reduction in Complications: Hydroxyurea therapy has been associated with reduced odds of complications such as extramedullary hematopoietic pseudotumors, pulmonary hypertension, leg ulcers, hypothyroidism, and osteoporosis in beta-thalassemia intermedia patients [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=27].

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Hidrogen saja maksudnya ?
answer:
Pengaruh Hidrogen terhadap Thalassemia

Jika yang dimaksud adalah hidrogen dalam bentuk hidrogen peroksida (H2O2), maka hidrogen peroksida dapat bereaksi dengan besi ferrous (Fe2+) melalui reaksi Fenton untuk membentuk radikal hidroksil dan oksigen singlet. Reaksi ini secara dramatis memperkuat kerusakan oksidan yang diakibatkan oleh proses inflamasi. Durasi atau "area di bawah kurva" paparan terhadap spesies oksidan ini adalah penyebab utama kerusakan organ terkait besi pada pasien thalassemia [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=116].

Namun, jika yang dimaksud adalah hidrogen secara umum, tidak ada informasi yang tersedia dalam sumber yang diberikan mengenai pengaruh hidrogen terhadap thalassemia. Untuk informasi lebih lanjut, Anda dapat menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: 2021 TDT 4TH EDITION
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

  • ß-thalassaemia mutations: Over 200 mutations have been identified, ranging from silent to very severe. These mutations can result in different forms of the disease, from mild thalassaemia intermedia to severe thalassaemia major [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=26].
  • Examples of mutations:
    B++ mutations ß+ mutations Bo mutations
    -101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
    IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
    IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
    C39
    [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=26]

Impact on Severity

  • Homozygous ß-thalassaemia: The severity can range from thalassaemia major, requiring regular blood transfusions, to thalassaemia intermedia, which may require occasional or no transfusions [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=26].
  • Co-inheritance of a-thalassaemia: This can reduce the severity of the disease by decreasing the imbalance between α- and ß-chains [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=26].
  • Increased HbF production: Genetic determinants that increase the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) can ameliorate the phenotype, leading to a milder form of the disease [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=26].
  • Genome-wide association studies: Identified loci such as BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB that influence disease severity by affecting HbF levels [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=26].

For more detailed information or specific cases, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins. There are two main types of thalassaemia based on the affected globin protein: α-thalassaemia and β-thalassaemia.

β-Thalassaemia

β-thalassaemia occurs due to mutations in the HBB gene, which affects the production of the β-globin protein. The severity of β-thalassaemia can vary widely based on the specific mutations and other genetic factors:

  • More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe forms [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Severe β-thalassaemia alleles can result in thalassaemia major, characterized by severe, life-threatening anaemia requiring regular blood transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Less severe mutations or the co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or genetic determinants that increase HbF production can result in thalassaemia intermedia, which may require occasional or no transfusions [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Specific mutations, such as the mild β+-type mutation -88 (C->T), generally result in a very mild clinical phenotype [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

α-Thalassaemia

α-thalassaemia occurs when genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated. The co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia can ameliorate the severity of β-thalassaemia by reducing the imbalance between α- and β-chains [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].

Other Genetic Factors

Several other genetic factors can influence the severity of thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of genetic determinants that increase γ-globin chain production and HbF can ameliorate the phenotype [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Changes in the ubiquitin-proteasome system or expression of α-haemoglobin stabilising protein can help detoxify and tolerate a modest pool of free α-globin, reducing disease severity [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

For more detailed information or specific cases, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: I can't go to the doctor how can I treat the thalassemia
answer:
How to Treat Thalassaemia Without Visiting a Doctor

While it is crucial to have regular medical supervision for thalassaemia, here are some steps you can take if you are unable to visit a doctor:

Blood Transfusions

Patients with thalassaemia major or transfusion-dependent thalassaemia need regular blood transfusions, usually every 2-5 weeks, to manage severe anaemia. If you cannot visit a doctor, try to arrange for blood transfusions at a local healthcare facility or through a home healthcare service if available [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

Iron Chelation Therapy

Iron chelation therapy is essential to remove excess iron from the body, which accumulates due to frequent blood transfusions. There are three main types of iron chelators:

  • Deferoxamine: Administered through subcutaneous injection.
  • Deferiprone: Taken orally.
  • Deferasirox: Taken orally [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].

Ensure you have a supply of your prescribed chelation medication and follow the dosage instructions carefully.

Diet and Supplements

Consider dietary adjustments to help manage iron levels:

  • Drink tea with meals to reduce iron absorption.
  • Consider botanicals like turmeric, wheatgrass, and silymarin, but consult with a healthcare provider before starting any new supplement.
  • Take a multi-vitamin mineral supplement without iron [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=27].

General Advice

Follow general health advice to manage thalassaemia effectively:

  • Limit intake of foods with added sugars.
  • Avoid smoking and limit alcohol consumption.
  • Maintain a varied diet rich in fruits and vegetables [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=27].

For more detailed guidance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the key components of a comprehensive national thalassaemia program?
answer:
Key Components of a Comprehensive National Thalassaemia Program

A comprehensive national thalassaemia program should include the following key components:

  • Public awareness and education campaigns to inform the community about thalassaemia [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=17].
  • Screening programs to identify carriers of the disease [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=17].
  • Provision of genetic counseling to individuals and at-risk couples [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=17].
  • Establishment and promotion of National Thalassaemia Patient/Parents Associations to advocate for necessary improvements in services [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=80].
  • Encouragement and support for studies and research to improve prevention strategies, clinical care, and to achieve a final cure [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=80].
  • Extension of knowledge and experiences from countries with successful control programs to those in need through educational programs, workshops, conferences, and electronic courses [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=80].
  • Promotion of policies to regional and national health authorities to prioritize thalassaemia on health agendas [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=80].
  • Establishment of equal access to high-quality health and social care services for all patients with thalassaemia [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=12].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources provided or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Thrombophilia and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Iron overload, leading to liver fibrosis, cirrhosis, and heart disease [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58]
  • Delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice) [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Dark urine [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Endocrine problems such as delayed puberty, diabetes, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities like arrhythmias and heart failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities including cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Wie viele menschen in deutschland haben a-thalassämie
answer:
Die genaue Anzahl der Menschen in Deutschland, die Alpha-Thalassämie haben, ist nicht direkt in den verfügbaren Quellen angegeben. Es ist jedoch bekannt, dass Alpha-Thalassämie in Populationen aus Südostasien, China, dem Mittelmeerraum und dem Nahen Osten häufiger vorkommt [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=4][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=10].

Aufgrund der Migration aus diesen Regionen gibt es auch in Deutschland eine zunehmende Anzahl von Trägern und Patienten mit Alpha-Thalassämie [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=10].

Für genauere Informationen oder spezifische Fragen wenden Sie sich bitte an info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Apakah olahraga dianjurkan untuk penderita thalassemia?
answer:
Olahraga untuk Penderita Thalassemia

Olahraga dianjurkan untuk penderita thalassemia karena memiliki berbagai manfaat, meskipun penelitian khusus mengenai manfaatnya pada penderita thalassemia masih terbatas. Berikut adalah beberapa poin penting terkait olahraga untuk penderita thalassemia:

  • Aktivitas fisik dikaitkan dengan peningkatan kualitas hidup, pengurangan rasa sakit, penurunan kadar ferritin serum, dan peningkatan kepadatan tulang [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=170].
  • Faktor-faktor seperti rasa sakit, anemia, kelelahan, dan kapasitas latihan yang menurun dapat mengurangi aktivitas fisik pada penderita thalassemia [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=163].
  • Aktivitas fisik yang tidak melibatkan kontak fisik dan yang melibatkan beban tubuh seperti berjalan sangat dianjurkan. Namun, konsultasi dengan ahli hematologi dan/atau ahli jantung pasien sebelum memulai program latihan sangat penting [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=170][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=162].
  • Olahraga tidak boleh menggantikan khelasi yang memadai atau nutrisi yang optimal, tetapi dianggap sebagai aktivitas sinergis untuk promosi kesehatan [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=170][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=163].
  • Evaluasi yang hati-hati diperlukan jika aktivitas atletik dipertimbangkan, terutama mengingat komorbiditas seperti penyakit tulang yang umum pada penderita thalassemia [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=232].

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut, Anda dapat menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sumber: Nutrition Guide Thal PKD, Guidelines for the Management of Transfusion Dependent Thalassaemia

question: Indications of splenectomy in thalassemia
answer:
Indications of Splenectomy in Thalassaemia

Splenectomy is a surgical procedure that may be considered for patients with thalassaemia under specific clinical scenarios. However, it is not recommended as a standard procedure due to the associated risks and complications. Here are the main indications for splenectomy in thalassaemia:

  • Increased Blood Requirements: When the blood transfusion requirement is so high that it prevents adequate control with iron chelation therapy. This is typically flagged by an annual transfusion volume of 200-275 mL/kg/year of red cells, provided the increased requirements are not due to allo/auto-antibodies or blood loss [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=107][EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=31].
  • Hypersplenism: This condition is characterized by cytopenias (low blood cell counts) causing clinical problems [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=31].
  • Symptomatic Splenomegaly: When the spleen is significantly enlarged, causing symptoms such as left upper quadrant pain, early satiety, or concerns about possible splenic rupture [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=31][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=41].
  • Oversized Spleen: When the spleen is more than 6 cm below the costal margin and causing discomfort [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Other Signs of an Overactive Spleen: Such as low white blood cell count and low platelet count [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

It is important to note that splenectomy should be avoided in children under 5 years of age due to the significantly higher risk of fulminant post-splenectomy sepsis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=102].

For more detailed guidelines, please refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) guidelines available at www.thalassaemia.org.cy.

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Vitamina k?
answer:
Vitamina K

La vitamina K è un termine generico utilizzato per un gruppo di composti liposolubili con strutture simili. Esistono due forme principali di vitamina K:

  • Vitamina K1 (fillochinone): È la forma principale presente nelle diete occidentali, trovata principalmente nelle verdure a foglia verde, nei semi di soia e negli oli di soia, nelle noci, nei semi e in alcuni frutti [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=107][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=108].
  • Vitamina K2 (menachinone): Prodotta dai batteri, ha una vita più lunga nel corpo. Si trova negli alimenti fermentati, nei cibi in salamoia e in alcune fonti animali come uova e formaggi [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=107][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=108].

La vitamina K è essenziale per la carbossilazione dell'acido glutammico nelle proteine della cascata della coagulazione, permettendo al calcio di legarsi a queste proteine e attivare il processo di coagulazione. È anche responsabile della carbossilazione dell'acido glutammico nell'osteocalcina, una proteina fondamentale per la formazione delle ossa [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=107][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=108].

La vitamina K2 è riconosciuta come un "chaperone del calcio", permettendo al calcio di essere depositato in modo sicuro nelle ossa e prevenendo la sua deposizione nelle arterie [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=108].

Le fonti alimentari più ricche di vitamina K1 includono:

Fonte Alimentare, Quantità Vitamina K1, µg
Verza, bollita 1/2 tazza 530
Spinaci, crudi 1 tazza 145
Broccoli, bolliti, 1/2 tazza 110
Olio di soia, 1 cucchiaio 25
Pignoli, 1 oncia 15
Anacardi, 1 oncia 10

Le fonti alimentari di vitamina K2 includono:

Fonte Alimentare, Quantità Vitamina K2, µg
Natto, 1 cucchiaio (MK-7) 150
Petto di pollo, 3 once (MK-4) 13
Formaggio cheddar, 50 grammi (MK-4) 12
Uovo, sodo, 1 (MK-4) 4

Per ulteriori informazioni, puoi contattare info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How early does the thalassemia detected?
answer:
Early Detection of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can be detected at various stages, depending on the methods used and the specific circumstances:

Carrier Testing and Family Studies

Carrier testing can identify individuals at risk for thalassaemia and other haemoglobinopathies. This is particularly effective in families with a history of the disorder, as many carriers can be detected early. Family studies following the diagnosis of a child with thalassaemia can identify carriers who can then receive reproductive counselling [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=79].

Newborn Screening

Newborn screening can detect carriers of beta-thalassaemia by measuring the expression of HbA at birth. This allows for early identification of carriers and can prevent unnecessary treatments [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=146]. However, diagnosing thalassaemia major at birth can be challenging due to the presence of foetal haemoglobin (HbF), which balances the number of globin chains and protects the child from ineffective red blood cell production. Molecular techniques can identify mutations, but these tests are usually performed only when there is a specific suspicion [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=32].

Surveillance and Follow-Up

Surveillance for early detection of complications, such as cardiovascular issues, is crucial for managing thalassaemia. Regular monitoring and specific patient-oriented programs are recommended [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=144].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Here are the editions of the guidelines and publications relevant to the management of thalassaemia:

  • Guidelines for the Management of Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT): 5th Edition [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=459]
  • Guidelines for the Management of Non-Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (NTDT): 2nd Edition [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=1]

  • Guidelines for the Clinical Management of Thalassaemia: 2nd Revised Edition, 2008 [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=23]
  • Guidelines for the Management of Non-Transfusion-Dependent ß-Thalassaemia: 3rd Edition, 2023 [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=384]

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood. The symptoms of thalassaemia can vary and may include severe anaemia, delayed growth and development, excessive tiredness and fatigue, yellow or pale skin (jaundice), dark urine, bone deformities, and enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to a range of complications, primarily due to iron overload from repeated blood transfusions. These complications include:

  • Chronic anaemia: poor vitality and growth
  • Expansion of haemopoietic tissue: deformities and pressure effects
  • Hypersplenism
  • Infections
  • Cardiac complications: siderosis, heart failure, arrhythmias, myocarditis
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Liver complications: siderosis, viral hepatitis, fibrosis, cirrhosis, liver failure, hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Endocrine complications: growth failure, hypogonadic hypogonadism, diabetes [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]

Iron overload can cause severe complications, including liver fibrosis and cirrhosis, heart disease, and delayed sexual maturation. These complications can appear as early as 10 years of age if not managed properly [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Quale valore post trasfusioni è ottimale per un paziente con Talassemia Major trasfusione dipendente
answer:
Valore Ottimale di Emoglobina Post-Trasfusione per Pazienti con Talassemia Major Trasfusione Dipendente

Per i pazienti con talassemia major dipendenti da trasfusioni, il valore ottimale di emoglobina post-trasfusione dovrebbe essere mantenuto tra 13-14 g/dL. Questo aiuta a garantire una buona ossigenazione e a minimizzare i sintomi dell'anemia [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=47].

Se hai bisogno di ulteriori informazioni, puoi contattare info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

There are more than 200 known ß-thalassaemia mutations, which can result in a range of phenotypic severities from very mild to very severe:

  • Severe (ß0) mutations: Examples include IVS1-1, IVS1-[-25], and C39.
  • Less severe (ß+) mutations: Examples include IVS1-110, IVS11-745, and IVS1-5.
  • Mild (ß++) mutations: Examples include -101, -87, -88, and -28.

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf]

Impact of Genetic Modifiers

The severity of thalassaemia can be influenced by several genetic factors:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the imbalance between α- and ß-globin chains, leading to a milder form of the disease.
  • Increased production of γ-globin chains: This results in higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can ameliorate the severity of the disease.
  • Genome-wide association studies (GWAS): Identified loci such as BCL11A on chromosome 2p16 and HBS1L-MYB intergenic region on chromosome 6q23 that influence disease severity.

[2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf][NursesGuide_English.pdf]

Examples of Specific Mutations

Some specific mutations and their effects include:

  • ß+-type mutation -88 (C->T): Generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype.
  • ß+-thalassaemia mutation Cap+1 (A->C): Can result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients.

[Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf]

Conclusion

The genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity are complex and influenced by a variety of factors. Accurate genetic diagnosis and counseling are essential for managing the condition effectively.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What hb levels blood transfusion should be given in ntdt
answer:
Haemoglobin Levels for Blood Transfusion in NTDT

In NTDT patients, the decision to initiate blood transfusion therapy should not be based solely on haemoglobin levels, except in cases of considerably severe anaemia (haemoglobin level <5 g/dL). Here are the key considerations:

General Recommendations

Occasional blood transfusions should be considered in NTDT patients in settings with anticipated acute stress, haemoglobin drop, or blood loss, such as:

  • Pregnancy
  • Surgery
  • Infections

More frequent transfusions should be considered in the following settings, with reassessment for tapering or withdrawal when a sustained clinical benefit is achieved:

  • Declining haemoglobin level in parallel with profound enlargement of the spleen (at a rate exceeding 3 cm/year in periods of maximal growth and development)
  • Growth failure (height is more indicative of growth pattern than weight)
  • Poor performance at school
  • Diminished exercise tolerance
  • Failure of secondary sexual development in parallel with bone age
  • Signs of bony changes
  • Frequent haemolytic crisis (haemoglobin H disease)
  • Poor quality of life

Transfusions may also be considered for the primary prevention, management, or secondary prevention of complications [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=20].

Pregnancy

During pregnancy, blood transfusion therapy is commonly considered due to the intensification of anaemia. Data suggest that keeping haemoglobin levels above 10 g/dL is optimal for fetal development and to avoid complications such as intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD), or preterm delivery [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=88][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=92].

For more detailed information, please refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation guidelines or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: hypertransfusion protocol
answer:
Hypertransfusion Protocol

The hypertransfusion protocol is an aggressive transfusion strategy aimed at maintaining higher levels of functional haemoglobin to reduce the production of endogenous, non-functional haemoglobin and improve overall patient outcomes. This approach is particularly relevant for patients with severe forms of thalassaemia, such as α-thalassaemia major and β-thalassaemia major. Here are the key aspects of the hypertransfusion protocol:

  • Pre-Transfusion Haemoglobin Levels: The goal is to maintain pre-transfusion haemoglobin levels at 9.5 to 10 g/dL [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39]. For patients with α-thalassaemia major, the target is to maintain functional haemoglobin (HbA) >90 g/L, or total haemoglobin at 105-110 g/L if precise HbH measurements are not available [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=184].
  • Transfusion Frequency: Patients typically require regular transfusions every two to four weeks to maintain the desired haemoglobin levels [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Blood Volume and Rate: The volume of blood transfused is calculated based on the patient's weight and clinical status. Generally, 10-15 ml of packed red blood cells per kg of body weight is transfused over 3-4 hours [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Iron Chelation Therapy: Due to the increased iron load from frequent transfusions, iron chelation therapy is essential to prevent iron overload and its associated complications [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=61].
  • Monitoring and Adjustments: The effectiveness of the transfusion therapy should be regularly evaluated. The haemoglobin fall should not exceed 1 g/dL per week in patients with an intact spleen and 1.5 g/dL per week in patients who have undergone splenectomy [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=168].

For more detailed guidelines, please refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) guidelines available at www.thalassaemia.org.cy.

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What is thalassemia
answer:
What is Thalassaemia?

Thalassaemia is a term used to describe a group of inherited blood disorders characterized by the body's inability to produce enough normal haemoglobin, the protein in red blood cells responsible for carrying oxygen throughout the body. This results in a shortage of functional red blood cells and low levels of oxygen in the bloodstream, leading to various health problems depending on the type and severity of the condition.

There are two main types of thalassaemia:

  • Alpha-thalassaemia: Caused by insufficient production of alpha-globin chains.
  • Beta-thalassaemia: Caused by inadequate production of beta-globin chains.

Beta-thalassaemia major, also known as thalassaemia major, is a severe form of the disease that results in transfusion-dependent anaemia and requires regular blood transfusions and chelation therapy to manage iron overload.

Thalassaemia is a genetic disorder passed on from parents to their children and is not caused by environmental factors or nutrition.

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Source: TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf, EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf, ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf, TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf, FocusOnAThal_EN.pdf, HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf, TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf, Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What types of psychosocial support are available for thalassaemia patients?
answer:
Psychosocial Support for Thalassaemia Patients

Psychosocial support is a crucial component of the comprehensive care for thalassaemia patients. Here are the types of psychosocial support available:

Comprehensive Team Approach

Thalassaemia centres of excellence, particularly in high-income countries, use a comprehensive team approach. These teams include:

  • Skilled nursing staff
  • Psychologists
  • Social workers
  • Family or child-life specialists

These professionals are equipped to assess and address social, emotional, or cognitive concerns and provide necessary interventions [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=258].

Support from NGOs

Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) play a significant role in providing psychosocial support by:

  • Encouraging optimism about the future
  • Improving life outside of thalassaemia
  • Enabling patients to pursue their dreams
  • Collaborating with the medical community to provide services like evening clinics [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=40]

Support for Parents

Effective psychological support for parents, especially around the time of diagnosis, includes:

  • Providing necessary information about thalassaemia
  • Opportunities to ask questions and share concerns
  • Meeting other parents of children with thalassaemia
  • Access to psychosocial clinicians to manage feelings of loss constructively [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=251]

Social Support Throughout Development

Social support is important for the psychological functioning of children and their families. This includes:

  • Deciding how to present information about the condition to friends and family
  • Learning about the harmful effects of keeping thalassaemia a secret
  • Relying on existing support systems
  • Meeting other patients and families through camps and events [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=254]

Age-Specific Support

Psychosocial support should be tailored to the patient's age, including:

  • Children
  • Adolescents (transition period)
  • Older adults (pain issues) [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=260]

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Cardiovascular in thalassaemia
answer:
Cardiovascular Disease in Thalassaemia

Cardiovascular (CV) disease in thalassaemia is primarily determined by the following factors:

  • The severity of the haematological defect dictated by the genetic background.
  • The applied disease-specific therapy including blood transfusions and iron chelation.
  • The impact of patients' ageing, increasing the occurrence of age-related conditions [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=19].

Spectrum of Cardiovascular Disease

The spectrum of CV disease in thalassaemia includes:

  • Left and/or right ventricular dysfunction, with or without heart failure.
  • Pulmonary hypertension.
  • Tachyarrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation) and bradyarrhythmias (e.g., atrioventricular block).
  • Valvular disease.
  • Pericarditis and myocarditis.
  • Thromboembolic events, resulting from either venous or arterial thrombosis.
  • Cerebrovascular disease, manifested as either ischaemic or haemorrhagic stroke.
  • Vascular abnormalities, including endothelial dysfunction and increased arterial stiffness [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=19].

Regular Assessment

Regular cardiovascular assessment should be part of a transfusion-dependent ß-thalassaemia (TDT) patient's multidisciplinary monitoring programme. This includes:

  • Annual cardiological examination, regardless of the presence of history or symptoms [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=19].
  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) T2*-guided iron chelation therapy to prevent cardiac dysfunction related to iron overload [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=146].
  • Echocardiographic screening starting at the age of 10 years [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=146].

Impact of Chronic Anaemia

Chronic anaemia in thalassaemia is associated with a vasodilated circulation and lower blood pressure compared to non-thalassaemic individuals. This can lead to:

  • Reduced vascular compliance and increased afterload on the heart.
  • Development of restrictive ventricular physiology, contributing to atrial fibrillation and heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=126].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

There are more than 200 known ß-thalassaemia mutations, which can result in a range of phenotypic severities from very mild to very severe:

  • Severe (ß0) mutations: Examples include IVS1-1, IVS11-1, and C39.
  • Less severe (ß+) mutations: Examples include IVS1-110, IVS11-745, and IVS1-5.
  • Mild (ß++) mutations: Examples include -101, -87, -88, and -28.

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Impact of Genetic Modifiers

The severity of thalassaemia can be influenced by several genetic modifiers:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the imbalance between α- and ß-globin chains, leading to a milder form of the disease.
  • Increased production of γ-globin chains: This results in higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can ameliorate the severity of the disease.
  • Hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH): Mutations that lead to high HbF levels can result in a milder form of ß-thalassaemia intermedia when combined with severe ß-thalassaemia alleles.
  • Genome-wide association studies (GWAS): Identified loci such as BCL11A on chromosome 2p16 and HBS1L-MYB intergenic region on chromosome 6q23 that influence disease severity.

[2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37]

Examples of Specific Mutations

Some specific mutations and their typical clinical outcomes include:

  • ß+-type mutation -88 (C->T): Generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype.
  • ß+-thalassaemia mutation Cap+1 (A->C): Can result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients.

[Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72]

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the symptoms of Yersinia infection in thalassaemia patients?
answer:
Symptoms of Yersinia Infection in Thalassaemia Patients

Yersinia enterocolitica infections in thalassaemia patients can present with a variety of symptoms. Key symptoms include:

  • Fever, which is the most common presenting feature [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=170].
  • Abdominal pain and enterocolitis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=170].
  • Diarrhoea [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=13][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=67].
  • Pharyngitis-tonsillitis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=170].
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=170].
  • Polyarthritis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=170].
  • Joint pains and skin rashes [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=63].
  • Sore throat [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=67].
  • Vomiting [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=63].

In severe cases, complications can include hepatic and splenic abscesses, osteomyelitis, intussusception, nephritis, meningitis, and endocarditis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=170].

If you suspect a Yersinia infection, it is crucial to stop DFO treatment immediately and begin intensive antibiotic treatment [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=63][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=170].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: My son telasamia major pation she ffritin 2600
answer:
Managing Ferritin Levels in Thalassaemia Major

For patients with thalassaemia major, it is crucial to monitor and manage ferritin levels to reduce the risk of complications, particularly cardiac issues. Here are some key points regarding ferritin levels:

  • Ferritin levels should ideally be kept between 1000-2000 µg/L to minimize the risk of complications [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69].
  • Consistently maintaining ferritin levels below 2500 µg/L has been shown to reduce the risk of cardiac complications [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69].
  • Ferritin levels can be influenced by factors such as inflammation, infections, and liver disease, so results should be interpreted with caution [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=61].
  • Regular monitoring of ferritin levels is recommended, ideally every 3 months for patients with thalassaemia major [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69].

Given that your son's ferritin level is 2600 µg/L, it is slightly above the recommended threshold. It is important to consult with his healthcare provider to discuss potential adjustments in his treatment plan, which may include iron chelation therapy to reduce iron overload.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: In Swahili
answer:
Je, ni mabadiliko gani ya kawaida ya thalassemia nchini Ugiriki?

Kulingana na data, mabadiliko ya kawaida ya thalassemia nchini Ugiriki ni pamoja na:

  • IVSI-110 G-A [PreventionVol2_English.pdf]
  • IVSI-5 (G-A) [PreventionVol1_English.pdf]
  • IVSI-6 (T-C) [PreventionVol1_English.pdf]
  • IVSI-109 (-T) [PreventionVol1_English.pdf]
  • CAP+10 (-T) [PreventionVol1_English.pdf]

Kwa maelezo zaidi, unaweza kuwasiliana kupitia barua pepe info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

answer:
Thalassaemia Information

If you have any questions or need assistance regarding thalassaemia, especially in the context of the COVID-19 outbreak, you can reach out to the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) Help Desk & Communication Line. They have created a dedicated line for issues concerning COVID-19.
