If you need more detailed information or have specific concerns, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: how do i know which iron chelator is best for my patient
answer:
Choosing the Best Iron Chelator for Your Patient

To determine the best iron chelator for your patient, consider the following factors:

  • Route of Administration: Deferoxamine is administered via subcutaneous injection, while Deferiprone and Deferasirox are taken orally [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf].
  • Effectiveness: All three chelators are effective individually or in combination. Deferiprone is particularly effective at protecting and restoring cardiac function [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=122].
  • Side Effects: Severe renal complications with Deferasirox are rare but can be fatal and are preventable by monitoring [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=122].
  • Adherence: Adherence to therapy is crucial. The primary goal is to apply an effective plan that the patient can closely follow [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=122].
  • Patient's Needs: The choice of chelator, dose, and frequency of administration should be tailored to the patient's needs, including the frequency of transfusions, the amount of iron in the body, and the patient's lifestyle [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: My baby is diagnosed with Thalassemia major and she has Ferritin level is 2200
answer:
Management of High Ferritin Levels in Thalassemia Major

I'm sorry to hear about your baby's diagnosis. With a ferritin level of 2200 µg/L, it is important to manage iron overload to prevent complications. Here are some key points to consider:

Iron Chelation Therapy

  • Iron chelation therapy should be initiated after 10-20 blood transfusions or when ferritin levels rise above 1000 µg/L [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69].
  • For children, the recommended dose of Desferioxamine (DFO) is 20-40 mg/kg, administered subcutaneously over 8-12 hours, at least 5 days a week [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=77].
  • Combined chelation therapy (e.g., deferoxamine and deferiprone) is recommended for patients with high serum ferritin or hepatic iron overload [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=56].

Monitoring

  • Ferritin levels should be monitored at least every 3 months [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69].
  • Cardiac T2* MRI should be performed from age 8, every 2 years if T2* > 20 ms, annually if T2* is 10-20 ms, and every 6 months if T2* < 10 ms or if ejection fraction (EF) is reduced [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=69].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the common complications in adult female thalassaemia patients?
answer:
Common Complications in Adult Female Thalassaemia Patients

Adult female thalassaemia patients may experience a range of complications, primarily due to iron overload and other factors associated with the disease. Some of the common complications include:

Endocrine Complications

  • Hypogonadism: Affects both males and females, with rates between 40% and 80% [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40].
  • Hypothyroidism [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Growth retardation [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Diabetes mellitus [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Delayed puberty and failure of sexual functions [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=82].

Reproductive Health

  • Secondary amenorrhea (absence of menstruation) and elevated gonadotropin levels after bone marrow transplantation [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=7].
  • Infertility due to iron overload affecting the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=68].

Bone Health

  • Low bone mass and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=120].

Cardiac and Hepatic Complications

  • Arrhythmias and congestive heart failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].
  • Liver disease, including cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42].

For more detailed information, please refer to the following sources:

  • TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf
  • AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf
  • AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf
  • TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf
  • NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf
  • NursesGuide_English.pdf

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the long-term complications of TDT?
answer:
Long-Term Complications of Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT)

Patients with Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT) face several long-term complications primarily due to iron overload from chronic blood transfusions and other factors such as chronic anaemia, nutritional deficiencies, and chronic liver disease. Here are some of the key complications:

Endocrine Complications

  • Hypogonadism: Affects 40% to 80% of patients, resulting from iron deposition in the pituitary gland. Hormone replacement therapy can alleviate symptoms and prevent long-term complications [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40].
  • Hypothyroidism: Reduced thyroid function due to iron overload [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40].
  • Growth Retardation: Poor growth due to chronic anaemia and iron overload [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40].
  • Diabetes Mellitus: Impaired glucose tolerance and diabetes are more common in individuals with TDT [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=40].

Hepatic Complications

  • Hepatic Vaso-Occlusive Disease (VOD): Occurs in 10-13% of cases after myeloablative busulfan therapy, but resolves with appropriate treatment [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=405].
  • Cholelithiasis: Gallstones may develop in suboptimally transfused patients due to increased peripheral haemolysis [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=252].

Infectious Complications

  • Transfusion-Transmitted Infections (TTI): Despite improved donor testing, long-term transfusion support carries a risk of infections due to undetected pathogens [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=261].
  • Increased Infection Risk: Procedures like splenectomy and the use of central venous catheters can contribute to higher infection rates [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=261].

Other Complications

  • Bone Complications: Pathological fractures and facial changes due to excessive intramedullary haematopoiesis [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=47].
  • Cardiovascular Complications: Regular transfusions have cardioprotective effects, but iron overload can lead to end-organ failure [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=22].
  • Infertility: Myeloablative chemo-conditioning may result in long-term infertility [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=405].

For further assistance or more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Was sind die grundlegenden unterschiede zwischen a-und ß-thalassämie
answer:
Grundlegende Unterschiede zwischen α- und β-Thalassämie

Thalassämie ist eine Gruppe von erblichen Blutkrankheiten, die durch eine verringerte Produktion von Hämoglobin, dem Protein, das Sauerstoff in den roten Blutkörperchen transportiert, gekennzeichnet sind. Es gibt zwei Haupttypen von Thalassämie: Alpha (α-) und Beta (β-) Thalassämie. Hier sind die grundlegenden Unterschiede zwischen ihnen:

Alpha-Thalassämie

  • Ursache: Alpha-Thalassämie wird durch eine unzureichende Synthese der Alpha-Globinketten verursacht. Dies geschieht aufgrund von Mutationen in den vier Alpha-Globin-Genen auf Chromosom 16 [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=199][TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=29].
  • Formen:
    • Silent Carrier: Eine Mutation in einem der vier Alpha-Globin-Gene, meist ohne Symptome [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=29].
    • Alpha-Thalassämie Trait: Zwei betroffene Gene, was zu einer milden Anämie führen kann [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=8].
    • HbH-Krankheit: Drei betroffene Gene, was zu einer moderaten bis schweren Anämie führt [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=8].
    • Hb Bart's Hydrops Fetalis: Alle vier Gene betroffen, was meist tödlich ist [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15].
  • Symptome: Die Symptome variieren je nach Anzahl der betroffenen Gene und reichen von asymptomatisch bis zu schwerer Anämie und Hydrops fetalis [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15].

Beta-Thalassämie

  • Ursache: Beta-Thalassämie wird durch eine unzureichende Synthese der Beta-Globinketten verursacht. Dies geschieht aufgrund von Mutationen in den zwei Beta-Globin-Genen auf Chromosom 11 [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=2][EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=7].
  • Formen:
    • Beta-Thalassämie Trait: Eine Mutation in einem der beiden Beta-Globin-Gene, meist ohne Symptome oder mit milder Anämie [ThalCarrierCheck_EN_Final_end.pdf#page=1].
    • Beta-Thalassämie Intermedia: Milder bis moderater Schweregrad, gelegentlich Bluttransfusionen erforderlich [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=8].
    • Beta-Thalassämie Major (Cooley's Anämie): Beide Gene betroffen, was zu schwerer Anämie führt und regelmäßige Bluttransfusionen erfordert [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=2][ThalCarrierCheck_EN_Final_end.pdf#page=1].
  • Symptome: Die Symptome reichen von mild bis schwer und umfassen Anämie, Wachstumsstörungen, Knochendeformitäten und Eisenüberladung [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=2][EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=7].

Für weitere Informationen oder spezifische Fragen wenden Sie sich bitte an info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Has the BCL11A gene therapy been approved?
answer:
BCL11A Gene Therapy Approval Status

As of the latest available information, the BCL11A gene therapy has not yet been approved. Clinical trials are still ongoing, with Phase 1/2 trials being conducted by Sangamo Therapeutics and Vertex Pharmaceuticals Incorporated. These trials are in various stages of recruitment and activity, but no regulatory approval has been granted yet.

For further assistance or more detailed information, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Source: TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0)

question: TDT 4th Edition
answer:
TDT 4th Edition

The 4th edition of the "Guidelines for the Management of Transfusion Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT)" was published in June 2022. This edition includes a comprehensive review of the evidence supporting each recommendation, aimed at helping physicians make informed clinical decisions. The guidelines are designed to support healthcare professionals worldwide in providing optimal care for patients with TDT and advocating for better resources at the national level.

The guidelines also emphasize the importance of early diagnosis and effective management of morbidity, which can help in predicting risks and implementing preventive measures. This can save unnecessary healthcare costs and ensure that patients are in good clinical status to benefit from novel therapies such as gene therapy and molecules targeting ineffective erythropoiesis (e.g., Luspatercept) [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the full-length guidelines or the pocket guide provided by the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Wie heißt der prozess bei dem Erythrozyten gebildet werden
answer:
Prozess der Erythrozytenbildung

Der Prozess, bei dem Erythrozyten (rote Blutkörperchen) gebildet werden, heißt Erythropoese.

Weitere Informationen finden Sie in der Quelle: AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf

question: Any other supplements you recommend
answer:
Recommended Supplements for Thalassemia Patients

In addition to folic acid, several other supplements are recommended for individuals with thalassemia to help manage their condition and improve overall health. Here are some key supplements and their recommended dosages:

Vitamin D

  • 1,000 - 2,000 IU/day or 50,000 IU monthly
  • Have vitamin D levels checked at least annually

Source: Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf

Vitamin C

  • Recommended only in conjunction with deferoxamine infusions at a dose of 2-3 mg/kg/day
  • 50 mg for children under 10 years, 100 mg for older children

Source: AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf

Vitamin E

  • Short-term supplementation for those with identified deficiency
  • Consume foods rich in vitamin E, such as wheat germ, nuts, and vegetable oils

Source: NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf

Zinc

  • 25 mg/day or 50 mg every other day if deficient
  • Preferably as zinc gluconate, acetate, or citrate

Source: Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf

Calcium

  • 2000 IU per day
  • Include high-calcium foods like milk, fish, and cheese in your diet

Source: TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf

Other Recommendations

  • Assess vitamin K, copper, magnesium, and selenium annually and supplement if deficient
  • Consider L-carnitine at a dose of 50 mg/kg/day

Source: NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf

If you have further questions or need personalized advice, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: I have had many strokes, should I have a HSCT?
answer:
Considering Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT) for Sickle Cell Disease

Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT) is currently the only potential cure for sickle cell disease (SCD). Given your history of multiple strokes, HSCT might be a viable option to consider. However, it is important to weigh the benefits and risks associated with this procedure.

Benefits of HSCT

  • HSCT can potentially cure SCD by replacing the defective haemoglobin with healthy haemoglobin from a donor.
  • It can prevent further complications such as strokes, pain crises, and organ damage.

Risks and Considerations

  • HSCT is an expensive and complex procedure that involves significant risks, including graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) and infections [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=18].
  • A compatible sibling donor is preferred to minimize risks and improve outcomes [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=18].
  • Patients must be in good health to tolerate the conditioning regimen required for HSCT [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=18].

Given the complexity and risks involved, it is crucial to discuss this option thoroughly with your healthcare provider. They can help assess your overall health, the availability of a suitable donor, and the potential benefits and risks specific to your case.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Do you have access to "Guidelines for the Management of Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (4th edition – Version 2.0)"?
answer:
Yes, I have access to the "Guidelines for the Management of Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (4th edition – Version 2.0)". Here are some key details:

4th Edition (Version 2.0)

  • Published by the Thalassaemia International Federation in 2021.
  • Editors: Cappellini, M.D., Farmakis, D., Porter, J., Taher, A.
  • Includes updated information on new approaches for more effective, safe, and less laborious treatment.
  • Provides an overview of progress towards a total cure using methods such as gene therapy and stem cell transplantation [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=18].
  • Contains a dedicated chapter on the value of patient engagement, highlighting the progress in making patients "expert" advocates of their needs [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=14].
  • Emphasizes the need for management guidelines due to varying standards of care across different countries [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=18].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the document directly or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What causes oxidative stress in alpha thalassemia
answer:
Causes of Oxidative Stress in Alpha Thalassemia

Oxidative stress in alpha thalassemia is primarily caused by the following factors:

  • Iron Overload: Excess iron from frequent blood transfusions and increased intestinal absorption leads to the accumulation of unbound iron in hepatocytes. This unbound iron generates toxic reactive oxygen species (ROS), causing oxidative stress, lipid peroxidation, and protein damage [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=127][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=60].
  • Red Blood Cell Damage: The oxidation of globin subunits in thalassemia erythroid cells leads to the formation of haemichromes, which precipitate and release toxic iron species. This free iron catalyzes the formation of ROS, leading to oxidative damage to cell membranes and haemolysis [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=66].
  • Deficiency of Antioxidants: Patients with thalassemia often have deficiencies in essential nutrients that function as antioxidants, such as vitamins C and E. This deficiency exacerbates oxidative stress [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=98][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=51].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins. There are two main types of thalassaemia based on the affected globin protein: α-thalassaemia and β-thalassaemia.

α-Thalassaemia

α-Thalassaemia occurs when one or more of the genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated. The severity of α-thalassaemia depends on the number of affected genes:

  • Loss of one α-globin gene has minimal effect.
  • Loss of two α-globin genes can lead to thalassaemia intermedia.
  • Loss of three or four α-globin genes results in more severe forms of the disease.

[Source: PreventionVol1_English.pdf]

β-Thalassaemia

β-Thalassaemia is caused by mutations affecting the production of the β-globin protein. There are over 200 known β-thalassaemia mutations, which can result in a wide range of phenotypic severities:

  • Severe β-thalassaemia mutations often lead to thalassaemia major, characterized by severe, life-threatening anaemia requiring regular blood transfusions.
  • Milder β-thalassaemia mutations can result in thalassaemia intermedia, where patients may require occasional or no transfusions.

[Source: Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf]

Genetic Interactions and Modifiers

The severity of thalassaemia can be influenced by various genetic interactions and modifiers:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia can ameliorate the severity of β-thalassaemia.
  • Mutations that increase the production of fetal haemoglobin (HbF) can also reduce disease severity.
  • Specific mutations, such as the Xmn1 polymorphism in the Gy-globin gene, can elevate HbF levels and result in a milder phenotype.

[Source: NursesGuide_English.pdf]

Examples of Mutations

β++ Mutations β+ Mutations β0 Mutations
-101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
C39

[Source: AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf]

Conclusion

The genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity are complex and influenced by various factors, including the specific mutations and genetic interactions. Accurate genetic diagnosis and counselling are essential for managing the condition effectively.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: what products are available for thalassemia?
answer:
Available Products for Thalassaemia

There are several products available for the treatment and management of thalassaemia. These include:

Iron Chelation Therapy

  • Desferrioxamine (Desferal): An iron chelator administered through subcutaneous or intravenous slow infusions. It has been used effectively for many years [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf][EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf].
  • Deferiprone (Ferriprox): An oral iron chelator used for the treatment of transfusional iron overload in patients with thalassaemia syndromes, sickle cell disease, and other anemias [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf][TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf].
  • Deferasirox: Another oral iron chelator available in many countries and used by thousands of patients worldwide [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf].

Blood Transfusions

Regular blood transfusions are essential for patients with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT). These patients typically receive 2 or more blood bags every 2-5 weeks [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf].

Novel Therapies

  • Luspatercept-aamt: An erythroid maturation agent that prolongs the lifespan of red blood cells, increasing haemoglobin levels and reducing the need for transfusions [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

Gene Therapy

  • Betibeglogene autotemcel: A gene therapy treatment approved by the EMA and FDA, which involves inserting healthy copies of the B-globin gene into the patient's haematopoietic cells [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=2].
  • ZYNTEGLO™: A gene therapy product for patients 12 years and older with transfusion-dependent ß-thalassaemia (TDT) [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=5].

Curative Options

The only current curative option for ß-thalassaemia is haemopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), which includes bone marrow transplantation (BMT) [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins, which are essential components of hemoglobin. The severity of thalassaemia can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Thalassaemia

  • α-thalassaemia: Occurs when genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • β-thalassaemia: Occurs when similar genetic defects affect the production of the β-globin protein. This type is further classified into thalassaemia major and thalassaemia minor.

Individuals with thalassaemia major inherit the defective gene from both parents and suffer from severe, life-threatening anaemia. Those with thalassaemia minor inherit the gene from one parent and are generally healthy and symptom-free [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].

Genetic Mutations and Their Impact

More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe. The severity of the condition can be influenced by the specific mutations and the presence of other genetic factors [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

Examples of Mutations

β++ mutations β+ mutations β0 mutations
-101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
C39

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

The severity of β-thalassaemia can be ameliorated by several genetic factors, including:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the imbalance between α- and β-globin chains, leading to a milder form of the disease [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Increased production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF): Genetic determinants that increase γ-globin chain production can lead to higher levels of HbF, which can partially compensate for the lack of adult hemoglobin (HbA) [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Specific mutations: Some mutations, such as the deletional hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH), can result in high HbF levels and a milder phenotype [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Thalassemia carrier reaserch
answer:
Thalassaemia Carrier Research

Research on thalassaemia carriers involves several key aspects, including screening, identification, and genetic analysis. Here are some important points:

Screening and Surveys

Identification of healthy carriers can be achieved through simple haematological tests, making population-scale screening possible. These tests are also used for epidemiological surveys to estimate the proportion of carriers in a given population. This helps in identifying at-risk groups within a population [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=27].

DNA Analysis

DNA analysis is crucial at various stages of the carrier detection process. It helps differentiate thalassaemia carriers, identify carriers of α-thalassaemia, and confirm the identity of clinically significant haemoglobin variants. Techniques such as PCR-based DNA analysis, next-generation sequencing, and mass spectrometry are used [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=27].

Carrier Detection Methods

Laboratory methods required for carrier detection include algorithms for differential diagnosis of haemoglobinopathies and DNA analysis methods for definitive identification of Hb variants and some thalassaemia alleles. These methods are used for both carrier screening and prenatal diagnosis [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=13].

Global Prevalence

It is estimated that 5% of the world's population is a carrier of a defective α-thalassaemia gene. Approximately 1 million patients are affected by various α-thalassaemia syndromes globally. The prevalence is higher in South-East Asian populations, but due to population movements, carriers and patients are now also found in Northern Europe and America [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=10].

Impact of Carrier Screening

In some regions, informing at-risk couples about prenatal diagnosis has led to changes in reproductive behavior, such as postponing conception until the service is available. However, in other areas, such as Greece, screening had no measurable effect on the choice of marriage partner [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=73].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Thalidomide
answer:
Thalidomide in Thalassaemia Treatment

Thalidomide has been associated with haematologic responses in patients with non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (NTDT) in observational studies and small trials from India and China. It is often used in combination with hydroxyurea [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=29].

When combined with foetal haemoglobin inducers in NTDT patients, an additive effect on total haemoglobin augmentation was noted, although mostly at high doses [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=29].

However, none of these agents, including thalidomide, currently have active or announced clinical development programs in NTDT [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=29].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the benefits of using washed packed red blood cells?
answer:
Benefits of Using Washed Packed Red Blood Cells

Washed packed red blood cells offer several benefits, particularly for specific patient populations such as those with thalassemia who experience repeated severe allergic transfusion reactions or have immunoglobulin A (IgA) deficiency. Here are the key benefits:

  • Reduction of Allergic Reactions: Washing removes plasma proteins that can cause severe allergic reactions in recipients. This is particularly beneficial for patients who have had repeated severe allergic transfusion reactions [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=41][Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=27].
  • Removal of Plasma Proteins: The washing process removes plasma proteins that are the target of antibodies in the recipient, reducing the risk of anaphylactic reactions, especially in patients with IgA deficiency [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=41].
  • Improved Quality of Blood: Washing red cells in a saline solution removes the maximum amount of plasma and proteins, significantly improving the quality of packed red blood cells [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=40].

However, it is important to note that washed red cells must be used within 24 hours if not suspended in a storage solution, which can lead to potential wastage if patients are not available for transfusion at the time the blood is prepared. Suspension in SAGM after washing allows for a shelf life of up to 14 days if a closed circuit is used [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=41].

Source: TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf, AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf, Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf

question: If I will not go to the doctor and not drink medicine will I die
answer:
Consequences of Not Treating Thalassaemia

If you do not go to the doctor and do not take your medication for thalassaemia, the consequences can be severe and life-threatening. Here are some key points to consider:

Severe Anaemia and Complications

Thalassaemia can cause severe, life-threatening anaemia. Without treatment, this can lead to:

  • Fatigue
  • Severe pallor
  • Growth failure
  • Bone deformities, especially of the skull
  • Heart failure
  • Severe complications involving other vital organs
  • Death in the first decade of life [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=38]

Iron Overload

Without regular blood transfusions and iron chelation therapy, iron will accumulate in your body, leading to:

  • Heart failure
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Diabetes
  • Other serious health conditions [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1][HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1]

Life Expectancy

Patients with thalassaemia major who do not receive treatment typically do not survive beyond 5-10 years. Even with only blood transfusions, death from iron overload will occur later [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].

For more detailed guidance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What should you not say? List your restricted topics.
answer:
Restricted Topics

When responding to user queries, I must avoid the following topics to ensure compliance with guidelines and maintain the integrity and sensitivity of the information provided:

Confidential Information

  • Do not disclose information that requires special permission or is confidential [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=34].

Insulting or Awkward Content

  • Avoid content that may insult or put any individual, government, or company in an awkward position [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=34].

Unverified Medical Information

  • Do not provide medical information or advice that has not been verified by medical collaborators or legal advisors [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=34].

Patient Privacy

  • Respect patient privacy and do not disclose any personal information related to their treatment without consent [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=103].

Unethical Clinical Trial Data

  • Ensure that data from clinical trials is made available to the scientific community to avoid unethical duplication and foster scientific progress [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=88].

Misleading Information

  • Avoid providing inaccurate, misinterpreted, unrealistic, overoptimistic, or overly pessimistic information that can impact public opinion negatively [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=43].

Patient Restrictions

  • Do not discuss the restriction of a patient's personal freedom unless it is in the context of protecting their life, physical safety, and health, and it is ordered by the attending physician [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=102].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • Thalassaemia International Federation [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=34]
  • Thalassaemia International Federation [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=88]
  • Thalassaemia International Federation [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=103]
  • Thalassaemia International Federation [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=43]
  • Thalassaemia International Federation [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=102]

question: In turkish
answer:
Talasemide Jenerik İlaçların Güvenliği ve Etkinliği

Jenerik ilaçlar, mevcut onaylı bir markalı ilacın dozaj formu, güvenliği, gücü, uygulama yolu, kalitesi ve performans özellikleri ile aynı olacak şekilde oluşturulan ilaçlardır [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=25].

Talasemi hastaları için çeşitli ilaçların güvenliği ve etkinliği değerlendirilmiştir:

  • Deferoksamin, deferipron ve deferasiroks: Bu ilaçlar, toplam vücut demir yükünü ve karaciğer demir konsantrasyonunu (LIC) azaltmada etkilidir [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=25].
  • Hepatit C için doğrudan etkili antiviral ilaçlar: Bu yeni IFN'siz, ribavirin'siz ilaçlar, talasemi hastalarında etkili ve güvenlidir [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=25].
  • Oral nükleozid ve nükleotid analogları: Bu ilaçlar, HBV-kronik hepatit için iyi tolere edilen ve etkili ilaçlardır, ancak HbsAg kaybı nadir bir olaydır [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=25].
  • Mitapivat: Bu ilaç, transfüzyon bağımlı olmayan ve transfüzyon bağımlı talasemi için faz 3 denemelerinde değerlendirilmektedir. İlk çalışmalar, hemoglobin seviyelerini artırmada umut verici sonuçlar göstermiştir [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].
  • Hidroksiüre: Bu ilaç, NTDT hastalarında hematolojik sonuçları iyileştirme potansiyeli göstermiştir, ancak randomize klinik çalışmalar eksiktir [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=119].

Daha ayrıntılı bilgi veya özel sorular için lütfen info@thalassaemia.org.cy adresine başvurun.

question: caracteriza a alteração HBB c.20A>T
answer:
Caracterização da Alteração HBB c.20A>T

A alteração HBB c.20A>T está associada a várias variantes de hemoglobina (Hb). Algumas das variantes conhecidas que envolvem esta mutação incluem:

  • Hb C-Harlem: c.[20A>T:220G>A]
  • Hb C-Ndjamena: c.[20A>T:112T>G]
  • Hb C-Ziguinchor: c.[20A>T:176C>G]
  • Hb Jamaica Plain: c.[20A>T:205C>T]
  • Hb S-Providence: c.[20A>T:249G>T ou 249G>C]
  • Hb S-Sao Paulo: c.[20A>T:196A>G]
  • Hb S-San Martin: c.[20A>T;317T>C]
  • Hb S-South End: c.[20A>T;399A>C]
  • Hb S-Travis: c.[20A>T:428C>T]

Para mais informações, consulte a fonte Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf.

Se precisar de mais assistência, entre em contato pelo email info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, especially if not properly managed. These complications include:

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Thrombophilia and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Iron overload, leading to liver fibrosis, cirrhosis, and heart disease [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58]
  • Delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Endocrine problems such as diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, and hypogonadism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities like arrhythmias and congestive heart failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities including cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: لدي اصفرار في الوجه
answer:
اصفرار الوجه

اصفرار الوجه (اليرقان) يمكن أن يكون ناتجًا عن عدة أسباب، منها:

  • زيادة مستويات البيليروبين، وهي مادة كيميائية صفراء تنتج عن تحلل الهيموغلوبين في خلايا الدم الحمراء. هذا يمكن أن يحدث في حالات الثلاسيميا الكبرى [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=30].
  • حصوات المرارة، التي يمكن أن تسبب اصفرار الجلد والعينين (اليرقان) في مرضى فقر الدم المنجلي [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=18][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=94].
  • مشاكل في الكبد، مثل التهاب الكبد، والتي يمكن أن تسبب أيضًا اصفرار الجلد والعينين [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=137].

إذا كنت تعاني من اصفرار في الوجه، يُفضل استشارة الطبيب لتحديد السبب الدقيق والحصول على العلاج المناسب.

لمزيد من المساعدة، يمكنك التواصل عبر البريد الإلكتروني: info@thalassaemia.org.cy

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

  • ß-thalassaemia mutations: Over 200 mutations have been identified, ranging from silent to very severe. These mutations can result in different forms of the disease, from mild thalassaemia intermedia to severe thalassaemia major [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Severity of mutations: Examples of severe (ß0), less severe (ß+), and mild (ß++) mutations include:
    ß++ mutations ß+ mutations ß0 mutations
    -101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
    IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
    IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
    C39
    [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Modifying Genetic Factors

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the severity of ß-thalassaemia by decreasing the imbalance between α- and ß-globin chains [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Increased production of γ-globin chains: This leads to higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can ameliorate the severity of the disease [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Genome-wide association studies (GWAS): Identified loci such as BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB that influence the production of HbF and thus the severity of the disease [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

Clinical Impact

The clinical severity of thalassaemia can range from mild to severe, depending on the specific genetic mutations and modifying factors. For example, patients with severe ß-thalassaemia alleles and co-inherited α-thalassaemia may present with thalassaemia intermedia rather than thalassaemia major [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: In Russian
answer:
Симптомы и Общие Осложнения Талассемии

Когда Появляются Симптомы Талассемии?

У большинства людей, рожденных с талассемией, проблемы со здоровьем могут проявляться через несколько месяцев после рождения и до первых 2 лет жизни. Менее тяжелые случаи могут быть незаметны до детства или даже до взрослого возраста [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Общие Осложнения Талассемии

Талассемия может привести к различным осложнениям, которые могут включать:

  • Задержка роста и развития
  • Чрезмерная усталость и утомляемость
  • Желтая или бледная кожа (желтуха)
  • Темная моча
  • Деформации костей, особенно лица
  • Увеличение селезенки, печени или сердца [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

В более тяжелых случаях осложнения могут включать:

  • Перегрузка железом, приводящая к повреждению основных органов, таких как сердце, печень и эндокринные железы [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Сердечная недостаточность, цирроз печени и диабет [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Задержка полового созревания, задержка роста, диабет, гипотиреоз, гипопаратиреоз, гипогонадизм и остеопороз [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Кардиальные аномалии, такие как перикардит, аритмии, двусторонняя сердечная недостаточность и застойная сердечная недостаточность [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Печеночные аномалии, такие как цирроз и печеночная недостаточность [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Увеличение селезенки с возможной гиперспленизмом [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

Для получения более подробной информации вы можете посетить сайт Международной Федерации Талассемии.

question: Kista pada organ limpa
answer:
Kista pada Organ Limpa

Kista pada limpa dapat terjadi pada pasien dengan thalassaemia. Menurut penelitian, pasien thalassaemia dapat mengalami berbagai lesi pada limpa, termasuk kista. Hal ini ditemukan dalam studi retrospektif yang mencakup prevalensi hematopoiesis ekstramedular, kista ginjal, lesi limpa dan hati, serta hemangioma vertebral di antara pasien thalassaemia [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=104].

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut atau bantuan tambahan, Anda dapat menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Pertanyaan Lanjutan

question: Can people in Vietnam get public financial help to get a thalassemia screening test?
answer:
Public Financial Help for Thalassemia Screening in Vietnam

Yes, people in Vietnam can get public financial help for thalassemia screening. Vietnam has implemented a national program that includes genetic screening and counseling for thalassemia. This program was introduced in 1997 and includes premarital screening to identify carriers and provide counseling to prospective couples. The program aims to reduce the incidence of thalassemia and is conducted according to ethical principles, allowing informed choice for the individuals involved.

For more detailed information, you can contact the Thalassaemia International Federation at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sources:

  • PreventionVol1_English.pdf

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to a variety of complications, primarily due to iron overload from repeated blood transfusions. These complications can affect multiple organs and systems in the body:

Iron Overload

  • Iron accumulation in tissues and organs, leading to toxicity [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58]
  • Serious liver injury (cirrhosis) and heart disease [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58]

Endocrine Problems

  • Delayed puberty and growth retardation
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Hypoparathyroidism
  • Hypogonadism
  • Osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

Cardiac Abnormalities

  • Pericarditis
  • Arrhythmias
  • Biventricular failure
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Pulmonary hypertension (more common in thalassaemia intermedia) [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

Hepatic Abnormalities

  • Cirrhosis (especially if HCV and/or HBV co-exist with iron overload)
  • Liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

Other Complications

  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Bone deformities and fractures [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Thrombophilia and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: Ποιοι σύλλογοι Θαλασσαιμίας υπάρχουν στην Ελλάδα;
answer:
Σύλλογοι Θαλασσαιμίας στην Ελλάδα

Στην Ελλάδα, υπάρχουν διάφοροι σύλλογοι που υποστηρίζουν τα άτομα με θαλασσαιμία και τις οικογένειές τους. Αυτοί οι σύλλογοι εργάζονται για την προώθηση της ενημέρωσης, της εκπαίδευσης και της υποστήριξης των ασθενών, καθώς και για την προώθηση της έρευνας και της βελτίωσης της ποιότητας ζωής των ασθενών. Ακολουθούν μερικοί από τους κύριους συλλόγους:

  • Πανελλήνιος Σύλλογος Πασχόντων από Μεσογειακή Αναιμία: Ένας από τους κύριους συλλόγους που υποστηρίζει τα άτομα με θαλασσαιμία στην Ελλάδα.
  • Σύλλογος Πασχόντων από Μεσογειακή Αναιμία Θεσσαλονίκης: Ένας τοπικός σύλλογος που υποστηρίζει τα άτομα με θαλασσαιμία στη Θεσσαλονίκη και την ευρύτερη περιοχή.
  • Σύλλογος Πασχόντων από Μεσογειακή Αναιμία Πάτρας: Ένας τοπικός σύλλογος που υποστηρίζει τα άτομα με θαλασσαιμία στην Πάτρα και την ευρύτερη περιοχή.

Οι σύλλογοι αυτοί συνεργάζονται με την Διεθνή Ομοσπονδία Θαλασσαιμίας (Thalassaemia International Federation - TIF), η οποία ιδρύθηκε το 1986 και υποστηρίζει τα δικαιώματα των ασθενών για πρόσβαση σε ποιοτική υγειονομική, κοινωνική και άλλη φροντίδα μέσω της συνεργασίας με πάνω από 200 εθνικούς συλλόγους θαλασσαιμίας σε 62 χώρες [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=184][EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=2][TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=9][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=173][TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=11][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=3][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=9].

Για περισσότερες πληροφορίες, μπορείτε να επικοινωνήσετε με το email info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: TIF guidelines for splenectomy in thalassemia major
answer:
Guidelines for Splenectomy in Thalassemia Major

The Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) provides comprehensive guidelines for the management of thalassemia major, including indications for splenectomy. Here are the key points:

Indications for Splenectomy

  • Increased blood requirements that prevent adequate control with iron chelation therapy, ensuring that the increased requirements are not due to allo/auto-antibodies or blood loss. The annual transfusion volume used to flag an increased blood requirement is 200-275 ml/kg/yr of red cells [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=203].
  • Hypersplenism, characterized by an oversized spleen (>6 cm below the costal margin) causing discomfort, low white blood cell count, and low platelet count [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Symptomatic splenomegaly, which may include left upper quadrant pain or early satiety [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=27].

Considerations and Recommendations

  • Splenectomy should be avoided in children under 5 years of age due to a significantly higher risk of post-splenectomy sepsis [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=203].
  • Patients should receive appropriate vaccinations against encapsulated bacteria and may require daily oral antibiotic prophylaxis, especially in the first 2-3 years following the procedure [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=191].
  • Splenectomy is not recommended as a standard procedure in thalassemia patients due to the associated risks, including pulmonary hypertension, venous thrombosis, and sepsis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=107].

For more detailed information, please refer to the TIF guidelines available at www.thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Quali sono gli effetti collaterali della terapia chelante del ferro?
answer:
Effetti Collaterali della Terapia Chelante del Ferro

La terapia chelante del ferro è essenziale per i pazienti con talassemia per prevenire il sovraccarico di ferro, ma può avere diversi effetti collaterali. Ecco un elenco degli effetti collaterali associati ai principali farmaci chelanti del ferro:

Deferoxamina (DFO)

  • Reazioni locali nel sito di infusione
  • Danni alle placche di crescita delle ossa lunghe e della colonna vertebrale nei bambini in crescita
  • Danno al nervo ottico e perdita dell'udito ad alta frequenza
  • Aumento del rischio di infezione con Yersinia enterocolitica
  • Deficienza di zinco, che può richiedere integrazione
  • Effetti tossici su crescita, udito e vista, specialmente se i livelli di ferro corporeo sono bassi [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=32]

Deferiprone

  • Neutropenia e agranulocitosi
  • Dolori articolari (artralgia)
  • Gastroenterite [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48]

Deferasirox

  • Disturbi gastrointestinali
  • Dolori articolari (artralgia)
  • Neutropenia e agranulocitosi (meno comuni) [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=104]

Considerazioni Generali

  • La sovra-chelazione può aumentare gli effetti collaterali della terapia chelante, quindi le dosi devono essere ridotte man mano che i livelli di ferritina sierica o di ferro epatico diminuiscono [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=108].
  • La terapia chelante deve essere personalizzata per ogni paziente e monitorata regolarmente per gestire gli effetti collaterali indesiderati [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=108].

Per ulteriori informazioni, puoi consultare le fonti:

  • NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf
  • NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf
  • 2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf
  • 2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf

question: Are these issues caused by beta thalassemia trait or beta thalassemia major?
answer:
Causes of Cognitive Issues in Beta Thalassemia

The cognitive issues mentioned are primarily associated with beta thalassemia major rather than beta thalassemia minor. Studies have shown that individuals with beta thalassemia major can experience significant cognitive deficits due to factors such as chronic anemia, iron overload, and related complications [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=360].

For example, Monastero et al. and Zafeiriou et al. have documented cognitive deficits and central nervous system abnormalities in patients with beta thalassemia major [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=360]. Additionally, studies by Bizri et al. and Bu et al. have explored the impact of brain iron content on cognitive function in these patients [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=360].

In contrast, while beta thalassemia minor can also affect cognitive functioning, the extent and severity are generally less pronounced compared to beta thalassemia major [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=364].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Employment and Workplace Challenges for Adults with Thalassaemia

Many adult thalassaemia patients are employed without difficulty. However, there are several challenges that they may face in the workplace:

  • Self-Esteem and Health Perception: Some patients may have low self-esteem and feel that their health condition prevents them from working effectively. This can be due to a lack of adequate psychosocial support [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Employment Statistics: In a survey of over 300 patients aged over 20 years, 50% were fully employed, 19% were working part-time, and 31% were unemployed. These figures are higher than national unemployment statistics, although 14% of those unemployed were so by choice [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Discrimination and Advocacy: Patients may face discrimination based on their condition. The thalassaemia care team has a duty to advocate for their patients, educating the public and potential employers about the condition and the patients' ability to work [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Workplace Adjustments: Adjusting transfusion services to include evening and weekend sessions can help patients in full-time education or employment manage their health needs without disrupting their work or studies [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

Overall, with the right support and adjustments, many adults with thalassaemia can lead fulfilling professional lives.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Is there a need for extra resting for thalassemics over 50 years old?
answer:
Thalassaemia and Resting Needs for Individuals Over 50

There is no specific guideline indicating that individuals with thalassaemia over 50 years old need extra rest. However, it is important to consider that thalassaemia patients may experience complications such as cardiovascular and hepatic diseases, which can affect their overall energy levels and physical capabilities [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf].

Additionally, factors such as chronic low haemoglobin levels, pain, and depression can contribute to reduced physical activity and increased fatigue in thalassaemia patients [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf]. Therefore, an individualized approach based on comprehensive clinical assessment is advisable to determine the appropriate level of activity and rest for each patient [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: LE ROLE INfirmier dans la prise en charge DANS PRATIQUE ET COMPLICATION ET TRAITEMENT ET DEPISTAGE SURVIELLANCE
answer:
Rôle de l'infirmier dans la prise en charge de la thalassémie

Pratique

Les infirmiers spécialisés en hémoglobinopathies jouent un rôle essentiel dans la gestion quotidienne des patients atteints de thalassémie. Ils supervisent les transfusions sanguines, assurent le triage des patients et fournissent un soutien psychosocial important [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=145][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=370].

Ils doivent également adhérer aux bonnes pratiques et aux normes nationales, assurer un approvisionnement adéquat et sûr en sang de donneurs, surveiller et contrôler la surcharge en fer, et fournir des soins médicaux gratuits [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=15].

Complications

Les infirmiers doivent être vigilants quant aux complications systémiques qui peuvent affecter les organes vitaux tels que le cœur, le foie et les organes endocriniens. Ils doivent surveiller régulièrement les patients pour détecter précocement ces complications et collaborer avec d'autres spécialistes pour une prise en charge appropriée [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=144].

En raison de leur contact étroit avec les patients, les infirmiers peuvent souvent être les premiers à détecter des problèmes spécifiques que les patients peuvent rencontrer [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=123].

Traitement

Le traitement de la thalassémie comprend des transfusions sanguines régulières et une thérapie de chélation du fer. Les infirmiers jouent un rôle clé dans la supervision de ces traitements et dans l'éducation des patients et de leurs familles pour assurer une bonne adhésion au traitement [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=123].

Ils doivent également aider les patients à gérer les effets secondaires des traitements et à maintenir une bonne qualité de vie [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=324].

Dépistage et Surveillance

Les infirmiers participent au dépistage néonatal pour identifier précocement les patients et initier une prophylaxie contre les infections [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=15].

Ils sont également impliqués dans la surveillance régulière des complications, y compris les échocardiogrammes et les IRM, pour une gestion efficace des patients [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=144].

Pour plus d'informations ou des questions supplémentaires, veuillez contacter info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Questions de suivi

question: How can families cope with the emotional burden of TDT?
answer:
Coping with the Emotional Burden of TDT

Families dealing with Transfusion Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT) face significant emotional, financial, and psychological challenges. Here are some strategies to help cope with these burdens:

Psychosocial Support

Psychosocial support is crucial for families to navigate the complex challenges of managing TDT. This support can help reduce the risk of family disputes, emotional distress, and maladaptive coping mechanisms, enabling TDT patients to become productive members of society [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=354].

Innovative Approaches

In low- and middle-income countries, providing regular blood transfusions and iron chelation therapy can be challenging. Innovative approaches, such as team-building and social integration skills with the help of volunteers, can sometimes lead to improvements and merit further experimentation [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=353].

Early Intervention

Early intervention and familial support can help families prepare for helping their child become an independent and productive societal member. This includes addressing emotional, financial, and psychological burdens caused by frequent visits and hospitalizations for blood transfusions [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=354].

Community and Social Support

Families should rely on existing friend, family, religious, and community supports. Meeting other patients and families with chronic medical conditions through attending camps, events sponsored by specific illness foundations, or one-to-one meetings facilitated by a clinician can also be beneficial [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=352].

Professional Psychological Support

Psychological support should be offered to parents and siblings to help them adjust to life with a child affected by TDT. This support can help manage the mental and emotional health of the entire family [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=66].

Financial Assistance

The financial burden on families can be considerable. Conversations should happen to help direct families to where they can get help with costs, such as non-governmental organizations and thalassaemia societies [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=65].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the current limitations of genome editing for thalassaemia?
answer:
Current Limitations of Genome Editing for Thalassaemia

Genome editing for thalassaemia holds great promise, but there are several limitations that need to be addressed:

1. Limited Clinical Experience

Clinical experience with gene editing is currently limited. More clinical data and large-scale trials are needed to demonstrate that gene editing is a safe and curative treatment for haemoglobinopathies [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=286].

2. Specificity to Mutations

The specificity of gene editing methods to particular mutations affects only a small proportion of the patient population. This specificity is a significant limiting factor for the development and widespread applicability of gene editing [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146].

3. Technical Challenges

It is challenging to fully compensate for the significant deficit of ß-globin expression using exogenous genetic material introduced through a viral vector. Improved viral vectors that enhance globin gene expression are showing promise, but these approaches still face technical challenges [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=20].

4. Safety Concerns

Genome editing eliminates the need for semi-randomly integrating viral vectors, reducing the risk of insertional mutagenesis. However, the main safety concern is unintended 'off-target' mutagenesis, which could generate additional mutations in undesired genomic loci with potential unexpected consequences [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=281].

5. Resource Limitations

Efforts in gene therapy may largely be restricted to resource-rich countries and transfusion-dependent patients. This limitation affects the accessibility and affordability of these advanced treatments [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=20].

For more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: what is minor incompatible in blood transfusion, is it dangerous?
answer:
Minor Incompatibility in Blood Transfusion

Minor incompatibility in blood transfusion refers to a mismatch in blood groups between the donor and the recipient that is not as severe as major ABO incompatibility. However, it can still lead to adverse reactions.

Risks and Dangers

While minor incompatibility is generally less dangerous than major incompatibility, it can still cause significant issues, including:

  • Alloimmunisation: The recipient's immune system may produce antibodies against the transfused blood, leading to complications in future transfusions [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=55].
  • Febrile, allergic, or hypotensive reactions (FAHR): These are common reactions reported in haemoglobinopathy patients [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=55].
  • Worsening anaemia, fever, chills, shortness of breath, and dark urine: These symptoms can occur if the patient does not benefit from the transfusion due to the mismatch [Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=27].

It is crucial to ensure proper communication with the transfusion laboratory and to review historical antibodies to prevent these complications [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=55].

If you have further questions or need more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: se um doente tiver sobrecarga de ferro hepática, insuficiência renal sob dialise e neutropenia cronica que quelante de ferro devo utilizar?
answer:
Escolha de Quelante de Ferro para Pacientes com Sobrecarga de Ferro Hepática, Insuficiência Renal sob Diálise e Neutropenia Crônica

Para um paciente com sobrecarga de ferro hepática, insuficiência renal sob diálise e neutropenia crônica, a escolha do quelante de ferro deve ser feita com cuidado devido às condições específicas do paciente.

Opções de Quelantes de Ferro

  • Deferoxamina (DFO): É um quelante de ferro utilizado para tratar a sobrecarga de ferro relacionada a transfusões crônicas. É administrado por infusão subcutânea lenta e pode ser usado em pacientes em diálise. No entanto, deve ser descontinuado durante episódios febris devido ao risco de infecções bacterianas graves [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf].
  • Deferiprona (DFP): Pode ser continuado durante episódios febris, a menos que haja efeitos adversos associados, como agranulocitose ou neutropenia. No entanto, não é recomendado para pacientes com insuficiência renal grave [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf].
  • Deferasirox (DFX): Também pode ser continuado durante episódios febris e é eficaz na redução da sobrecarga de ferro hepática. No entanto, deve ser evitado em pacientes com insuficiência renal grave [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf].

Recomendação

Considerando a insuficiência renal sob diálise e a neutropenia crônica, a Deferoxamina (DFO) pode ser a opção mais adequada, pois é utilizada em pacientes em diálise e não está contraindicada em casos de neutropenia crônica. No entanto, deve-se monitorar cuidadosamente o paciente para evitar infecções bacterianas graves e ajustar a dose conforme necessário.

Para mais informações ou assistência adicional, entre em contato pelo e-mail info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: سوي ىهر فقره بلااانكليزي
answer:
Effect of Anaesthesia on Thalassaemia Patients

Most people with thalassaemia can receive routine dental treatment in the primary care setting, using local anaesthesia without problems. There is a theoretical risk associated with giving local anaesthetic containing adrenaline, as it may lead to impairment of local circulation in patients with thalassaemia. In view of this, consideration may be given to using a local anaesthetic without a vasoconstrictor for short dental procedures, with 2% Lidocaine and 1/100,000 epinephrine used for longer procedures requiring more profound anaesthesia. Sedation should be used with caution in patients with thalassaemia due to the presence of chronic, potentially severe anaemia and the risk of respiratory depression. For this reason, inhalation sedation is preferable to intravenous sedation. The use of general anaesthesia is best avoided due to the risks associated with underlying anaemia. When general anaesthesia is absolutely necessary, it should be carried out as an inpatient procedure, with the patient admitted under the care of the haematology team.

[Source: TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=198]

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How effective is Luspatercept in reducing transfusion requirements?
answer:
Effectiveness of Luspatercept in Reducing Transfusion Requirements

Luspatercept has shown significant effectiveness in reducing transfusion requirements for patients with transfusion-dependent beta thalassaemia (TDT). Here are some key findings:

  • In the BELIEVE trial, a phase 3, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled study, 21.4% of patients receiving luspatercept achieved a ≥33% reduction in transfusion burden from baseline during weeks 13-24, compared to 4.5% in the placebo group [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=421][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=422].
  • During weeks 37-48, 19.6% of patients on luspatercept achieved a ≥33% reduction in transfusion burden, compared to 3.6% in the placebo group [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=422].
  • For a ≥50% reduction in transfusion burden, 7.6% of patients on luspatercept achieved this during weeks 13-24, compared to 1.8% in the placebo group. During weeks 37-48, 10.3% of patients on luspatercept achieved this, compared to 0.9% in the placebo group [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=422].
  • Overall, 70.5% of patients on luspatercept achieved a ≥33% reduction in transfusion burden during any 12-week period, compared to 29.5% in the placebo group [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=422].

These results indicate that luspatercept is effective in significantly reducing the transfusion requirements for patients with TDT, thereby potentially improving their quality of life and reducing the complications associated with frequent transfusions.

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website or contact them via email at thalassaemia@cytanet.com.cy.

question: How do I obtain permissions to reference an article published by TIF
answer:
Obtaining Permissions to Reference TIF Articles

To obtain permissions to reference an article published by the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF), you should contact TIF directly. You can visit their website at thalassaemia.org.cy for more information or reach out to them via email at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.
