question: Was soll schwere anämie heißen? Was sind denn die folgen einer anämie?
answer:
Schwere Anämie und ihre Folgen

Schwere Anämie ist ein Zustand, bei dem der Körper nicht genügend gesunde rote Blutkörperchen hat, um ausreichend Sauerstoff zu den Geweben zu transportieren. Bei Thalassämia Major ist die Anämie besonders schwerwiegend und lebensbedrohlich, wenn sie nicht behandelt wird. Hier sind die Hauptursachen und Folgen einer schweren Anämie:

Ursachen der schweren Anämie bei Thalassämia Major

  • Genetische Mutationen im ß-Globin-Gen führen zu einer verminderten oder fehlenden Produktion von ß-Globin-Ketten, was zu einem Ungleichgewicht mit den α-Globin-Ketten führt [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=2].
  • Dieses Ungleichgewicht verursacht ineffektive Erythropoese (Bildung von roten Blutkörperchen) und Hämolyse (Zerfall der roten Blutkörperchen), was zu schwerer Anämie führt [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=2].

Folgen einer schweren Anämie

  • Fatigue und Erschöpfung: Patienten fühlen sich ständig müde und haben wenig Energie, da ihre Gewebe nicht genügend Sauerstoff erhalten [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=38].
  • Blässe: Die Haut und Schleimhäute erscheinen blass aufgrund des niedrigen Hämoglobinspiegels im Blut [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=38].
  • Wachstumsverzögerung: Kinder mit Thalassämia Major wachsen langsamer und entwickeln sich nicht altersgerecht [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • Knochenverformungen: Besonders im Gesicht, aufgrund der Knochenmarkexpansion, die versucht, die Produktion der roten Blutkörperchen zu kompensieren [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=38].
  • Gelbsucht: Gelbfärbung der Haut und Augen aufgrund des schnellen Abbaus der roten Blutkörperchen und der Freisetzung von Bilirubin [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=30].
  • Dunkler Urin: Aufgrund des Abbaus von Hämoglobin [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • Vergrößerte Milz, Leber oder Herz: Diese Organe arbeiten härter, um die defekten roten Blutkörperchen zu verarbeiten [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • Herzinsuffizienz: Aufgrund der chronischen Anämie und der erhöhten Belastung des Herzens, das versucht, den Sauerstoffmangel zu kompensieren [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=104].
  • Wachstumsstörungen und hormonelle Probleme: Aufgrund der Eisenüberladung und der Belastung der endokrinen Drüsen [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=104].

Langfristige Komplikationen

  • Herzinsuffizienz und Arrhythmien: Aufgrund der chronischen Anämie und Eisenüberladung [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15].
  • Leberkomplikationen: Wie Fibrose, Zirrhose und Leberversagen aufgrund der Eisenablagerung [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15].
  • Endokrine Komplikationen: Wie Diabetes und Wachstumsstörungen aufgrund der Eisenüberladung [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15].

Für weitere Informationen oder spezifische Fragen können Sie sich gerne an info@thalassaemia.org.cy wenden.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by mutations in the beta-globin (ß-globin) gene, leading to a wide range of phenotypic severities, from mild to very severe forms. The severity of thalassaemia is influenced by several genetic factors:

Types of ß-Thalassaemia Mutations

  • More than 200 ß-thalassaemia mutations have been described, each contributing to varying degrees of severity [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Examples of severe (ß0), less severe (ß+), and mild (ß++) mutations include:
    ß++ mutations ß+ mutations ß0 mutations
    -101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
    IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
    IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
    C39
    [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

  • Co-inheritance of alpha-thalassaemia (a-thalassaemia) can reduce the severity of ß-thalassaemia by decreasing the imbalance between alpha (a) and beta (ß) chains [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Genetic determinants that increase the production of foetal haemoglobin (HbF) can also ameliorate the phenotype. For example, the co-inheritance of hereditary persistence of foetal haemoglobin (HPFH) mutations results in higher HbF levels and a milder form of ß-thalassaemia intermedia [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified loci such as BCL11A on chromosome 2p16 and the HBS1L-MYB intergenic region on chromosome 6q23, which are associated with increased HbF production and reduced disease severity [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

Clinical Impact

The clinical severity of thalassaemia can range from thalassaemia major, requiring regular blood transfusions, to thalassaemia intermedia, which may require occasional or no transfusions. The presence of ameliorating genetic factors can significantly influence the clinical outcome and management of the disease [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Complications

When Do Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood.

In thalassaemia major, clinical symptoms of iron overload generally appear around the age of 10, although evidence of the toxic effects of iron has been found in the liver of much younger children.

In thalassaemia intermedia, symptoms may be mild and go undiagnosed for a long time, or they may become more apparent later in life.

[HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]

Common Complications

Iron Overload

Iron overload is a significant complication due to repeated blood transfusions. It can cause:

  • Liver injury (fibrosis and cirrhosis)
  • Heart disease (heart failure, arrhythmias)
  • Endocrine problems (delayed puberty, diabetes, hypothyroidism)
  • Delayed sexual maturation

[NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]

Other Complications

Other complications common to both thalassaemia major and intermedia include:

  • Bone deformities and fractures
  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism
  • Hepatic abnormalities (liver failure)
  • Cardiac abnormalities (congestive heart failure, pulmonary hypertension)

[NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]

Symptoms of Thalassaemia

Symptoms can vary and may include:

  • Severe anaemia
  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart

[HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

Further Assistance

If you need more information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Azacytidine on beta thalassemia
answer:
Azacytidine and Beta Thalassemia

Azacytidine, also known as 5-azacytidine, is one of the drugs that has been investigated for its potential to treat beta thalassemia. It works by increasing the production of gamma (γ) chains, which can pair with alpha (α) chains to form fetal hemoglobin (HbF). This reduces the amount of free alpha chains, which is beneficial for patients with thalassemia.

However, both 5-azacytidine and cytosine arabinoside demonstrated toxic effects in patients with thalassemia, leading to the discontinuation of their use. Researchers are now exploring newer, less toxic derivatives of these drugs [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=119].

If you need more detailed information or have specific questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: TDT
answer:
Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT)

Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT) is a severe form of thalassaemia that requires regular blood transfusions to manage the condition. Here are some key points regarding the management and considerations for TDT patients:

Glucose Metabolism and Diabetes Management

  • Glucose levels should be checked monthly starting from conception, and an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) should be done between 24 and 28 weeks of gestation [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=193].
  • In TDT patients with diabetes, an educational program to improve self-monitoring of blood glucose and management of hypoglycaemia is crucial [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=193].
  • Regular checks for micro- and macroangiopathic complications are recommended [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=193].
  • Management of iron overload through oral or combinatorial regimens can stabilize or reverse glucose metabolism disorders [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=193].

Cardiovascular Health

  • Ambulatory ECG monitoring should be considered for older patients to detect atrial fibrillation, followed by anticoagulation therapy if significant atrial fibrillation is detected [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=146].
  • Screening and treatment of endocrine and metabolic comorbidities are crucial for preventing cardiovascular disease [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=146].
  • Lifestyle choices that promote cardiovascular health, such as not smoking, physical exercise, weight control, and a healthy diet, should be vigorously promoted [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=146].
  • Venous thromboembolic risk assessment and prophylaxis should be conducted based on local guidelines, especially in older patients who are splenectomised, have low pretransfusion haemoglobin, or are pregnant [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=146].

Cardiac Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

The development of MRI to non-invasively quantify tissue iron has significantly improved the management of TDT, contributing to a 70% reduction in mortality. The T2* MRI method is the international standard for assessing tissue iron loading [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=141].

Transition from Paediatric to Adult Care

An organized transition process is essential for young adults moving from paediatric to adult-centred health systems. The GOT TRANSITION®'s Six Core Elements of Health Care Transition™ can guide this process [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=371].

Global Prevalence and Survival

The prevalence of TDT is higher in the Middle East, Asia, and the Mediterranean compared to Europe or North America. Survival estimates for TDT patients have improved over the years [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=30].

Psychological Support

Including psychological support as part of standard care can help manage anxiety and depression symptoms, which are common in TDT patients. This support is crucial for preventing long-term health consequences [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=258].

If you have further questions or need more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: which type of breakpoints are the most common in -alpha3.7 Thalassemia?
answer:
Common Breakpoints in -alpha3.7 Thalassemia

The most common breakpoints in -alpha3.7 thalassemia result from unequal homologous recombination of duplicated alpha-genes during meiosis. This leads to the -alpha3.7 deletion, which is the most prevalent alpha+-thalassemia deletion.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: What are the treatment options for thalassaemia?
answer:
Treatment Options for Thalassaemia

Blood Transfusions

Regular blood transfusions are a cornerstone of thalassaemia treatment. Patients with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) typically receive transfusions every 2-5 weeks to maintain pre-transfusion hemoglobin levels at 9.5 to 10 g/dL [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39][TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

Iron Chelation Therapy

Iron chelation therapy is essential to remove excess iron from the body, which accumulates due to frequent blood transfusions. There are three main types of iron chelators: deferoxamine (administered via injection), and two oral medications [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].

Splenectomy

Splenectomy, the surgical removal of the spleen, is less common now but may be necessary in cases of an oversized spleen or other signs of an overactive spleen [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

Novel Therapies

Luspatercept-aamt is a novel pharmaceutical agent that helps prolong the lifespan of red blood cells, reducing the need for frequent transfusions and iron chelation therapy. It is particularly beneficial for non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

Curative Options

  • Allogeneic Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT): This is currently the only available curative option for thalassaemia. It involves replacing the patient's defective blood-forming stem cells with healthy ones from a compatible donor [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=129][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=279].
  • Gene Therapy: Gene therapy, such as Zynteglo®, aims to correct the genetic defect causing thalassaemia. It is available for young patients and those without severe comorbidities [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=286].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: Future treatment
answer:
Future Treatment Options for Thalassaemia

Currently, there are several promising future treatment options for thalassaemia, including:

1. Allogeneic Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT)

Allogeneic HSCT is the only curative option currently available for patients with thalassaemia. It involves substituting the ineffective or abnormal erythropoiesis with donor-derived red blood cells that produce adequate functional haemoglobin. This treatment is particularly effective when performed early, before the onset of organ dysfunction due to iron overload. Improvements in transplantation platforms and graft versus host disease prophylaxis have expanded the use of alternative donors with comparable outcomes to matched sibling donors [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=140][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=193][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=129].

2. Gene Therapy

Gene therapy is an experimental and promising scientific process that involves correcting the affected gene outside the body and then replacing it into the patient's blood-forming tissues. This method aims to make the patient's cells capable of producing new red cells containing normal haemoglobin. The European Commission has granted conditional approval for the Bluebird bio gene therapy product, Zynteglo®, for treating transfusion-dependent ß+ thalassaemia in patients 12 years and older who are eligible for stem cell transplantation but do not have a matched related donor. However, more clinical data and large-scale trials are needed to demonstrate the long-term safety and efficacy of gene therapy [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=24][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=128].

3. Precision Medicine with Genome Editing

Precision medicine using genome editing tools has shown potential in overcoming some obstacles associated with gene addition gene therapy. However, clinical experience with gene editing is currently limited, and more clinical data and large-scale trials are needed to demonstrate its safety and curative potential for haemoglobinopathies [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=286].

For more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Dose beta thalassemia cause serum iron level decrease
answer:
Does Beta Thalassemia Cause Serum Iron Level Decrease?

No, beta thalassemia does not typically cause a decrease in serum iron levels. In fact, patients with beta thalassemia, especially those who are not regularly transfused, often experience iron overload rather than iron deficiency. This is due to increased intestinal iron absorption and repeated blood transfusions in some cases.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • TIF Guidelines on Non-Transfusion-Dependent Beta Thalassemia [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=37]
  • Alpha Thalassemia Guidelines [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=126]

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: اسباب الوفاه فى مرضىةانيميا البحر المتوسط
answer:
أسباب الوفاة في مرضى أنيميا البحر المتوسط

مرضى أنيميا البحر المتوسط (الثلاسيميا) يواجهون عدة مخاطر صحية قد تؤدي إلى الوفاة إذا لم يتم التعامل معها بشكل صحيح. من بين الأسباب الرئيسية للوفاة:

1. فشل القلب

فشل القلب هو أحد الأسباب الرئيسية للوفاة في مرضى الثلاسيميا. يحدث ذلك نتيجة لفقر الدم المزمن الذي يؤدي إلى تضخم القلب وفشله في النهاية [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=35].

2. التحميل الزائد بالحديد

التحميل الزائد بالحديد نتيجة لنقل الدم المتكرر يمكن أن يؤدي إلى تلف الكبد، تليف الكبد، وسرطان الكبد، بالإضافة إلى مضاعفات الغدد الصماء [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=35].

3. مضاعفات التخثر

الأحداث التخثرية، خاصة الوريدية، هي سبب آخر للوفاة. المرضى الذين خضعوا لاستئصال الطحال أو الذين لديهم تاريخ شخصي أو عائلي من الأحداث التخثرية هم أكثر عرضة لهذه المضاعفات [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=63].

4. التهابات الكبد الفيروسية

التهابات الكبد الفيروسية (مثل التهاب الكبد B وC) يمكن أن تؤدي إلى تلف الكبد وتليف الكبد، مما يزيد من خطر الوفاة [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=47].

5. التوسع المفرط في إنتاج خلايا الدم الحمراء خارج النخاع

التوسع المفرط في إنتاج خلايا الدم الحمراء خارج النخاع يمكن أن يؤدي إلى مضاعفات مثل تضخم الطحال، مما يزيد من خطر الوفاة [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=35].

للمزيد من المعلومات أو المساعدة، يرجى التواصل عبر البريد الإلكتروني info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Employment and Workplace Challenges for Adults with Thalassaemia

Many adult thalassaemia patients are employed without difficulty. However, there are several challenges that they may face in the workplace:

  • Self-Esteem and Health Perception: Some patients may have low self-esteem and feel that their health condition prevents them from working effectively. This can be due to a lack of adequate psychosocial support [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Discrimination: Thalassaemia can be viewed as an 'immigrant disease' in some countries, potentially leading to racial and ethnic discrimination. This requires educational interventions to address [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Employment Statistics: In a survey of over 300 patients over 20 years of age, 50% were fully employed, 19% were working part-time, and 31% were unemployed. These figures are higher than national unemployment statistics, although 14% of those unemployed were by choice [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Workplace Adjustments: Patients may need to interrupt work for clinic and transfusion appointments, which are often during daytime working hours. Adjusting these services to include evening and weekend sessions can help patients maintain full-time employment [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Advocacy and Education: Thalassaemia care teams have a duty to advocate for their patients, educating the public and potential employers about the condition and the ability of patients to work. This includes ensuring non-discrimination and equal remuneration for work of equal value [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

Overall, with appropriate support and adjustments, many adults with thalassaemia can successfully integrate into the workforce and contribute to society.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice) [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Dark urine [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Iron overload, leading to damage to major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Heart failure, liver cirrhosis, and diabetes in poorly treated patients [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1]
  • Endocrine problems such as delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities such as pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, and congestive heart failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities such as cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Follow-up Questions

question: What are the symptoms of vitamin D deficiency in thalassaemia patients?
answer:
Symptoms of Vitamin D Deficiency in Thalassaemia Patients

Vitamin D deficiency is common in thalassaemia patients and can present with a range of symptoms. Here are the key symptoms and clinical presentations:

General Symptoms

  • Delayed linear growth, teething, and closure of the fontanel in children
  • Broad wrist joints and 'bow legs' in severe deficiency
  • Hypocalcaemic tetany and fractures in severe cases [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=101]

Radiological Findings

  • Absent or irregular line of ossification at metaphyseal fronts
  • Excessive osteoid deposition (wide wrist space) with cupping
  • Metaphysis decalcification and subperiosteal erosion of the shafts of long bones
  • Pseudo-fractures affecting the femoral neck or scapula
  • Generalized or metaphyseal osteoporosis [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=102]

Symptoms in Adolescents

  • Pain in weight-bearing joints, back, thighs, and/or calves
  • Difficulty in walking, climbing stairs, and running
  • Muscle cramps, facial twitches, and carpo-pedal spasms
  • Improvement in back and joint pains and increased exercise tolerance after treatment with vitamin D [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=102]

Additional Symptoms

  • Decreased cardiac function and muscle weakness
  • Glucose insensitivity and refractory congestive heart failure
  • Secondary hyperparathyroidism, which exacerbates heart failure [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=104]

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: what is iron chelation?
answer:
What is Iron Chelation?

Iron chelation is a medical therapy used to remove excess iron from the body. This is particularly important for individuals with conditions like thalassaemia, where frequent blood transfusions can lead to iron overload. The body has no natural way to remove excess iron, so iron chelators (iron binders) are used to form compounds with iron that can be excreted through urine and/or stools [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=55].

Types of Iron Chelation Therapy

  • Preventive Therapy: Maintains safe levels of body iron by balancing iron intake from blood transfusions with iron excretion by chelation [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=38].
  • Rescue Therapy: Removes excess iron stored in the body [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=38].
  • Emergency Therapy: Urgently intensifies iron chelation in cases of iron-induced heart failure [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=38].
  • Dose Adjustment: Adjusts dosing and treatment regimens based on careful monitoring of body iron and its distribution [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=38].

Common Iron Chelators

Desferrioxamine (DFO) was the first iron chelation drug, introduced in the early 1970s. DFO binds iron to form a substance called ferrioxamine, which is then excreted from the body. DFO also decreases the toxicity of iron by mopping up free radicals [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=55].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How much of the health expenditure in Vietnam is being used on thalassemia treatments?
answer:
Health Expenditure on Thalassemia Treatments in Vietnam

Currently, there is no specific data available on the exact percentage of Vietnam's health expenditure used for thalassemia treatments. However, we can provide some context based on general information about the costs and economic impact of thalassemia treatments in various countries:

  • The cost of treating thalassemia patients can be extremely variable among countries, depending on different healthcare systems, methods of obtaining blood, practices in screening for blood pathogens, and costs of drugs and equipment [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=18].
  • In some countries, the cost of optimal treatment for thalassemia can be a significant portion of the national health expenditure. For example, in Iran, the cost is about $150 million a year, equivalent to almost 8% of the total national health expenditure [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=75].
  • Without prevention programs to limit the number of births of affected children, the cost of treating thalassemia can become unsustainable for many countries [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=133].

For more detailed and specific information regarding Vietnam, you may contact the Thalassaemia International Federation at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sources:

  • TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf
  • PreventionVol1_English.pdf
  • AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf

question: What are the long-term effects of regular blood transfusions?
answer:
Long-Term Effects of Regular Blood Transfusions

Regular blood transfusions are essential for managing thalassemia, but they come with several long-term effects that need to be carefully managed:

  • Iron Overload: One of the most significant risks is secondary iron overload, which can lead to end-organ failure if not managed with effective iron chelation therapy [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=22].
  • Infections: Although rare in developed countries due to improved blood screening, there is still a risk of transmitting infections such as hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and HIV through blood transfusions [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=92].
  • Alloimmunization: The development of antibodies against transfused blood can occur, making it more difficult to find compatible blood for future transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=106].
  • Cardiovascular Issues: Regular transfusions can lead to volume overload, which may result in congestive heart failure and pulmonary edema, especially in patients with pre-existing heart conditions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=106].
  • Metabolic Disturbances: Transfusions can cause metabolic disturbances such as hypoglycemia and other imbalances, particularly in children [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=106].
  • Bone and Growth Issues: Without effective management, severe anemia and bone marrow expansion can lead to poor growth, bone deformities, and fragile bones [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=35].
  • Psychological Impact: Transitioning to a transfusion-dependent lifestyle can affect mental well-being and quality of life, requiring significant lifestyle adjustments [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=22].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: If blood filter is blocked, can we transfuse the rest of the blood through regular BD set?
answer:
Blood Transfusion and Blocked Filters

If a blood filter becomes blocked during a transfusion, it is not advisable to continue the transfusion using a regular BD set without a filter. The filtration process is crucial for removing white blood cells and associated infectious agents, which is particularly important for patients with thalassaemia who may have weakened immune systems or are undergoing treatments like bone marrow transplantation [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=41].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely depending on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

There are more than 200 known ß-thalassaemia mutations, which can result in a range of phenotypic severities from very mild to very severe:

  • Severe (ß0) mutations: Examples include IVS1-1, IVS11-1, and C39. These mutations typically result in thalassaemia major, which requires regular blood transfusions for survival [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].
  • Less severe (ß+) mutations: Examples include IVS1-110 and IVS11-745. These mutations can result in thalassaemia intermedia, where patients may require occasional or no transfusions [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].
  • Mild (ß++) mutations: Examples include -101, -87, and -88. These mutations generally result in a very mild clinical phenotype [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].

Modifying Genetic Factors

Several genetic factors can modify the severity of thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the imbalance between α- and ß-globin chains, leading to a milder form of the disease [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].
  • Increased production of γ-globin chains: This leads to higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can ameliorate the severity of the disease [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf][NursesGuide_English.pdf].
  • Genome-wide association studies (GWAS): Identified loci such as BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB that influence HbF levels and disease severity [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf].

Clinical Implications

The clinical severity of thalassaemia can range from thalassaemia major, which requires regular blood transfusions, to thalassaemia intermedia, which may require occasional or no transfusions. The specific genetic mutations and modifying factors play a crucial role in determining the clinical outcome [NursesGuide_English.pdf].

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: does it refer to transferrin saturation
answer:
Understanding the 1.25 Factor in TIBC Calculation

The factor 1.25 used in the calculation of Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) from transferrin does not directly refer to transferrin saturation. Instead, it is a conversion factor that accounts for the molecular weight and binding capacity of transferrin for iron. This factor helps convert the concentration of transferrin (measured in mg/dL) to the TIBC (measured in µg/dL).

Transferrin saturation, on the other hand, is the ratio of serum iron to TIBC and is expressed as a percentage. It indicates how much of the transferrin is saturated with iron. In healthy adults, transferrin is about 30% saturated [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=32][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=59].

For further details, please refer to the sources or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sources:

  • TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf
  • TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf

question: How do I find a thalassemia clinic in a new country I am moving to?
answer:
Finding a Thalassaemia Clinic in a New Country

When moving to a new country, it is important to find a thalassaemia clinic to ensure you continue receiving the necessary medical care. Here are some steps to help you find a clinic:

  • Contact the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) for information on the nearest treatment centre in your new location. You can reach them at thalassaemia@cytanet.com.cy or visit their website at thalassaemia.org.cy [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=6][ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=62].
  • Familiarize yourself with the healthcare system in your new country to understand the provisions for chronic and complex diseases like thalassaemia. This will help you know your rights and access appropriate healthcare facilities and specialists [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=6].
  • Investigate and understand the procedures and processes for accessing treatment in your new location well in advance, including the costs of blood transfusion, iron chelation, and other medicines [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=5].
  • Connect with a Reference Centre in the city or country for more specialized consultation if needed [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=5].

If you need further assistance, please contact TIF at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What's your opinion on NAD and NMN supplements?
answer:
Opinion on NAD and NMN Supplements

Currently, there is no specific information or recommendation regarding the use of NAD (Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) and NMN (Nicotinamide mononucleotide) supplements for individuals with thalassaemia in the provided sources. The guidelines and studies focus on other vitamins and minerals such as folate, vitamin D, zinc, and antioxidants like vitamins C and E, which have been studied for their potential benefits in thalassaemia patients.

For more detailed and personalized advice, it is recommended to consult with a healthcare professional or nutritionist who can provide guidance based on the latest research and individual health needs.

question: Pulmonary hypertension
answer:
Pulmonary Hypertension in Thalassaemia

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is a condition characterized by abnormally high blood pressure in the pulmonary arteries. This condition results in the right side of the heart working harder to push blood through the arteries to the lungs, potentially leading to right-sided heart failure and reduced exercise tolerance.

Prevalence and Risk Factors

PH is more common in adults with non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (NTDT) than in those with β-thalassaemia major. The prevalence in well-treated NTDT patients is around 2% [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=52]. Risk factors include:

  • Chronic anemia
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis
  • Hemolysis
  • Iron overload
  • Vasculopathy
  • Splenectomy
  • Hypercoagulability [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=52][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=77]

Diagnosis

Diagnosis of PH is typically made using echocardiography to measure tricuspid valve regurgitant velocity (TRV). A TRV >2.5 m/s suggests possible PH, while a TRV >3.2 m/s indicates a high likelihood of PH. Confirmation is done through right heart catheterization [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=79].

Management and Treatment

Management includes addressing the underlying causes such as ineffective erythropoiesis, chronic anemia, and iron overload. Drug therapies like sildenafil and bosentan are used based on data from other conditions [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=52]. Regular monitoring and preventive strategies are crucial to manage this serious condition [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=77].

Prognosis

PH in NTDT patients is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. The median survival time for patients with confirmed PH is 9 years, with high rates of mortality [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=76].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: for patient's with splenectomy can they receive zoster or covid vaccines?
answer:
Vaccination for Splenectomised Thalassaemia Patients

Yes, patients who have undergone a splenectomy can receive both the zoster (shingles) and COVID-19 vaccines. Here are the relevant details:

Zoster Vaccine

There is no specific contraindication for the zoster vaccine in splenectomised patients. However, it is always best to consult with the treating physician to ensure it aligns with the patient's overall health plan.

COVID-19 Vaccine

Splenectomised patients are advised to receive the COVID-19 vaccine as per local standards. This is because they are considered at moderate risk of complications from COVID-19 due to their increased susceptibility to infections [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=33][HbDisordersCOVID-19_Classification-of-Risk-Groups_V4.pdf#page=20].

For more detailed guidance, please refer to the following sources:

  • TIF Guidelines for Non-Transfusion Dependent Beta Thalassaemia
  • Hb Disorders COVID-19 Classification of Risk Groups

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Twisting Blood Pipes During Transfusion

Twisting blood pipes during a transfusion is not recommended. Proper transfusion protocols should be followed to ensure patient safety and the effectiveness of the transfusion. If there is an issue with the flow of blood, it is important to check the equipment and ensure that it is being used according to the manufacturer's recommendations. Any issues should be addressed by a medical officer.

question: โภชนาการที่แนะนำ สำหรับผู้ป่วยธาลัสซีเมีย อัลฟา hbh diase
answer:
โภชนาการสำหรับผู้ป่วยธาลัสซีเมีย อัลฟา HbH Disease

สำหรับผู้ป่วยธาลัสซีเมีย อัลฟา HbH Disease มีคำแนะนำด้านโภชนาการดังนี้:

  • แนะนำให้เสริมกรดโฟลิกในปริมาณ 1-5 มก./วัน เพื่อสนับสนุนการสร้างเม็ดเลือดแดง [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=168][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=34].
  • แนะนำให้เสริมแคลเซียมและวิตามินดีในปริมาณ 2000 IU ต่อวัน และตรวจระดับวิตามินดีทุก 6 เดือน [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=117][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=168].
  • แนะนำให้รับประทานอาหารที่มีแคลเซียมสูง เช่น นม ปลา ชีส เป็นต้น [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=117].
  • แนะนำให้รับประทานอาหารที่มีวิตามินอีสูง เช่น ไข่ และน้ำมันพืช แต่การใช้เสริมวิตามินอีในระยะยาวต้องการการวิจัยเพิ่มเติม [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=117].
  • ควรหลีกเลี่ยงการเสริมธาตุเหล็ก เว้นแต่จะมีการยืนยันว่าขาดธาตุเหล็ก เนื่องจากการสะสมธาตุเหล็กอาจเกิดขึ้นจากการดูดซึมธาตุเหล็กในทางเดินอาหารที่เพิ่มขึ้น [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=34][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=27].
  • แนะนำให้ใช้วิตามินรวมที่ไม่มีธาตุเหล็ก โดยเฉพาะในผู้ป่วยเด็ก [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=34].
  • แนะนำให้ตรวจความหนาแน่นของกระดูกตั้งแต่อายุ 10 ปี และตรวจทุก 2-3 ปี หรือบ่อยกว่านั้นหากจำเป็น [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=27].

สำหรับข้อมูลเพิ่มเติม กรุณาติดต่อ info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Thalassaemia

  • α-thalassaemia: Occurs when genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • β-thalassaemia: Occurs due to genetic defects affecting the production of the β-globin protein. This type is further classified into thalassaemia major and thalassaemia minor.

[HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf]

Genetic Mutations and Their Impact

More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe. The severity of the condition can be influenced by the specific mutations and their interactions:

  • Homozygosity for severe β-thalassaemia alleles typically results in thalassaemia major, which requires regular blood transfusions for survival.
  • Homozygosity or compound heterozygosity for mild β-thalassaemia mutations can result in thalassaemia intermedia, which may require occasional or no transfusions.
  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or genetic determinants that increase fetal hemoglobin (HbF) production can ameliorate the severity of the disease.

[Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf][NursesGuide_English.pdf]

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

Several genetic factors can reduce the severity of thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: Reduces the imbalance between α- and β-chains, leading to a milder form of the disease.
  • Increased synthesis of γ-chains: Leads to higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can partially compensate for the lack of adult hemoglobin (HbA).
  • Specific mutations: Some mutations, such as deletional hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH), result in higher HbF levels and a milder phenotype.

[2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf]

Examples of Mutations

β++ mutations β+ mutations β0 mutations
-101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
C39

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf]

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Employment and Workplace Challenges for Adults with Thalassaemia

Many adult thalassaemia patients are employed without difficulty. However, there are several challenges that they may face in the workplace:

  • Self-Esteem and Health Perception: Some patients may have low self-esteem and feel that their health condition does not allow them to work effectively. This can be due to a lack of adequate psychosocial support [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Discrimination: Thalassaemia can be viewed as an 'immigrant disease' in some countries, potentially leading to racial and ethnic issues. This requires educational interventions to address [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Employment Statistics: In a survey of over 300 patients over 20 years of age, 50% were fully employed, 19% were working part-time, and 31% were unemployed. These figures are higher than national unemployment statistics, although 14% of those unemployed were by choice [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Workplace Adjustments: Patients may need to interrupt work for clinic and transfusion appointments, which are often during daytime working hours. Adjusting these services to include evening and weekend sessions can help patients maintain full-time employment [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Advocacy and Education: Thalassaemia care teams have a duty to advocate for their patients, educating the public and potential employers about the condition and the ability of patients to work. This includes ensuring non-discrimination and equal remuneration for work of equal value [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

Overall, with appropriate support and adjustments, many adults with thalassaemia can successfully integrate into the workforce and achieve their professional goals.

question: what s HbC/beta-thalassemia
answer:
HbC/Beta-Thalassemia

HbC/beta-thalassemia is a compound heterozygous condition where an individual inherits one gene for hemoglobin C (HbC) and one gene for beta-thalassemia. This condition results in a combination of the characteristics of both disorders.

Pathophysiology

Beta-thalassemia is caused by reduced or absent synthesis of the beta-globin chains of the adult hemoglobin (HbA) tetramer, leading to severe anemia and other complications [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=2].

HbC is a variant of hemoglobin that causes red cells to become dehydrated and rigid, leading to hemolytic anemia. However, patients with HbC do not develop sickling symptoms [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=96].

Clinical Features

The clinical severity of HbC/beta-thalassemia can vary. It may present with symptoms of anemia and other complications associated with beta-thalassemia, but the presence of HbC can modify the clinical picture [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=24].

Management

Management of HbC/beta-thalassemia typically involves regular monitoring and may include blood transfusions and other supportive treatments to manage anemia and prevent complications [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=51].

For more detailed information or specific medical advice, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the latest advancements in gene therapy for thalassaemia?
answer:
Latest Advancements in Gene Therapy for Thalassaemia

Gene therapy has shown significant promise in the treatment of thalassaemia, particularly for patients with transfusion-dependent β-thalassaemia. Here are some of the latest advancements:

Zynteglo™

Zynteglo™ is a gene therapy product developed by Bluebird Bio Inc. It involves the transfer of a functional β-globin gene into the patient's cells using a lentiviral vector. This therapy has shown promising results in clinical trials:

  • For patients with the less severe form of the disease (non-βº/βº genotype or β+ genotype), the majority (4 in 5) have become transfusion-independent shortly after gene therapy [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=5].
  • For patients with the more severe form of thalassaemia (βº/βº genotype), most did not become transfusion-independent, but many experienced a significant decrease in their annual transfusion requirements [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=5].

Gene Editing

Gene editing approaches, particularly those using CRISPR/Cas9 technology, are also being explored for the treatment of β-thalassaemia:

  • CRISPR Therapeutics is conducting phase I/II clinical trials (CTX001-111) targeting the reactivation of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) by disrupting the BCL11A binding site, which has shown potential in reducing transfusion requirements [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=283].
  • Gene editing for the correction of specific point mutations, mainly by base editing, is being evaluated for hemoglobinopathies, including β-thalassaemia. However, clinical experience with gene editing is currently limited, and more data from large-scale trials are needed to demonstrate its safety and efficacy [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=128].

Clinical Trials and Long-Term Follow-Up

Patients treated with gene therapy are followed in long-term trials lasting up to 15 years to monitor the safety and sustainability of the response. This is crucial to ensure that the therapy remains effective and does not lead to adverse effects over time [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=286].

Future Prospects

While gene therapy and gene editing offer promising avenues for curing thalassaemia, ongoing research and clinical trials are essential to overcome current technical challenges and ensure these treatments are safe and effective for all patients [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=24].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the full guidelines here.

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Thalassaemia

  • α-thalassaemia: Occurs when genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • β-thalassaemia: Occurs when similar genetic defects affect the production of the β-globin protein.

β-thalassaemia is further classified into two main forms:

  • Thalassaemia major: Inheriting the gene from both parents causes severe, life-threatening anaemia.
  • Thalassaemia minor: Inheriting the gene from one parent causes a generally symptom-free condition known as the thalassaemia trait.
[HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf]

Genetic Mutations and Their Impact

More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe. The severity of the condition can be influenced by the specific mutations and their interactions:

  • Homozygosity for severe β-thalassaemia alleles typically results in thalassaemia major.
  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or genetic determinants that increase HbF production can ameliorate the phenotype, potentially resulting in thalassaemia intermedia.
  • Specific mutations, such as the mild β+-type mutation -88 (C->T), generally result in a very mild clinical phenotype.
  • Other mutations, like Cap+1 (A->C), can result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients.
[Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72]

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

Several genetic factors can reduce the severity of thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia, which decreases the synthesis of α-chains, reducing the imbalance between α- and β-chains.
  • Increased synthesis of γ-chains, leading to higher levels of foetal haemoglobin (HbF), which can partially correct the imbalance.
  • Mutations that increase HbF production, such as deletional and non-deletional hereditary persistence of foetal haemoglobin (HPFH) mutations.
  • Changes in the ubiquitin-proteasome system or expression of α-haemoglobin stabilising protein, which help detoxify and tolerate a modest pool of free α-globin.
[2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Conclusion

The genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity are complex and influenced by multiple factors. Genetic counselling is often recommended to understand the potential outcomes and manage the condition effectively.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely depending on the specific mutations and their interactions.

Types of Mutations

  • ß-thalassaemia mutations: Over 200 mutations have been identified, leading to a range of phenotypic severities from silent to very severe. These mutations can result in conditions ranging from thalassaemia intermedia to thalassaemia major [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=64].
  • α-thalassaemia mutations: These mutations can also affect the severity of thalassaemia. For example, the co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia can ameliorate the severity of ß-thalassaemia by reducing the imbalance between α- and ß-globin chains [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].

Impact on Severity

The severity of thalassaemia is influenced by several factors:

  • Homozygous ß-thalassaemia: Patients can experience a wide range of clinical severities, from thalassaemia major, which requires regular blood transfusions, to thalassaemia intermedia, which may require occasional or no transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Specific mutations: For instance, the mild ß+-type mutation -88 (C->T) generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype, while the Cap+1 (A->C) mutation can result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=64].
  • Co-inheritance of other genetic factors: The presence of other genetic conditions, such as decreased synthesis of α-chains or increased synthesis of γ-chains, can reduce the severity of the disease [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the sources provided or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy for further assistance.

question: What are the treatment options for autoimmune haemolytic anaemia in thalassaemia patients?
answer:
Treatment Options for Autoimmune Haemolytic Anaemia in Thalassaemia Patients

Autoimmune haemolytic anaemia (AIHA) is a serious complication that can occur in thalassaemia patients, often in those with alloantibodies. Here are the primary treatment options:

Steroids

Steroids are commonly used as the first line of treatment for AIHA. They help reduce the immune system's attack on red blood cells [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=29][EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=9].

Immunosuppressive Drugs

Immunosuppressive drugs are used to further suppress the immune system and reduce the destruction of red blood cells. These drugs are often used when steroids alone are not effective [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=29][EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=9].

Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG)

IVIG is administered to help modulate the immune system. It can be particularly useful in acute cases of AIHA [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=29][EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=9].

Rituximab

Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets B cells, which are part of the immune system. It is used in cases where other treatments are not effective [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=29][EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=9].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins. There are two main types:

  • α-thalassaemia: Occurs when genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • β-thalassaemia: Occurs when similar genetic defects affect the production of the β-globin protein.

In β-thalassaemia, the severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific mutations and other genetic factors:

  • More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from mild to very severe [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Homozygosity for severe β-thalassaemia alleles typically results in thalassaemia major, which requires regular blood transfusions for survival [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or genetic determinants that increase fetal hemoglobin (HbF) production can ameliorate the severity, potentially resulting in thalassaemia intermedia [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Specific mutations, such as the mild β+-type mutation -88 (C->T), generally result in a very mild clinical phenotype [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Deletional and non-deletional hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH) mutations can also result in milder forms of the disease [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

Overall, the genetic interactions leading to the phenotype of β-thalassaemia intermedia are very heterogeneous, and the clinical severity can vary significantly even among individuals with similar genotypes [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=61].

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: what is the employment rate of thalassemia patients?
answer:
Employment Rate of Thalassaemia Patients

The employment rate of thalassaemia patients varies by region and individual circumstances. According to a survey in Europe, of more than 300 patients over 20 years of age:

  • 50% were fully employed
  • 19% were working part-time
  • 31% were unemployed

In Cyprus, 79% of thalassaemia patients are employed in various fields such as handicrafts, agriculture, secretarial work, teaching, and medical or paramedical roles [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=130].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What is Hb e beta thalassemia
answer:
Hb E Beta Thalassemia

Hb E beta thalassemia is a genetic disorder that results from the co-inheritance of a beta-thalassemia allele from one parent and the structural variant hemoglobin E from the other parent. Hemoglobin E is caused by a G-to-A substitution in codon number 26 of the beta-globin gene, leading to a structurally abnormal hemoglobin and an abnormally spliced non-functional mRNA. This results in hemoglobin E being synthesized at a reduced rate and behaving like a mild beta-thalassemia.

Hb E beta thalassemia can present in various clinical forms:

  • Severe: Hemoglobin levels as low as 4-5 g/dl, transfusion-dependent, with clinical symptoms similar to beta-thalassemia major.
  • Moderate: Hemoglobin levels between 6 and 7 g/dl, transfusion-independent, with clinical symptoms similar to beta-thalassemia intermedia.
  • Mild: Hemoglobin levels between 9 and 12 g/dl, transfusion-independent, usually without clinically significant problems.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the sources:

  • NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf
  • TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Are protein powders safe for thalassemia major?
answer:
Are Protein Powders Safe for Thalassemia Major?

Protein intake is typically adequate in patients with thalassemia major, and there is no specific limitation on protein intake for these patients. However, it is important to consider the following points:

  • High calorie, high protein diets have historically improved weight, body composition, and nutritional biochemistries in young children with thalassemia [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=93].
  • Protein intake does not appear to be limited in patients with thalassemia, except for those who are vegetarian, vegan, or avoid animal meat products due to high iron content [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=168].
  • Consistent intake of dietary protein is necessary for optimal function of every organ in the body [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=88].

While protein powders can be a convenient way to ensure adequate protein intake, it is essential to consult with a healthcare provider or a nutrition professional to determine if they are appropriate for your specific needs and to ensure they do not interfere with your overall dietary plan.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

  • ß-thalassaemia mutations: Over 200 mutations have been identified, ranging from silent to very severe. These mutations can produce a spectrum of disorders from mild thalassaemia intermedia to severe thalassaemia major [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Severity of mutations: Examples of severe (ß0), less severe (ß+), and mild (ß++) mutations include:
    ß++ mutations ß+ mutations ß0 mutations
    -101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
    IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
    IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
    C39
    [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Modifying Genetic Factors

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: This can reduce the severity of ß-thalassaemia by decreasing the imbalance between α- and ß-globin chains [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Increased production of γ-globin chains: This leads to higher levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can ameliorate the severity of the disease [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Genome-wide association studies (GWAS): Identified loci such as BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB that influence the production of HbF and thus the severity of the disease [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

Clinical Impact

The clinical severity of thalassaemia can range from thalassaemia major, requiring regular blood transfusions, to thalassaemia intermedia, which may require occasional or no transfusions. The specific genetic mutations and modifying factors determine the clinical outcome [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.
