question: What is the role of iron chelation therapy in thalassaemia management?
answer:
Role of Iron Chelation Therapy in Thalassaemia Management

Iron chelation therapy is a critical component in the management of thalassaemia, particularly for patients who receive regular blood transfusions. The primary purpose of iron chelation therapy is to remove excess iron from the body, which accumulates as a result of frequent blood transfusions.

Why is Iron Chelation Therapy Necessary?

Blood transfusions, while essential for managing thalassaemia, lead to the accumulation of iron in the body. This excess iron can be toxic and cause damage to vital organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands. Without proper management, iron overload can result in severe complications, including heart failure, liver cirrhosis, and diabetes [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2][EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=13].

Types of Iron Chelation Therapy

There are three main types of iron chelation medicines currently in use:

  • Deferoxamine: Administered through subcutaneous injection, usually over several hours per day.
  • Deferiprone: An oral iron chelator.
  • Deferasirox: Another oral iron chelator.

The choice of chelator, dosage, and frequency of administration are determined by the treating physician based on the patient's needs, lifestyle, and the availability and cost of the chelators [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].

Goals of Iron Chelation Therapy

Iron chelation therapy aims to:

  • Maintain safe levels of body iron by balancing iron intake from blood transfusions with iron excretion (prevention therapy).
  • Remove excess iron stored in the body (rescue therapy).
  • Urgently intensify iron chelation in cases of iron-induced heart failure (emergency therapy).
  • Adjust dosing and treatment regimens based on careful monitoring of body iron levels (dose adjustment) [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=13].

Challenges and Adherence

Adherence to iron chelation therapy can be challenging due to the chronic nature of the treatment and potential side effects. Psychological and social support can significantly improve adherence and overall treatment outcomes [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=25].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Symptoms

  • Severe anaemia
  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

Common Complications

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, including:

  • Iron overload due to regular blood transfusions, which can cause damage to major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Endocrine problems such as delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities including pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, congestive heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities such as cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation guidelines.

question: average transfusion burden of thalassemia
answer:
Average Transfusion Burden of Thalassemia

The average transfusion burden for patients with thalassemia major varies based on several factors, including whether the patient has undergone a splenectomy. Here are some key points:

  • Unsplenectomised thalassemia major patients have higher transfusion requirements, averaging about 0.43 mg/kg/day of iron loading, compared to 0.33 mg/kg/day in splenectomised patients [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=47].
  • The recommended transfusion scheme for thalassemia major involves transfusing the equivalent of 100-200 ml of pure red blood cells per kg body weight per year. This translates to an annual iron loading of 116-232 mg/kg/year, or 0.32-0.64 mg/kg/day [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=57].
  • For a patient weighing 40 kg, the annual blood requirement is calculated as 195 ml/kg, which results in an annual pure red cell requirement of 117 ml/kg/year and a daily transfusional iron loading of 0.34 mg/kg [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=46].

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: آیا انجمن تالاسمی ایران برنامه‌های آموزشی برای بیماران دارد؟
answer:
برنامه‌های آموزشی انجمن تالاسمی ایران

بله، انجمن تالاسمی ایران برنامه‌های آموزشی متعددی برای بیماران و خانواده‌های آنها ارائه می‌دهد. این برنامه‌ها شامل موارد زیر می‌شوند:

  • آموزش بیماران و والدین: انجمن تالاسمی ایران به آموزش بیماران و والدین آنها در مورد بیماری، درمان‌ها و مدیریت آن می‌پردازد. این آموزش‌ها به بیماران کمک می‌کند تا با بیماری خود بهتر کنار بیایند و کیفیت زندگی خود را بهبود بخشند [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=39].
  • کارگاه‌ها و سمینارها: انجمن تالاسمی ایران با همکاری فدراسیون بین‌المللی تالاسمی (TIF) و سایر سازمان‌های مرتبط، کارگاه‌ها و سمینارهای آموزشی برگزار می‌کند. این رویدادها به بیماران و خانواده‌های آنها اطلاعات به‌روز و دقیق در مورد تالاسمی ارائه می‌دهند [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=316][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=115].
  • مواد آموزشی: انجمن تالاسمی ایران مواد آموزشی متنوعی از جمله کتاب‌ها، بروشورها و ویدئوهای آموزشی تهیه و توزیع می‌کند. این مواد به بیماران و خانواده‌های آنها کمک می‌کنند تا با جنبه‌های مختلف بیماری آشنا شوند [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=43][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=10].
  • برنامه‌های آگاهی‌بخشی عمومی: انجمن تالاسمی ایران برنامه‌های آگاهی‌بخشی عمومی را برای افزایش آگاهی جامعه در مورد تالاسمی و اهمیت پیشگیری از آن برگزار می‌کند [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=17].

برای اطلاعات بیشتر می‌توانید به info@thalassaemia.org.cy ایمیل بزنید.

question: What to do when there is a blood shortage?
answer:
What to Do During a Blood Shortage

In the event of a blood shortage, several measures can be taken to mitigate the impact:

  • Facilitate blood donations through mobile units and ensure a safe environment for donors and staff. Use telephone, SMS, email, and social media to organize blood donation campaigns. [Haemoglobin-Disorders_-Blood-COVID-19-1.pdf#page=16]
  • Consider targeted pools of family and friends as donors, and if necessary, import blood from less affected regions or other countries. [Haemoglobin-Disorders_-Blood-COVID-19-1.pdf#page=16]
  • Monitor the national inventory of blood supplies daily to move blood to where it is most needed. [Haemoglobin-Disorders_-Blood-COVID-19-1.pdf#page=16]
  • Prioritize patients for transfusion and postpone less urgent transfusions. Treating physicians should review decisions based on the patient's clinical condition. [HbDisordersCOVID-19_Classification-of-Risk-Groups_V4.pdf#page=17]
  • Reduce whole blood donation intervals for donors with robust hemoglobin levels who can tolerate more frequent donations. [Haemoglobin-Disorders_-Blood-COVID-19-1.pdf#page=13]
  • Strengthen existing and develop new mobile unit services to facilitate blood donations. [COVID-19-pandemic-and-haemoglobin-disorders_V3.pdf#page=8]

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation's Blood & COVID-19 Guide.

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the disorder can vary widely depending on the specific mutations involved and their interactions. Here are some key points:

Types of Mutations

  • More than 200 ß-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Examples of severe (ßo), less severe (ß+), and mild (ß++) mutations include:
    ß++ mutations ß+ mutations ßo mutations
    -101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
    IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
    IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
    C39
    [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Impact on Severity

  • The severity of homozygous ß-thalassaemia is influenced by factors such as the co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or gene modifiers that increase Hb F production [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • For example, the mild ß+-type mutation -88 (C->T) generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype, while the mild ß+-thalassaemia mutation Cap+1 (A->C) can result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Patients with thalassaemia major require regular blood transfusions to survive, whereas those with thalassaemia intermedia may survive with occasional or no transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Other genetic conditions, such as decreased synthesis of α-chains or increased synthesis of γ-chains, can also reduce the severity of the disease [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources provided or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Hypertransfusion
answer:
Hypertransfusion in Thalassemia Major

Hypertransfusion is a treatment strategy used in thalassemia major to maintain higher hemoglobin levels and manage complications. Here are the key aspects:

Goals of Hypertransfusion

  • Maintain pre-transfusion hemoglobin levels at 9.5 to 10 g/dL to suppress ineffective erythropoiesis and optimize patient well-being [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Prevent complications such as bone deformities, poor growth, and extramedullary hematopoiesis [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=19].

Criteria for Initiating Transfusion Therapy

  • Confirmed diagnosis of thalassemia [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=44].
  • Hemoglobin level (Hb) < 7 g/dL on two occasions, more than two weeks apart, excluding other causes such as infections [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Clinical criteria irrespective of hemoglobin level, such as significant symptoms of anemia, poor growth, bone fractures, and extramedullary hematopoiesis [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=3].

Transfusion Regimen

  • Patients typically receive transfusions every two to four weeks [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • The volume of blood required depends on the patient's age, clinical status, and the target hemoglobin level [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=42].
  • For hypertransfusion, the aim is to maintain pre-transfusion hemoglobin levels at 90 g/L as a minimum, and in some cases, higher levels may be targeted [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=31].

Considerations

  • Hypertransfusion may lead to increased iron load, necessitating effective iron chelation therapy [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Monitoring and recording the size of the spleen is important, as splenomegaly may be reversible with increased transfusion [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=31].

For more detailed information, please refer to the TIF guidelines available at www.thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What is the function of hemopexin
answer:
Function of Hemopexin

Hemopexin is a plasma protein that plays a crucial role in the body's defense against oxidative stress and iron toxicity. Its primary functions include:

  • Hemoglobin Binding: Hemopexin binds free heme released from hemoglobin during red blood cell breakdown. This binding prevents the heme from catalyzing the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and protects tissues from oxidative damage [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=58].
  • Iron Conservation: By binding free heme, hemopexin helps to conserve iron and facilitate its safe transport to the liver, where it can be recycled for the production of new red blood cells [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=58].
  • Anti-inflammatory Role: Hemopexin reduces inflammation by preventing the pro-inflammatory effects of free heme, which can activate immune cells and promote the release of inflammatory cytokines [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=58].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the most recent therapies for thalassemia major?
answer:
Recent Therapies for Thalassaemia Major

There have been significant advancements in the treatment of thalassaemia major. Here are some of the most recent therapies:

Gene Therapy

Gene therapy has shown promising results, particularly with the product ZYNTEGLO™ developed by Bluebird Bio Inc. This therapy involves transferring a functional β-globin gene into the patient's cells using a lentiviral vector. Clinical trials have demonstrated that:

  • The majority of patients with the less severe form of the disease (non-ßº/Bº genotype) have become transfusion independent shortly after gene therapy.
  • Patients with the more severe form (ß0/Bº genotype) did not become transfusion independent but had a significant decrease in their annual transfusion requirements [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=5].

The European Commission granted conditional approval for ZYNTEGLO™ in June 2019 for patients 12 years and older who are eligible for stem cell transplantation but do not have a matched related donor [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=128].

Allogeneic Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT)

HSCT remains the only widely available curative treatment for thalassaemia major. Improved conditioning regimens and better prevention of graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) have significantly improved outcomes, with a cure rate of 80% to 90% in patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=122].

Luspatercept-aamt

Luspatercept-aamt is a novel pharmaceutical agent that acts in the late stages of red blood cell maturation. It helps prolong the lifespan of red blood cells, increasing haemoglobin levels and reducing the frequency of transfusions. This can lead to lower iron overload and fewer hospital visits, improving the quality of life for patients [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website or contact us at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Yersinia
answer:
Yersinia enterocolitica and Thalassaemia

Yersinia enterocolitica is a bacterium that can cause serious infections in individuals with thalassaemia, particularly those with iron overload. Here are some key points:

  • Yersinia enterocolitica does not have its own mechanism for collecting and using iron from its environment. In healthy individuals, it is usually harmless [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=90][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=56].
  • In thalassaemia major, where there is excess iron in the body, Yersinia can grow and multiply rapidly, leading to severe, life-threatening infections [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=90][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=56].
  • Infections with Yersinia enterocolitica are commonly associated with the use of the iron chelator desferrioxamine (DFO) [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=66].
  • Clinical manifestations of Yersinia infection include fever, abdominal pain, enterocolitis, pharyngitis-tonsillitis, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and polyarthritis. Severe cases can lead to complications such as hepatic and splenic abscesses, osteomyelitis, nephritis, meningitis, and endocarditis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90].
  • Laboratory diagnosis requires specific culture conditions for blood and stool samples, and serological tests may be used to confirm recent infection [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: does thalassemia affect women more than men?
answer:
Thalassaemia does not affect women more than men. The prevalence and impact of thalassaemia are generally similar across genders. However, specific complications such as hypogonadism, which can lead to pubertal failure, sexual dysfunction, and infertility, can affect both men and women with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=234].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What specific exercises are recommended for thalassemia patients?
answer:
Recommended Exercises for Thalassemia Patients

Thalassemia patients can benefit from various types of physical activities. Here are some specific exercises recommended:

Weight-Bearing Activities

  • Walking
  • Jogging
  • Dancing
  • Jumping

These activities are particularly beneficial for bone health [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Weight-Less Activities

  • Swimming
  • Biking

These activities are important for heart health but are less helpful for bone health [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Flexibility and Balance Exercises

  • Yoga
  • Pilates

These exercises improve muscle strength and balance, thereby reducing the risk of falling [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

General Recommendations

  • Consult with a haematologist and/or cardiologist before starting any new exercise regime [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=170].
  • Engage in non-contact, weight-bearing physical activities [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=162].
  • Physical activity should complement, not replace, adequate chelation and optimal nutrition [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=170].

For more detailed information, you can contact the Thalassaemia International Federation at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What lifestyle changes can help manage thalassaemia symptoms?
answer:
Lifestyle Changes for Managing Thalassaemia Symptoms

Healthy Lifestyle Recommendations

Adopting a healthy lifestyle is crucial for managing thalassaemia symptoms and preventing complications. Here are some key recommendations:

Dietary Changes

  • Consume a varied, nutrient-dense diet with plenty of fruits and vegetables every day [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].
  • Include high-fibre, starchy foods such as wholegrain breads, cereals, beans, peas, lentils, and oats [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43].
  • Consume adequate amounts of calcium from food sources like milk, yogurt, tofu, and kale [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Take a vitamin D supplement of 1,000 - 2,000 IU/day or 50,000 IU per month [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Limit vitamin C intake to no more than 1,000 mg per day [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].
  • Stay hydrated by drinking mostly water and non-sugar sweetened beverages [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].

Physical Activity

  • Engage in regular physical activity, particularly weight-bearing exercises such as walking, jogging, dancing, and jumping to promote bone health [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Include activities that improve flexibility, such as yoga and Pilates, to enhance muscle strength and balance [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Monitoring and Prevention

  • Regularly monitor glucose metabolism markers and maintain a healthy body weight to prevent complications [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=50].
  • Check zinc blood levels and take supplements if necessary [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Regular cardiovascular assessments should be part of a multidisciplinary monitoring program [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=123].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Follow-up Questions

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Employment and Workplace Challenges for Adults with Thalassaemia

Many adult thalassaemia patients are employed without difficulty. However, there are several challenges that they may face in the workplace:

  • Self-Esteem and Health Perception: Some patients may have low self-esteem and feel that their health does not allow them to work effectively. This can be due to inadequate psychosocial support [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Discrimination: Thalassaemia patients may face discrimination based on disability, which can affect their employment opportunities and working conditions. Advocacy and education by the thalassaemia care team are essential to combat this [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Medical Appointments: The need to attend clinic and transfusion appointments during daytime working hours can disrupt education and employment. Adjusting these services to include evening and weekend sessions can help [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Mental Health: A considerable proportion of adult patients with thalassaemia show evidence of depression and anxiety, which can impact their work life [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=112].

Despite these challenges, with appropriate treatment and support, many thalassaemia patients can achieve their career goals and lead fulfilling professional lives [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=125].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Tell me about gene therapy for thalasemia
answer:
Gene Therapy for Thalassaemia

Gene therapy aims to cure thalassaemia by manipulating the genome of haematopoietic stem cells to compensate for the faulty function of mutated genes. This can be achieved through:

  • Gene Addition: Inserting a healthy copy of the therapeutic gene into the cells using viral vectors [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=279][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=127].
  • Gene Editing: Precisely directed mutations that repair the gene in situ or induce a disease-modifying effect, such as reactivation of fetal hemoglobin (Hb F) synthesis [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=279][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=127].

Ex vivo gene therapy involves a haematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation-based procedure. The patient's own HSCs are mobilized, harvested, enriched, and genetically modified outside the body before being reintroduced [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=279][TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=24].

Clinical trials have shown promising results, with many patients achieving transfusion independence or significant reductions in transfusion requirements [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=5]. However, more trials are needed to confirm the safety and efficacy of gene therapy as a permanent cure [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=2].

For more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

  • What are the potential risks and side effects of gene therapy for thalassaemia?
  • How long does the gene therapy process take?
  • Are there any ongoing clinical trials for gene therapy in thalassaemia patients?

question: Suggest a good descriptive research about thalassemia in a developing country
answer:
Descriptive Research on Thalassemia in a Developing Country

A good descriptive research study on thalassemia in a developing country can be found in the work of Weatherall DJ, which discusses the challenge of haemoglobinopathies in resource-poor countries. This study highlights the significant contribution of haemoglobin disorders to the global tally of disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) and the urgent need for national control programs of prevention and management [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=23][ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=57].

Another relevant study is by Angastiniotis M and Modell B, which provides a global epidemiology of haemoglobin disorders and derived service indicators. This research emphasizes the importance of epidemiological surveys and patient registries to gather evidence-based information on the size of the problem and its impact on community health [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=22].

For further details, you may refer to the following sources:

  • Thalassaemia and Sickle Cell syndromes [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=55]
  • Thalassemia as a global health problem [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=23]
  • Thalassaemia International Federation [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=57]

If you need more specific information or assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Do children with undiagnosed thalassemia major have high reticulocyte counts?
answer:
Reticulocyte Counts in Children with Undiagnosed Thalassemia Major

Children with undiagnosed thalassemia major typically do not have high reticulocyte counts. Reticulocyte counts are more relevant in the context of diagnosing and managing alpha-thalassemia major and HbH disease, where reticulocytosis can be observed [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=184][PreventionVol2_English.pdf#page=30].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: How can patients in Pakistan get involved with TIF?
answer:
How Can Patients in Pakistan Get Involved with TIF?

Patients in Pakistan can get involved with the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) through several avenues:

1. Join or Form a National Thalassaemia Association

Patients can join existing national thalassaemia associations or work towards forming one if it does not exist. These associations are crucial for representing patients at the national level and collaborating with TIF [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=56].

2. Participate in Educational Programs

TIF offers comprehensive educational programs for patients, which include workshops, seminars, conferences, and webinars. These programs aim to build a knowledgeable patient community that can advocate effectively for their rights and quality care [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=316][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=116].

3. Engage in Advocacy

Patients can actively participate in advocacy efforts at national, regional, and international levels. TIF encourages patient involvement in decision-making processes to ensure their voices are heard and their needs are met [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=117][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=319].

4. Provide Feedback and Identify Gaps

Patients can help TIF by identifying gaps and weaknesses in the care they receive. This feedback is essential for TIF to tailor its activities and projects to better meet the needs of patients [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=116].

For more information or assistance, you can contact TIF at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: how common is thalassaemia in pakistna
answer:
Thalassaemia Prevalence in Pakistan

Thalassaemia is the most common single gene disorder in Pakistan, with more than 4,000 births of affected children each year. This indicates a significant prevalence of the condition in the country.

For further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sources:

  • PreventionVol1_English.pdf

question: is thalesemea a disablity?
answer:
Is Thalassaemia a Disability?

Thalassaemia can be considered a disability, particularly in its more severe forms. Individuals with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) require regular, lifelong blood transfusions and iron chelation therapy, which can significantly impact their daily lives and overall health [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=17][ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=57].

Thalassaemia intermedia, or non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (NTDT), can also lead to disability due to its clinical diversity and the occasional need for blood transfusions [ThalCarrierCheck_EN_Final_end.pdf#page=1].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

There are more than 200 known ß-thalassaemia mutations, which can result in a range of phenotypic severities from very mild to very severe forms of the disease [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72]. These mutations are categorized as follows:

B++ mutations ß+ mutations Bo mutations
-101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
C39

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Impact on Severity

The severity of thalassaemia is influenced by several factors:

  • Type of Mutation: Severe mutations (Bo) typically result in thalassaemia major, while less severe mutations (ß+) and mild mutations (B++) can result in thalassaemia intermedia or even a very mild form of the disease [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].
  • Co-inheritance of a-thalassaemia: The co-inheritance of a-thalassaemia can reduce the imbalance between a- and ß-globin chains, leading to a milder phenotype [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Increased HbF Production: Genetic determinants that increase the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) can ameliorate the severity of the disease. For example, the co-inheritance of hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH) mutations can result in a milder form of ß-thalassaemia intermedia [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Other Genetic Modifiers: Changes in the ubiquitin-proteasome system or the expression of a-haemoglobin stabilizing protein can also help reduce disease severity by detoxifying and tolerating a modest pool of free a-globin [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

Overall, the clinical outcome of thalassaemia is determined by a complex interplay of these genetic factors, making genetic counseling and diagnosis challenging [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=64].

question: are patients of hb e disease transfusion dependent?
answer:
Transfusion Dependency in Hb E Disease

Patients with Hb E disease are generally not transfusion-dependent. They usually remain clinically well with no relevant symptoms even with hemoglobin values in the 6-7 g/dL range [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=48].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely based on the specific genetic mutations involved and other modifying genetic factors.

Types of Mutations

  • ß-thalassaemia mutations: Over 200 mutations have been identified, ranging from silent to very severe. These mutations can result in different clinical phenotypes, from thalassaemia intermedia to thalassaemia major [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • α-thalassaemia mutations: Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia can reduce the severity of ß-thalassaemia by decreasing the imbalance between α- and ß-globin chains [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].

Impact of Genetic Modifiers

  • Increased HbF production: Genetic determinants that increase the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) can ameliorate the severity of ß-thalassaemia. For example, the co-inheritance of hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH) mutations can result in a milder form of the disease [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Genome-wide association studies (GWAS): Studies have identified loci such as BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB that influence the severity of ß-thalassaemia by affecting HbF levels [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

Examples of Specific Mutations

ß++ mutations ß+ mutations ß0 mutations
-101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
C39

[AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Conclusion

The genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity are complex and influenced by a variety of factors, including the specific mutations present and other genetic modifiers. Accurate genetic diagnosis and counseling are essential for managing the condition effectively.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Apakah ada tes khusus untuk mendeteksi thalassaemia pada bayi?
answer:
Tes Khusus untuk Mendeteksi Thalassaemia pada Bayi

Untuk mendeteksi thalassaemia pada bayi, ada beberapa tes khusus yang dapat dilakukan. Berikut adalah beberapa metode yang digunakan:

  • Amniocentesis: Dilakukan pada trimester kedua kehamilan (setelah sekitar 15-22 minggu). Tes ini melibatkan pengambilan sampel cairan ketuban untuk dianalisis [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=140].
  • Teknik Molekuler: Tes ini dapat mengidentifikasi mutasi yang diwarisi anak dari masing-masing orang tua. Tes ini biasanya dilakukan jika ada kecurigaan khusus, seperti jika orang tua diketahui sebagai pembawa thalassaemia [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=32].
  • Pengujian Genetik atau DNA: Tes ini memberikan diagnosis definitif dan penting untuk membedakan antara berbagai jenis status pembawa thalassaemia. Tes ini juga dapat digunakan untuk mendiagnosis penyakit HbH pada tahap awal [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=44].
  • Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT): Analisis DNA janin bebas sel dalam darah ibu. Meskipun aplikasinya masih terbatas, teknologi ini dapat membantu dalam diagnosis prenatal [ThalCarrierCheck_EN_Final_end.pdf#page=1].

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut, Anda dapat menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the best foods to include in a thalassaemia-friendly diet?
answer:
Thalassaemia-Friendly Diet

For individuals with thalassaemia, a balanced and nutrient-dense diet is essential to manage their condition effectively. Here are some dietary recommendations:

Key Nutrients and Foods

  • High-Fibre Carbohydrates: Choose wholegrain breads and cereals, beans, peas, lentils, brown rice, and oats. These foods are high in dietary fibre and help maintain stable blood sugar levels [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43].
  • Fruits and Vegetables: Consume a variety of fruits and vegetables every day. These foods are rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, which help reduce oxidative stress caused by iron overload [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43][Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=11].
  • Calcium-Rich Foods: Include milk, cheese, and oily fish in your diet to ensure adequate calcium intake, which is crucial for bone health [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=236].
  • Healthy Fats: Use small amounts of mono-unsaturated fats and oils, such as olive oil and rapeseed oil, in cooking. Avoid saturated fats and fried foods [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43][Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Vitamin E-Rich Foods: Include foods like eggs and vegetable oils, which are rich in vitamin E and help reduce oxidative stress [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=236].
  • Folic Acid: Consider folic acid supplements, especially if you are on a low transfusion regimen, to support nucleoprotein synthesis and reduce the risk of thrombosis [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=236].

Foods to Limit

  • Iron-Rich Foods: Limit the intake of iron-rich foods, especially for non-transfusion dependent thalassaemia patients. Avoid foods like red meat, spinach, and iron-fortified cereals [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=13].
  • Vitamin C: Be cautious with foods high in vitamin C, as it increases the absorption of non-meat iron. Limit the intake of fruits, fruit juices, and vegetables high in vitamin C [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=163].
  • Added Sugars and Alcohol: Avoid foods with added sugars and limit alcohol consumption. People with liver inflammation should avoid alcohol altogether [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=27].
  • Low-Fibre Carbohydrates: Avoid large portions of starchy carbohydrates that are low in fibre, such as potatoes, white bread, white rice, and pasta [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Additional Recommendations

  • Small, Regular Meals: Consume small, regular meals spread throughout the day to maintain stable blood sugar levels and prevent fatigue [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Hydration: Stay well-hydrated by drinking plenty of water and non-sugar sweetened beverages [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=168].
  • Exercise: Engage in regular physical activity, such as brisk walking, as long as it is safe based on heart checks [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

If you need further assistance, please contact

question: Come si gestisce il sovraccarico di ferro nella talassemia?
answer:
Gestione del Sovraccarico di Ferro nella Talassemia

Il sovraccarico di ferro è una complicazione comune nei pazienti con talassemia, specialmente in quelli che ricevono trasfusioni di sangue regolari. Ecco come viene gestito:

Terapia Chelante del Ferro

La terapia chelante del ferro è essenziale per rimuovere l'eccesso di ferro dal corpo. Questo trattamento è necessario perché il ferro accumulato può diventare tossico per molti organi vitali come il cuore, il fegato e le ghiandole endocrine.

  • I pazienti con ß-talassemia richiedono una terapia chelante del ferro per tutta la vita, di solito a partire dalla prima infanzia e generalmente su base giornaliera [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • Esistono tre tipi principali di farmaci chelanti del ferro attualmente in uso:
    • Deferoxamina: somministrata tramite iniezione sottocutanea.
    • Deferiprone: somministrato per via orale.
    • Deferasirox: somministrato per via orale [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].

Monitoraggio e Gestione

Il monitoraggio regolare dei livelli di ferro è cruciale per gestire efficacemente il sovraccarico di ferro. Questo include:

  • Monitoraggio della concentrazione di ferro epatico (LIC) per valutare il contenuto totale di ferro nel corpo [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=114].
  • Valutazione della funzione cardiaca, poiché il sovraccarico di ferro può causare danni significativi al cuore [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=22].

Obiettivi della Terapia Chelante

Gli obiettivi principali della terapia chelante del ferro sono:

  • Prevenire o invertire i danni agli organi causati dalla tossicità del ferro.
  • Rimuovere l'eccesso di ferro accumulato nel corpo [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=114].

Per ulteriori informazioni, puoi consultare le fonti:

  • HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf
  • AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf
  • EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf

question: Do we avoid iron in thalassemia patient
answer:
Iron Intake in Thalassaemia Patients

Yes, thalassaemia patients, particularly those with non-transfusion dependent thalassaemia, should avoid foods rich in iron. This is because their bodies absorb significantly more iron from the gut compared to healthy individuals. Foods to avoid include spinach, liver, and certain kinds of beans. Additionally, iron supplements should be avoided unless specifically recommended by a healthcare provider.

For patients who are regularly transfused, the dietary iron intake is less critical because the iron from transfusions far outweighs dietary iron absorption. However, it is still advisable to monitor iron levels closely.

Drinking tea with meals can help reduce iron absorption from food, which can be beneficial for non-transfusion dependent thalassaemia patients. However, this practice is not recommended for young children as it can reduce their intake of essential nutrients found in milk.

It is also recommended to take a multi-vitamin mineral supplement without iron and to consult with a doctor before starting any new supplements.

For more detailed guidance, please refer to the following sources:

  • Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients
  • About Thalassaemia

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question:
Tif thalassemia k leay kya kr raha hy? 
Roman urdu may ans dein
answer:
Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) thalassaemia k mareezon k liye bohat kuch kar raha hai. TIF ka mission hai ke har mulk mein thalassaemia ke liye national control programmes banayein jayein taake is bimari ka behtareen ilaj aur prevention ho sake. TIF ne WHO ke sath mil kar policies promote ki hain jo thalassaemia patients ki health aur quality of life ko behtar banane mein madadgar hain [ngoguideenglish.pdf#page=57][Sickle-cell-disease-booklet_EN-1.pdf#page=9].

TIF ne naye treatment protocols aur therapies, jaise ke gene therapy aur stem cell transplantation, ko promote kiya hai jo ke thalassaemia ke ilaj mein bohat madadgar hain. Yeh therapies patients ko behtar health status aur zindagi ka waada karti hain [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=18].

Agar aap ko mazeed maloomat chahiye, to aap info@thalassaemia.org.cy par raabta kar sakte hain.

question: What does thalassaemia do to the body?
answer:
What Does Thalassaemia Do to the Body?

Thalassaemia is a genetic blood disorder that affects the body's ability to produce hemoglobin, leading to various health issues. The severity and range of symptoms can vary, but common effects include:

  • Severe anaemia, leading to fatigue, pallor, and delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf][NursesGuide_English.pdf]
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face and skull [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf][NursesGuide_English.pdf]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf]
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice) and dark urine [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf]
  • Iron overload due to frequent blood transfusions, causing damage to major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf]
  • Endocrine complications, including delayed puberty, diabetes, and hypothyroidism [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf]
  • Increased risk of cardiovascular disease due to metabolic changes and iron accumulation [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf]

Without proper treatment, thalassaemia can lead to severe complications and even premature death. Regular blood transfusions and iron chelation therapy are essential to manage the condition and prevent iron overload [ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: thalassaemia and arthritis
answer:
Thalassaemia and Arthritis

Thalassaemia is a genetic blood disorder that affects the production of haemoglobin, leading to various health issues. One of the complications that can arise in thalassaemia patients is arthritis.

Connection Between Thalassaemia and Arthritis

Arthritis in thalassaemia patients can be associated with several factors:

  • Infections: Thalassaemia patients are prone to infections due to their compromised immune system. Specific infections, such as those caused by Yersinia enterocolitica, can lead to polyarthritis [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=90].
  • Iron Overload: Frequent blood transfusions in thalassaemia patients can lead to iron overload, which may contribute to joint problems and arthritis [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=61].
  • Septic Arthritis: There have been cases where septic arthritis was the initial manifestation of severe infections in thalassaemia patients, particularly those with iron overload [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=179].

If you need more detailed information or have specific concerns, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: reference centres in thalassaemia
answer:
Reference Centres in Thalassaemia

Reference Centres for thalassaemia are specialized medical facilities that provide comprehensive care for patients with thalassaemia and other haemoglobin disorders. These centres are recognized based on the quality of services and patient-centred care they offer. Below are the key prerequisites and components of a Reference Centre:

Prerequisites for Reference Centres

  • Capacity to provide expert diagnosis of the disease and its long-term complications.
  • Expert case management based on best practice guidelines, including a multidisciplinary approach and psychosocial support.
  • Experienced healthcare personnel in adequate numbers to ensure continuity of care.
  • Structured environment with clearly defined roles and hierarchy for healthcare professionals.
  • Maintain a patient registry to report patient outcomes and other epidemiological information.

[2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=375][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=125]

Quality Standards and Certification

The Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) has initiated a Certification Programme for Reference Centres, focusing on the application of specific quality standards. These standards are based on principles developed by relevant organizations such as the Joint Commission International (JCI) and the European Union Committee of Experts on Rare Diseases (EUCERD).

[TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=125]

Examples of Reference Centres

  • Royal Hospital for Children, Glasgow, UK
  • AOOR Villa Sofia-V. Cervello, Palermo, Italy
  • Boston Children's Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, USA
  • Charité - Universitätsmedizin Berlin, Germany
  • Pediatric Hospital "A. Cao," A.O. "G. Brotzu", Cagliari, Italy
  • George Papanikolaou Hospital, Thessaloniki, Greece

[TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=9]

Additional Information

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact the Thalassaemia International Federation at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, especially if not properly managed. These complications include:

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Thrombophilia and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Iron overload, leading to liver fibrosis, cirrhosis, and heart disease [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58]
  • Delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Endocrine problems such as diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities like arrhythmias and congestive heart failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities including cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Contact for Further Assistance

If you need more information or have specific questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What does it mean if your doctor says I store iron in my macrophage cells?
answer:
Iron Storage in Macrophages

If your doctor says you store iron in your macrophage cells, it means that iron is accumulating in these cells, which are part of your body's immune system. Macrophages play a role in recycling iron from old red blood cells. In conditions like thalassaemia, iron overload can occur due to frequent blood transfusions or increased iron absorption. This excess iron is stored in various tissues, including macrophages.

Iron overload in macrophages can lead to the saturation of transferrin, a protein that normally binds and transports iron in the blood. When transferrin is saturated, non-transferrin bound iron (NTBI) can form, which is harmful and can cause damage to organs and tissues [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=32][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=60].

Iron chelation therapy is often used to manage iron overload. This therapy helps to remove excess iron from the body, primarily by targeting iron released from macrophages and other storage sites [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=32][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=73].

For more detailed information, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: attività fisica e motoria nella thalassemia
answer:
Attività Fisica e Motoria nella Talassemia

Le persone con talassemia possono trarre numerosi benefici dall'attività fisica, nonostante alcune limitazioni. Ecco alcune linee guida e raccomandazioni:

Benefici dell'Attività Fisica

  • Miglioramento della Qualità della Vita: L'attività fisica è stata associata a una migliore qualità della vita, meno dolore, riduzione della ferritina sierica e maggiore densità ossea [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=170][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=163].
  • Salute delle Ossa: Partecipare regolarmente ad attività fisiche, in particolare quelle "weight bearing" come camminare, fare jogging, ballare e saltare, può promuovere la salute delle ossa. Anche le attività "weight-less" come nuoto e ciclismo sono importanti per la salute del cuore [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Tipi di Attività Raccomandate

  • Attività "Weight Bearing": Camminare, fare jogging, ballare e saltare sono particolarmente utili per la salute delle ossa [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Attività "Weight-Less": Nuoto e ciclismo sono importanti per la salute cardiovascolare [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Flessibilità e Forza: Yoga e Pilates migliorano la forza muscolare e l'equilibrio, riducendo il rischio di cadute [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Considerazioni Speciali

  • Consultazione Medica: È fondamentale consultare il proprio ematologo e/o cardiologo prima di iniziare un nuovo regime di esercizi [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=163].
  • Limitazioni: Dolore, anemia, fatica e decondizionamento possono ridurre la capacità di esercizio. È importante considerare questi fattori e adattare l'attività fisica di conseguenza [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=160][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=162].
  • Supporto di Fisioterapisti: I fisioterapisti possono aiutare a tradurre le raccomandazioni mediche in esercizi quotidiani sicuri [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=162].

Se hai bisogno di ulteriori informazioni o assistenza, puoi contattare info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: in beta thalesenia what is the best way to check iron overload
answer:
Best Ways to Check Iron Overload in Beta Thalassemia

Monitoring iron overload in patients with beta thalassemia is crucial for effective management. Here are the recommended methods:

Serum Ferritin

Test Frequency Adequacy
Blood test 1-3 months < 1000 ug/l in TDT < 800 ug/l in NTDT

Serum ferritin is an easily available test and has a reasonable correlation to liver iron concentration (LIC). However, it can be affected by inflammation and other factors [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=176][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=94].

Liver Iron Concentration (LIC)

Test Frequency Adequacy
MRI using validated technique
  • Stable level 3-7 mg iron/g dry weight: 1-2 yearly
  • > 7 mg/g: yearly
  • Rapidly falling or < 3 mg/g: 6 to 12 monthly
 1.8 mg/g dry weight (wt), up to 7 mg/g dry wt

MRI T2* has replaced liver biopsy as the gold standard for LIC quantification because it is non-invasive, rapid, accurate, and reproducible [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=176][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=94].

Myocardial Iron Estimation

Test Frequency Adequacy
MRI T2*
  • From age 10
  • 2 yearly if result > 20 ms on last test
  • Yearly if < 20 ms on last test
  • 6 monthly if < 10 ms on last test
 >20ms

Monitoring of cardiac iron by MRI is critical in all TDT patients with thalassemia [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=176][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=119].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Globin Gene Server database [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=92].

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Hare is bron ali taher
answer:
Professor Ali Taher

Professor Ali T. Taher, MD, PhD, FRCP, is a distinguished medical professional specializing in internal medicine, hematology, and oncology. He holds several prominent positions at the American University of Beirut Medical Center in Beirut, Lebanon, including:

  • Professor of Internal Medicine, Hematology & Oncology
  • Associate Vice President for Academic Centers, Development and External Affairs
  • Director of the Naef K. Basile Cancer Institute

Professor Taher is also a key contributor and editor for various guidelines and publications related to thalassaemia, including the "Guidelines for the Management of Transfusion-Dependent B-Thalassaemia (TDT)" and the "Guidelines for the Management of Non-Transfusion-Dependent B-Thalassaemia (NTDT)" [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=15][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=6].

His work has significantly contributed to the advancements in managing hemoglobin disorders, bringing hope and improved quality of life to patients worldwide [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=6].

For more information, you can contact the Thalassaemia International Federation at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does iron chelation therapy work?
answer:
How Iron Chelation Therapy Works

Iron chelation therapy is essential for managing iron overload in patients with Transfusion-Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT). The therapy involves the use of drugs called iron chelators, which bind to excess iron in the body and facilitate its excretion through urine and/or stools [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=55].

Mechanism of Action

Iron chelators work by forming a compound with iron, which can then be excreted from the body. This process helps to balance the iron intake from blood transfusions with iron excretion, preventing iron accumulation and its associated toxic effects [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=72].

Types of Iron Chelators

There are several iron chelators used in clinical practice:

  • Desferrioxamine (DFO): The first iron chelation drug, introduced in the early 1970s. DFO binds iron to form ferrioxamine, which is then excreted in the urine. It also decreases the toxicity of iron by mopping up free radicals [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=55].
  • Deferiprone (DFP): An oral chelator that binds iron and facilitates its excretion through urine and feces [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=72].
  • Deferasirox (DFX): Another oral chelator that binds iron and promotes its excretion primarily through feces [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=72].

Goals of Chelation Therapy

The primary goals of iron chelation therapy are:

  • Prevention Therapy: To maintain safe levels of body iron by balancing iron intake from transfusions with iron excretion [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=72].
  • Rescue Therapy: To remove excess iron once iron overload has occurred. This involves increasing the rate of iron excretion to exceed the rate of iron accumulation [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=82].

Importance of Continuous Chelation

Continuous exposure to adequate levels of chelator is crucial to prevent iron toxicity. Regular adherence to iron chelation therapy is key to preventing iron toxicity and improving survival. Even short periods of treatment interruption can be damaging [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=72].

Benefits of Chelation Therapy

Chelation therapy is effective in improving survival, decreasing the risk of heart failure, and reducing morbidities associated with transfusional iron overload [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=18].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the side effects of thalidomide?
answer:
Side Effects of Thalidomide

Thalidomide, while used in the treatment of thalassaemia, can have several side effects. These include:

  • Neurological Effects: Thalidomide can cause peripheral neuropathy, which is a condition resulting in damage to the peripheral nerves, leading to symptoms such as numbness, tingling, and pain in the hands and feet [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=97].
  • Gastrointestinal Issues: Patients may experience abdominal disturbances and diarrhoeal symptoms, particularly within the first week of drug administration. These symptoms usually subside and rarely require dose reduction [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].
  • Skin Reactions: About 10% of patients can experience an itchy skin rash, which can be widespread or localized to the palms or soles. This usually appears within the first 15 days of administration and typically subsides without the need to stop or reduce the dose [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].
  • Fever and Cold Symptoms: Periodic fever and common cold symptoms have also been reported [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].
  • Increased Creatinine Levels: In some patients, an increase in creatinine levels, which is closely associated with kidney function, has been observed [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=74].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How can employers better support employees with thalassaemia?
answer:
Supporting Employees with Thalassaemia

Employers can play a significant role in supporting employees with thalassaemia by implementing several strategies to ensure a fair and accommodating work environment.

Prohibit Discrimination

Employers should recognize the right of persons with disabilities to work on an equal basis with others. This includes prohibiting discrimination based on disability and ensuring equal remuneration for work of equal value, as well as providing safe and healthy working conditions [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

Flexible Work Schedules

Adjusting work schedules to accommodate medical appointments can greatly assist employees with thalassaemia. This may include allowing flexible hours or providing the option to work from home when necessary [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

Education and Awareness

Employers should educate themselves and their staff about thalassaemia to reduce stigma and misconceptions. This can be achieved through training sessions and informational materials provided by healthcare teams [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

Psychological Support

Providing access to psychological support can help employees manage the emotional and mental health challenges associated with thalassaemia. This support can include counseling services and support groups [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=120].

Advocacy and Liaison

Thalassaemia care teams should advocate on behalf of their patients, educating the public and potential employers about the abilities of thalassaemia patients. This advocacy can help create a more inclusive and supportive work environment [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.
