question: What are the symptoms of iron overload?
answer:
Symptoms of Iron Overload

Iron overload can cause a variety of symptoms and complications, affecting different organs and systems in the body. Here are some of the key symptoms:

Cardiac Symptoms

  • Disturbed heartbeat (arrhythmia)
  • Impaired relaxation of the heart muscle (diastolic dysfunction)
  • Impaired pumping performance (systolic dysfunction)
  • Accumulation of fluid in the tissues (pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, ascites, peripheral oedema)
  • Cardiac failure, which may occur without any symptoms initially
  • Palpitations, syncopes (fainting), shortness of breath, pain just above the stomach, tiring easily during exercise, swelling around the ankles or other parts of the body [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=80]

Liver Symptoms

  • Fibrosis and cirrhosis of the liver
  • Hepatic inflammation and cell necrosis
  • Elevations in liver enzymes (2-3 times the upper limit of normal)
  • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), palmar erythema, spider naevi [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=23][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58]

Endocrine Symptoms

  • Delayed sexual maturation
  • Hypogonadism
  • Growth retardation [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=23][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=75]

Other Symptoms

  • Bone pain and bone fragility
  • Osteopenia
  • Delayed puberty [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=23]

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Gene therapy
answer:
Gene Therapy for Thalassaemia

Gene therapy aims to provide a cure for thalassaemia by manipulating the genome of haematopoietic stem cells to compensate for the inadequate or faulty function of mutated genes. Here is a detailed overview of the mechanism, types, and current status of gene therapy for thalassaemia:

Mechanism of Gene Therapy

Gene therapy for thalassaemia involves either:

  • Gene Addition: This method involves the semi-random insertion of a healthy copy of the therapeutic gene into the cells using viral vectors. This approach aims to introduce a functional β-globin gene into the patient's haematopoietic stem cells [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=279][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=127].
  • Gene Editing: This method involves a precisely directed mutation that repairs the gene in situ or induces a disease-modifying effect, such as reactivation of fetal haemoglobin (Hb F) synthesis, using site-specific nucleases like CRISPR/Cas9 [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=279][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=127].

Types of Gene Therapy

There are two main forms of gene therapy for thalassaemia:

  • Ex Vivo Gene Therapy: This is a haematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation-based procedure. The patient's own HSCs are mobilised with granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) plus plerixafor, harvested by cytapheresis, CD34+ cell-enriched by immunomagnetic separation, and genetically modified ex vivo. The patient then undergoes myeloablative conditioning followed by infusion of the gene-modified cells [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=279][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=127].
  • In Vivo Gene Therapy: This approach is still experimental and involves correcting the affected gene outside of the body in the laboratory and then replacing it into the patient's blood-forming tissues [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=24].

Current Status and Clinical Trials

Several clinical trials have been conducted to evaluate the safety and efficacy of gene therapy for thalassaemia:

  • Evidence from clinical trials by Bluebird Bio Inc showed that after introducing the "corrected" stem cells in multitransfused β-thalassaemia patients, the majority of patients with the less severe form of the disease (non-βº/βº genotype) became transfusion independent shortly after gene therapy. However, most patients with the more severe form (βº/βº genotype) did not become transfusion independent but had a significant decrease in their annual transfusion requirements [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=5].
  • Ongoing clinical trials are evaluating gene editing approaches, such as CRISPR/Cas9, to reactivate γ-globin expression and correct the imbalance of the α-like/β-like globin chain ratio, which is the main pathophysiological cause of the disease [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=281][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=146].

Benefits and Concerns

Gene therapy offers several benefits over traditional treatments:

  • It uses the patient's own stem cells, thus avoiding complications associated with allogeneic stem cell transplants, such as graft-vs-host disease (GvHD) and the need for long-term immunosuppression [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=2].
  • It has the potential to be available to a larger number of patients, not just those with an HLA-matched donor [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=2].

However, there are still concerns and limitations:

  • Gene therapy is still experimental, and more trials are needed to determine its long-term safety and efficacy [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=2].
  • Current technical difficulties need to be overcome to make gene therapy a viable cure for all patients [

question: What lifestyle changes can help manage thalassemia complications?
answer:
Lifestyle Changes to Manage Thalassemia Complications

Managing thalassemia complications involves several lifestyle changes, including:

Diet

  • Consume small, regular meals spread throughout the day [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43].
  • Choose high-fiber, starchy foods such as wholegrain breads, cereals, beans, peas, lentils, and oats [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43].
  • Include fruits and vegetables in your daily diet [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Use small amounts of fats and oils in cooking, preferring olive oil and rapeseed oil over palm or coconut oil [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Consume no more than 1000 mg of vitamin C per day [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].
  • Hydrate frequently, drinking mostly water and non-sugar sweetened beverages [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].

Exercise

  • Engage in regular physical activity, such as brisk walking, as long as heart checks show it is safe [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Weight Control

  • Maintain a healthy body weight to reduce the risk of cardiovascular complications [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=58].

Smoking Abstinence

  • Avoid smoking to reduce cardiovascular and other health risks [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Management of Comorbid Conditions

  • Regularly monitor and manage conditions such as diabetes, thyroid disease, and liver disease [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=58].
  • Take a vitamin D supplement (1,000 - 2,000 IU/day or 50,000 IU monthly) and have vitamin D levels checked at least annually [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].

For more detailed information, you can contact the Thalassaemia International Federation at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: what is the incidence of thalassemia in the world?
answer:
Global Incidence of Thalassaemia

The global incidence of thalassaemia is significant, with various forms affecting millions of people worldwide. Here are some key statistics:

  • Approximately 42,409 annual B-thalassaemia conceptions globally [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=34].
  • About 68,000 children are born with various thalassaemia syndromes each year [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=9].
  • 23,000 children are born with transfusion-dependent B-thalassaemia major each year [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=9].
  • 5% of the world's population is affected by severe haemoglobin disorders, including thalassaemia [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=132].
  • Approximately 1 million patients are affected by various a-thalassaemia syndromes globally [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=10].
  • 80 to 90 million people are carriers of B-thalassaemia worldwide, which is about 1.5% of the global population [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=9].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the sources provided:

  • PreventionVol1_English.pdf
  • NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf
  • TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf
  • AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf
  • AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf

question: what screening tests are recommend for beta thalassemia minor
answer:
Recommended Screening Tests for Beta Thalassemia Minor

To screen for beta thalassemia minor, the following tests are recommended:

Initial Screening

  • Complete Blood Count (CBC): This test measures the levels of hemoglobin and other parameters related to red blood cells, such as Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV) and Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH). A low MCV (less than 75 fl) may indicate a carrier state [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=138].
  • Hemoglobin A2 Measurement: Elevated levels of hemoglobin A2 (HbA2 ≥ 3.5-4%) are nearly always present in beta thalassemia carriers [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=10].

Confirmatory Tests

  • Hemoglobin Electrophoresis: This test quantitatively measures HbA and HbA2, the main and minor components of adult hemoglobin, respectively [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=138].
  • High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC): This method is used for both screening and confirming the diagnosis of hemoglobin disorders [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=20].
  • Capillary Electrophoresis: Another reference method for screening and confirming hemoglobin disorders [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=20].

Additional Tests

  • Genetic Testing: If initial tests are inconclusive, genetic tests based on DNA examination may be required. Blood samples from family members might be needed for a definite diagnosis [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=20].
  • Iron Studies: Tests such as serum ferritin and Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) to exclude iron deficiency as the cause of red cell abnormalities [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=138].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How is thalassaemia intermedia diagnosed?
answer:
Diagnosis of Thalassaemia Intermedia

Thalassaemia intermedia is diagnosed through a combination of clinical evaluation and laboratory tests. The following methods are commonly used:

Clinical Evaluation

Patients with thalassaemia intermedia may present later in life and are capable of maintaining a haemoglobin level above 6g/dl without transfusion. The clinical phenotype can vary widely, with some patients presenting symptoms between 2 and 6 years of age, while others may not become symptomatic until adulthood [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=60].

Laboratory Tests

  • Haematological Parameters: These include measuring the size and volume of red blood cells and the concentration of haemoglobin inside them. Common findings include low haemoglobin levels, reduced mean corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH), and mean cell volume (MCV) [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=24].
  • Red Blood Cell Morphology: Under a microscope, red blood cells appear paler (hypochromic) and smaller (microcytic) than normal, with abnormal sizes and shapes (anisocytosis and poikilocytosis) [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=25].
  • Haemoglobin Electrophoresis: This process separates the different proteins that make up haemoglobin. Elevated levels of foetal haemoglobin (HbF) and variations in HbA2 levels are indicative of thalassaemia intermedia [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=25].
  • Molecular Methods: DNA technology is used to identify the genetic mutations causing the disorder. This can confirm the diagnosis and provide information on the clinical severity of the disease [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=25].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • Prevention and Diagnosis of Haemoglobinopathies
  • TIF Haemoglobin Disorders
  • TDT 4th Edition

If you have further questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Risks in transplant
answer:
Risks in Bone Marrow Transplantation for Thalassaemia

Bone marrow transplantation (BMT) is a potential cure for thalassaemia, but it carries several risks and potential complications:

Infections and Bleeding

These complications are common during the myeloablation process due to the toxic effects of chemotherapy or irradiation. Research is ongoing to develop milder chemotherapy treatments to reduce these side effects [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=6].

Graft versus Host Disease (GvHD)

GvHD occurs when the donated stem cells attack the patient's own cells, considering them foreign. This can be acute (often lethal) or chronic, severely affecting the patient's quality of life. The risk of GvHD is higher when the donor is not a fully HLA-matched sibling [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=6][TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=7].

Graft Rejection

The patient's body may reject and attack the donated cells, especially if the donor is not fully HLA-matched. Immunosuppressive medications are required to prevent this, but they can lead to other complications such as infections [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=7].

Inadequate Dose of Stem Cells

If the stem cells harvested (e.g., from the umbilical cord) are insufficient, the transplant may fail or result in a mixed population of red cells, some of which are still thalassaemic (chimera) [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=7].

Reduced Fertility

Myeloablation, which involves chemotherapy to destroy the patient's bone marrow, can lead to reduced fertility [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=7].

Long-term Complications

Survivors of HSCT may face long-term complications such as growth issues, fertility problems, and endocrinopathies. These risks are influenced by pre-HSCT health status, therapeutic exposures, and post-transplantation management [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=139].

Iron Overload

Patients may still require iron reduction therapy post-HSCT to prevent complications related to iron overload [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=139].

COVID-19 Risks

Transplanted patients are at higher risk of severe illness from COVID-19 due to their immunosuppressed status, which can lead to prolonged virus shedding and increased transmission risk [Haemoglobin-Disorders_-Blood-COVID-19-1.pdf#page=8].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What treatments are available for thalassaemia?
answer:
Treatments for Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia treatment options vary depending on the type and severity of the condition. Here are the main treatments available:

Blood Transfusions

Regular blood transfusions are essential for patients with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT). These transfusions help maintain adequate haemoglobin levels and are typically required every 2-5 weeks [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

Iron Chelation Therapy

Due to the frequent blood transfusions, iron accumulates in the body, which can be toxic. Iron chelation therapy is used to remove excess iron. There are three main iron chelators:

  • Deferoxamine: Administered via subcutaneous injection [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • Deferiprone: An oral medication [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=23].
  • Deferasirox: Another oral medication [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=23].

Allogeneic Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT)

HSCT is currently the only curative treatment for thalassaemia. It involves replacing the patient's defective bone marrow with healthy donor marrow. This treatment is most effective when performed early, before the onset of organ dysfunction due to iron overload [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=140].

HSCT can be performed using matched sibling donors, unrelated donors, or haploidentical donors, with improved outcomes in recent years [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=140].

Gene Therapy

Gene therapy aims to correct the genetic defects causing thalassaemia by manipulating the genome of haematopoietic stem cells. This approach is still under research but holds promise for a future cure [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=279].

Splenectomy

In some cases, a splenectomy (removal of the spleen) may be necessary, particularly if the spleen becomes enlarged and causes discomfort or if there is an increased need for blood transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Employment and Workplace Challenges for Adults with Thalassaemia

Many adult thalassaemia patients are employed without difficulty. However, several challenges can affect their employment and workplace experience:

  • Self-Esteem and Health Perception: Some patients may have low self-esteem and feel that their 'poor health' does not allow them to work effectively. This can be due to inadequate psychosocial support [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Discrimination: Thalassaemia can be viewed as an 'immigrant disease' in some countries, potentially leading to racial and ethnic issues. This requires educational interventions to address [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Employment Statistics: In a survey of over 300 patients over 20 years of age, half were fully employed, 19% were working part-time, and 31% were unemployed. These figures exceed national unemployment statistics, although 14% of those unemployed were so by choice [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Workplace Adjustments: Interruptions for clinic and transfusion appointments, often scheduled during daytime working hours, can be a limiting factor. Adjusting these services to include evening and weekend sessions can greatly assist patients in maintaining full-time employment [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Mental Health: A considerable proportion of adult patients show evidence of depression and anxiety, which can impact their work life. This is more pronounced in patients with ß-thalassaemia intermedia [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=112].

To support thalassaemia patients in the workplace, it is crucial for healthcare teams to advocate on their behalf, educate potential employers, and instill a positive attitude in patients regarding their ability to work [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the side effects of luspatercept?
answer:
Side Effects of Luspatercept

Luspatercept, used for the treatment of β-thalassemia, has several reported side effects. These side effects vary in frequency and severity, and some may lead to treatment discontinuation.

Common Side Effects

  • Headache: Reported in 26% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138].
  • Bone Pain: Reported in 19.7% of patients, most common in the first 3 months [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].
  • Arthralgia (Joint Pain): Reported in 19.3% of patients [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=303].
  • Fatigue: Reported in 14% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138].
  • Cough: Reported in 14% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138].
  • Abdominal Pain: Reported in 14% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138].
  • Diarrhea: Reported in 12% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138].
  • Dizziness: Reported in 11% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138].

Less Common Side Effects

  • Hypertension: Reported in 8.1% of patients, with an average increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure of 5 mmHg [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=303].
  • Hypersensitivity Reactions: Including eyelid edema, drug hypersensitivity, swelling face, periorbital edema, face edema, angioedema, lip swelling, and drug eruption, reported in 4.5% of patients [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=304][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=139].
  • Injection Site Reactions: Including erythema, pruritus, swelling, and rash, reported in 2.2% of patients [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=304][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=139].
  • Thromboembolic Events: Including deep vein thrombosis, portal vein thrombosis, ischemic stroke, and pulmonary embolism, reported in 3.6% of patients [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=304][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=139].

Serious Adverse Events

  • Serious adverse events were reported in 12% of patients in the luspatercept group compared to 25% in the placebo group [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How can genetic counseling help couples at risk of having a child with thalassemia?
answer:
How Genetic Counseling Can Help Couples at Risk of Having a Child with Thalassemia

Genetic counseling plays a crucial role for couples at risk of having a child with thalassemia. Here are some ways in which genetic counseling can help:

  • Identification and Education: Genetic counselors help identify individuals and families at risk for thalassemia and provide education about the condition, including its prognosis, management, and recurrence risks [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=160].
  • Clarifying Reproductive Options: Counselors assist families in understanding their reproductive options, including the possibility of prenatal diagnosis and preimplantation genetic diagnosis to select unaffected offspring [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=68].
  • Support in Decision-Making: Genetic counselors provide information to help couples make informed decisions about pregnancy, including the risks and benefits of different prenatal tests and the implications of test results [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=121][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=77].
  • Long-Term Support: Genetic counselors offer ongoing support and can connect families with regional experts, such as hematologists, to ensure comprehensive care and access to necessary resources [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=161][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) guidelines.

If you have further questions or need personalized advice, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Thalassaemia and Employment Challenges

Many adult thalassaemia patients are employed without difficulty. However, there are several challenges that they may face in the workplace:

  • Low self-esteem and the belief that 'poor health' prevents them from working, often due to inadequate psychosocial support [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Discrimination based on disability, which requires advocacy and education by the thalassaemia care team to ensure equal opportunities and safe working conditions [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Interruptions in work or education due to the need for regular clinic and transfusion appointments, which are typically scheduled during daytime working hours [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • High levels of anxiety and depression, which can affect job performance and overall quality of life [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=112].

Despite these challenges, with appropriate treatment and support, many patients can achieve their career goals and lead fulfilling lives [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=125].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins, which are essential components of hemoglobin. There are two main types of thalassaemia based on the affected globin chain: α-thalassaemia and β-thalassaemia.

β-Thalassaemia

β-thalassaemia occurs when mutations affect the production of the β-globin protein. More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, leading to a wide range of phenotypic severity, from silent to very severe forms. The severity of β-thalassaemia can be influenced by several factors:

  • Homozygous β-thalassaemia: Patients with two severe β-thalassaemia alleles typically present with thalassaemia major, requiring regular blood transfusions to survive. However, the co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or gene modifiers that increase HbF production can ameliorate the condition to thalassaemia intermedia, which may require less frequent transfusions or none at all [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Mild β-thalassaemia mutations: Some mutations, such as the β+-type mutation -88 (C->T), generally result in a very mild clinical phenotype. However, other mild mutations like Cap+1 (A->C) can still result in thalassaemia major in some homozygous patients [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Compound heterozygosity: The combination of a severe β-thalassaemia mutation with a mild mutation or other genetic factors, such as α-thalassaemia trait or Hb Lepore trait, can result in thalassaemia intermedia. Additionally, the presence of the Xmn1 polymorphism can elevate HbF levels, leading to a milder phenotype [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=61].

α-Thalassaemia

α-thalassaemia occurs when one or more genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated. The severity of α-thalassaemia depends on the number of affected α-globin genes:

  • Loss of one α-globin gene: This has a minimal effect and patients are more likely to have thalassaemia major, although the onset of blood transfusion requirement may be delayed [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Loss of two α-globin genes: Patients are much more likely to have thalassaemia intermedia [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].

Overall, the genetic interactions leading to thalassaemia are complex and can result in a broad spectrum of clinical severity. Accurate genetic diagnosis and counselling are essential for managing the condition effectively [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=64].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the symptoms of alloimmunisation?
answer:
Symptoms of Alloimmunisation in Thalassaemia Patients

Alloimmunisation is a common complication in transfusion-dependent thalassaemia patients, occurring in 10-20% of cases. Here are the key symptoms and related complications:

Delayed Transfusion Reactions

These reactions usually occur within 5-14 days after a transfusion and are characterized by:

  • Unexpected levels of anaemia
  • Malaise
  • Jaundice

These symptoms are typically caused by an alloantibody that was not detectable at the time of transfusion or by the development of a new antibody [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=9][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=49][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=29].

Autoimmune Haemolytic Anaemia

This is a serious complication that can occur in patients with alloantibodies. Symptoms include:

  • Severe anaemia
  • Jaundice
  • Fatigue

Management may involve steroids, immunosuppressive drugs, intravenous immunoglobulin, and rituximab [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=9][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=29].

General Symptoms of Alloimmune Reactions

Other symptoms that may be observed include:

  • Mild fever
  • Chills
  • Moderate jaundice
  • Unexplained decreases in haemoglobin (Hb) values

These symptoms can develop days or weeks after the transfusion [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=47].

Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

TRALI is another serious complication caused by specific anti-neutrophil or anti-HLA antibodies. Symptoms include:

  • Dyspnoea (difficulty breathing)
  • Tachycardia (rapid heart rate)
  • Fever
  • Hypotension (low blood pressure)
  • Hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels) with bilateral infiltrates typical of pulmonary oedema

These symptoms can occur during or within six hours of transfusion [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=9].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Symptoms

  • Severe anaemia
  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

Common Complications

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, often due to iron overload from repeated blood transfusions:

  • Endocrine problems: delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities: pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, congestive heart failure, pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities: cirrhosis, liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Bone deformities and fractures [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Severe anaemia and growth failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=38]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins, which are essential components of hemoglobin. There are two main types of thalassaemia based on the affected globin chain: α-thalassaemia and β-thalassaemia.

β-Thalassaemia

β-thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the HBB gene, which encodes the β-globin protein. Over 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been identified, leading to a wide range of phenotypic severities, from mild to very severe forms of the disease [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].

Severity of β-Thalassaemia

  • Thalassaemia Major: Patients with severe β-thalassaemia mutations often require regular blood transfusions to survive. This condition is characterized by severe, life-threatening anemia [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Thalassaemia Intermedia: This form can result from a combination of mild and severe mutations or the co-inheritance of other genetic factors that ameliorate the condition. Patients may require occasional or no transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=61].

Genetic Modifiers

The severity of β-thalassaemia can be influenced by several genetic factors:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia: The presence of α-thalassaemia can reduce the imbalance between α- and β-globin chains, leading to a milder phenotype [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].
  • Increased HbF Production: Genetic determinants that increase the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) can ameliorate the severity of β-thalassaemia [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101][Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=61].

α-Thalassaemia

α-thalassaemia occurs when there are mutations or deletions in the genes responsible for α-globin production. The severity of α-thalassaemia depends on the number of affected α-globin genes [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].

Severity of α-Thalassaemia

  • Silent Carrier: Loss of one α-globin gene usually has minimal clinical impact.
  • α-Thalassaemia Trait: Loss of two α-globin genes can cause mild anemia.
  • Hemoglobin H Disease: Loss of three α-globin genes leads to moderate to severe anemia.
  • Hydrops Fetalis: Loss of all four α-globin genes is usually fatal before or shortly after birth.

For more detailed information or specific genetic counseling, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Wird thalassämie immer noch cooley amämie genannt
answer:
Cooley's Anämie und Thalassämie

Ja, Thalassämie wird immer noch manchmal als Cooley's Anämie bezeichnet. Diese Bezeichnung stammt von Dr. Thomas Benton Cooley, einem amerikanischen Kinderarzt, der die Krankheit erstmals 1925 beschrieb. Cooley's Anämie ist ein anderer Name für die Bedingung, die als ß-Thalassämie oder Thalassämie major bekannt ist.

Die Krankheit wird auch als Mittelmeeranämie bezeichnet, da sie ursprünglich in Ländern rund um das Mittelmeer verbreitet war. Heute ist bekannt, dass Thalassämie-Syndrome weltweit vorkommen, insbesondere in Regionen, in denen Malaria endemisch ist oder war.

Weitere Informationen finden Sie in den folgenden Quellen:

  • Thalassaemia from A to Z: A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia [Thalassaemia from A to Z_A comprehensive e-glossary for thalassaemia.pdf#page=6]
  • TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=55]
  • AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=21]

Für weitere Fragen können Sie sich an info@thalassaemia.org.cy wenden.

question: Könntest du mir die Symptome der thalassämia major noch mak genauer erklären?
answer:
Symptome der Thalassämia Major

Thalassämia Major ist die schwerste Form der Thalassämie und tritt auf, wenn ein Kind zwei mutierte Gene erbt, eines von jedem Elternteil. Die Symptome beginnen normalerweise innerhalb des ersten Lebensjahres und ohne regelmäßige Behandlung kann die Krankheit lebensbedrohlich sein. Hier sind die wichtigsten Symptome und deren Ursachen:

Frühe Symptome

  • Schwere mikrozytäre Anämie: Die roten Blutkörperchen sind kleiner als normal und enthalten weniger Hämoglobin, was zu einer verminderten Sauerstoffversorgung des Körpers führt [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=25].
  • Leichte Gelbsucht: Gelbfärbung der Haut und Augen aufgrund des schnellen Abbaus der roten Blutkörperchen [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=25].
  • Hepatosplenomegalie: Vergrößerung von Leber und Milz aufgrund der erhöhten Belastung durch den Abbau der defekten roten Blutkörperchen [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=25].
  • Wachstumsverzögerung: Betroffene Kinder wachsen langsamer und entwickeln sich nicht altersgerecht [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • Ernährungsprobleme und Reizbarkeit: Schwierigkeiten beim Füttern und häufige Reizbarkeit aufgrund des allgemeinen Unwohlseins [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=25].
  • Wiederkehrende Fieberanfälle: Aufgrund eines hypermetabolischen Zustands oder interkurrenter Infektionen [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=25].

Spätere Symptome

  • Verzögerte körperliche Entwicklung: Kinder bleiben in ihrer körperlichen Entwicklung zurück [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • Übermäßige Müdigkeit und Erschöpfung: Aufgrund der chronischen Anämie [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • Dunkler Urin: Aufgrund des Abbaus von Hämoglobin [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • Knochenverformungen, besonders im Gesicht: Aufgrund der Knochenmarkexpansion, die versucht, die Produktion der roten Blutkörperchen zu kompensieren [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=196].
  • Vergrößerte Milz, Leber oder Herz: Diese Organe arbeiten härter, um die defekten roten Blutkörperchen zu verarbeiten [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Langfristige Komplikationen

  • Herzinsuffizienz: Aufgrund der chronischen Anämie und Eisenüberladung durch häufige Bluttransfusionen [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=102].
  • Diabetes: Aufgrund der Eisenablagerung in der Bauchspeicheldrüse [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=102].
  • Osteoporose und pathologische Frakturen: Aufgrund der Knochenmarkexpansion und Eisenüberladung [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=102].
  • Hormonelle Störungen: Betroffen sind die Hypophyse, die Schilddrüse und die Nebenschilddrüsen, was zu Wachstumsstörungen und anderen hormonellen Problemen führt [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=102].

Für weitere Informationen oder spezifische Fragen können Sie sich gerne an info@thalassaemia.org.cy wenden.

question: ما هى الثلاثيميا المتوسطة و ما هى طرق علاجها
answer:
الثلاسيميا المتوسطة و طرق علاجها

ما هي الثلاسيميا المتوسطة؟

الثلاسيميا المتوسطة هي نوع من أنواع الثلاسيميا التي تتراوح شدتها بين الخفيفة والشديدة. قد يعاني المرضى من أعراض خفيفة مثل شحوب طفيف وتضخم طفيف في الطحال، أو قد تكون الأعراض أكثر شدة وتشمل التعب، شحوب البشرة، تشوهات العظام، والكسور.

بعض المرضى قد لا يظهرون أعراضًا كبيرة وقد يظلون غير مشخصين لفترة طويلة، بينما قد يحتاج آخرون إلى نقل دم منتظم في مراحل لاحقة من الحياة بسبب مضاعفات مثل ضعف العظام، التخثر، وارتفاع ضغط الدم الرئوي.

[NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]

طرق علاج الثلاسيميا المتوسطة

  • نقل الدم: قد يحتاج المرضى إلى نقل دم متقطع بناءً على مستوى الحديد في الجسم. نقل الدم يساعد في تخفيف فقر الدم ومنع تضخم الكبد والطحال ومنع مضاعفات أخرى مثل العدوى وتشوهات العظام. [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=44]
  • العلاج بالاستخلاب الحديدي: يستخدم لعلاج زيادة الحديد في الجسم الناتجة عن نقل الدم أو الامتصاص الزائد للحديد من الأمعاء. يمكن استخدام دواء ديسفيريوكسامين (Desferrioxamine) كعلاج بالاستخلاب الحديدي. [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=107]
  • استئصال الطحال: قد يكون ضروريًا في حالات تضخم الطحال الكبير أو زيادة متطلبات نقل الدم أو أعراض تضخم الطحال. [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • تجنب الأطعمة الغنية بالحديد: ينصح المرضى بتجنب الأطعمة الغنية بالحديد مثل السبانخ والكبد وبعض أنواع الفاصوليا، وشرب الشاي الأسود مع الوجبات لتقليل امتصاص الحديد. [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=107]

للمزيد من المعلومات، يمكن زيارة موقع Thalassaemia International Federation.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Thrombophilia and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Iron overload causing damage to major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice) [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Dark urine [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Endocrine problems such as delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities such as pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, congestive heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities such as cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: my serum feritin is 3700 microgram per liter. cardiac mri t2* is 27. should i start desferal? I am pregnant
answer:
Desferal (Deferoxamine) Use During Pregnancy

Given your serum ferritin level of 3700 µg/L and a cardiac MRI T2* of 27 ms, it is important to consider the following:

  • For patients without significant myocardial iron loading (cardiac MRI T2* >20 ms) and a normal echocardiogram, cardiac assessment should be conducted early in the third trimester to develop a delivery plan and chelation therapy if needed [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=236].
  • Desferal (Deferoxamine) is the only chelation agent with an established safety profile for use in the second and third trimesters. Over three decades, studies on more than 45 pregnancies in iron-overloaded patients receiving Desferal have shown no adverse effects on the fetus or neonate [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=236].
  • Iron chelation therapy during pregnancy must be approached with caution, particularly in the first trimester, due to the lack of comprehensive safety data [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=236].

It is essential to consult with your healthcare provider to determine the best course of action based on your specific medical condition and iron load.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Regarding thalassemia,  what kind of information could you provide?
answer:
Information on Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia is a group of inherited blood disorders characterized by decreased production of haemoglobin, the protein that carries oxygen in red blood cells. There are two main types of thalassaemia: alpha (α-) and beta (β-). The severity of the condition can vary, and it is commonly classified into three categories:

  • Thalassaemia minor: Individuals are generally healthy and may have mild anaemia but typically do not require medical treatment.
  • Thalassaemia intermedia: Patients may occasionally need blood transfusions, especially during infections or pregnancy.
  • Thalassaemia major: The most severe form, requiring regular blood transfusions and iron chelation therapy to manage iron overload from transfusions [ThalCarrierCheck_EN_Final_end.pdf#page=1][TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

Thalassaemia major, also known as β-thalassaemia, is a severe disorder requiring lifelong blood transfusions and iron chelation therapy. Without appropriate care, patients can experience many complications, a poor quality of life, and early death. However, with proper treatment, patients can enjoy a very good quality of life and a life expectancy close to that of the general population [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=125][HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website or contact us at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: آیا درمان‌های جدیدی برای تالاسمی وجود دارد؟
answer:
درمان‌های جدید برای تالاسمی

در سال‌های اخیر، چندین درمان نوین برای تالاسمی معرفی شده‌اند که شامل موارد زیر می‌شوند:

لوسپاترسپت (Luspatercept-aamt)

لوسپاترسپت یک عامل بلوغ اریتروئیدی است که در مراحل پایانی بلوغ سلول‌های قرمز خون عمل می‌کند. این دارو باعث افزایش طول عمر سلول‌های قرمز خون تولید شده توسط بیماران تالاسمی می‌شود و به آنها اجازه می‌دهد تا به جای تخریب زودرس، بالغ شوند. این امر باعث افزایش سطح هموگلوبین و کاهش نیاز به تزریق خون می‌شود، که در نتیجه بار آهن و نیاز به شلاتورهای آهن کاهش می‌یابد و کیفیت زندگی بیماران بهبود می‌یابد [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1].

درمان ژنی

درمان ژنی به عنوان یک روش درمانی نویدبخش برای تالاسمی مطرح شده است. این روش شامل اصلاح ژن‌های معیوب در خارج از بدن و سپس جایگزینی آنها در بافت‌های خون‌ساز بیمار است. این روش می‌تواند به تولید سلول‌های قرمز خون جدید با هموگلوبین طبیعی کمک کند. یکی از محصولات درمان ژنی که توسط کمیسیون اروپا تأیید شده است، Zynteglo® است که برای بیماران مبتلا به تالاسمی وابسته به تزریق خون که واجد شرایط پیوند سلول‌های بنیادی هستند اما دهنده مناسب ندارند، استفاده می‌شود [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=286][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=128].

پیوند سلول‌های بنیادی هماتوپوئتیک (HSCT)

پیوند سلول‌های بنیادی هماتوپوئتیک (HSCT) همچنان به عنوان یک روش درمانی مؤثر برای تالاسمی مطرح است. این روش شامل استفاده از سلول‌های بنیادی از یک دهنده مناسب برای جایگزینی سلول‌های خون‌ساز بیمار است. این روش به ویژه برای بیماران جوان با دهنده‌های مناسب HLA توصیه می‌شود [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=3].

داروهای افزایش‌دهنده هموگلوبین جنینی (HbF)

دانشمندان در حال بررسی داروهایی هستند که می‌توانند تولید هموگلوبین جنینی (HbF) را افزایش دهند. این داروها شامل هیدروکسی‌اوره و اریتروپویتین هستند که می‌توانند به کاهش عدم تعادل زنجیره‌های گلوبین کمک کنند. این داروها به ویژه برای بیماران مبتلا به تالاسمی اینترمدیا مفید بوده‌اند [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=119].

برای اطلاعات بیشتر می‌توانید به info@thalassaemia.org.cy ایمیل بزنید.

question: What is HbE/beta0thalassemia
answer:
HbE/Beta0-Thalassemia

HbE/beta0-thalassemia is a genetic disorder resulting from the inheritance of one gene for hemoglobin E (HbE) and one gene for beta0-thalassemia. This condition is particularly common in Southeast Asian populations.

Pathophysiology

Hemoglobin E (HbE) is a structural variant of hemoglobin that is produced in reduced amounts. Beta0-thalassemia is characterized by the absence of beta-globin chain production. The combination of these two genetic abnormalities leads to a significant imbalance in globin chain synthesis, resulting in severe anemia and other complications [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=17].

Clinical Features

The clinical severity of HbE/beta0-thalassemia can vary widely, ranging from mild anemia to severe, transfusion-dependent anemia. Symptoms may include jaundice, gallstones, and hepatosplenomegaly. The variability in clinical presentation is influenced by genetic and possibly environmental factors [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=31][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=18].

Management

Management of HbE/beta0-thalassemia typically involves regular monitoring, blood transfusions, and other supportive treatments to manage anemia and prevent complications. Genetic counseling may also be recommended for affected families [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=14].

For more detailed information or specific medical advice, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How does thalassaemia affect employment and workplace challenges for adults?
answer:
Employment and Workplace Challenges for Adults with Thalassaemia

Many adult thalassaemia patients are employed without difficulty. However, there are several challenges that they may face in the workplace:

  • Self-Esteem and Health Perception: Some patients may have low self-esteem and feel that their health does not allow them to work effectively. This can be due to inadequate psychosocial support [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Employment Statistics: In a survey of over 300 patients aged over 20, half were fully employed, 19% were working part-time, and 31% were unemployed. These figures are higher than national unemployment statistics, although 14% of those unemployed were so by choice [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Discrimination and Advocacy: Patients may face discrimination based on their condition. The thalassaemia care team has a duty to advocate for their patients, educating the public and potential employers about the abilities of thalassaemia patients and ensuring equal opportunities [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Medical Appointments: The need to attend clinic and transfusion appointments during daytime working hours can disrupt education and employment. Adjusting these services to include evening and weekend sessions can help patients maintain their social integration and contribution to society [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

Overall, with appropriate support and adjustments, many thalassaemia patients can achieve their employment goals and contribute effectively in the workplace.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What is the iron chelator for 1y an 3 months old child
answer:
Iron Chelator for a 1 Year and 3 Months Old Child

For a child aged 1 year and 3 months, the use of iron chelators is generally approached with caution due to concerns about the effects on cognitive development and organ immaturity. Here are the key points regarding iron chelation for young children:

  • Iron chelation is rarely started before 2 years of age due to concerns about cognitive development and organ immaturity [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=120].
  • Deferasirox (Exjade) is approved for use by children over 2 years of age by the EMA and over 6 years of age by the FDA [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=67].
  • Deferiprone and Deferasirox are both oral iron chelators, while Desferrioxamine is administered via injection [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • For children under 2 years, deferasirox can be started at a low dose (3 to 5 mg/kg) and increased gradually, but aggressive chelation is not recommended [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=64].

Given the age of the child, it is advisable to consult with a healthcare professional to determine the appropriate course of action. For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: ما هي مخاطر العلاج الجيني لمرضى الثلاسيميا الكبرى بيتا؟
answer:
مخاطر العلاج الجيني لمرضى الثلاسيميا الكبرى بيتا

المخاطر المحتملة والمخاوف

  • الطفرات الإدخالية: العلاج الجيني عن طريق إضافة الجينات يحمل خطرًا منخفضًا ولكنه موجود للطفرات الإدخالية، حيث يمكن أن يؤدي إدخال الجين العلاجي إلى تعطيل جينات أخرى هامة، مما يؤدي إلى عواقب غير مقصودة مثل السرطان [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=283].
  • التأثيرات غير المستهدفة: تقنيات تحرير الجينات مثل CRISPR/Cas9 لديها القدرة على التسبب في كسور مزدوجة في الحمض النووي في مواقع غير مقصودة، مما قد يؤدي إلى طفرات ضارة [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=283].
  • خطر الأورام: المرضى الذين يخضعون للعلاج الجيني قد يكونون في خطر متزايد لتطوير الأورام بسبب عوامل مثل الخلفية المرضية، نقص الأكسجين المزمن، الالتهاب، والطفرات المرتبطة بالعلاج [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=283].
  • تأثير محدود على الإنجاب: العلاج الجيني يعالج فقط نظام إنتاج الدم لدى المريض ولا يؤثر على نظام الإنجاب. هذا يعني أن المرضى الذين يتم علاجهم بالعلاج الجيني يمكنهم نقل الاضطراب الجيني إلى أطفالهم [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=2].
  • السلامة على المدى الطويل: لا تزال السلامة على المدى الطويل للعلاج الجيني قيد التقييم. يحتاج المرضى إلى مراقبة لمدة لا تقل عن 15 عامًا لتقييم استدامة الفوائد السريرية وتحديد أي آثار جانبية طويلة الأمد [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=283].

لمزيد من المعلومات التفصيلية، يمكنك زيارة موقع الاتحاد الدولي للثلاسيميا.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

For thalassaemia major, complications due to iron overload from repeated blood transfusions can include:

  • Heart disease (heart failure, arrhythmias, myocarditis)
  • Liver complications (fibrosis, cirrhosis, liver failure, hepatocellular carcinoma)
  • Endocrine problems (delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, osteoporosis) [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For thalassaemia intermedia, complications can include:

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures
  • Thrombophilia
  • Pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Symptoms

  • Severe anaemia
  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

Common Complications

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, primarily due to iron overload from repeated blood transfusions. These complications include:

  • Endocrine problems: delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities: pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, congestive heart failure, pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities: cirrhosis, liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Chronic anaemia: poor vitality and growth [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Expansion of haemopoietic tissue: deformities and pressure effects [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Infections [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Complications of blood transfusions: iron overload, immune reactions, infections [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: In USG Report a slight problem related to Renal System. How this will be solved
answer:
Management of Renal System Issues in Thalassaemia

If your USG report indicates a slight problem related to the renal system, it is important to follow a comprehensive care plan. Here are some steps that can be taken:

Comprehensive Care

  • Encourage clinical care management from a team of specialists: urologist, nephrologist, endocrinologist, and dietitian [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=57].

Specific Treatments

Condition Guidance
Hypercalciuria Low salt diet, protein restriction (adults only), and consider a thiazide diuretic. In adults with hypercalciuria and osteoporosis, bisphosphonate therapy may be considered [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=57].
Hyperuricosuria Dietary purine restriction, increased fluid intake, urine alkalinisation, improve transfusion regimen if evidence of increased ineffective erythropoiesis, and consider allopurinol [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=57].
Hypocitraturia Potassium citrate [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=57].

Hydration

  • Maintain urine output greater than 2-2.5 L/day [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=57].

Additional Considerations

  • Monitor adverse effects of chelators on zinc, phosphate, and calcium excretion [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=56].
  • Encourage adequate hydration, especially if there is a history of nephrolithiasis [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=56].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: are there spesific markers used to monitor platelet activation in TDT patients?
answer:
Markers for Monitoring Platelet Activation in TDT Patients

In transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) patients, specific markers are used to monitor platelet activation:

  • CD62P (P-selectin): This marker is expressed on the surface of activated platelets and is used to indicate in vivo platelet activation [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=61][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=66].
  • CD63: Another marker of platelet activation, CD63 is also expressed on the surface of activated platelets [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=61][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=66].
  • Prostacyclin (PG I2) and Thromboxane A2 Metabolites: These are markers of haemostatic activity and are found at higher levels in TDT patients compared to healthy individuals [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=61][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=66].

These markers help in assessing the extent of platelet activation and the associated risk of thrombotic events in TDT patients.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How often should thalassemia patients with diabetes visit their healthcare provider?
answer:
Frequency of Healthcare Visits for Thalassemia Patients with Diabetes

Thalassemia patients with diabetes should have regular follow-ups with their healthcare provider. The Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) guidelines recommend:

  • Monthly assessment of serum fructosamine concentrations.
  • Regular reviews in a specialist diabetic clinic.

These frequent visits help in closely monitoring and managing the condition to prevent complications.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Thalassaemia International Federation or contact them at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Source: TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0)

question: Help center in india
answer:
Thalassaemia Help Centers in India

There are several organizations and centers in India dedicated to the treatment and management of thalassaemia. Here are some notable ones:

  • Thalassaemics India - New Delhi
  • National Thalassaemia Welfare Society - India
  • Bai Jerbai Wadia Hospital for Children - Mumbai, which has a thalassaemia control programme established in collaboration with the Perinatal Haemoglobinopathy Genetics Centre of University College Hospital, London [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=76]
  • Zoho Corporation, Tenkasi, Tamil Nadu, which is involved in comprehensive thalassaemia care [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=338]

These organizations and centers provide various services, including blood transfusions, iron chelation therapy, genetic counseling, and bone marrow transplantation. For more detailed information, you can visit their respective websites or contact them directly.

For further assistance, you can also reach out to the Thalassaemia International Federation or contact them at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: please dont include hb e beta thalassemia in your anewer. I am only asking about hb e disease particularly
answer:
Treatment and Management of Hemoglobin E Disease

The treatment and management of Hemoglobin E disease focus on managing symptoms and preventing complications. Here are the key aspects:

Blood Transfusions

Regular blood transfusions should be considered if there is declining baseline hemoglobin, rapid enlargement of the spleen, failure of growth or secondary sexual development, signs of bone changes, poor quality of life, and frequent hemolytic crises. During hemolytic episodes, red cell transfusion should be provided to restore hemoglobin levels to 80-90 g/L [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=168].

Iron Chelation Therapy

Iron overload is a common complication due to increased intestinal iron absorption and frequent blood transfusions. Iron chelation therapy is essential to prevent or reduce excess iron deposits in the body [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=39].

Management of Extramedullary Hematopoiesis (EMH)

EMH can occur in various locations, including the spleen, liver, and lymph nodes. Treatment options for EMH include hypertransfusion, radiation therapy, surgery, and hydroxyurea. Hypertransfusion is the preferred treatment, and radiotherapy has been shown to be effective due to the radiosensitivity of EMH masses [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=39].

Folic Acid Supplementation

Patients with Hemoglobin E disease should receive folic acid supplementation at a dose of 1-5 mg/day to support erythropoietic activity [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=168].

Vaccinations and Infection Management

Complete immunization against vaccine-preventable diseases, prompt treatment of fever and infections, and routine vaccinations against common infections such as influenza, pneumococcus, and SARS-CoV-2 are strongly recommended [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=38].

Monitoring and Support

Regular monitoring of hemoglobin levels, growth, and development is essential. Psychosocial support may be required, and patients should be monitored for complications of chronic transfusion and given iron chelation support as needed [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=169].

Additional Information

For further assistance or more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

  • What are the potential side effects of iron chelation therapy?
  • How often should patients with Hemoglobin E disease undergo monitoring?
  • Are there any dietary recommendations for patients with Hemoglobin E disease?

question: What types of exercises are recommended for thalassaemia patients?
answer:
Recommended Exercises for Thalassaemia Patients

Thalassaemia patients can benefit from various types of exercises. Here are some recommended activities:

Weight-Bearing Activities

Weight-bearing exercises are particularly beneficial for bone health. These include:

  • Walking
  • Jogging
  • Dancing
  • Jumping [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23]

Weight-Less Activities

While less beneficial for bone health, weight-less activities are important for cardiovascular health. These include:

  • Swimming
  • Biking [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23]

Flexibility and Balance Exercises

Exercises that improve flexibility and balance can reduce the risk of falls and improve muscle strength. These include:

  • Yoga
  • Pilates [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23]

General Recommendations

Before starting any exercise regimen, it is important for thalassaemia patients to consult with their haematologist and cardiologist. This ensures that the chosen activities are safe and appropriate for their individual health status [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=163].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the treatment options for thalassaemia?
answer:
Treatment Options for Thalassaemia

Conventional Treatments

  • Blood Transfusions: Regular blood transfusions are essential for patients with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) to maintain hemoglobin levels. These are typically required every 2-5 weeks [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf][HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf].
  • Iron Chelation Therapy: To manage iron overload resulting from frequent blood transfusions, patients must undergo iron chelation therapy. This involves taking medications to remove excess iron from the body, which can be administered orally or via injection [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf][NursesGuide_English.pdf].
  • Splenectomy: In some cases, removal of the spleen may be necessary, particularly if the spleen becomes enlarged and causes discomfort or other complications [NursesGuide_English.pdf].

Curative Treatments

  • Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT): This is currently the only available curative option for patients with transfusion-dependent thalassaemia. It involves replacing the patient's defective blood-forming stem cells with healthy ones from a compatible donor [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf].
  • Gene Therapy: Gene therapy, such as with Zynteglo®, aims to correct the genetic defect causing thalassaemia. This treatment is available for young patients and adults without severe comorbidities [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf].

Novel Therapies

  • Luspatercept-aamt: This erythroid maturation agent helps prolong the lifespan of red blood cells in thalassaemia patients, reducing the need for frequent transfusions and helping manage iron overload [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Follow-up Questions

question: Makanan apa yang harus dihindari penderita thalassemia
answer:
Makanan yang Harus Dihindari Penderita Thalassemia

Penderita thalassemia disarankan untuk menghindari makanan yang kaya akan zat besi. Berikut adalah beberapa jenis makanan yang sebaiknya dihindari:

  • Bayam
  • Hati
  • Beberapa jenis kacang-kacangan seperti kacang merah

Selain itu, ada beberapa makanan dan minuman lain yang juga sebaiknya dibatasi atau dihindari:

  • Makanan yang digoreng atau berlemak tinggi seperti mentega, lemak babi, minyak kelapa sawit merah, pastry, keju, keripik, mayones, dan kue
  • Makanan yang mengandung karbohidrat tinggi seperti kentang, roti, nasi, dan pasta dalam porsi besar
  • Minuman beralkohol dan minuman energi
  • Diet ketogenik dan diet protein cair

Untuk informasi lebih lanjut, Anda dapat menghubungi info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Is there an Age limit for gene therapy in thalassemia?
answer:
Age Limit for Gene Therapy in Thalassaemia

Gene therapy for thalassaemia, specifically using the Zynteglo® product, has specific age-related eligibility criteria:

  • Young patients (12 to 17 years old) with a β+ genotype who do not have an HLA-compatible sibling donor are eligible for gene therapy with Zynteglo® [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=128][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=286].
  • Patients aged 17 to 55 years with a β+ genotype who do not have severe comorbidities and are at risk or ineligible to undergo an allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplant can also be considered for gene therapy with Zynteglo® [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=129][TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=286].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the Guidelines for the Management of Transfusion Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT).

question: please summarize the screenig achievements of thalassaemia screening in thailand
answer:
Thalassaemia Screening Achievements in Thailand

Thailand has made significant strides in the screening and management of thalassaemia. Key achievements include:

  • Improved survival rates for transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (TDT) patients, with survival estimates approaching those of the general population in recent birth cohorts in Western countries [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=31].
  • Implementation of comprehensive screening strategies, including public awareness and education, public surveillance, population screening, extended family screening, premarital screening, genetic counselling, prenatal diagnosis, and family planning [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=31].
  • Significant improvements in research, control, and management of both alpha (α) and beta (β) thalassaemia [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=451].
  • Development of advanced diagnostic methods, such as capillary electrophoresis and molecular testing, which have improved the specificity and availability of diagnosing individuals outside the neonatal period [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=12].

Despite these achievements, patient and family involvement in decision-making remains limited [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=451].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the main changes in the 4th edition compared to the previous editions?
answer:
Main Changes in the 4th Edition of TDT Guidelines

The 4th edition of the "Guidelines for the Management of Transfusion Dependent Thalassaemia (TDT)" includes several significant updates and changes compared to previous editions. Here are the main changes:

  • Comprehensive Evidence Review: The 4th edition includes a full review of the evidence supporting almost each recommendation, providing physicians with detailed information to form the basis of their clinical decisions [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13].
  • New Sections and Updates: The guidelines have been expanded to include new sections and updates on various aspects of TDT management, such as blood transfusion, iron overload assessment and monitoring, iron chelation, cardiovascular disease assessment, liver disease, growth and development, splenomegaly and splenectomy, and managing pregnancy in thalassaemia [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13].
  • Focus on National Standards: Emphasis on the need for national standards to reflect the specifics of the environment in which they will be implemented, while also providing a universal standard to guide practitioners and health services [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13].
  • Short Pocket Guide: In addition to the full-length guidelines, a short pocket guide has been created to facilitate physicians in their daily consultations by providing a concise reference of best practices [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation or contact them via email at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What gene therapies are authorised for thalassaemia?
answer:
Authorised Gene Therapies for Thalassaemia

Currently, there are a few gene therapies that have been authorised for the treatment of thalassaemia:

Zynteglo®

  • Commercial name: Zynteglo®
  • Developer: Bluebird Bio
  • Approval: Conditional approval by the European Commission in June 2019
  • Indication: Treatment of transfusion-dependent β+ thalassaemia in patients 12 years and older who are eligible for stem cell transplantation but do not have a matched related donor
  • Mechanism: Autologous CD34+ cells encoding the β A-T87Q-globin gene

Source: TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf

Betibeglogene Autotemcel

  • Commercial name: Not specified
  • Developer: Bluebird Bio
  • Approval: Approved by the FDA in the US
  • Indication: Gene therapy based on gene addition, inserting healthy copies of the B-globin gene into the patient's haematopoietic cells using a viral vector

Source: TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf

Exa-cel

  • Commercial name: Not specified
  • Developer: CRISPR Therapeutics
  • Approval: Close to EMA and FDA approval
  • Indication: Gene editing treatment for β thalassaemia

Source: TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, which may include:

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Thrombophilia and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40]
  • Iron overload causing damage to major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Delayed growth and development [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice) [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Dark urine [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]
  • Endocrine problems such as delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities such as pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, congestive heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities such as cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: What about cordyceps
answer:
Can I Use Cordyceps?

There is no specific information available regarding the use of Cordyceps mushrooms for individuals with thalassaemia in the provided sources. However, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional before adding any new supplement to your diet, especially if you have a medical condition like thalassaemia.
