  • ngoguideenglish.pdf
  • AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf

question: What lifestyle changes can help manage thalassaemia symptoms?
answer:
Lifestyle Changes to Help Manage Thalassaemia Symptoms

Managing thalassaemia involves a combination of medical treatment and lifestyle adjustments. Here are some recommended lifestyle changes:

Healthy Eating

  • Consume a varied, nutrient-dense diet with plenty of fruits and vegetables every day [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].
  • Include high-fibre, starchy foods such as wholegrain breads, cereals, beans, peas, lentils, and oats [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43].
  • Consume adequate amounts of calcium from food sources like milk, yogurt, tofu, and kale [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Take a vitamin D supplement (1,000 - 2,000 IU/day or 50,000 IU monthly) and have your vitamin D levels checked at least annually [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].
  • Limit vitamin C intake to no more than 1,000 mg per day [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].
  • Stay hydrated by drinking mostly water and non-sugar sweetened beverages [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=26].

Physical Activity

  • Engage in regular physical activity, particularly weight-bearing exercises such as walking, jogging, dancing, and jumping to promote bone health [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Include activities that improve flexibility, such as yoga and Pilates, to enhance muscle strength and balance [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Monitoring and Prevention

  • Maintain a healthy body weight and monitor glucose metabolism markers regularly [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=50].
  • Regular cardiovascular assessments should be part of a multidisciplinary monitoring program [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=123].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: چه مراقبت‌هایی برای بیماران تالاسمی لازم است؟
answer:
مراقبت‌های لازم برای بیماران تالاسمی

مراقبت از بیماران تالاسمی شامل چندین جنبه مهم است که باید به دقت رعایت شوند:

انتقال خون

بیماران تالاسمی نیاز به انتقال خون منظم دارند تا سطح هموگلوبین پیش از انتقال خون را بین 9.5 تا 10 گرم در دسی‌لیتر نگه دارند. این انتقال‌ها معمولاً هر 2 تا 5 هفته یکبار انجام می‌شود [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39][TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1][ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf#page=2].

درمان کاهنده آهن

به دلیل انتقال خون مکرر، آهن اضافی در بدن تجمع می‌یابد که می‌تواند به اعضای حیاتی بدن آسیب برساند. بنابراین، بیماران باید درمان کاهنده آهن (chelators) را به صورت روزانه مصرف کنند. این داروها می‌توانند به صورت قرص، شربت یا تزریق زیرجلدی باشند [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1][ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf#page=2][HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].

مراقبت‌های تخصصی

بیماران باید تحت مراقبت‌های تخصصی در مراکز تالاسمی قرار گیرند و توسط تیمی از متخصصان مختلف از جمله قلب‌شناسان، کبد‌شناسان، غدد‌شناسان و روان‌شناسان پیگیری شوند [TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=1][HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1].

اسپلنکتومی

در برخی موارد، برداشتن طحال (اسپلنکتومی) ممکن است ضروری باشد، به ویژه اگر طحال بیش از حد بزرگ شده باشد یا نیاز به انتقال خون بیش از حد باشد [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

برای اطلاعات بیشتر می‌توانید به سایت فدراسیون بین‌المللی تالاسمی مراجعه کنید.

منابع: NursesGuide_English.pdf, TreatingThalassaemia_English.pdf, ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf, HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf, HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf

answer:
Rôle de l'infirmier dans la prise en charge de la bêta-thalassémie

Symptômes de la thalassémie

  • Pâleur
  • Fatigue
  • Déformations osseuses
  • Fractures
  • Splénomégalie (augmentation de la taille de la rate)
  • Ictère (jaunisse)

Source: NursesGuide_English.pdf

Complications

  • Hypertension pulmonaire
  • Thrombose (DVT, douleur thoracique, hypoxie, changements ECG) [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=17].
  • Complications endocriniennes (diabète, hypocalcémie, hypothyroïdie) [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=17].
  • Complications neurologiques (abcès cérébral, AVC) [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=17].
  • Complications hépatiques (carcinome hépatocellulaire) [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13].

Source: EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf

Épidémiologie

La thalassémie est une maladie héréditaire fréquente dans les régions méditerranéennes, le Moyen-Orient, l'Asie du Sud et l'Afrique subsaharienne. La prévalence varie en fonction des régions et des populations.

Source: NursesGuide_English.pdf

Traitement

  • Transfusions sanguines régulières [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13].
  • Thérapie de chélation du fer [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13].
  • Transplantation de cellules souches (dans certains cas) [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=13].

Source: TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf

Rôle de l'infirmier

  • Prévention et éducation : Éducation des patients et de leurs familles, participation aux programmes de dépistage néonatal [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=11].
  • Surveillance et évaluation clinique : Surveillance régulière des complications, évaluation clinique continue [2025 TDT 5

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Common Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Symptoms

  • Severe anaemia
  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

Common Complications

Thalassaemia can lead to various complications, including:

  • Iron overload due to regular blood transfusions, which can affect major organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15]
  • Endocrine problems such as delayed puberty, growth retardation, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypogonadism, and osteoporosis [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Cardiac abnormalities including pericarditis, arrhythmias, biventricular failure, congestive heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Hepatic abnormalities such as cirrhosis and liver failure [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]
  • Splenic enlargement with possible hypersplenism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=42]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: What is the recommended dosage of hydroxyurea for beta thalassemia patients?
answer:
Recommended Dosage of Hydroxyurea for Beta Thalassemia Patients

The recommended dosage of hydroxyurea for beta thalassemia patients is as follows:

  • Starting Dose: 10 mg/kg/day [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=37][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=32][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=33].
  • Dosage Escalation: Increase by 3-5 mg/kg/day every 8 weeks to the maximal tolerated dose, but not exceeding 20 mg/kg/day [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=37][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=32][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=33].
  • Folic Acid Supplementation: Concomitant folic acid supplementation is recommended [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=37][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=33].

Response Evaluation:

  • Evaluate response after 3 and 6 months of therapy. A response is defined as a total hemoglobin level increase of >1 g/dl at 6 months [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=37].
  • Discontinue the drug in patients not showing a response [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=37].
  • Patients showing a response should be re-evaluated at 12, 18, and 24 months to ensure maintenance of response [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=37].

Safety Measures:

  • Complete blood counts every two weeks for the first three months, then monthly [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=37][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=33].
  • Hepatic and renal function studies every two weeks for the first three months, then monthly [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=37][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=33].
  • Monthly history and physical examination evaluating for gastrointestinal, neurologic, or dermatologic side effects [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=37][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=33].
  • Follow-up on gonadal function [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=37][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=33].

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the potential side effects of protein powders?
answer:
Potential Side Effects of Protein Powders

While protein powders can be beneficial for meeting dietary protein needs, there are potential side effects to be aware of:

  • Nephrolithiasis (Kidney Stones): Excessive protein intake has been associated with the formation of kidney stones [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=178].
  • Digestive Issues: High protein intake can lead to digestive problems such as constipation, especially if not balanced with adequate fiber and fluid intake [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=178].
  • Fatigue and Altered Kidney Function: Inadequate fluid intake, which can sometimes accompany high protein diets, may lead to fatigue and altered kidney function [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=178].
  • Protein Calorie Malnutrition (PCM): Though uncommon, signs of PCM include fatigue, growth disturbances, decreased muscle mass, immune dysfunction, thinning hair, brittle nails, and dry skin [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=88].

It is important to consult with a healthcare provider or a nutrition professional to determine the appropriate amount of protein for your specific needs and to avoid potential side effects.

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What legal protections are available for thalassaemia patients in the workplace?
answer:
Legal Protections for Thalassaemia Patients in the Workplace

Thalassaemia patients are entitled to several legal protections in the workplace to ensure they are treated fairly and equitably. These protections include:

  • Equal Employment Opportunities: Thalassaemia patients have the right to work on an equal basis with others. This includes prohibiting discrimination based on disability and ensuring equal remuneration for work of equal value [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Safe and Healthy Working Conditions: Employers are required to provide safe and healthy working conditions for all employees, including those with thalassaemia [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].
  • Non-Discrimination: Discrimination on the grounds of race, color, social, or economic background is illegal in most countries. Thalassaemia patients should be treated with dignity and respect, and their rights must be protected [PatientsRights_English.pdf#page=11].
  • Advocacy and Education: Thalassaemia care teams have a duty to advocate on behalf of their patients, educating the public and potential employers about the condition and the patients' ability to work [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=233].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What lifestyle changes can help manage thalassaemia?
answer:
Lifestyle Changes to Help Manage Thalassaemia

Managing thalassaemia effectively involves a combination of medical treatments and lifestyle changes. Here are some key lifestyle recommendations for thalassaemia patients:

Healthy Eating

  • Consume small, regular meals spread throughout the day [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Choose high-fibre, starchy foods such as wholegrain breads, cereals, beans, peas, lentils, brown rice, and oats [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43].
  • Avoid large portions of low-fibre starchy carbohydrates like potatoes, white bread, white rice, and pasta [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Consume fruits and vegetables daily [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Use small amounts of fats and oils in cooking, preferring olive oil and rapeseed oil over palm or coconut oil [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Limit fried foods and trim fat from meats, opting for lean meats like chicken [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Physical Activity

  • Engage in regular physical activity, particularly weight-bearing exercises such as walking, jogging, dancing, and jumping to promote bone health [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Include activities that improve flexibility, such as yoga and Pilates, to enhance muscle strength and balance [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Ensure that exercise is safe for the heart by consulting with healthcare providers [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

Weight Management

  • Maintain a normal body weight to prevent complications such as cardiovascular disease [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=50].
  • Monitor body composition to avoid issues like increased adiposity and sarcopenic obesity [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=50].

Cardiovascular Health

  • Avoid smoking to reduce cardiovascular risks [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Adopt lifestyle choices that promote cardiovascular health, including regular exercise and a healthy diet [EN_Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals.pdf#page=22].

Bone Health

  • Consume adequate amounts of calcium from food sources like milk, yogurt, tofu, and kale [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Take a vitamin D supplement of 1,000 - 2,000 IU/day or 50,000 IU per month [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].
  • Check zinc blood levels and supplement if necessary [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23].

For more detailed information, you can refer to the following sources:

  • Nutrition Guide
  • Recommendations for Healthcare Professionals
  • Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients

question: How often should vitamin levels be checked in thalassaemia patients?
answer:
Vitamin Level Checks in Thalassaemia Patients

Regular monitoring of vitamin levels is crucial for patients with thalassaemia to ensure optimal health and manage potential deficiencies. Here are the recommended frequencies for checking various vitamin levels:

Vitamin D

  • Check vitamin D levels every 6 months to maintain circulating levels above 30 ng/ml (75 mmol/L) [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=314][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=104].
  • For patients with inadequate vitamin D levels on screening (<25 nmol/L), high-dose supplementation may be required, and monitoring is recommended [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=104].

Vitamin C

  • Assess vitamin C levels annually as it may be useful for optimal chelator medication function. If deficiency is observed, ensure adequate chelation while supplementing with vitamin C [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=27].

Vitamin E

  • Annual assessment of vitamin E in the blood is recommended, and supplementation should be provided to those with deficiency [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=27].

Zinc

  • Assess zinc levels annually. If deficient, supplement with 25 mg zinc/day, preferably as zinc gluconate, acetate, or citrate [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=27].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Increased hemoglobin levels improve growth and development
answer:
Increased Hemoglobin Levels and Growth and Development

Increased hemoglobin levels can significantly improve growth and development in individuals with thalassaemia. For example, a 12-year-old female with B-thalassaemia intermedia showed considerable improvement in growth parameters and functional status after her hemoglobin level increased by 2.5 g/dl due to hydroxyurea treatment [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=33].

Blood transfusions are also used to improve hemoglobin levels in symptomatic patients, which helps prevent or reduce the long-term effects of chronic hemolytic anemia, allowing normal growth and development in children and adolescents [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=103].

For pregnant women with B-thalassaemia intermedia, maintaining hemoglobin levels above 10 g/dL is optimal for fetal development and to avoid complications such as intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and preterm delivery [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=93].

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by mutations in the beta-globin (ß-globin) gene, leading to a wide range of phenotypic severities, from mild to very severe forms. The severity of thalassaemia is influenced by several genetic factors:

Types of ß-Thalassaemia Mutations

  • More than 200 ß-thalassaemia mutations have been described, each contributing to varying degrees of severity [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Examples of severe (ß0), less severe (ß+), and mild (ß++) mutations include:
    ß++ mutations ß+ mutations ß0 mutations
    -101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
    IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
    IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
    C39
    [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

  • Co-inheritance of alpha-thalassaemia (a-thalassaemia) can reduce the severity of ß-thalassaemia by decreasing the imbalance between alpha (a) and beta (ß) chains [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=101].
  • Genetic determinants that increase the production of foetal haemoglobin (HbF) can also ameliorate the phenotype. For example, the co-inheritance of hereditary persistence of foetal haemoglobin (HPFH) mutations results in milder forms of ß-thalassaemia intermedia [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].
  • Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified loci such as BCL11A on chromosome 2p16 and the HBS1L-MYB intergenic region on chromosome 6q23, which are associated with increased HbF production and reduced disease severity [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=32].

Clinical Impact

The clinical severity of thalassaemia can range from thalassaemia major, requiring regular blood transfusions, to thalassaemia intermedia, which may require occasional or no transfusions. The presence of ameliorating genetic factors can significantly influence the clinical outcome and management of the disease [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].

question: هل هناك أطعمة يجب تجنبها لمرضى الثلاسيميا المتوسطة؟
answer:
الأطعمة التي يجب تجنبها لمرضى الثلاسيميا المتوسطة

هناك بعض الأطعمة التي يجب على مرضى الثلاسيميا المتوسطة تجنبها أو تقليل تناولها لتجنب المضاعفات الصحية. إليك بعض التوصيات:

  • الأطعمة الغنية بالحديد: يجب تجنب الأطعمة الغنية بالحديد مثل السبانخ، الكبد، وبعض أنواع الفاصوليا. [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=107]
  • الأطعمة المقلية والدهنية: يجب تقليل تناول الأطعمة المقلية والدهنية مثل الزبدة، السمن، زيت النخيل الأحمر، المعجنات، الجبن، رقائق البطاطس، المايونيز، والكعك. [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=24]
  • الأنظمة الغذائية الضارة: يجب تجنب الأنظمة الغذائية الضارة مثل النظام الغذائي الكيتوني والأنظمة الغذائية السائلة والبروتينية. [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=25]
  • المشروبات الكحولية ومشروبات الطاقة: يجب تقليل تناول المشروبات الكحولية ومشروبات الطاقة أو تجنبها تمامًا. [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=25]
  • التدخين: يجب تجنب التدخين تمامًا. [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=25]

للمزيد من المعلومات، يمكن التواصل عبر البريد الإلكتروني: info@thalassaemia.org.cy

question: Mri
answer:
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) in Thalassaemia Management

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is a crucial tool in the management of thalassaemia, particularly for assessing iron overload in the liver and heart. Here are some key points about the use of MRI in thalassaemia patients:

Iron Overload Assessment

In patients with thalassaemia, iron overload can be assessed using MRI to measure liver iron concentration (LIC) and cardiac iron through T2* MRI. The goal is to maintain LIC to less than 7 mg/g of dry weight, ideally between 2-5 mg/g dry weight. LIC should be measured annually starting from the first year of life, and cardiac iron should be assessed if LIC is greater than 7 mg/g dry weight or starting at 10 years of age [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=63].

Cardiac MRI T2*

Cardiac MRI T2* is used to assess myocardial iron overload. This technique is advantageous because it requires shorter acquisition times and can be achieved with a single breath-hold. It is recommended to perform cardiac MRI T2* simultaneously with hepatic MRI T2* at intervals determined by the degree of iron load and local protocols. Typically, the first MRI T2* scan is performed 7-10 years after the initiation of blood transfusions and repeated every 2 years thereafter [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=54].

Procedure and Patient Experience

The MRI machine makes loud clanking and banging noises during the procedure, but the patient wears a headset to protect their ears. The test is non-invasive and painless. MRI can also assess heart function more accurately than routine cardiac ultrasound and measure the size and performance of the right ventricle, which is important for patients at risk of developing pulmonary hypertension [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=167].

Limitations and Considerations

While MRI is a powerful tool, it has limitations. For example, MRI determination is unreliable above LIC of 30 mg/g dry weight. Additionally, serum ferritin concentration, although widely used, correlates poorly with cardiac iron content and should not be used as a surrogate for MRI T2* [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=64][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=54].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: What are the potential side effects of gene therapy for thalassemia?
answer:
Potential Side Effects of Gene Therapy for Thalassemia

Gene therapy for thalassemia, while promising, is associated with several potential side effects. These side effects can be attributed to the myeloablative conditioning regimen required before the infusion of gene-modified cells, as well as the gene therapy procedure itself.

Common Non-Hematological Side Effects

The most common non-hematological side effects observed in studies using the lentiviral vector product ZYNTEGLO™ include:

  • Stomatitis (mouth inflammation)
  • Febrile neutropenia (fever during neutropenia)
  • Epistaxis (nosebleed)
  • Veno-occlusive liver disease
  • Abdominal pain

It is important to note that these side effects were consistent with the myeloablative conditioning regimen and were not attributed to the lentiglobin gene therapy product. All of these side effects resolved with or without treatment [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf#page=5].

Long-term Risks

Patients undergoing gene therapy need to be monitored for at least 15 years to evaluate the sustainability of clinical benefits and long-term safety. Potential long-term risks include:

  • Increased Risk of Malignancies: Patients may be at an increased risk of developing malignancies due to several factors:
    • Host factors generated by the disease background or treatment, such as chronic hypoxia, inflammation, clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP)-related mutations, and chronic exposure to hydroxyurea.
    • Solid organ hemosiderosis in thalassemia patients may create a permissive environment for the development of malignancies.
    • The transplant procedure itself, including the conditioning regimen and low engraftment of gene-corrected HSCs, may allow for clonal proliferation of endogenous cells, constituting additional risk factors for oncogenesis.
    • Gene therapy by gene addition is associated with a low, but existing risk of insertional mutagenesis, while gene therapy by gene editing has the potential to cause double-strand breaks at unintended locations ("off-target" effects) [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=283].

In the Bluebird Bio trials with the longest follow-up, there have been three SCD patients who developed myeloid malignancies following gene therapy by gene addition [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=283].

If you need further assistance or specific information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Are there foods I should avoid as a person with thalassemia?
answer:
Foods to Avoid for Individuals with Thalassaemia

As a person with thalassaemia, there are certain foods and dietary habits you should avoid or limit to manage your condition effectively:

  • Iron-rich foods: Avoid foods high in iron, such as red meat, liver, and iron-fortified cereals, as they can contribute to iron overload [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=128].
  • High-calorie, nutrient-poor foods: Avoid 'filler' foods that are high in calories but low in nutritional value, such as sugary snacks, fast food, and processed foods [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=13].
  • Fried and fatty foods: Limit intake of fried foods, foods high in saturated fats (e.g., butter, lard, ghee, red palm oil, pastry, cheese, crisps, mayonnaise, and cakes) [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=43].
  • Excessive alcohol: Limit alcohol consumption, especially if you have liver issues. People with liver inflammation should avoid alcohol altogether [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=27][AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=128].
  • Energy drinks and excessive caffeine: Avoid energy drinks and limit caffeine intake [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=51].
  • Popular but harmful diets: Avoid diets such as ketogenic, liquid protein diets, and the Southern diet [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=25].
  • Smoking: Avoid smoking cigarettes [Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=27].

For further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sources:

  • AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf
  • Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf
  • NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf
  • Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf
  • NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf
  • Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_ 2024_web_FINAL.pdf

question: هل هناك نظام غذائي معين يجب اتباعه؟
answer:
النظام الغذائي لمرضى الثلاسيميا المتوسطة

نعم، هناك نظام غذائي معين يجب اتباعه لمرضى الثلاسيميا المتوسطة. إليك بعض التوصيات الغذائية:

  • الترطيب: شرب كمية كافية من الماء، وإذا كان هناك تاريخ سابق لحصى الكلى، ينصح بشرب أكثر من 2.5 لتر يوميًا. [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=56]
  • تناول الصوديوم: ينصح بتقليل تناول الصوديوم إلى أقل من 2300 ملغ يوميًا. [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=56]
  • تناول الفواكه والخضروات: ينصح بتناول 5 إلى 7 حصص من الفواكه والخضروات يوميًا. [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=56]
  • الحفاظ على وزن صحي: ينصح بالحفاظ على مؤشر كتلة الجسم (BMI) بين 18.5-22.9 كجم/م² (للآسيويين) أو 18.5-24.9 كجم/م² (لبقية المجموعات). [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=56]
  • النشاط البدني: ينصح بممارسة النشاط البدني غير الملامس للوزن لمدة لا تقل عن 150 دقيقة في الأسبوع للبالغين و60 دقيقة في اليوم للأطفال والمراهقين. [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=56]
  • تناول الكالسيوم: ينصح بتناول 1000 ملغ من الكالسيوم يوميًا (للبالغين أقل من 50 عامًا) مع التركيز على المصادر الغذائية. يجب تقليل المكملات الغذائية إلى 500 ملغ من الكالسيوم (العنصري) يوميًا. [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=56]
  • فيتامين د: ينصح بالحفاظ على مستوى فيتامين د بين 30-50 نانوغرام/مل (75-125 نانومول/لتر). [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=56]

للمزيد من المعلومات، يمكن التواصل عبر البريد الإلكتروني: info@thalassaemia.org.cy

question: Faktor apa yang menyebabkan thalasemia
answer:
Penyebab Thalassemia

Thalassemia adalah penyakit genetik yang disebabkan oleh mutasi atau penghapusan gen yang mempengaruhi produksi rantai globin dalam hemoglobin. Berikut adalah beberapa faktor penyebab thalassemia:

  • Mutasi Genetik: Thalassemia disebabkan oleh mutasi genetik yang diwariskan dari orang tua. Mutasi ini dapat berupa penghapusan satu atau kedua gen α-globin pada kromosom 16 atau mutasi yang mempengaruhi proses transkripsi atau translasi [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=20].
  • Jenis Thalassemia: Ada dua jenis utama thalassemia, yaitu α-thalassemia dan β-thalassemia. α-thalassemia terjadi ketika gen yang terkait dengan protein α-globin hilang atau berubah, sedangkan β-thalassemia terjadi ketika ada cacat genetik yang mempengaruhi produksi protein β-globin [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].
  • Distribusi Geografis: Mutasi genetik yang menyebabkan thalassemia lebih umum ditemukan di daerah tropis dan subtropis, termasuk Asia Timur, wilayah Mediterania, subkontinen India, Timur Tengah, dan Afrika [NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=20].

Thalassemia adalah penyakit yang diwariskan dan tidak disebabkan oleh faktor nutrisi atau lingkungan lainnya [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=1].

Referensi

  • NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf
  • HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf

Pertanyaan Lanjutan

question: Iron chelation side effects
answer:
Iron Chelation Side Effects

Iron chelation therapy, while essential for managing iron overload in thalassaemia patients, can have several side effects. These include:

  • Gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea and upper GI ulceration [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=51][NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=104].
  • Joint pain or arthralgia [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=104].
  • Neutropenia and agranulocytosis, although these are less common [NTDT-final-combined-1.pdf#page=48].
  • Over-chelation can lead to increased side effects, necessitating dose adjustments as serum ferritin or liver iron levels fall [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=47][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=108].

It is crucial to tailor the chelation regimen to the individual patient's needs and monitor for adverse effects regularly [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=47][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=108].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is primarily caused by genetic mutations affecting the production of globin proteins. There are two main types of thalassaemia:

  • α-thalassaemia: Occurs when genes related to the α-globin protein are missing or mutated.
  • β-thalassaemia: Occurs when similar genetic defects affect the production of the β-globin protein [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf].

Severity of β-Thalassaemia

The severity of β-thalassaemia varies widely and is influenced by the specific mutations present and other genetic factors:

  • More than 200 β-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf].
  • Severe β-thalassaemia alleles can result in thalassaemia major, which requires regular blood transfusions for survival [NursesGuide_English.pdf].
  • Less severe mutations can lead to thalassaemia intermedia, where patients may survive with occasional or no transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf].

Ameliorating Genetic Factors

Several genetic factors can ameliorate the severity of β-thalassaemia:

  • Co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia can reduce the imbalance between α- and β-chains, leading to a milder form of the disease [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf].
  • Increased production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) due to genetic determinants can also ameliorate the phenotype. This includes hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH) mutations [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf].
  • Specific mutations, such as the mild β+-type mutation -88 (C->T), generally result in a very mild clinical phenotype [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf].

For further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the treatment options for managing EMH in thalassemia patients?
answer:
Treatment Options for Managing Extramedullary Hematopoiesis (EMH) in Thalassemia Patients

Extramedullary hematopoiesis (EMH) can be managed through various treatment options depending on the severity and location of the EMH masses. Here are the primary treatment modalities:

1. Blood Transfusion

Blood transfusions with a target pretransfusion haemoglobin level above 10 g/dL are the principal treatment modality for stopping or decreasing the compensatory medullary tissue expansion in patients with β-thalassemia. This approach is crucial for controlling EMH masses and preventing severe neurologic complications, especially in paraspinal locations. However, this modality alone may not be sufficient for patients with severe neurological or rapidly progressive symptoms [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=259].

2. Hydroxyurea

Hydroxyurea has been used successfully as a first-line treatment for EMH in patients with beta-thalassemia. It helps in reducing the size of EMH masses and improving clinical symptoms [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=48][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=107].

3. Low-Dose Radiotherapy

Low-dose radiotherapy is another effective treatment option for EMH, particularly in cases of spinal cord compression. It can be used alone or in combination with other treatments such as erythropoietin or hydroxyurea [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=48][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=107].

4. Surgery

Surgical intervention may be necessary for EMH masses that cause significant symptoms or are located in critical areas. Pre-operative transfusion and post-operative radiotherapy may be used to manage the condition effectively [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=103].

5. Wait-and-See Strategy

A wait-and-see strategy may be indicated if the EMH lesion is asymptomatic and located in an anatomical site that poses no danger. This approach involves regular monitoring without immediate intervention [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=259].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: what about beta thalasemia major ?
answer:
Beta Thalassaemia Major

Overview

Beta thalassaemia major (TM) is a severe form of beta thalassaemia that results in transfusion-dependent anaemia. Patients typically require blood transfusions every 2-4 weeks to manage their condition [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf#page=8].

Clinical Presentation

Individuals with beta thalassaemia major are usually asymptomatic at birth due to the high production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF). However, as HbF levels decline, affected infants present with severe anaemia during the first or second year of life [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=60][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=91].

Treatment

The primary treatment for beta thalassaemia major includes regular blood transfusions combined with iron chelation therapy to control iron overload. Without this treatment, patients are at risk of death from heart failure in the second or third decade of life. However, with modern treatment, many patients now reach the fourth and fifth decades of life in good health and can lead relatively normal lives [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=91].

Pathophysiology

Beta thalassaemia major is caused by reduced or absent synthesis of the beta-globin chains of the adult hemoglobin (HbA) tetramer. This leads to ineffective erythropoiesis and haemolysis, resulting in severe anaemia. The body responds by increasing erythropoietin synthesis, causing intense proliferation of the bone marrow, skeletal deformities, and various growth and metabolic abnormalities [TIF-BMT-v4_FINAL (1).pdf#page=2].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: Life span of NTDT delta beta thalassemia patient
answer:
Life Span of NTDT Delta Beta Thalassemia Patients

The life expectancy of patients with Non-Transfusion Dependent Thalassemia (NTDT), including delta beta thalassemia, can vary. A recent large global study of 2033 NTDT patients showed the following survival estimates:

  • By age 18: 99.4%
  • By age 50: 93.4%
  • By age 65: 81.8%
  • By age 75: 66.2%
  • By age 85: 25.4%

The median age at death was 46.3 years. Cardiovascular disease, mostly non-iron related, was the leading cause of early death, while hepatic disease was the leading cause of death in older patients [TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=14][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=15].

For more detailed information, you can contact the Thalassaemia International Federation at info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: I have thalassemia what to do?
answer:
Thalassaemia Management

If you have thalassaemia, it is crucial to follow a comprehensive management plan to ensure the best possible outcomes. Here are the key aspects of managing thalassaemia:

  • Regular blood transfusions to maintain pre-transfusion hemoglobin levels at 9.5 to 10 g/dL [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].
  • Iron chelation therapy to remove excess iron from the body, which is essential due to the iron accumulation from frequent blood transfusions [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • Monitoring and controlling iron overload to prevent damage to vital organs such as the heart, liver, and endocrine glands [HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=2].
  • Adherence to good practice guidelines and national standards [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].
  • Multidisciplinary care in expert centers and networking with secondary centers [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].
  • Psychosocial support and holistic care [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].
  • Monitoring of complications and early response to any issues that arise [PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=16].

For more detailed information on the management of thalassaemia, you can refer to the guidelines published by the Thalassaemia International Federation (TIF) available at www.thalassaemia.org.cy [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=39].

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: physical activity
answer:
Physical Activity and Thalassaemia

Engaging in physical activity offers numerous health benefits for individuals with thalassaemia, although research specific to this population is limited. Here are some key points:

Benefits of Physical Activity

  • Improved quality of life
  • Less pain
  • Reduced serum ferritin levels
  • Higher bone density
  • Improved sleep quality
  • Reduced anxiety
  • Lower risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes
  • Improved bone health
  • Reduced risk of falls

[NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=159][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=170][NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=163]

Recommended Activities

  • Weight-bearing activities: walking, jogging, dancing, jumping
  • Weight-less activities: swimming, biking
  • Flexibility exercises: yoga, Pilates

[Nutrition in Thalassaemia for Patients_2024_web_FINAL.pdf#page=23]

Considerations for Thalassaemia Patients

  • Consult with a haematologist and/or cardiologist before starting an exercise regime
  • Ensure adequate haemoglobin levels are maintained
  • Consider complications such as heart disease and bone disease
  • Encourage non-contact, weight-bearing activities
  • Physical activity should complement, not replace, adequate chelation and optimal nutrition

[NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=46][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=116]

Challenges

  • Pain
  • Anaemia
  • Fatigue
  • Deconditioning
  • Decreased exercise capacity

[NutritionGuide_ThalPKD_v2.pdf#page=163]

For more detailed information or specific advice, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Complications

When Do Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Symptoms

  • Severe anaemia
  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

Common Complications

  • Weak bones with deformities and fractures
  • Thrombophilia
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Iron overload leading to liver fibrosis, cirrhosis, and heart disease
  • Delayed sexual maturation
  • Growth retardation
  • Heart problems such as heart failure and arrhythmias
  • Endocrine issues like diabetes and hypothyroidism [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=40][NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=58][ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf#page=2][PreventionVol1_English.pdf#page=15][HowToTreatBThal_EN.pdf#page=1]

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

Follow-up Questions

If you need further assistance, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: When do thalassaemia symptoms appear, and what are common complications?
answer:
Thalassaemia Symptoms and Complications

When Do Thalassaemia Symptoms Appear?

Most people born with thalassaemia experience health problems that can manifest from a few months after birth up until the first 2 years of life. Less severe cases may not be noticeable until later in childhood or even until adulthood [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2].

Common Complications of Thalassaemia

The symptoms of thalassaemia can vary and may include severe anaemia and other health problems, such as:

  • Delayed growth and development
  • Excessive tiredness and fatigue
  • Yellow or pale skin (jaundice)
  • Dark urine
  • Bone deformities, especially in the face
  • Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart [HaveYouHeard_EN.pdf#page=2]

If left untreated or suboptimally treated, thalassaemia can lead to many complications, including:

  • Heart failure
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Diabetes
  • Growth retardation
  • Darkening of the skin
  • Feeling of weakness and "lacking energy"
  • Spleen enlargement
  • Deformities in the child's face
  • Short stature [ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf#page=2]

For more information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website.

question: What lifestyle changes can help manage HbH disease?
answer:
Lifestyle Changes to Help Manage HbH Disease

Diet and Nutrition

Proper diet and nutrition play a crucial role in managing HbH disease. Key dietary recommendations include:

  • Folic acid supplementation (1-5 mg/day) to support increased erythropoietic activity [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=34][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=168].
  • Avoiding iron supplements unless laboratory tests show iron deficiency, as iron accumulation can occur from increased gastrointestinal absorption [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=34][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=27].
  • Moderation in consuming iron-rich foods to prevent excessive iron intake [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=34].
  • Ensuring adequate intake of vitamin D and calcium, with biannual monitoring of vitamin D levels and supplementation as needed [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=168].

Physical Activity

Maintaining physical activity and participating in sports is encouraged for individuals with HbH disease. Regular exercise helps in overall health and well-being [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=27].

Monitoring and Medical Care

Regular medical check-ups are essential for managing HbH disease. This includes:

  • Complete immunization against vaccine-preventable diseases [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=169].
  • Prompt treatment of fever and infections to prevent complications [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=169].
  • Close monitoring for acute anaemic symptoms and other complications [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=169].
  • Regular follow-up visits to document normal growth and development, especially in children [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=27].

Environmental Considerations

Environmental factors such as climate, air pollution, and lifestyle habits can impact the management of HbH disease. It is important to adapt your lifestyle to support overall health, especially if relocating to a new area [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=8].

Psychosocial Support

Psychosocial support is important for individuals with HbH disease. Establishing a support system, connecting with local patient associations, and sharing experiences with others can help cope with the stress and emotional aspects of the condition [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=8][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=169].

Planning Ahead

Planning ahead for medical needs, including organizing medical supplies, finding appropriate housing, and understanding transportation options to healthcare facilities, is crucial for managing HbH disease effectively [LivingWithThalassaemia_TravelBooklet_web.pdf#page=8].

Additional Information

For more detailed information or specific inquiries, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: What are the side effects of Luspatercept?
answer:
Side Effects of Luspatercept

Luspatercept, also known as Reblozyl®, is associated with several side effects. Here are the most commonly reported adverse reactions:

  • Bone Pain: Reported in 19.7% of patients, most commonly in the first 3 months of treatment. Most events were Grade 1-2, with a few Grade 3 events [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].
  • Headache: Occurred in 26% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].
  • Arthralgia (Joint Pain): Reported in 19.3% of patients, leading to treatment discontinuation in 0.9% of cases [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138][TIF_Guidelines_NTD_BThal.pdf#page=30].
  • Fatigue: Occurred in 14% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138].
  • Cough: Reported in 14% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138].
  • Abdominal Pain: Occurred in 14% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138].
  • Diarrhea: Reported in 12% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138].
  • Dizziness: Occurred in 11% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=423].
  • Hypertension: Reported in 8.1% of patients, with an average increase in blood pressure of 5 mmHg [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=138][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=423].
  • Hypersensitivity Reactions: Including eyelid oedema, face swelling, and angioedema, reported in 4.5% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=139].
  • Injection Site Reactions: Including erythema, pruritus, and swelling, reported in 2.2% of patients [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=139].
  • Thromboembolic Events: Including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, occurred in 3.6% of patients, primarily those with pre-existing risk factors [TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=139][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=423].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website or contact them via email at thalassaemia@cytanet.com.cy.

question: What are protocol hemoglobin levels for thalassemia patients with congestive heart failure?
answer:
Protocol Hemoglobin Levels for Thalassemia Patients with Congestive Heart Failure

For thalassemia patients with cardiac complications, including congestive heart failure, the recommended protocol is to maintain pre-transfusion hemoglobin levels at 10-11 g/dL. This ensures good oxygenation of the cardiac muscle. Additionally, it is recommended that these patients receive frequent, small transfusions of concentrated red blood cells to avoid overloading the heart. In cases of established heart failure, a diuretic may be given with each transfusion at the doctor's discretion.

Source: AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf

question: Ευχαριστώ
answer: Παρακαλώ, αν χρειάζεστε περαιτέρω βοήθεια, μη διστάσετε να επικοινωνήσετε με το email info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How long is the treatment/ procedure
answer:
How long is the treatment/procedure for Gene Therapy?

The gene therapy procedure for β-thalassaemia involves several steps and can take a few months to complete. Here is a general outline of the process:

  1. Patient Evaluation: The patient undergoes a thorough evaluation to ensure they are in good general health and suitable for the treatment.
  2. Stem Cell Collection: Haematopoietic (blood-forming) progenitor stem cells are mobilized and harvested from the patient's blood. This process can take a few days.
  3. Genetic Modification: The harvested stem cells are sent to a specialized laboratory where they undergo genetic modification to correct the faulty gene. This step can take several weeks.
  4. Conditioning Treatment: The patient receives chemotherapy to reduce the number of unhealthy stem cells and make space in the bone marrow for the new cells. This conditioning treatment typically lasts about a week.
  5. Stem Cell Infusion: The genetically modified stem cells are infused back into the patient's bloodstream. This is similar to a blood transfusion and takes a few hours.
  6. Recovery and Monitoring: The patient remains in the hospital for several weeks to monitor for any complications and to ensure the new stem cells engraft successfully in the bone marrow.

Overall, the entire process from initial evaluation to recovery can take several months [TIF-GENE-THERAPY_FINAL.pdf][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf].

For more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: if a suspected thalassaemia child has recently been transfused what investigations should i send to confirm thalassaemia
answer:
Investigations to Confirm Thalassaemia in a Recently Transfused Child

If a child suspected of having thalassaemia has recently been transfused, the following investigations should be carried out to confirm the diagnosis:

Laboratory Tests

  • Serial haemoglobin (Hb) measurements to monitor levels over time [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=44].
  • Full red cell phenotype to determine the specific characteristics of the red blood cells [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=44].
  • Liver function tests and baseline ferritin level to assess liver health and iron levels [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=44].
  • Hepatitis B surface antigen or other serological markers if vaccinated (anti-HBs) [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=44].
  • Hepatitis C antibody (and HCV-RNA if positive) [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=44].
  • HIV antibody (and HIV Ag and/or HIV-RNA if positive) [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=44].
  • Testing for co-existence of G6PD deficiency using qualitative and quantitative tests [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=44].

Genetic Testing

  • Genetic or DNA-based testing to identify the specific mutations inherited from each parent, which can provide a definitive diagnosis [TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf#page=44].

For further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Sources:

  • NursesGuide_English.pdf
  • TIF-HAEMOGLOBIN-DISORTERS-3-low.pdf

question: What information should be included in the certificate?
answer:
Information to Include in a Thalassaemia Status Certificate

When requesting a certificate to confirm that you are not affected by thalassaemia, it is important to ensure that the document includes specific information to make it valid and comprehensive. Here is a list of the essential details that should be included:

Personal Information

  • Full Name
  • Date of Birth
  • Identification Number (if applicable)

Medical Evaluation Details

  • Statement confirming that you are not affected by thalassaemia
  • Summary of medical tests conducted, such as:
    • Complete Blood Count (CBC)
    • Peripheral Blood Smear
    • Haemoglobin Electrophoresis or High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC)
    • Molecular Genetic Testing (if applicable)
  • Results of the tests indicating normal values and absence of thalassaemia traits

Medical Professional's Information

  • Name of the Doctor or Medical Professional
  • Medical License Number
  • Signature of the Doctor or Medical Professional
  • Official Stamp or Letterhead of the Medical Institution

Including these details will help ensure that the certificate is recognized and accepted by relevant authorities. If you need further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

[Source: AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf]

question: publication by dr Gabriel Kalakoutis for preimplantation genetics diagnosis of thalassaemia
answer:
Publication by Dr. Gabriel Kalakoutis for Preimplantation Genetic Diagnosis of Thalassaemia

Unfortunately, there is no specific publication by Dr. Gabriel Kalakoutis listed in the provided sources regarding preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) of thalassaemia. However, there are several relevant studies and publications on the topic by other researchers:

  • Monni G, Cau G, Usai V, et al. Preimplantation genetic diagnosis for beta-thalassaemia: the Sardinian experience. Prenat Diagn. 2004; 24(12):949-954. [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=76]
  • Vrettou C, Traegaer Synodinos J, Tzetis M, et al. Real-time PCR for single-cell genotyping in sickle cell and thalassemia syndromes as a rapid, accurate, reliable, and widely applicable protocol for preimplantation genetic diagnosis. Hum Mutat. 2004; 23(5):513-521. [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=76]
  • Kuliev A, Rechitsky S, Verlinsky O, et al. Preimplantation diagnosis and HLA typing for haemoglobin disorders. Reprod Biomed Online. 2005; 11(3):362-370. [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=76]

For further assistance or more detailed information, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: Are there any long-term safety concerns with Luspatercept?
answer:
Long-Term Safety of Luspatercept

Long-term safety data for luspatercept, derived from the BELIEVE trial and its extensions, indicate that there are no new safety concerns emerging with prolonged use. Here are the key points:

  • Adverse Events: Common side effects include transient bone pain, arthralgia, dizziness, hypertension, and hyperuricemia. These were more frequent in luspatercept-treated patients compared to placebo [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=423][TDT-GUIDE-2022-FOR-web.pdf#page=130].
  • Thromboembolic Events: Higher rates of thromboembolic events were observed in patients with pre-existing risk factors [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=423].
  • Extramedullary Haematopoietic Masses: Worsening of these masses was noted, primarily in non-transfusion-dependent thalassaemia (NTDT) patients with pre-existing risk factors [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=423].
  • Iron Overload: Long-term data show considerable improvements in iron overload indices and decreasing trends in overall iron chelation use and dosing [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=422].
  • Overall Safety: No additional safety concerns have emerged from long-term follow-up studies [2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=422][2025 TDT 5TH EDITION.pdf#page=433].

For more detailed information, you can visit the Thalassaemia International Federation website or contact them via email at thalassaemia@cytanet.com.cy.

question: How do I know if I have iron in my pancreas?
answer:
How to Know if You Have Iron in Your Pancreas

To determine if you have iron in your pancreas, the following methods can be used:

  • MRI Scan: An MRI of the pancreas can detect non-reactive Fe3+ iron. High levels of iron detected by MRI in the pancreas indicate prolonged exposure to high levels of non-transferrin-bound iron (NTBI) or labile plasma iron (LPI) [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=122][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=191].
  • Transferrin Saturation: Transferrin saturation levels greater than 50%, and certainly above 70%, on multiple measures can be a surrogate for circulating NTBI/LPI, which can lead to iron deposition in the pancreas [AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=122][AlphaThalGuidelines_web.pdf#page=191].
  • Fasting Glucose/Insulin Tests: These tests are complementary screening tools that, if proven valid, may identify high-risk patients before irreversible pancreatic damage occurs [TDT 4TH EDITION (Version 2.0).pdf#page=155].

If you suspect iron overload in your pancreas, it is important to consult with your healthcare provider for appropriate testing and management.

For further assistance, you can contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

Follow-up Questions

question: Was heißt thalassämie
answer:
Was ist Thalassämie?

Thalassämie ist ein Begriff, der eine Gruppe von erblichen Blutkrankheiten beschreibt, die zu einer verminderten Produktion von Hämoglobin führen. Hämoglobin ist ein Protein in den roten Blutkörperchen, das für den Sauerstofftransport von den Lungen zu den Geweben und Organen verantwortlich ist [ThalassaemiaforParents_English.pdf].

Diese Erkrankungen sind genetisch bedingt und werden von den Eltern an ihre Kinder weitergegeben. Sie entstehen durch Mutationen in den Genen, die für die Produktion der Hämoglobin-Proteinketten verantwortlich sind [FocusOnAThal_EN.pdf].

Es gibt verschiedene Arten von Thalassämie, darunter Alpha-Thalassämie und Beta-Thalassämie, die jeweils durch unterschiedliche genetische Defekte verursacht werden [EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-OF-THALASSAEMIA-LOW-1.pdf].

Für weitere Informationen oder Unterstützung können Sie sich an info@thalassaemia.org.cy wenden.

question: What are the genetic causes of thalassaemia and their impact on severity?
answer:
Genetic Causes of Thalassaemia and Their Impact on Severity

Thalassaemia is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of hemoglobin. The severity of the condition can vary widely depending on the specific mutations involved and their interactions. Here are some key points:

Types of Mutations

  • More than 200 ß-thalassaemia mutations have been described, ranging from silent to very severe [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Examples of severe (ßo), less severe (ß+), and mild (ß++) mutations include:
    ß++ mutations ß+ mutations ßo mutations
    -101, -87, -88, -28 IVS1-110 IVS1-1
    IVS1-106 IVS11-745 IVS11-1
    IVS1-5 IVS1-[-25]
    C39
    [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29]

Impact on Severity

  • The severity of homozygous ß-thalassaemia can be affected by ameliorating factors such as the co-inheritance of α-thalassaemia or gene modifiers that increase Hb F production [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • For example, the mild ß+-type mutation -88 (C->T) generally results in a very mild clinical phenotype in patients homozygous for this mutation [Preventiondiagnosis-of-Hbpathies_BOOKLETNEW-1.pdf#page=72].
  • Patients with thalassaemia major cannot survive for long without regular blood transfusions, while those with thalassaemia intermedia may survive with occasional or no transfusions [NursesGuide_English.pdf#page=37].
  • Other genetic conditions, such as decreased synthesis of α-chains or increased synthesis of γ-chains, can also reduce the severity of the disease [AboutThalassaemia_English.pdf#page=29].

For more detailed information, please refer to the sources provided or contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.

question: How to get tested
answer:
How to Get Tested for Thalassaemia

There are several ways to get tested for thalassaemia, depending on your situation:

Routine Monitoring Tests

If you need to measure the iron load of the liver and the heart using MRI T2* as part of your routine monitoring tests:

  • If the test is not available in your home country, request the S2 form before traveling. No payment for medical costs will be needed from your side.
  • If the test is available in your home country but you wish to take it in another EU Member State, you may travel and take the test in the health establishment of your choice. You will need to pay upfront all medical costs and claim a reimbursement afterwards from your national health system.

[Source: CrossBorderHealthcare-Factsheet.pdf]

Prenatal Diagnosis

If you are in early pregnancy and wish to test the foetus for thalassaemia:

  • Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS): This test involves obtaining a sample from the chorionic villi, which contains copies of the genes the baby has inherited. The test can be done either through the vagina and cervix, or by putting a needle through the abdominal wall after the injection of a local anaesthetic. An ultrasound scan is used to guide the needle.
  • Amniocentesis: This test is done up to 20 weeks of pregnancy. A small needle is inserted into the womb to remove a sample of the fluid surrounding the baby. The fluid is then tested to reveal the genes the baby has inherited. An ultrasound scan is used to guide the needle.

[Source: NursesGuide_English.pdf]

Newborn Screening

If a newborn screening indicates a likely pathological result, the following steps are recommended:

  • Referral to specialized care and/or laboratories for confirmatory DNA testing.
  • Counseling the family on their options, including treatment of an affected child, testing the parents, and information on their reproductive options.

[Source: PreventionVol1_English.pdf]

Contact Information

If you need further assistance or have more questions, please contact info@thalassaemia.org.cy.
